Speaker: NA
Text: Monday, 29 November 2004

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Mr David Hawker)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 12.30 p.m. and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: MEMBER SWORN

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Sophie Panopoulos made and sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed the oath of allegiance.

Speaker: NA
Text: GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S SPEECH

Speaker: NA
Text: Address-in-Reply

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 18 November, on

Speaker: NA
Text: motion by Mrs Markus:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the address be agreed to.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Text: Fadden) (12.32 p.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General, in his speech to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, made particular reference to the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's initiatives in terms of overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. I would like to inform the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of that in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Fadden. As I have mentioned previously, the

Speaker: NA
Text: seat of Fadden encompasses the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the Gold Coast continues to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: foremost tourist destination, and tourism and

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitality are the chief money earners, I

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder if there is a realisation within the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal bureaucracy that the income gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by the tourism industry may not last for

Speaker: NA
Text: very much longer. The reality is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast is becoming very much a focal

Speaker: NA
Text: point for export industries for Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to mention to the House just

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the things that are happening. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the film industry which is based at

Speaker: NA
Text: Oxenford is now creating films for world-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide distribution. It is not only Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: productions which are being made; a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of American productions are also being

Speaker: NA
Text: made. The flow-on affect of that is tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous. There are editing houses and specialty

Speaker: NA
Text: audio suites which have been established as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as specialty legal firms which deal in

Speaker: NA
Text: patents and copyright in association with

Speaker: NA
Text: particular industry. While the industry has

Speaker: NA
Text: had a bit of a down time in the past 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months, the forward projections on produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions look absolutely tremendous.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has also been the advent of the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast Marina, which is now a major luxury

Speaker: NA
Text: shipbuilder. Last year, the income generated

Speaker: NA
Text: from that through exports was in the vicinity

Speaker: NA
Text: of $250 million. Estimates are that this year

Speaker: NA
Text: it could be as high as $400 million, with

Speaker: NA
Text: principal markets being places like Fort

Speaker: NA
Text: Lauderdale in the United States. A new in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial estate has been established at Yatala,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the northern area of the Gold Coast. Along

Speaker: NA
Text: with our Austrade people, I have been under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taking some visits to a number of the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers there. There is a pet food company

Speaker: NA
Text: there-a $50 million business-that has now

Speaker: NA
Text: gone into the export of chilled pet food

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Asia. It is estimated that its in-

Speaker: NA
Text: the come, particularly through these exports, is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to double within the next 12 months to

Speaker: NA
Text: two years. A smallgoods manufacturer has

Speaker: NA
Text: started exporting to Japan. There is only one

Speaker: NA
Text: buyer, but that will amount to up to 30 ton-

Speaker: NA
Text: nes of specialist sausages for the Kyoto mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket from 5 January next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Jewellery manufacturing has taken on

Speaker: NA
Text: quite an image on the Gold Coast. One par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular manufacturer there, based at Sanctu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary Cove, is now exporting around the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have the largest producer of computer

Speaker: NA
Text: games in the Asia-Pacific area. It is a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany that employs 250 people, 170 of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: are graduates. It supplies video games and

Speaker: NA
Text: computer games to all areas of the Asia-

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific except Japan. It is no wonder that

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 60,000 people employed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Fadden actually live in Fadden. It is no won-

Speaker: NA
Text: der that our unemployment rates are some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the lowest in Australia. The Gold Coast is

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually becoming a focal point for high-

Speaker: NA
Text: tech international manufacturing. As we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen in recent times, we have got to a stage

Speaker: NA
Text: that now where we have actually had to import

Speaker: NA
Text: labour from South Australia, from the old

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitsubishi plant, to meet some of the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, throughout the electorate we are

Speaker: NA
Text: finding that one of the greatest difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have is getting skilled labour. In that

Speaker: NA
Text: respect, the announcement of a technical

Speaker: NA
Text: college that will be built and operated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth to meet those specific needs

Speaker: NA
Text: is especially welcome. The Gold Coast is, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I said, very much a focal point for this. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we have seen is a spin-off into our educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional institutions. After the recent redistriburequired

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, I have inherited the Gold Coast campus

Speaker: NA
Text: of Griffith University from my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moncrieff. To give you an ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample of what happens there, a whole new

Speaker: NA
Text: music division has been established specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally to meet the digital music requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: of the movie production houses. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge business, with five sound stages now

Speaker: NA
Text: based at Griffith University all going flat-out

Speaker: NA
Text: producing graduates who have the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to go into areas such as the film industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the video games industry with digital

Speaker: NA
Text: music, which is really quite unlike anything

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have seen before. Quite proudly,

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith University boasts of the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: something like four of its graduates have

Speaker: NA
Text: been picked up by Hollywood already be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the standard of student that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing there.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, we must have realised within

Speaker: NA
Text: the government that the Gold Coast is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer just froth and bubble. It is not just an

Speaker: NA
Text: area that caters for tourism; it is very much

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming the specialist manufacturing heart

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. With the expansion of Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: airport, we have a major requirement now

Speaker: NA
Text: for specialist aviation engineering people.

Speaker: NA
Text: While a lot of that training is being done in a

Speaker: NA
Text: new school that has been established, with

Speaker: NA
Text: government help, at Brisbane airport, all the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland universities are very much in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved now in producing graduates who will

Speaker: NA
Text: have the capacity to go for the highly techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal jobs that will come with the advent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new Qantas 767 maintenance base. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: also talk of a joint facility being set up be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween Qantas and Singapore Airlines for the

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance and work involved with the

Speaker: NA
Text: new A380 aircraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there are exciting times on the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast. Employment levels are very high. The

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for labour is immense. While we

Speaker: NA
Text: speak of technical areas, we have only to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the building industry to see what is

Speaker: NA
Text: there. I understand from the Master

Speaker: NA
Text: Builders Association that at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: there are some 2,300 apprenticeships going

Speaker: NA
Text: within the building industry. The situation

Speaker: NA
Text: has become so drastic and there is such a

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement for qualified builders that a

Speaker: NA
Text: third-year apprentice in the building industry

Speaker: NA
Text: at the moment, if that person is good, has the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to draw something like $100,000 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year. So the Gold Coast is, I think, probably

Speaker: NA
Text: the most exciting part of Australia at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment. It is exciting because it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: much an international city, but it is most ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: citing because of the tremendous contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion it is making to the development of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Watson, Mr Burke, I

Speaker: NA
Text: pro- remind the House that this is the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's first speech. I ask the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend to him the usual courtesies.

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson) (12.39 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, it is hard to believe I am here. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is the room where the arguments of the na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion come to a head, the room where the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the nation is determined and

Speaker: NA
Text: the room where all the diverse opinions

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia are broken down to 150

Speaker: NA
Text: voices. To be selected by the community to

Speaker: NA
Text: be one of those 150 voices is an extraordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nary honour. It is the community where I

Speaker: NA
Text: have grown up, where my parents grew up

Speaker: NA
Text: and now where my own family is growing

Speaker: NA
Text: up so quickly. It means the world to me to

Speaker: NA
Text: see them all here today: my wife, Cathy, who

Speaker: NA
Text: had the right of veto as to whether I would

Speaker: NA
Text: run for federal parliament and who has of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fered nothing but love and support in the

Speaker: NA
Text: many years that have led to today, and my

Speaker: NA
Text: three gorgeous daughters. Liana is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: lery, and Caitlyn and Helena are carefully

Speaker: NA
Text: positioned behind soundproof glass! Mum,

Speaker: NA
Text: Dad, Rosemary, Sharon, and Michael:

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it was as your youngest child or lit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tle brother, every supportive comment has

Speaker: NA
Text: helped me to get here and all the other com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments just count as training.

Speaker: NA
Text: The campaign for Watson was run by Ari

Speaker: NA
Text: Margossian, the National President of Young

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor, with the ever present strategic advice

Speaker: NA
Text: of Morris Iemma. With so many volunteers

Speaker: NA
Text: to thank, I want to acknowledge all my

Speaker: NA
Text: friends on the campaign team and every

Speaker: NA
Text: branch member. I particularly want to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: those who were there every single day:

Speaker: NA
Text: Maria Iannotti, Vince Badalati, Wilma

Speaker: NA
Text: Hickey, Claire Haig, Peter Papodopoulos and

Speaker: NA
Text: Chris Taylor. I also thank Greg Donnelly and

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone from the SDA. A particular thank

Speaker: NA
Text: you to those friends who helped form Watson

Speaker: NA
Text: Young Labor Association more than 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, who made all this possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Campaigns are not only fought at a local

Speaker: NA
Text: level. In only 10 months Mark Latham did a

Speaker: NA
Text: great job to raise the spirits of Labor sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters and ensure that the party were seri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously competitive as we moved into the cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign. I also note the improved result in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales and congratulate my good

Speaker: NA
Text: friends Mark Arbib and Karl Bitar on their

Speaker: NA
Text: roles in the campaign. A number of good

Speaker: NA
Text: friends ran in marginal seats and some

Speaker: NA
Text: missed out in difficult circumstances. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to acknowledge their effort, commitment and

Speaker: NA
Text: talent. They have been friends for some time

Speaker: NA
Text: and I look forward to calling them parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary colleagues in the years ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: The local area now covered by the seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson was well represented in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: for 25 years by Leo MCLeay. He served this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber as both Speaker and Chief Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment Whip. After the election I came

Speaker: NA
Text: down here to set up my office and, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: galwalked through the Members Hall, it dawned

Speaker: NA
Text: on me that it had really happened: Leo had in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact retired and I was now the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson. As I walked along through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Members Hall I noticed out of the corner of

Speaker: NA
Text: my eye the framed pictures on the walls and

Speaker: NA
Text: glanced up to see who they were of. And

Speaker: NA
Text: there he was, staring straight back at me-a

Speaker: NA
Text: portrait of Leo MCLeay, still here and still

Speaker: NA
Text: watching me. Leo, I wish you and Janice

Speaker: NA
Text: well for the years ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am in the unusual position of delivering

Speaker: NA
Text: my second first speech. Only last year I had

Speaker: NA
Text: the chance to deliver my first speech to the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales Legislative Council. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year I deliver another first speech. Next year

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not. This will be my final first speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: But in introducing myself to a new parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, I have not changed all that radically in

Speaker: NA
Text: a year. So, for the friends here who heard my

Speaker: NA
Text: last first speech, there will be some moments

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be familiar. Sorry about that. I can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not help it-it is the same me.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been a number of articles writ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten and speeches made over the last 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: which have profiled the previous careers of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the House of Representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have even been check lists in some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the more recent articles that said how terrible

Speaker: NA
Text: it is that so many federal MPs have previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously worked as lawyers, teachers, staffers,

Speaker: NA
Text: state members of parliament and union offi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cials. On that list I score four out of five. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have never been a teacher, although the busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness I ran did do training, so I might be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to stretch the definition and still get to full

Speaker: NA
Text: marks. I have no intention of trying to rein-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent myself here today. I have great pride in

Speaker: NA
Text: the work I have done and the people I have

Speaker: NA
Text: helped. There have been two main themes in

Speaker: NA
Text: my own working life and upbringing: small

Speaker: NA
Text: business and trade unions. You will not find

Speaker: NA
Text: me ever walking away from either.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dad opened a small business in River-

Speaker: NA
Text: wood when he was 27, and he stayed there

Speaker: NA
Text: until he retired. The sign in Belmore Road

Speaker: NA
Text: still reads ‘Burke's Riverwood Pharmacy'. I

Speaker: NA
Text: grew up with no knowledge of the term ‘nine

Speaker: NA
Text: to five', and I never understood small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness as being where you worked for yourself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dad was employed by a few thousand cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tomers. He felt a real sense of service and

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation to each of them, and a handful of

Speaker: NA
Text: those customers knew how to be extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: tough employers. I remember dinner being

Speaker: NA
Text: postponed more often than not because extra

Speaker: NA
Text: customers had arrived at the exact moment

Speaker: NA
Text: Dad was about to close the shop for the

Speaker: NA
Text: night. I remember vividly Dad sitting at the

Speaker: NA
Text: dining table at night as I went to bed while

Speaker: NA
Text: he completed the streams of paperwork that

Speaker: NA
Text: were required while Mum sat at the other

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the table marking work for her stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents at school.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had all the small business themes: the

Speaker: NA
Text: frustration of mounting paperwork; the pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure of government paying its bills to us late,

Speaker: NA
Text: when every creditor was demanding we pay

Speaker: NA
Text: them on time; and the difficulties associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with ever being able to organise time off

Speaker: NA
Text: when the business was your own. Do not get

Speaker: NA
Text: me wrong; I had a very fortunate upbringing.

Speaker: NA
Text: These were never crisis issues; they were just

Speaker: NA
Text: part of every day life. By simple, understated

Speaker: NA
Text: example, my parents taught me a work ethic

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have never let go.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had the satisfaction of forming my own

Speaker: NA
Text: business some years ago with Ben Richards

Speaker: NA
Text: and Ray D'Cruz whom I had met through

Speaker: NA
Text: debating. Aticus Pty Ltd still runs success-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully, providing public speaking and advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cacy training around Australia and into vari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous parts of South-East Asia. To have been

Speaker: NA
Text: there from the start-planning the business,

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the bureaucracy that comes with

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporation-and going through the initial

Speaker: NA
Text: period of diversification while we gradually

Speaker: NA
Text: established the core business was an exciting

Speaker: NA
Text: and valuable time. To see the business still

Speaker: NA
Text: flourishing years later is a fantastic reward

Speaker: NA
Text: for the effort we all put in at the start, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly the drive and commitment shown

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ray and Ben in seeing the importance and

Speaker: NA
Text: power of encouraging people to not only

Speaker: NA
Text: hold opinions but to advocate them.

Speaker: NA
Text: During my time with Aticus, and while we

Speaker: NA
Text: went through that early period of diversifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, I became involved in lobbying two is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues which found supporters on both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber. As a result, I formed many

Speaker: NA
Text: friendships early on with various caucus

Speaker: NA
Text: members, and I have enjoyed a good work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing relationship with the member for Men-

Speaker: NA
Text: zies and the member for Wentworth. I sin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerely hope it is not long before their party

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises their talent and allows both of

Speaker: NA
Text: them the opportunity which is already mine:

Speaker: NA
Text: to serve in this chamber as a shadow minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter.

Speaker: NA
Text: My first job, and my first involvement

Speaker: NA
Text: with unions, was delivering the Sunday pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: pers for the Beverly Hills Newsagency.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a grave injustice there: we were

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving 10 per cent commission while

Speaker: NA
Text: other shops were all paying 12½ per cent. I

Speaker: NA
Text: organised the other paperboys and said,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Let's form a union.' We worked out our de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mands, but when I took them to the boss, he

Speaker: NA
Text: would not listen. He said we could not be a

Speaker: NA
Text: union because we had not charged fees. So

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone threw in a copper coin, and I went

Speaker: NA
Text: back to negotiate. It was a comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: log of claims: 12½ per cent commission, an

Speaker: NA
Text: extra $1 every time it rained and free food

Speaker: NA
Text: for a Christmas party. He came back with the

Speaker: NA
Text: typical response, ‘Why should I give you lot

Speaker: NA
Text: that?' I can still hear my 12-year-old voice

Speaker: NA
Text: answering him: ‘If you don't, we'll have a

Speaker: NA
Text: paperboy picket line out the front of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shop. The TV cameras will turn up because

Speaker: NA
Text: they'll think it's really funny. We'll be on

Speaker: NA
Text: TV, so we'll feel really important. The cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tomers will know it's your shop and you'll

Speaker: NA
Text: look really bad.' He gave in to all three de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mands. To celebrate, we spent the union fees

Speaker: NA
Text: on mixed lollies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Years later, I became a full-time official

Speaker: NA
Text: with the union I first joined as a checkout

Speaker: NA
Text: operator with Grace Bros: the SDA. While

Speaker: NA
Text: the fees were more than a copper coin, the

Speaker: NA
Text: methods of workplace organising through

Speaker: NA
Text: local delegates and giving people a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: stake in the outcomes achieved were not all

Speaker: NA
Text: that different.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is bizarre that there have been speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber claiming that the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: work union officials do is not real work; that

Speaker: NA
Text: people like me do not get real world experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence during those years. Seriously, does any-

Speaker: NA
Text: one actually believe that I would have had

Speaker: NA
Text: more real world experience if, instead, I had

Speaker: NA
Text: utilised my law degree to represent the same

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the same issues but charged them a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of hundred dollars an hour to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: with me in some solicitor's office with

Speaker: NA
Text: dodgy wood panelling and terminally ill

Speaker: NA
Text: goldfish? The critics of trade unionists enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing parliament speak as though unionism

Speaker: NA
Text: was a single industry where we spend our

Speaker: NA
Text: days in the same sorts of union offices doing

Speaker: NA
Text: the same sort of job, and that we bring the

Speaker: NA
Text: same life experiences to parliament. As an

Speaker: NA
Text: organiser, I did not have an office-I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: even have a desk. My workplace was wher-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever my members worked. My meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: rooms would be at Flemings at Bexley or

Speaker: NA
Text: Big W at Campsie. My lunch room would be

Speaker: NA
Text: the food courts at Roselands or at Hurstville.

Speaker: NA
Text: My desk would be whatever box I might

Speaker: NA
Text: have to lean on in that KFC at William

Speaker: NA
Text: Street, Earlwood.

Speaker: NA
Text: I look around this chamber and am as

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to be among those with a union back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground as I am to be among those with a

Speaker: NA
Text: small business background. Just as business

Speaker: NA
Text: varies radically from one sector to another,

Speaker: NA
Text: so does the experience of union officials.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we bring in common is experience

Speaker: NA
Text: from the front line of the concerns and aspi-

Speaker: NA
Text: rations of people in every industry. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces have been our workplaces. For

Speaker: NA
Text: those who want to use the ‘not a real job'

Speaker: NA
Text: line, I can only say that when I met with

Speaker: NA
Text: night fillers in the early hours of the morning

Speaker: NA
Text: to uncover systematic underpayments, it felt

Speaker: NA
Text: like a real job; when I visited fast food out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lets on weekends and found that cost savings

Speaker: NA
Text: had been extended to not replenishing the

Speaker: NA
Text: first aid kit, with one manager telling 15-

Speaker: NA
Text: year-old employees to use serviettes and

Speaker: NA
Text: sticky tape as a substitute for bandaids, it felt

Speaker: NA
Text: like a real job; and when I negotiated roster

Speaker: NA
Text: changes for employees such as one who had

Speaker: NA
Text: been given a roster which would have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: him working nine hours during the only day

Speaker: NA
Text: he had access to his children or for another

Speaker: NA
Text: who would have had to leave her young

Speaker: NA
Text: children unsupervised had the original roster

Speaker: NA
Text: gone ahead, not only did it feel like a real job

Speaker: NA
Text: to me, I reckon those employees and every

Speaker: NA
Text: member of their families thought the job I

Speaker: NA
Text: was doing was pretty real too.

Speaker: NA
Text: And none of these outcomes were

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved through aggression. Like any other

Speaker: NA
Text: organiser, I would sit down with the member,

Speaker: NA
Text: the delegate and management and we would

Speaker: NA
Text: work through the problem. All day, every

Speaker: NA
Text: day, managers and business owners would be

Speaker: NA
Text: explaining their pressures, their constraints-

Speaker: NA
Text: often explaining those pressures far more

Speaker: NA
Text: candidly to me than they would to their own

Speaker: NA
Text: head office. We would arrive at sensible so-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutions that everyone could work with.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have read the Hansard of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debates in this chamber and have to smile at

Speaker: NA
Text: the claims that, for people like myself, the

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement with unions is an albatross

Speaker: NA
Text: around our necks. Around the neck is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: way you wear a badge of honour. I will al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways wear my history with small business

Speaker: NA
Text: and my history with unions the same way.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is not a day of my employment history

Speaker: NA
Text: I would ever want to change.

Speaker: NA
Text: I value every moment I spent in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, and thank those friends from the

Speaker: NA
Text: state parliament who have come down today.

Speaker: NA
Text: To be part of Bob Carr's government, to

Speaker: NA
Text: chair the State Development Committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: to work in Macquarie Street with a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: life-long friends was a real privilege. Yet for hurt.

Speaker: NA
Text: me, right here is where I have wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: work for a long time. I know you lose the

Speaker: NA
Text: intimacy and the intensity of those New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales debating chambers and that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a lonelier place for members in many

Speaker: NA
Text: ways, but there is something about the fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral parliament that goes way beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation we pass here and way beyond our

Speaker: NA
Text: constitutional powers. I realised this one day

Speaker: NA
Text: about eight years ago when Cathy came

Speaker: NA
Text: home from work and told me the children

Speaker: NA
Text: were playing differently at the community

Speaker: NA
Text: based child-care centre where she taught and

Speaker: NA
Text: racist taunts had suddenly crept into the

Speaker: NA
Text: guage of the children as they played. It did

Speaker: NA
Text: not happen because any law had changed. It

Speaker: NA
Text: did not happen because of government

Speaker: NA
Text: spending. It happened because a speech had

Speaker: NA
Text: been made by an Independent member in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber which was seen to legitimise racist

Speaker: NA
Text: comment in the name of free speech. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is something about what is said in this cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber that changes the mood of the nation, that

Speaker: NA
Text: gives us a role in affecting how Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to each other. Just as we have the ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity here to run our politics in ways that

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to the worst of the attitudes in Austraworking

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, we have the capacity to appeal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we acknowledge the incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: strength and richness of the many cultures

Speaker: NA
Text: which make our nation so vibrant, from In-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous Australians through to the most

Speaker: NA
Text: recent immigrant, it has an impact on how

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians relate to each other at the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place, in the shopping centre and in the play-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground. When members of this chamber talk,

Speaker: NA
Text: very few people tune in and certainly none of

Speaker: NA
Text: the under-fives in that Greenacre playground

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to the broadcasts, but somehow the

Speaker: NA
Text: message gets out. When members here de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mean others, divide communities and vilify

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the most vulnerable people, those

Speaker: NA
Text: people do not have to be listening to feel the

Speaker: NA
Text: No matter how many pet issues an indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual member can bring to this chamber, so

Speaker: NA
Text: much of what we have to address is deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined by the pressure of the period of his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory in which we find ourselves here. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve there are three overarching themes

Speaker: NA
Text: which will dominate the lives of anyone in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in the battle of ideas over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: generation: the ageing population, climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change and globalisation. Some of the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacts of a lower birth rate combined with an

Speaker: NA
Text: increased life expectancy have already been

Speaker: NA
Text: well documented and discussed broadly. We

Speaker: NA
Text: lan- all know the subsequent importance of na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional savings and the pressures which flow

Speaker: NA
Text: to our health and welfare systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is an added impact which is consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered too rarely. We have an education system

Speaker: NA
Text: which is designed to cater for the demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphic make-up of Australians more than 40

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago. By and large our education system

Speaker: NA
Text: presumes you can receive all the qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions you need well before you turn 25 and

Speaker: NA
Text: then you are set for life, but an ageing popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation will see people wanting, and in some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases needing, to have a significantly longer

Speaker: NA
Text: life, and technological change will

Speaker: NA
Text: best create an ongoing need for the update of

Speaker: NA
Text: skills. Many methods of continuing educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion are poorly planned, impractical for peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple who are already balancing work and fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily commitments, and way too expensive for

Speaker: NA
Text: people under modern financial pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the last four years I have served as

Speaker: NA
Text: President of Bankstown Community College

Speaker: NA
Text: and have seen the value of affordable short

Speaker: NA
Text: courses, not only for their content but for

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to ensure that people do not forget

Speaker: NA
Text: how to learn. I will never forget when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lakemba Franklins store was for sale and

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the staff members was worried about

Speaker: NA
Text: her future employment. She said, ‘Tony, if

Speaker: NA
Text: only I'd learnt how to type, but it's too late

Speaker: NA
Text: now.' Even though she ended up with secure

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in retail, the words she spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: still sound a warning for anyone who be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieves lifelong learning is just a luxury. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills shortage intensifies and our popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ages it will become an economic neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I first joined the Labor Party all the

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental issues were about saving

Speaker: NA
Text: iconic sites: the Franklin, the Daintree,

Speaker: NA
Text: Kakadu. Climate change moves any envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronmental debate to a new plane. The impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for water, salinity, the viability

Speaker: NA
Text: many industries, and consequent issues in

Speaker: NA
Text: trade and health, right through to bushfire

Speaker: NA
Text: and natural disaster, all combine to move the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on. The arguments over the causes of

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change or even questioning the exis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence of climate change are all fast becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: conversations of the past. The responses

Speaker: NA
Text: need to occur at each level of government

Speaker: NA
Text: and our international role needs to be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously. The tired old stunts of bashing the

Speaker: NA
Text: UN and refusing to sign international agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have reached their use-by dates. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is too much at stake to get this one wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: In any discussion about globalisation I

Speaker: NA
Text: should start by making clear that I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: afraid of it-not a bit. The growth in interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional campaigns on human rights has oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred hand in hand with globalisation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the strongest pressure on many nations to lift

Speaker: NA
Text: their game and open up the rights of their

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens as they open up their economies. It

Speaker: NA
Text: the was Labor that lowered the tariffs and intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced the competition reforms which began

Speaker: NA
Text: the process of breaking down the cartels

Speaker: NA
Text: which had shut out new businesses and pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vented families from spending their income

Speaker: NA
Text: on fairly priced goods. This gave families a

Speaker: NA
Text: real increase in buying power-effectively a

Speaker: NA
Text: pay rise without a tax increase-thanks to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor reforms of the eighties and nine-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to make sure that in pursuing the

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements available to people as con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers we do not now sacrifice their dignity

Speaker: NA
Text: at work. No-one should have any pride in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of casualisation. Anyone who thinks that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is all about voluntary flexibility on the part

Speaker: NA
Text: of employees should come with me to a local

Speaker: NA
Text: supermarket at one o'clock in the morning,

Speaker: NA
Text: go to a coffee shop the next day and see the

Speaker: NA
Text: same people working, and then go again to

Speaker: NA
Text: find the same people working as domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: cleaners or mowing lawns in a scramble to

Speaker: NA
Text: of so find the hours that used to be available

Speaker: NA
Text: through full-time work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The flexibility that comes with upskilling

Speaker: NA
Text: is an important boost to productivity but that

Speaker: NA
Text: flexibility will always have a limit. Paying

Speaker: NA
Text: bills is not flexible, the mortgage and rent are

Speaker: NA
Text: not flexible and the demand to feed the fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily will never be flexible. I have seen peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple's personal lives thrown into chaos by

Speaker: NA
Text: shifts suddenly disappearing or by one roster

Speaker: NA
Text: change meaning that the second job is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer viable. The world will force us to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to embrace competition and to be flexi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble with skills development. There are many

Speaker: NA
Text: great benefits along that road, but if the word

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘dignity' drops out of workplaces on the way

Speaker: NA
Text: through then we are missing some essential

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian values.

Speaker: NA
Text: Do not get me wrong. For all the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity that comes with being a member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House I also recognise that being in opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has nothing going for it. Five months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago I was in government. I am 100 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: glad I went federal, but I do want to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about the seating plan here. We

Speaker: NA
Text: become involved in the political system to

Speaker: NA
Text: make changes. We run for this parliament to

Speaker: NA
Text: affect the nation. Policy development is only

Speaker: NA
Text: ever the prologue. The real work is about

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation: reaching people and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving their lives. I have never believed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the nobility of defeat. I do believe in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity of the Labor Party to lift the

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation and lead Australia forward. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: job is to win: to implement the policies we

Speaker: NA
Text: offer, to provide fresh opportunities while

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting the most vulnerable and to see

Speaker: NA
Text: reward for excellence without ever deserting

Speaker: NA
Text: those in genuine need.

Speaker: NA
Text: My predecessor was a member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House for 25 years. If I manage the same

Speaker: NA
Text: length of service and spend only the first

Speaker: NA
Text: three years in opposition then there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable chance to contribute. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: worked here in 1993 every commentator was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying how invincible we were. They soon

Speaker: NA
Text: said the same about Jeff Kennett. In fact, in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years the pattern has been that most

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian governments do look invincible at

Speaker: NA
Text: the start of their final term. Three years of

Speaker: NA
Text: effective hard work stands between Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: and government-work to which Labor has

Speaker: NA
Text: an absolute commitment, work which is al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready under way, work which I am honoured

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a direct role in. I realise that this

Speaker: NA
Text: the only time that the House observes the

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesy of no-one interjecting during a

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. Good. There is a battle of ideas that I

Speaker: NA
Text: desperately want to be involved in and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the perfect room to have it out in open de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate. Mr Speaker, bring it on.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Robb, I remind honourable members that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is his first speech. I therefore ask that the

Speaker: NA
Text: usual courtesies be extended to him.

Speaker: Mr ROBB
Text: Goldstein) (1.00 p.m.)-From

Speaker: NA
Text: as early as I can remember, my mother and

Speaker: NA
Text: father instilled in me and my eight brothers

Speaker: NA
Text: and sisters that opportunity and freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: would come through education, personal

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility and self-belief; that our destiny

Speaker: NA
Text: was largely in our own hands-how hard we

Speaker: NA
Text: studied and worked, the opportunities we

Speaker: NA
Text: took, how we dealt with people. I grew to

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that I was responsible for charting

Speaker: NA
Text: my own course-that I was free to follow

Speaker: NA
Text: ca- my dreams, make my own mistakes, take the

Speaker: NA
Text: spirits of consequences of my decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, my parents never seemed to

Speaker: NA
Text: convey any resentment or jealousy that oth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers might have more than we had. There was

Speaker: NA
Text: no chip on the shoulder; rather, a notion of

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘blue sky', a sense that if we really wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: what others had-whatever that might be-

Speaker: NA
Text: then the opportunity was there to achieve it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ambition was presented as a good thing,

Speaker: NA
Text: something to be nurtured and applauded, and

Speaker: NA
Text: not only in sport. I embraced these simple

Speaker: NA
Text: truths as a philosophy, elements that I later

Speaker: NA
Text: came to see as best captured by the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party philosophy.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there was no road to Damascus for me

Speaker: NA
Text: in my support for the Liberal philosophy. It

Speaker: NA
Text: evolved and owed most to my parents, which

Speaker: NA
Text: to some would seem surprising given their

Speaker: NA
Text: background. Many other life experiences

Speaker: NA
Text: have served to further entrench but also add

Speaker: NA
Text: to these principles or a set of ‘tram tracks'-

Speaker: NA
Text: a set of ‘tram tracks' that guide daily my re-

Speaker: NA
Text: is sponses to issues and events and will help to

Speaker: NA
Text: direct my response to matters in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: I come to this place keen to put my ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience to good use and proud to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: all the people of Goldstein and I come very

Speaker: NA
Text: conscious of the trust they have placed in

Speaker: NA
Text: me. I intend that they will be well repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented. I am also conscious of the wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: support for my campaign from so many Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: erals in Goldstein, under the very able direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of my campaign director, Jeannette

Speaker: NA
Text: Rawlinson.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vida Goldstein, after whom my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: is named, was Victoria's foremost suffragist

Speaker: NA
Text: for two decades, standing for parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1903-the first woman in the British Empire

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so. Vida was a woman of achievement

Speaker: NA
Text: and conviction, as befits the people of my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. Vida grew up in the Western Dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trict of Victoria, like another accomplished

Speaker: NA
Text: woman in my life: my wife, Maureen. I ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge the presence today in the gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: of Maureen and our children, Tom, Joe and

Speaker: NA
Text: Pip. They are my strength.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this occasion I am also mindful of the

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding service given to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldstein by my predecessor, Dr David

Speaker: NA
Text: Kemp, over 14 years. David, a man of great

Speaker: NA
Text: intellect, integrity and endeavour, should be

Speaker: NA
Text: justly proud of his wonderful contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: public policy over more than three decades. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suspect and hope that David's contribution is

Speaker: NA
Text: not yet finished.

Speaker: NA
Text: I bring to this place 33 years of work ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience, with 20 years in and around the

Speaker: NA
Text: political process. I have worked in the public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, the private sector and the very private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector-the political machine. In the early to

Speaker: NA
Text: mid-eighties, I was the chief executive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cattle Council of Australia and then the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Farmers Federation. During those

Speaker: NA
Text: years I was involved in negotiating federal

Speaker: NA
Text: land rights legislation pertaining to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: As it turned out, the land rights legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: was a totally inadequate response to the real

Speaker: NA
Text: issue-namely, the collapse of personal dig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity and self-esteem among many Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nals, particularly the young. In seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: come to grips with Indigenous issues, I spent

Speaker: NA
Text: many, many weeks over a period of years in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory, the Kimberley and

Speaker: NA
Text: North Queensland talking to cattlemen, to

Speaker: NA
Text: businesspeople, to officials and to other lo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cals. I visited Aboriginal settlements and

Speaker: NA
Text: outback towns.

Speaker: NA
Text: On many occasions, I would be taken to a

Speaker: NA
Text: bend in a river on a cattle station and shown

Speaker: NA
Text: where 100, 200 or 300 Aboriginals had lived

Speaker: NA
Text: for decades, with the men employed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: stations as stockmen and drovers, the older

Speaker: NA
Text: men as gardeners, and the women in the

Speaker: NA
Text: homestead. In many cases, schools were

Speaker: NA
Text: provided for the children. Aboriginal people

Speaker: NA
Text: were disadvantaged, but they had work and

Speaker: NA
Text: self-esteem, reasonable quality of life, strong

Speaker: NA
Text: mentoring from their elders, schooling and

Speaker: NA
Text: strict controls on alcohol.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, all that ceased in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970s following the understandable granting

Speaker: NA
Text: of equal wages in the pastoral industry, along

Speaker: NA
Text: with the misplaced provision of unfettered

Speaker: NA
Text: and generous welfare handouts. The related

Speaker: NA
Text: exodus of these people from their ancestral

Speaker: NA
Text: lands saw them living in settlements and on

Speaker: NA
Text: the fringes of towns. The highly disturbing

Speaker: NA
Text: result in many Aboriginal communities today

Speaker: NA
Text: is that we have basically poisoned recent

Speaker: NA
Text: generations; poisoned their bodies with alco-

Speaker: NA
Text: hol and other substances and poisoned their

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit and self-belief with handouts and wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare dependency. In many places we are see-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a total breakdown in the social order.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I was driven around vast cattle sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, I witnessed cattlemen come across an

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal elder known to them. The mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: respect was palpable. On the same day I saw

Speaker: NA
Text: the same cattleman come across young Abo-

Speaker: NA
Text: riginal men seriously affected by years of

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol and aimlessness, young men stripped

Speaker: NA
Text: of any personal dignity or self-esteem. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cattleman's contempt was palpable. The

Speaker: NA
Text: chilling fact is that the very fabric of a proud

Speaker: NA
Text: and fascinating culture, many thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: years in the making, has been brought to its

Speaker: NA
Text: knees in less than 30 years by well-

Speaker: NA
Text: intentioned but seriously misguided policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: For me the lesson is clear. People are

Speaker: NA
Text: very responsive to incentives, for good or

Speaker: NA
Text: bad. The wrong incentives, no matter how

Speaker: NA
Text: well meaning, can debilitate a community in

Speaker: NA
Text: no time. In this case, unconditional handouts

Speaker: NA
Text: have provided the seeds of destruction in a

Speaker: NA
Text: breathtakingly short period of time. It is why

Speaker: NA
Text: every piece of public policy in this place is

Speaker: NA
Text: important. It is why every piece of public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy must be measured against a set of

Speaker: NA
Text: principles, a set of ‘tram tracks'. It is why

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, restoring personal dignity and

Speaker: NA
Text: self-esteem is the bedrock of any solution for

Speaker: NA
Text: our Aboriginal community. In many places

Speaker: NA
Text: this means replacing the grog, the petrol and

Speaker: NA
Text: the paint with work. To this end, I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the direction outlined by the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General in his speech to the opening of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 41st Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: During my years at the National Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation I was involved with two major

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial disputes: the Mudginberri abattoir

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute and the wide combs dispute. These

Speaker: NA
Text: two disputes proved that success is never

Speaker: NA
Text: easy, regardless of the merits. Importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: they also proved the underlying strength of

Speaker: NA
Text: the employer-employee relationship in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. Mudginberri sought to establish a right

Speaker: NA
Text: for employer and employee to negotiate

Speaker: NA
Text: terms and conditions which best met the pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: culiar nature of that abattoir's operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: wide combs dispute sought to establish the

Speaker: NA
Text: right of employers and employees to agree to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt new technology-in this case, a wider

Speaker: NA
Text: shearing comb-on a workplace by work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nearly 20 years later it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: conceive that these rights were in dispute.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet Mudginberri took 27 court cases, two

Speaker: NA
Text: years of litigation and a $10 million farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting fund to win. The wide combs dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: pute had to contend with bullets flying,

Speaker: NA
Text: shearing sheds being torched and paid thugs

Speaker: NA
Text: very, intimidating communities. These two dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: putes were only won because, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: belligerent stance of the unions, there ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: isted-and, I believe, still exists-a funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentally healthy and mature relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: between employer and employee in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: with a mutual trust that the benefits of

Speaker: NA
Text: change can and will be shared.

Speaker: NA
Text: The disputes also highlighted that no two

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces among the millions of work-

Speaker: NA
Text: places in Australia are the same. The more

Speaker: NA
Text: we do as a government to free up employers

Speaker: NA
Text: and their employees to settle on terms and

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions which maximise the unique op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunities in each workplace, the more jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and the more prosperity we will see. From

Speaker: NA
Text: my experience, many employers have come

Speaker: NA
Text: to realise that, if they give their team the

Speaker: NA
Text: right incentives, they can move mountains.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have also observed that this power of

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiating one to one has parallels in the

Speaker: NA
Text: international trade arena. My experience on

Speaker: NA
Text: the international scene includes expanding a

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial business into the New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: market in the late 1990s; advising major

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand companies on their move into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; facilitating large commercial pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects in Asia, particularly in Thailand; em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploying trade lobbyists in Washington in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s and negotiating with the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Union, the United States and Japan on agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: The cultural trade matters over a decade. These

Speaker: NA
Text: experiences have long convinced me that the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing emphasis on trade agreements nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiated bilaterally between two countries is

Speaker: NA
Text: not only in Australia's best interests but also

Speaker: NA
Text: a harbinger of real progress on trade liberali-

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to sation on a global basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: While multicountry World Trade Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation negotiations obviously hold out the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of more comprehensive liberalisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, they proceed at a snail's pace, if at all,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas bilateral trade agreements are deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ering major benefits in our lifetime. The

Speaker: NA
Text: closer economic relations agreement with

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand is a wonderful case in point.

Speaker: NA
Text: Successful bilateral agreements, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: stymying progress on multicountry agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, are in fact creating a competitive im-

Speaker: NA
Text: perative for non-participating countries to be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved, leading the way incrementally to

Speaker: NA
Text: more comprehensive removal of trade barri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last 33 years in my roles as an

Speaker: NA
Text: animal health officer working in abattoirs

Speaker: NA
Text: and saleyards and on farms; as a tutor in

Speaker: NA
Text: macro-economics working with highly moti-

Speaker: NA
Text: vated, mature age university students; as an

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural economist and farm organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: and political party executive setting up and

Speaker: NA
Text: running an Australia-wide direct marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: IT company and, in recent years, as an ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: viser on business strategy to global compa-

Speaker: NA
Text: nies and large organisations, I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: regularly to all corners of Australia. Working

Speaker: NA
Text: with people and communities from Albany to

Speaker: NA
Text: Cairns and from Hobart to the North West

Speaker: NA
Text: Shelf has left me a committed federalist. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a great distrust of any central power, by

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, understanding and effectively meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: the needs of far-flung communities and busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I see the federal government having

Speaker: NA
Text: a critical leadership role to play, I agree

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly with the sentiment expressed by Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Menzies in 1960 when he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... there is a deep instinct in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: for a system of Government which, by a division

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislative and administrative powers, limits

Speaker: NA
Text: centralisation (or “control from Canberra”) and

Speaker: NA
Text: protects a measure of individual freedom by not

Speaker: NA
Text: giving us one set of rules-even elected rulers-

Speaker: NA
Text: who have absolute power. In a great island conti-

Speaker: NA
Text: nent with widely scattered communities, this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy sentiment.

Speaker: NA
Text: No matter how much it might irk members in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place from time to time-and, I suspect,

Speaker: NA
Text: me in the future-I believe that our great

Speaker: NA
Text: history of stability and resourcefulness owes

Speaker: NA
Text: much to the decisions about local issues be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing taken locally. It owes much to the bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance between our three tiers of government,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the sovereignty and authority of

Speaker: NA
Text: the states and the role played by local gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in Australia. This balance has served

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The federalist imperative was further re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flected in the intent of our founding fathers

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Senate be a states house of review, a

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber designed to ensure that the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of communities in each state, large and

Speaker: NA
Text: small, were taken into account by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment of the day. In recent decades this

Speaker: NA
Text: intent has been progressively eroded, espe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially with minor parties in some cases being

Speaker: NA
Text: far more concerned with propagating an ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: treme left, international agenda than consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ering the impact of national policies on local

Speaker: NA
Text: communities in their state. This is one key

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why I favour consideration being

Speaker: NA
Text: given by a simple act of parliament to divid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing each state into six regions with two sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors selected from each region-one at each

Speaker: NA
Text: election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Drawing senators from a smaller area

Speaker: NA
Text: within a state and being accountable to that

Speaker: NA
Text: area would go some way to restoring the

Speaker: NA
Text: original intent of the founding fathers for a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong state perspective to be present in the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal parliament without requiring any

Speaker: NA
Text: change to our proven institutions. This im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mind perative to preserve our proven institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: underscored my support for an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: head of state involving only minimal change

Speaker: NA
Text: to our Constitution. I still see, some time in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, an Australian head of state provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a powerful and stabilising symbol with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out detracting from our proud history and the

Speaker: NA
Text: stability of our institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: My involvement with the Garvan Medical

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Foundation has opened my eyes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent revolution in medical and biologi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal science-a revolution which, proudly,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is in the thick of. While it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: 51 years since DNA was discovered, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: only in the last six to seven years

Speaker: NA
Text: tists have seriously begun to unlock this ge-

Speaker: NA
Text: netic code which not only controls our de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment from a fertilised egg to a complex

Speaker: NA
Text: human being but also determines what goes

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong in disorders as diverse as cancer, men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal illness and obesity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The innovations flowing from these dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: coveries in basic science are only just emerg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and will reach well beyond health and

Speaker: NA
Text: disease. We will see genetically modified

Speaker: NA
Text: micro-organisms used in the creation of en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy products, industrial products and a host

Speaker: NA
Text: of other traditional areas of manufacturing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Biotechnology will have an unimaginable

Speaker: NA
Text: impact over the next few decades, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: critical factor in gaining benefits for Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia is owning the intellectual property. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not own the technology, the profits will

Speaker: NA
Text: go elsewhere. It is about taking responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for our own future. To achieve this will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire Australian investors to take big risks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Areas such as biotechnology, at this stage,

Speaker: NA
Text: involve high risks and low returns.

Speaker: NA
Text: My last seven years working with the top

Speaker: NA
Text: end of town suggest to me that our capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: for risk taking is fading. Our great entrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: neurial spirit is residing in fewer and fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: people. Perhaps our self-belief is being

Speaker: NA
Text: eroded. The clamour for endless reporting,

Speaker: NA
Text: misplaced accountability and draconian

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations are choking the boldness of busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness and need a serious rethink. In my view

Speaker: NA
Text: you cannot legislate for ethical behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: The values of a society and its institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: dictate acceptable ethical behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reducing high personal income tax rates

Speaker: NA
Text: must also play a big part in promoting risk

Speaker: NA
Text: taking. If we are to encourage individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: and businesspeople to pursue opportunities,

Speaker: NA
Text: if we are to reignite our entrepreneurial spirit

Speaker: NA
Text: and if we are to discourage some of our best

Speaker: NA
Text: and brightest from remaining overseas be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of uncompetitive tax rates, personal

Speaker: NA
Text: that scien- tax rates need to come down.

Speaker: NA
Text: The biotechnology revolution also has

Speaker: NA
Text: major implications for older Australians and

Speaker: NA
Text: how we cope with a rapidly ageing popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Over the last 100 years in Australia, life

Speaker: NA
Text: expectancy has increased from 55 to 77 years

Speaker: NA
Text: for men and from 58 to 82 years for women.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet this life expectancy stands to quickly

Speaker: NA
Text: reach much greater ages in the wake of the

Speaker: NA
Text: genetic revolution. As such, providing a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent quality of life for our older Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: presents a real challenge, especially with the

Speaker: NA
Text: birthrate at its lowest point ever. In my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: increased taxation is not an option; it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: backward step.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best way to meet the challenge is to

Speaker: NA
Text: grow the economy. Getting many healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to keep working into their 70s in

Speaker: NA
Text: the years ahead is fundamental to achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: this objective. Many of these older Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians would prefer to continue taking respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility for their own lives by undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent part-time contract work. If they

Speaker: NA
Text: were able to secure up to 100 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their income from one employer, and still

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve independent contractor status, this

Speaker: NA
Text: would seriously encourage continuing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement in the work force. We should not

Speaker: NA
Text: underestimate the challenge. It will require a

Speaker: NA
Text: serious cultural shift.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I look forward to a rich and varied

Speaker: NA
Text: political experience in the years ahead, both

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate and in this House, I do ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect that two types of security issues will

Speaker: NA
Text: dominate that experience. The first is our

Speaker: NA
Text: national security. The world has changed

Speaker: NA
Text: dramatically since 9-11. Terrorists have de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clared war on us for ideological reasons of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own, and there is no easy way out of

Speaker: NA
Text: this conflict, which is not of our making.

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeasement is not an option. It will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: long fight, and we will need our traditional

Speaker: NA
Text: friends.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second security issue is one of per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal security. My years of political observa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion have led me to understand very clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: that what the majority of Australians aspire

Speaker: NA
Text: to most is a secure life-put simply, food on

Speaker: NA
Text: the table, a job, a manageable mortgage, a

Speaker: NA
Text: holiday, a movie with the kids, an ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise some choices. To this end, maintain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a strong economy is paramount. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that aspiration and in this place I will

Speaker: NA
Text: do what I can to deliver it. In particular, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will take whatever opportunities I get to

Speaker: NA
Text: vey, especially to our young people, that true

Speaker: NA
Text: happiness and true freedom come from

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement-using whatever god-given

Speaker: NA
Text: talents we have to chart our own course, to

Speaker: NA
Text: take the consequences of our decisions, to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a go. If we do this, success and security

Speaker: NA
Text: will follow. I thank the House for the cour-

Speaker: NA
Text: tesy extended to me today.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Cunningham, I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mind honourable members that this is her

Speaker: NA
Text: first speech. I therefore ask that the usual

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesies be extended to her.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (1.19 p.m.)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: is an incredible honour to be chosen by the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who make up the community in

Speaker: NA
Text: which you live to be their representative,

Speaker: NA
Text: their voice in the federal parliament. So

Speaker: NA
Text: many good people contest elections and put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward their visions for the nation and yet

Speaker: NA
Text: so few of us are honoured with victory and

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibilities that come with it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: like to express my appreciation of the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant and effective role that the Hon. Stephen

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin played as my Labor predecessor in

Speaker: NA
Text: the seat of Cunningham, both through his

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary career and through his tireless

Speaker: NA
Text: and enthusiastic advocacy for our region.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the 2002 by-election the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham sent a strong message to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. They returned Michael Organ as

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for the two years preceding this

Speaker: NA
Text: year's election. Michael is a person of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment and integrity. I wish to take this op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to wish him and his family well for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each of us brings to this House our direct

Speaker: NA
Text: experiences of both the triumphs and the

Speaker: NA
Text: troubles of the people-individuals, families

Speaker: NA
Text: and communities-that make up our elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ates. Over the past 20 years my area has seen

Speaker: NA
Text: significant change that has brought many

Speaker: NA
Text: exciting new opportunities and shown us

Speaker: NA
Text: con- new horizons. As a region, we have aggres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sively taken up the challenge of the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: restructures of the 1980s and diversified our

Speaker: NA
Text: economic base with great success.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a vibrant small, medium and

Speaker: NA
Text: home-based business community in the Illa-

Speaker: NA
Text: warra that employs 83 per cent of the local

Speaker: NA
Text: people. The people in these businesses not

Speaker: NA
Text: only provide employment and growth oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities but also are active in supporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: community in which they and their families

Speaker: NA
Text: live. At fundraising events in my electorate I

Speaker: NA
Text: am often impressed by the number of small

Speaker: NA
Text: business people actively involved in fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: raising for really good causes in our area. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is insightful to talk to them about the chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges they face in a modern economic

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge the work of the Illawarra

Speaker: NA
Text: Business Chamber and the Wollongong of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice of the Australian Industry Group in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: searching and advocating on behalf of their

Speaker: NA
Text: would memberships. Sometimes we disagree, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we will no doubt continue to do so on some

Speaker: NA
Text: issues, but I value the positive and consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive approach they always bring when raising

Speaker: NA
Text: their concerns with me. I recommit today to

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing my role in that constructive rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last few weeks I have been visit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing many tremendous local organisations and

Speaker: NA
Text: companies that are involved in exciting new

Speaker: NA
Text: ventures and growth in our area, including a

Speaker: NA
Text: local catamaran maker which exports inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: nationally and employs over 50 local people

Speaker: NA
Text: and 14 apprentices-it makes very nice

Speaker: NA
Text: catamarans, I might add-and the local con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servatorium of music, which is hopefully

Speaker: NA
Text: soon to be exporting its music education

Speaker: NA
Text: programs into Asia. I also visited the opening

Speaker: NA
Text: only last Friday of new facilities by 313, the

Speaker: NA
Text: music, entertainment and arts training or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation. We were entertained by a recent

Speaker: NA
Text: local success story, the group Porcelain,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has only just signed an international

Speaker: NA
Text: contract.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wollongong is officially titled ‘City of

Speaker: NA
Text: novation'. It is clear from these success sto-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries and so many others that we do more than

Speaker: NA
Text: pay lip-service to this title. We act on

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, seek opportunities and retain confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence in our capacity. The arts, culture and

Speaker: NA
Text: entertainment sector in Wollongong's econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy is also important and growing. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: yet another indication of the way that Wol-

Speaker: NA
Text: longong has responded to the major chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges that have taken place over the last 20

Speaker: NA
Text: years. This sector provides nearly 5,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: or seven per cent of our employment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the arts and cultural indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries in Wollongong not only provides jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and opportunity to grow our economy but

Speaker: NA
Text: also, crucially, acts as a focus for innovation,

Speaker: NA
Text: talent and creativity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to take this opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to acknowledge and recognise the traditional

Speaker: NA
Text: owners and custodians of the land on which

Speaker: NA
Text: we meet today and of the land encompassing

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Cunningham. I had the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to meet with local Aboriginal eld-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and community workers during my can-

Speaker: NA
Text: didacy. Against multiple barriers and too

Speaker: NA
Text: often under attack, they continue to advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: for their people. They represent resilience in

Speaker: NA
Text: the face of much adversity and I recommit

Speaker: NA
Text: today to assisting them in my new role.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people of my area have built on the

Speaker: NA
Text: determination and resilience of our forebears

Speaker: NA
Text: in the mining and agriculture industries. My

Speaker: NA
Text: own family has worked in the Illawarra min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing industry since the early 1900s. The un-

Speaker: NA
Text: shakeable belief in the need to support each

Speaker: NA
Text: other through good times and bad which was

Speaker: NA
Text: forged in a dangerous and difficult industry

Speaker: NA
Text: has left a strong legacy of communal respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility in me, my family and, indeed, the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole community in which we live. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: region we enriched our diversity and opti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mism by welcoming migration. For decades

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants have settled in Wollongong to work

Speaker: NA
Text: in the steelworks and other industries. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: In- same time, they have made a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the wonderful arts, enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainment and gastronomic diversity available

Speaker: NA
Text: innovato us-although the member for Watson as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sures me that I need to visit his electorate to

Speaker: NA
Text: truly appreciate that. This complements their

Speaker: NA
Text: important economic contribution to our re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion. My parents tell of the novelty of visit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing one of the first coffee shops, located in

Speaker: NA
Text: Globe Lane, Wollongong-coincidentally,

Speaker: NA
Text: where my office now sits-and enjoying the

Speaker: NA
Text: exotic experience of a glass of apple cider or

Speaker: NA
Text: a cup of continental coffee and a slice of

Speaker: NA
Text: blackforest cake. We continue to welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: people from around the world who settle in

Speaker: NA
Text: our region, including our newest arrivals

Speaker: NA
Text: from the African nations in crisis today. We

Speaker: NA
Text: live the positive experience of tolerance and

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity each day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our area has a very distinctive geographic

Speaker: NA
Text: identity, sitting between the escarpment and

Speaker: NA
Text: the sea. You will have to excuse me if I

Speaker: NA
Text: sound like a travel brochure-I am quite at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tached to the area. It gives us our wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: lifestyle and provides important economic

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities through both tourism and our

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to attract businesses by providing

Speaker: NA
Text: lifestyle advantages. An excellent example is

Speaker: NA
Text: the world-class University of Wollongong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each year it attracts thousands of students

Speaker: NA
Text: through its excellence in research and educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, but marketing its high-quality programs

Speaker: NA
Text: is no doubt made easier when you add Wol-

Speaker: NA
Text: longong's unique lifestyle advantages. Talk

Speaker: NA
Text: to any person from the Illawarra and they

Speaker: NA
Text: will describe the emotional pleasure they feel

Speaker: NA
Text: when, after being away from home for any

Speaker: NA
Text: length of time, they reach the top of Bulli

Speaker: NA
Text: Pass and look down at the breathtaking pano-

Speaker: NA
Text: rama of the Illawarra spread out before them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only do we enjoy the beauties of our

Speaker: NA
Text: geography; the uniqueness of the landscape

Speaker: NA
Text: also gives us a very strong sense of identity

Speaker: NA
Text: with our place and our community. This, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, greatly contributes to our optimism

Speaker: NA
Text: and strong sense of community. Our area has

Speaker: NA
Text: been through many changes. We have met

Speaker: NA
Text: them with resilience and grown stronger. We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not, however, accept that there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: downside to change. We know from hard

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle that there are always potential vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tims in even the most promising of circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances. I believe that the challenge of good

Speaker: NA
Text: government is not only to seek out opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities for increased prosperity but also to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that all people are able to take advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage of the new circumstances. I have been a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Australian Labor Party for 27

Speaker: NA
Text: years-I do not always admit that, but I do

Speaker: NA
Text: today-because we are a party that takes

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously the need to find sound policies and

Speaker: NA
Text: programs that open doors for all people and

Speaker: NA
Text: actively seek to assist them in overcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: barriers that nature, society or life circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances have placed before them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last three years that I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: talking with local people as the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: candidate, it has become absolutely clear to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that there are some groups in my com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity whose struggle to access a healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: and constructive life has become increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly difficult. When my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lalor visited our area I asked her

Speaker: NA
Text: to focus the entire visit on the issue of mental

Speaker: NA
Text: health because several local organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: had been telling me about the growing num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of people needing assistance and their

Speaker: NA
Text: shrinking capacity to provide help. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: astonished, after the visit, by the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who contacted me. Most simply

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to express their appreciation that we

Speaker: NA
Text: had raised the profile of the issue. So many

Speaker: NA
Text: people had a family member or friend who

Speaker: NA
Text: had experienced a period of mental ill health

Speaker: NA
Text: and had become aware of the stigma and

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of services for both sufferers and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families and supporters. I sincerely believe

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a crucial public policy issue for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. It will become even more urgent as

Speaker: NA
Text: we begin to see many more crises in our

Speaker: NA
Text: communities that occur when mental illness

Speaker: NA
Text: is not given a priority. I have given a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to these people and groups to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to advocate for them in this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and I reaffirm that commitment today.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the campaign I attended a forum

Speaker: NA
Text: on poverty in Wollongong. I had already met

Speaker: NA
Text: with many of the organisations that attended

Speaker: NA
Text: the forum over the years preceding the cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign and I found their commitment and pro-

Speaker: NA
