Text: fessionalism an inspiration. It is true that

Speaker: NA
Text: economic prosperity has resulted in material

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements in the lifestyles of many in

Speaker: NA
Text: our community. It is equally true that the

Speaker: NA
Text: pace and demands of the new economy are

Speaker: NA
Text: even more likely to leave too many people

Speaker: NA
Text: behind. Our local St Vinnies tell me they

Speaker: NA
Text: have experienced a 17 per cent increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the demands on their services in the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Many groups who have traditionally

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced hardship and poverty as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of poor educational outcomes; poor health,

Speaker: NA
Text: wellbeing and safety experiences; or neglect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful and abusive life circumstances are still as

Speaker: NA
Text: trapped in the poverty cycle as they ever

Speaker: NA
Text: were.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, a new trend is emerging. Fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies who appear to be relatively well-off ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: terially are increasingly seeking assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the apparently more affluent sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: urbs in my electorate have families register-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for food hampers this Christmas for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time ever. Many families are clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: living on optimism about their capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: service their personal debt. Rising house

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and the large mortgages that come

Speaker: NA
Text: with them mean that many families are

Speaker: NA
Text: committing a larger and larger proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the family budget to mortgage payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their lifestyle is then often supported by the

Speaker: NA
Text: significant use of credit cards. It is not un-

Speaker: NA
Text: common for families to be balancing several

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of credit commitments at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time. This clearly means that they are only

Speaker: NA
Text: one setback away from financial hardship:

Speaker: NA
Text: one period of prolonged ill health, one period

Speaker: NA
Text: of unexpected unemployment or one major

Speaker: NA
Text: car repair or other unexpected expense. The

Speaker: NA
Text: spending optimism is often balanced on a

Speaker: NA
Text: fragile capacity and hides an underlying con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stant worry about the next bill to come in.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not easy in the current environment to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise these issues. You cannot help feeling a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit like the bore at the party who is warning

Speaker: NA
Text: about the potential hangover the next morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. Clearly people are enjoying their mate-

Speaker: NA
Text: rial consumption, and to raise concerns about

Speaker: NA
Text: the potential for financial problems is a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: like prodding a wound. I firmly believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that it would be irresponsible not to

Speaker: NA
Text: be talking about this issue in this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is irresponsible to allow this level of per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal debt and the increased potential for

Speaker: NA
Text: significant losses to be ignored. It is unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: simply rely on our charity organisations, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready struggling to meet current demand, to

Speaker: NA
Text: do even more. Addressing housing afforda-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility, access to affordable health care, access

Speaker: NA
Text: to reliable work and reasonable working

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions and access to affordable child care

Speaker: NA
Text: are all crucial responsibilities for govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, but even more so given the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges so many families face today.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the issues that have caused great

Speaker: NA
Text: concern in our area over recent years has

Speaker: NA
Text: been our unacceptably high level of youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. I well remember the huge

Speaker: NA
Text: annual intakes of apprentices at the steel-

Speaker: NA
Text: works and the coalmines when I was a teen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ager in the area. Over the last 20 years these

Speaker: NA
Text: have almost completely disappeared. Like so

Speaker: NA
Text: many other areas with a significant manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing base, we now face the disgraceful

Speaker: NA
Text: situation of both high youth unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: and high skills shortages.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Illawarra Regional Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Board commissioned a report in August this

Speaker: NA
Text: year on the size and nature of the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage in our area. They did this in recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nition of the increasing restraint this problem

Speaker: NA
Text: is placing on the growth of business. The

Speaker: NA
Text: board recognised the importance of quality

Speaker: NA
Text: data at a regional level to develop appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate regional strategies for addressing prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems. I commend their foresight in recognis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that national and state focused data and

Speaker: NA
Text: strategies are important but are far more use-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful when complemented by additional re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion-specific data.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a member representing a region in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, it is my intention to advocate for

Speaker: NA
Text: more extensive regional development pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams based on sound research and consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with the specific regions themselves. I

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to the final report of the Illa-

Speaker: NA
Text: warra Regional Development Board to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide the analysis needed to add to the anec-

Speaker: NA
Text: dotal evidence from businesses of the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: to creasing problem of the shortage of skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must say that I found myself somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: stunned in my first week in this parliament-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I rushed to rewrite part of my speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: to hear various members opposite make

Speaker: NA
Text: claims that my colleagues have failed to give

Speaker: NA
Text: due attention to the importance of technical

Speaker: NA
Text: education and training. As a former TAFE

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher and coordinator of joint schools-

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE programs and traineeship programs,

Speaker: NA
Text: not surprisingly I take pride in being a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate for our excellent TAFE system and

Speaker: NA
Text: I have followed debate on these issues over

Speaker: NA
Text: the years very closely.

Speaker: NA
Text: My colleague the member for Throsby

Speaker: NA
Text: very effectively advocated, over the three

Speaker: NA
Text: years of the last parliament, a new approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to creating apprenticeship opportunities in

Speaker: NA
Text: our area, and a very successful program is

Speaker: NA
Text: now running. I reject completely the claims

Speaker: NA
Text: by government members that Labor have

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to promote the importance of voca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional training. In fact, we have had to drag

Speaker: NA
Text: this government kicking and screaming even

Speaker: NA
Text: to address the fact that there is a skills

Speaker: NA
Text: lem in this country. Throughout my cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign, I raised the concerns of local indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals and organisations, including my for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mer colleagues at TAFE, about the issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment and skills shortages,

Speaker: NA
Text: and today I reaffirm my commitment to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to advocate on these issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: I realistically expect to experience both

Speaker: NA
Text: frustration and satisfaction in working as the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal member for Cunningham-it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: combination of experiences that I am well

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar with-but I am also familiar with

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of perseverance in the pursuit

Speaker: NA
Text: of good outcomes for the people I sought to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent and who have now placed their

Speaker: NA
Text: trust in me.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have several other concerns that I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to fight for over the coming weeks, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to give notice of one in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: following also on some of the work done by

Speaker: NA
Text: my colleague the member for Throsby in

Speaker: NA
Text: pursuit of the allocation of a Medicare li-

Speaker: NA
Text: cence for the MRI machine based at Wollon-

Speaker: NA
Text: gong Hospital. It is well past time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government took their responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for this matter seriously and provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: licence, and that they gave public hospitals a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit of a priority in their allocations.

Speaker: NA
Text: A candidate in any election never wins

Speaker: NA
Text: through their own hard work alone. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: team effort, and many people have helped

Speaker: NA
Text: me over many years. I would like to take this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to place on the record my appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation for their efforts. I would like to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the many dedicated branch members and

Speaker: NA
Text: party supporters who letterboxed, attended

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraising events and staffed polling

Speaker: NA
Text: booths. They took a blow in 2002, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: rallied around their commitment to our party

Speaker: NA
Text: and their belief in a better Australia under a

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Labor government. Their support was

Speaker: NA
Text: invaluable, and I say to them today: one

Speaker: NA
Text: probmore rally around and we will be there.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to thank the volunteers

Speaker: NA
Text: who staffed my office-Craig, Paul, Liz,

Speaker: NA
Text: Berna, Rhys, Michael, Wilf, Stan, Joan, Reg

Speaker: NA
Text: and Chris-and the branch campaign team of

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin, Bob, Evan, Ryan, Justin and Marc.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you also to my fellow elected repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives in the Illawarra: Senator Michael

Speaker: NA
Text: Forshaw; member for Throsby, Jennie

Speaker: NA
Text: George; my state colleagues; and the many

Speaker: NA
Text: local government colleagues who gave me

Speaker: NA
Text: invaluable support during the campaign. I

Speaker: NA
Text: also received tremendous support from

Speaker: NA
Text: EMILY's List, and I would like to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: Karen Mow for the many small but crucial

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks she undertook to help me-particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: remembering to take photos on election

Speaker: NA
Text: night.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am deeply appreciative of the support of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members and officials of the union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement in the Illawarra and the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast Labour Council, in particular Richard

Speaker: NA
Text: Olsen and the TWU members, Mark Arm-

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and the MUA members, Mick Lane

Speaker: NA
Text: and members of the CFMEU building divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion and Bob Mitchell and members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU mining division.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one group of people spread

Speaker: NA
Text: across New South Wales who could not help

Speaker: NA
Text: directly that I wish to acknowledge. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: seven years prior to my election I was enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously privileged to work with a team in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Justice Conferencing Directorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales Department of Juve-

Speaker: NA
Text: nile Justice. This group of people, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: inspiring and supportive leadership of the

Speaker: NA
Text: director, Jenny Bargen, demonstrated every

Speaker: NA
Text: day the true meaning of public service. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were privileged to work with a truly innova-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive and successful piece of legislation introyounger

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by the Carr government, which estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished restorative justice practices for juve-

Speaker: NA
Text: nile offenders-a true success story. The

Speaker: NA
Text: team I worked with truly believed in their

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose and seriously applied themselves to

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering a high-quality program. I really

Speaker: NA
Text: valued working with them and I appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: their efforts in supporting me.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the Leader of the Opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow ministers who visited the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate: thank you for your support, advice

Speaker: NA
Text: and encouragement. Thank you also to the

Speaker: NA
Text: tireless Alison who helped organise so many

Speaker: NA
Text: of these visits.

Speaker: NA
Text: I bring to my new role a strength that has

Speaker: NA
Text: sustained me throughout my life-the won-

Speaker: NA
Text: derful support and unending faith of my fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily. I am proud of the values they have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stilled in me and the example they constantly

Speaker: NA
Text: provide to me. I thank my maternal grand-

Speaker: NA
Text: parents, Jimmy and Mavis Kerr, who taught

Speaker: NA
Text: me the value of strong beliefs and strong

Speaker: NA
Text: family, and my paternal grandmother, Annie

Speaker: NA
Text: Reed, who always had time to listen and

Speaker: NA
Text: made me feel I was special.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank my aunts, uncles and cousins, who

Speaker: NA
Text: always rally around to support me: my Aunt

Speaker: NA
Text: Cath, whom we sorely miss, and Uncle

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin; Jim and Vanessa; Lorraine and John;

Speaker: NA
Text: Arthur and Lynn; Bob and Jane; Norm-also

Speaker: NA
Text: missed-and Jan; and Jack and Jeanette. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have 17 cousins, whom I will not name, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: very much value their numbers as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: their support and friendship.

Speaker: NA
Text: To my former husband, Barry, and his

Speaker: NA
Text: family, Merv and Ruby, Russ and Cheryl,

Speaker: NA
Text: Barb and Tom, I say thank you for the years

Speaker: NA
Text: of support and encouragement that you gave

Speaker: NA
Text: me in so many ways. My great appreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: and thanks go to Gino for his faith in me and

Speaker: NA
Text: his invaluable encouragement and support.

Speaker: NA
Text: I often jokingly comment that one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons I am a survivor is that I have four

Speaker: NA
Text: brothers. The truth is they enrich me

Speaker: NA
Text: as a person each and every day. I thank Kev

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sharon and the kids; Rod and Dana and

Speaker: NA
Text: the girls; and Anthony and Maria and our

Speaker: NA
Text: newest little member Nicholas, who staffed

Speaker: NA
Text: his first polling booth and attended his first

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraiser at the age of three months. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: thank my other brother, Brett. You have all

Speaker: NA
Text: been through very difficult times with me on

Speaker: NA
Text: my journey here and your companionship

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a great strength to me. I am so

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased you can all be with me today.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hardly know where to find words for the

Speaker: NA
Text: next two people I want to thank. It seems

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible to begin to describe what they

Speaker: NA
Text: have done for me, but I know they know

Speaker: NA
Text: how much I value what I cannot even begin

Speaker: NA
Text: to put into words. To my mum and dad, Bev

Speaker: NA
Text: and Kev Reed, I simply say thank you and I

Speaker: NA
Text: will not let you down.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I wish to thank the two most im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant people in my life, my sons, Michael

Speaker: NA
Text: and Chris. I know that sometimes you

Speaker: NA
Text: probably thought Mum was a bit mad to per-

Speaker: NA
Text: severe with her dream, but I never doubted

Speaker: NA
Text: your love and support. You both make me

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud as I look at the wonderful young

Speaker: NA
Text: men you have grown into, and I am so glad

Speaker: NA
Text: to have you both here today.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (1.41 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointment as Speaker and your exhibition of

Speaker: NA
Text: generosity in the last few minutes. The ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress-in-reply debate gives us an opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at the past three years and the chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges of the future, of the next three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a pivotal point where the government

Speaker: NA
Text: sets out its plans for the coming period,

Speaker: NA
Text: based on the result of the election. A critical

Speaker: NA
Text: factor of the past three years has surely been

Speaker: NA
Text: the growth of Australia. Growth is needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply employment, and a growth of three to

Speaker: NA
Text: four per cent is critical for there to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in jobs. The current government has

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved that growth. There has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in jobs, and there has been an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the capacity of business and fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most important factor in achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: growth is to establish confidence. Confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence in business and families is the key

Speaker: NA
Text: tor in a successful economy and a successful

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. There has been confidence in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. Confidence has been built up over a pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod of time. One of the most significant fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors in achieving that confidence has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to pay off the debt that we were left

Speaker: NA
Text: with by the previous Labor government. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was a confidence-building factor for most

Speaker: NA
Text: people. They knew we were in debt and they

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted a process whereby we could restore a

Speaker: NA
Text: proper balance. There was $9 or $10 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: going out every year just to cover the debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: was a huge drain on Australian taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: They understood that a plan to deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: debt was significant. A plan to reduce taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, to give people more of their own

Speaker: NA
Text: money, was a significant confidence builder

Speaker: NA
Text: as well. We had a plan to be competitive, to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to establish our place in the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: trade with the best and to hold our own. The

Speaker: NA
Text: community has seen that and has welcomed

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to expand into world markets

Speaker: NA
Text: and to expand into local markets and replace

Speaker: NA
Text: imports.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reward for effort is a significant part of

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence building and, therefore, a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant part of growth and a successful econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy. An increase in productivity has been

Speaker: NA
Text: brought about by people being more content

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workplace. There have been fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: strikes, fewer stoppages, real increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: reward, better returns for effort, better re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turns for families and better outcomes for a

Speaker: NA
Text: week's work. These have also been part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence-building process that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced and which indeed has been part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reason for the growth in the econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy-more jobs, falling unemployment, real

Speaker: NA
Text: wage increases, a low cost-of-living increase

Speaker: NA
Text: and low interest rates. All these factors to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether have produced a boost in confidence,

Speaker: NA
Text: a capacity for growth, increased wealth, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased income and increased prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now is an opportunity for us to assess some

Speaker: NA
Text: fac- of the problems that have been overcome:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian economic crisis, world terrorism

Speaker: NA
Text: and the declining rainfall that has affected so

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australian industries.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Causley)-Order! It being 1.45 p.m., the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is interrupted in accordance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion agreed to on 18 November 2004. The

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is adjourned and the resumption of

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate will be made an order of the day

Speaker: NA
Text: for a later hour of the day. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mitchell will have leave to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: It tinue his remarks when the debate is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Lehner, Mr Mal

Speaker: Ms CORCORAN
Text: Isaacs) (1.45 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: So often local people who put so much into

Speaker: NA
Text: to their community do not receive recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: unless they are in the media spotlight. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, once in a while somebody truly dedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated and excellent is recognised and given

Speaker: NA
Text: the kudos they deserve. Earlier this year I

Speaker: NA
Text: had the pleasure of recognising the achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of one such person-Mal Lehner. Mal

Speaker: NA
Text: has put years of work and commitment into

Speaker: NA
Text: his local football club, the Seaford Junior

Speaker: NA
Text: Football Club.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Father's Day this year, I was invited

Speaker: NA
Text: by the club to their annual presentation day

Speaker: NA
Text: to award Mal with his Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Sports Award. Mal was nominated for the

Speaker: NA
Text: award by his colleagues, who were im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed by Mal's dedication to the club and

Speaker: NA
Text: his work with the junior players. His work

Speaker: NA
Text: has fostered talent and given confidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: those who needed a little extra help. Not only

Speaker: NA
Text: did Mal play as a junior for the club for five

Speaker: NA
Text: years; he then returned as a trainer. His

Speaker: NA
Text: nephew was there playing for the club, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuing the family tradition.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1996 Mal began coaching the team he

Speaker: NA
Text: once played in as a youngster. He stepped

Speaker: NA
Text: aside in 2003 because the club could only

Speaker: NA
Text: field one team, but he has returned this year

Speaker: NA
Text: to coach the under-nines-the most inexperi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced players in the club. Mal has a very

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging coaching style. It is based on

Speaker: NA
Text: giving positive feedback and facilitating an

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusive atmosphere amongst the players.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year Mal was rewarded with a life

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of the Seaford Junior Football

Speaker: NA
Text: Club in recognition of his 16 years service in

Speaker: NA
Text: different capacities in the club. (Time ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Welfare: Disability Services

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Text: Makin) (1.46 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I congratulate you on your election

Speaker: NA
Text: to such high office. I rise to speak today in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the aims of a group of parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: community leaders who have formed Dignity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Disabled to lobby the government of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia for more support for intellec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually disabled people. For too long, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rann Labor government has ignored the

Speaker: NA
Text: plight of the disabled and their families. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is why these community based groups have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken the unprecedented step of organising a

Speaker: NA
Text: very public campaign to demand that their

Speaker: NA
Text: needs be heard on North Terrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Group leader David Holst and other par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents have raised in the vicinity of $100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for their campaign, which demonstrates the

Speaker: NA
Text: seriousness and urgency of the situation, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly for the Moving On program. The

Speaker: NA
Text: program was designed as a day-stay program

Speaker: NA
Text: which provides social interaction and self-

Speaker: NA
Text: development for school leavers. It used to be

Speaker: NA
Text: five days a week, but this had been cut back

Speaker: NA
Text: to three and even fewer due to underfunding

Speaker: NA
Text: by the state government. While Minister Jay

Speaker: NA
Text: Weatherill has made an announcement,

Speaker: NA
Text: probably only because of adverse publicity,

Speaker: NA
Text: to now fund it five days a week, this per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance is not good enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most people would find it difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine how stressful daily life is for the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents of children who require around-the-

Speaker: NA
Text: clock care, and, to make it even harder, these

Speaker: NA
Text: are not small children but grown adults. The

Speaker: NA
Text: level of stress is magnified by the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: this supervision is needed seven days a week

Speaker: NA
Text: for anything up to 30 or 40 years. According

Speaker: NA
Text: to David Holst, there are 330 people on the

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting list for urgent intellectual disability

Speaker: NA
Text: services council residential care. Premier

Speaker: NA
Text: Rann and his government must take immedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate action to remedy this situation. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Cox, Captain Rodney

Speaker: Ms BURKE
Text: Chisholm) (1.48 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, congratulations on your elevation to

Speaker: NA
Text: this role. I rise today to say congratulations

Speaker: NA
Text: also to the Victorian nominee for the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian of the Year-Captain Rodney Cox, who

Speaker: NA
Text: is an extraordinary human being. In his 28

Speaker: NA
Text: years of life, he has managed to put in an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous amount. Sadly, Rodney is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer a constituent of mine-since the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent redistribution of electorates-but I got

Speaker: NA
Text: to know Rodney very well when he was the

Speaker: NA
Text: resident captain of the reservist Army bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: racks in Huntingdale. Rodney then went to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve in Timor with INTERFET, and he was

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately involved in the Bali bombing.

Speaker: NA
Text: For this event Rodney has been recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Army.

Speaker: NA
Text: He then decided that he needed a quieter

Speaker: NA
Text: life. He managed to do six weeks of his arti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cles and then took a posting with the UN,

Speaker: NA
Text: where, yes, you guessed it, he was blown up

Speaker: NA
Text: in Iraq. He has been nominated for a bravery

Speaker: NA
Text: award, and I hope he is recognised for that

Speaker: NA
Text: service. Rodney has left Iraq, but he is now

Speaker: NA
Text: serving in Kabul in Afghanistan, in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: of security. It is a very risky pursuit, but he is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it with absolute fervour and his normal

Speaker: NA
Text: dedication. Rodney is an exceptional person.

Speaker: NA
Text: I fervently hope that he will be made the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian of the Year, because he sums up

Speaker: NA
Text: what we need to hold near and dear in our

Speaker: NA
Text: lives at the moment-mateship, commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to your country. I congratulate him on his

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian nomination and hope that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: get to congratulate him on Australia Day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryan Electorate: Recognition Awards

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Text: Ryan) (1.50 p.m.)-Last

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday, 26 November, I had the wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity of hosting the 2004 Ryan Rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognition Awards. It is the third occasion that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had the opportunity of doing this. We

Speaker: NA
Text: held it at Nudgee Junior College in In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dooroopilly, in the Ryan electorate. We had

Speaker: NA
Text: an enormous number of residents from the

Speaker: NA
Text: community-in excess of 350-come along.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a wonderful gathering of young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, businesspeople, community leaders and

Speaker: NA
Text: those many residents of Ryan who have

Speaker: NA
Text: made service to the community their No. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I first initiated these awards, we had

Speaker: NA
Text: only some 25 to 30 recipients. On this occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion the recipients are too many to name and

Speaker: NA
Text: too many to be able to speak of all their con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributions to the Ryan community. But I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay tribute in the parliament today to

Speaker: NA
Text: those people who, from across the spectrum

Speaker: NA
Text: of business, schools and community organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations such as Rotary and Lions, have really

Speaker: NA
Text: led the way, showing how Australians give

Speaker: NA
Text: their time very generously to their fellow

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. I want to mention very quickly

Speaker: NA
Text: the three categories that we had. We had the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryan youth recognition awards, the Ryan

Speaker: NA
Text: Recognition Awards and a special category

Speaker: NA
Text: for young people from school who will

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly show the way in the future. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Election: Visually Impaired and

Speaker: NA
Text: Blind Voters

Speaker: NA
Text: Amongst the questions I placed on the first

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice Paper of this parliament is question

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 40, addressed on 17 November 2004 to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister representing the Special Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of State. My question asks what the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister is doing to ensure that visually impaired

Speaker: NA
Text: and blind people are able to independently

Speaker: NA
Text: cast a vote at the next federal election.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Royal Blind Society of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and the Association of Blind Citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: of New South Wales are located in Enfield

Speaker: NA
Text: and Burwood respectively. I am very proud

Speaker: NA
Text: to report to the House that these wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions that do so much to help the visu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally impaired are both situated in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate of Lowe. In this modern and very techno-

Speaker: NA
Text: logical age, there is no reason why people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are visually impaired cannot be afforded

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to cast a vote in secret. This is their

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic right. Accordingly, I call on the

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the Joint Standing Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee on Electoral Matters to immediately in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestigate this matter and provide the tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology and a system that will allow visually

Speaker: NA
Text: impaired people to vote independently at the

Speaker: NA
Text: next federal election, which is expected in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007. I urge all members of this House to

Speaker: NA
Text: support this initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Macquarie Electorate: Rural Fire Service

Speaker: NA
Text: and State Emergency Service

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Text: Macquarie) (1.53

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-Last Saturday I attended a presenta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ceremony for members of the local bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gades of the Rural Fire Service, to present

Speaker: NA
Text: the national medal and long service awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was the third such ceremony in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: two months. Also in that time I attended a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar ceremony for the State Emergency

Speaker: NA
Text: Service members in the Blue Mountains. All

Speaker: NA
Text: these ceremonies recognised the outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts of close to 100 men and women in the

Speaker: NA
Text: local brigades and SES. These awards range

Speaker: NA
Text: from 15 years to 50 years of service to the

Speaker: NA
Text: local community-voluntary service total-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling many hundreds of years, with hundreds

Speaker: NA
Text: of hours for each of those years; service at

Speaker: NA
Text: great personal cost and cost to their own

Speaker: NA
Text: families; and service on the front line, which,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the face of blazing infernos and other dan-

Speaker: NA
Text: gers, involves serious risks to their own

Speaker: NA
Text: lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most communities have their army of

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency service and firefighting volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: teers, yet the nature of the Blue Mountains

Speaker: NA
Text: makes us particularly prone to the fury of

Speaker: NA
Text: nature. The incredible efforts of the men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women of organisations such as the RFS and

Speaker: NA
Text: the SES, not to mention others such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: ambulance service and the Red Cross, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide much-needed and greatly appreciated

Speaker: NA
Text: protection for our local community. We

Speaker: NA
Text: thank them for their outstanding effort and

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate them for these thoroughly de-

Speaker: NA
Text: served awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Artists: Remuneration

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney) (1.54 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I rise today because I have been presented

Speaker: NA
Text: with a petition from 1,622 local artists call-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for the fair treatment of artists. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that the contribution of artists is often

Speaker: NA
Text: overlooked in the Australian community. As

Speaker: NA
Text: for so many people who undertake work that

Speaker: NA
Text: they truly love, often the remuneration is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply not there; they are expected to work

Speaker: NA
Text: for love. These 1,622 artists ask that-

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of being expected to fulfil the cliche

Speaker: NA
Text: of the starving artist-consistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the Myer report, they

Speaker: NA
Text: are properly remunerated for some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: work they do.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the coalition government was first

Speaker: NA
Text: elected in 1996, a mandatory fee that was

Speaker: NA
Text: usually paid to artists who were exhibiting in

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly funded galleries was withdrawn.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has made an enormous difference to the

Speaker: NA
Text: income of the average artist. The artists who

Speaker: NA
Text: signed the petition want to see that fee rein-

Speaker: NA
Text: stated, consistent with the recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Myer report. It is worth remembering

Speaker: NA
Text: that the median income for artists in 2000-01

Speaker: NA
Text: was about $18,500. That of course includes

Speaker: NA
Text: some-very few-very highly paid artists.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is just above the poverty line. We need

Speaker: NA
Text: to work together to ensure that artists no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer fulfil the cliche of the starving artist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Corangamite Electorate: Otway National

Speaker: NA
Text: Park

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Text: Corangamite) (1.55

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-In the Otways, in the heartland of

Speaker: NA
Text: Corangamite, the Victorian government is set

Speaker: NA
Text: to create a 100,000-hectare national park.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Environment, John

Speaker: NA
Text: Thwaites, announced this yesterday. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a nine times increase. I put on the public

Speaker: NA
Text: record concern about what resources will be

Speaker: NA
Text: devoted to this national park. Will the roads

Speaker: NA
Text: that were provided by the timber industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous 40 years be maintained? Will

Speaker: NA
Text: the national park be able to fight another Ash

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday? Will the resources of the Victo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rian government be allocated to maintain the

Speaker: NA
Text: park, to make sure that weeds such as black-

Speaker: NA
Text: fair berries do not get out of control, that feral

Speaker: NA
Text: animals are kept under control and that ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess will be available for the residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: Corangamite? And will the state government

Speaker: NA
Text: be accountable in the way in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the park and put on the public re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cord the value that the park now has and the

Speaker: NA
Text: value the park might have in another 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years? This is a very critical issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bracks government threw out the

Speaker: NA
Text: RFA in the Otways and are to remove log-

Speaker: NA
Text: ging by the year 2008, and they have now

Speaker: NA
Text: created this massive national park. But they

Speaker: NA
Text: have given no undertaking or guarantee that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will maintain the Otway National Park

Speaker: NA
Text: in its present state and that they

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, and they have given no guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: of the amount of money they will put in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. Also, will the fuel reduction burning

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be undertaken to maintain the

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity in that park be undertaken on an

Speaker: NA
Text: annual basis to ensure that the quality of the

Speaker: NA
Text: park remains? (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra Electorate: Burns Club Pipe

Speaker: Ms ANNETTE ELLIS
Text: Canberra) (1.57

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-My congratulations to you, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, on your election to your office. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate I have a Burns Club-in fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the largest in the world. They very

Speaker: NA
Text: proudly sponsor a Burns Club Pipe Band. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is my pleasure to tell this House that, over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last two years, the members of that band

Speaker: NA
Text: did some fairly serious fundraising and man-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged to get enough money together to send a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of nearly 200 people to Scotland a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of months ago for the world champi-

Speaker: NA
Text: onship pipe band competition. They sent a

Speaker: NA
Text: second grade and fourth grade band across.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second grade band, amongst other

Speaker: NA
Text: things, won a fourth place. The fourth grade

Speaker: NA
Text: band won a first place. They had an ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely successful tour of Scotland, around

Speaker: NA
Text: Glasgow, Perth and Crieff, just north of

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth, and came back not only having

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved a great deal of success but also hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing represented my community extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the thing that makes it even

Speaker: NA
Text: better for me is that this band, under Pipe

Speaker: NA
Text: Major Athol Chalmers, actually runs a col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege to ensure that young pipers and young

Speaker: NA
Text: drummers are encouraged to take up their

Speaker: NA
Text: musical talent with pipe band music. With

Speaker: NA
Text: that group of 200 were included several very

Speaker: NA
Text: young students who are now budding pipers

Speaker: NA
Text: and drummers of the future. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: endorse to the House the very great success

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Burns Club Pipe Band at that competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: will do so in tion. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Tofa Mamao a Samoa Park

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Text: Oxley) (1.59 p.m.)-On

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday, 30 October, I had the pleasure of

Speaker: NA
Text: attending the official opening of a commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity park in the Ipswich suburb of Redbank.

Speaker: NA
Text: This park, the Tofa Mamao a Samoa Park, is

Speaker: NA
Text: not your average garden variety council park.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is dedicated to the local Samoan commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: Band nity, although I might add it is certainly able

Speaker: NA
Text: to be enjoyed by all members of the local

Speaker: NA
Text: community and belongs to all the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ipswich. ‘Tofa mamao' translates roughly

Speaker: NA
Text: into ‘thinking future', which is an apt de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription of what those who were involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of this park were doing-

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking about the future and creating a place

Speaker: NA
Text: where their local people will be able to enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: many hours of play, community and togeth-

Speaker: NA
Text: erness.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the best of my knowledge, this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: first council park in Australia to be named in

Speaker: NA
Text: honour of a local Samoan community. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Oxley and in and around Ips-

Speaker: NA
Text: wich and the south-western Brisbane area the

Speaker: NA
Text: Samoan community has nearly 3,000 mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers. Over the years, this park has become

Speaker: NA
Text: something of a focal point for the local

Speaker: NA
Text: community and it has attracted up to 10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people to specific events. I want to congratu-

Speaker: NA
Text: late the Samoan community for the great

Speaker: NA
Text: work they have done and for having this park

Speaker: NA
Text: named after them.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 2 p.m.,

Speaker: NA
Text: the time for members' statements has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: CONDOLENCES

Speaker: NA
Text: Haines, Ms Janine, AM

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: 2.00 p.m.)-I inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of the death on Saturday, 20 Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber 2004 of Janine Haines AM, a former

Speaker: NA
Text: senator. Janine Haines represented the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of South Australia from 1977 to 1978 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1981 to 1990, and was a former Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Democrats.

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: Gwydir-Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister) (2.00 p.m.)-On indulgence,

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to say a few words about the

Speaker: NA
Text: passing on 20 November of Janine Haines, a

Speaker: NA
Text: former leader of the Australian Democrats.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janine Haines was born on 8 May 1945 in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia to Francis Carter, a police-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, and his wife, Beryl, a schoolteacher.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was educated at Brighton High School

Speaker: NA
Text: and Adelaide University, where she received

Speaker: NA
Text: a Bachelor of Arts, and the Adelaide Teach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers College, where she received a diploma of

Speaker: NA
Text: teaching. She went on to become a teacher of

Speaker: NA
Text: English and maths in high schools before

Speaker: NA
Text: entering politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1975, Janine Haines stood for the Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate on the Liberal Movement Party ticket.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was not elected at that time, but was

Speaker: NA
Text: later chosen by the then Premier of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Don Dunstan, to fill a casual va-

Speaker: NA
Text: cancy in the Senate following the retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: of Steele Hall in 1977. Janine Haines became

Speaker: NA
Text: the first senator and also the first female

Speaker: NA
Text: senator for the Australian Democrats. Her

Speaker: NA
Text: first term as a senator expired on 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978. She was elected to the Senate again in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980, taking up the position on 1 July 1981.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was re-elected in 1983 and 1987. She

Speaker: NA
Text: was appointed leader of the Australian De-

Speaker: NA
Text: mocrats in March 1986 on the retirement of

Speaker: NA
Text: Don Chipp, becoming the first woman to

Speaker: NA
Text: lead a political party in Australia. She held

Speaker: NA
Text: that position until March 1990, when she

Speaker: NA
Text: resigned from the Senate to contest the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives seat of Kingston

Speaker: NA
Text: and was defeated by the incumbent member,

Speaker: NA
Text: Gordon Bilney, from the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout her time in parliament Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Haines was always an advocate for gender

Speaker: NA
Text: equity and women's issues, but she also

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained a strong interest in a wide range

Speaker: NA
Text: of issues affecting the Australian community.

Speaker: NA
Text: In her first speech to the parliament she said

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was not her intention to restrict herself

Speaker: NA
Text: to so-called women's issues or to put only

Speaker: NA
Text: the women's point of view but that she in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended to concern herself with as many is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues as possible affecting the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and in particular her home state of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. She was the Australian De-

Speaker: NA
Text: mocrats' spokeswoman for what she called

Speaker: NA
Text: the social justice portfolios-health, social

Speaker: NA
Text: security, housing and construction, commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity services and women's affairs-as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as finance, Attorney-General's, Special Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister of State and Prime Minister and Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: During her time as a senator and party

Speaker: NA
Text: leader she was a key figure in the Senate's

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of quite a wide range of legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. Among her political achievements she

Speaker: NA
Text: listed changes to the sex discrimination leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation, the negotiation of changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke government's Medicare system, her

Speaker: NA
Text: determined public opposition to the Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: card and her stewardship of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats through one of their most suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful periods.

Speaker: NA
Text: During her time as a senator Mrs Haines

Speaker: NA
Text: was a member of a number of Senate com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees, including the Senate Select Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes,

Speaker: NA
Text: the creation of which she strongly supported.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was also a member of the Senate Stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Committee on Social Welfare, the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on the National Crime Authority,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Joint Select Committee on an Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia Card. She travelled overseas to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian parliament with parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: delegations to Italy, Spain, Greece, Cyprus

Speaker: NA
Text: and New Zealand.

Speaker: NA
Text: After she left politics she remained very

Speaker: NA
Text: active. She wrote a book, Suffrage to Suffer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance: 100 Years of Women in Politics. She

Speaker: NA
Text: served on the council of Adelaide University.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was the President of the Australian Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vacy Charter Council. She travelled the

Speaker: NA
Text: country speaking on a range of issues and

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in radio, newspaper and consultancy

Speaker: NA
Text: work. In the 2001 Queen's Birthday Honours

Speaker: NA
Text: List Janine Haines was appointed as a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of the Order of Australia for service to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian parliament and to politics,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly as parliamentary leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats, and to the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the government and, I am sure,

Speaker: NA
Text: all who knew her in this place, I extend to

Speaker: NA
Text: her husband, Ian, to her daughters, Bronwyn

Speaker: NA
Text: and Melanie, and to other family members

Speaker: NA
Text: and friends our very real and sincere sympa-

Speaker: NA
Text: thy on their loss.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: Werriwa-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (2.04 p.m.)-On indulgence, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party joins with the Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in expressing our condo-

Speaker: NA
Text: lences and sympathy on the passing of Janine

Speaker: NA
Text: Haines. She was well liked and respected

Speaker: NA
Text: around this building and, of course, well

Speaker: NA
Text: membered as leading the Australian Democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: rats when they were at their peak. She can

Speaker: NA
Text: take great credit for that achievement.

Speaker: NA
Text: She saw them as much more than a Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: party-she saw the true legitimacy of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian politics as resting in this place,

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives, and so at the 1990

Speaker: NA
Text: election she decided to give up her place in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate to contest the seat of Kingston in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place. She won more than 26 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the primary vote but failed to attract the

Speaker: NA
Text: preferences that were needed to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: That was a real landmark in the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Democrats and an achievement in its

Speaker: NA
Text: own right. For that party, it had the spin-off

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of lifting their profile. In fact, at that

Speaker: NA
Text: election, in the Senate they lifted their sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port to 12.6 per cent of the vote nationwide

Speaker: NA
Text: and so her party easily held the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: power in the other place. So while she was

Speaker: NA
Text: unsuccessful in trying to be the first Democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: rat elected to the House of Representatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: she gave them their high-water mark in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: She was a very effective politician. She

Speaker: NA
Text: was the first woman to lead an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: political party and in that role was an inspira-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to a huge number of Australians. She

Speaker: NA
Text: was a strong and committed leader of her

Speaker: NA
Text: party and saw its role as much more than an

Speaker: NA
Text: upper house political organisation. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990s, after that defeat, she continued to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an important contribution to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian community through her writing and

Speaker: NA
Text: her public speaking. In fact, she had just be-

Speaker: NA
Text: gun a new career as the Deputy Vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, her

Speaker: NA
Text: home town, when she was struck by illness.

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the Labor Party-and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure it is shared right around the House-I

Speaker: NA
Text: pass on my condolences to Janine's partner,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ian, to her daughters and to her grandchil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren. She was well respected in Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: re- House and well respected indeed in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian public life, and she will be greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: missed.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins-Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (2.06 p.m.)-On indulgence, on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party, I too wish to pass on our con-

Speaker: NA
Text: the dolences to the family of Janine Haines: to

Speaker: NA
Text: her husband, Ian, to her daughters, Bronwyn

Speaker: NA
Text: and Melanie, and to other family members,

Speaker: NA
Text: on what will be a very great loss for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janine Haines filled a casual Senate vacancy

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1977 at the age of 32. It was a very young

Speaker: NA
Text: seat. age to begin a parliamentary career. She

Speaker: NA
Text: came into the Senate to fill the vacancy

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by Steele Hall, who had been elected

Speaker: NA
Text: on the votes of the Liberal Movement Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Steele had been a premier of the Liberal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Country League in South Australia and had

Speaker: NA
Text: disagreed with the Liberal and Country

Speaker: NA
Text: League and formed the Liberal Movement

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. He had been elected to the Senate and,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he vacated the Senate seat, Janine

Speaker: NA
Text: Haines filled it. Steele was to bring the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Movement Party back into the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: and Country League and turn it into the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party of Australia in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janine went on to the other third party force

Speaker: NA
Text: which was then gathering in Australia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats-which had also been

Speaker: NA
Text: formed by a former senior member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party, Don Chipp.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janine Haines's view was that if the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: mocrats were to become the significant third

Speaker: NA
Text: party force in Australian politics they had to

Speaker: NA
Text: win lower house seats. She had the courage

Speaker: NA
Text: of her convictions to run for a lower house

Speaker: NA
Text: seat in 1990, when she did exceptionally

Speaker: NA
Text: well but did not win. The seat that she ran

Speaker: NA
Text: for, Kingston, has been very much a mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginal seat, slipping between the various po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical parties, ever since 1990. Janine

Speaker: NA
Text: Haines's position in the Senate was taken by

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Meg Lees, who in turn was also to

Speaker: NA
Text: go on to lead the Australian Democrats.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Haines began what has proven to

Speaker: NA
Text: be quite a tradition in the Australian Democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: rats. She was the first woman to lead a po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical party, and she did it with great panache

Speaker: NA
Text: and great aplomb. There is no doubt that in

Speaker: NA
Text: her day she was a very significant political

Speaker: NA
Text: player. She attracted a lot of adherence to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats, and she was a very

Speaker: NA
Text: forceful spokeswoman for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats. There is no doubt that she had a

Speaker: NA
Text: keen intellect, a very good political feel and

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal of charisma as she led that po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janine Haines went through some per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal difficulties. She came close to death in

Speaker: NA
Text: a car accident once, out at Whyalla, but she

Speaker: NA
Text: never let those difficulties deter her. She

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about a ravenous hunger for politics

Speaker: NA
Text: and said, ‘Once you've tried it, you get

Speaker: NA
Text: hooked.' That may well be the experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: many members in the House. It is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy for her and her family, to whom I

Speaker: NA
Text: pass on the condolences of the Liberal Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a loss to the people of South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and those people who supported her in third

Speaker: NA
Text: party politics during her career. On behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party, I pass on condolences to

Speaker: NA
Text: her friends and supporters.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (2.10 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: On indulgence, I am very pleased to join the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speakers to offer my condolences to

Speaker: NA
Text: Janine's family. Hers was an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: life cut far too short. Janine Haines became

Speaker: NA
Text: the first woman to lead a federal parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary party, in 1986. I have to say I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry that I did not know her. Those who did

Speaker: NA
Text: know her often described Janine Haines as

Speaker: NA
Text: having a very direct and no-nonsense style-

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the great characteristics that I think

Speaker: NA
Text: many people will remember her for. She cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly demonstrated that in some of her early

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches in the parliament where she called

Speaker: NA
Text: for urgent action to address the plight of In-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous Australians. She also called for

Speaker: NA
Text: greater recognition of and participation by

Speaker: NA
Text: women in public life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given her prior career as a teacher, she

Speaker: NA
Text: pursued with great passion the issue of ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to education. As she said herself, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right of children to the best education system

Speaker: NA
Text: possible was something that she pursued

Speaker: NA
Text: right throughout her parliamentary career.

Speaker: NA
Text: She called for the government of the day to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop providing placebos and start administer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing restorative medicine in the form of action

Speaker: NA
Text: not words, teachers not tape recorders and

Speaker: NA
Text: relationships not rock gardens. She had a

Speaker: NA
Text: great passion for education that of course

Speaker: NA
Text: came from her time as a teacher. In an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: usual combination for a teacher, she was a

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher of both maths and English. She stud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ied the Australian poet John Shaw Nielsen

Speaker: NA
Text: while she was teaching part time. She was a

Speaker: NA
Text: woman of extraordinary talents and interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: As others have said already today, there

Speaker: NA
Text: no question that she was a popular and very

Speaker: NA
Text: widely respected leader of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats. I think that, as others have said

Speaker: NA
Text: today, those years could be looked upon as

Speaker: NA
Text: the party's golden years, and that owes so

Speaker: NA
Text: much to her extraordinary leadership. To her

Speaker: NA
Text: husband of 37 years, Ian, her daughters,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melanie and Bronwyn, and their families, the

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren, we offer our sincere condo-

Speaker: NA
Text: lences.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: Mayo-Minister for For-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign Affairs) (2.12 p.m.)-On indulgence, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would very briefly like to support the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that have been made and say how very

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry I was to hear of Janine Haines's death.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think Janine Haines was the most substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial leader that the Australian Democrats

Speaker: NA
Text: had, and I really mean that. As others have

Speaker: NA
Text: said, she was a very articulate woman and a

Speaker: NA
Text: very intelligent woman. She was also a very

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable and honest woman. Whilst I did

Speaker: NA
Text: not agree with her on many issues, I really

Speaker: NA
Text: did admire her fortitude, her courage and her

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity. She was, as I said, the most sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial leader that the Australian Democrats

Speaker: NA
Text: have had. She was substantial not just in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of her high profile but in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: substance of the person.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had a little to do with her, as she came

Speaker: NA
Text: from my own state of South Australia. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular I think today is the day to confess

Speaker: NA
Text: that in 1990 we were very concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: her determination to win the seat of King-

Speaker: NA
Text: ston. Janine Haines was very popular at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time. The Democrats were riding very high

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1990, and she put a substantial effort into

Speaker: NA
Text: winning the seat of Kingston against the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor member for Kingston, Gordon Bilney.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have known Gordon Bilney for a fair pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod of time, including before he became a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament. We were both in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: together. But, curiously enough, I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: is want to see the Democrats win the seat from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party, because I believed that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats won Kingston then that would

Speaker: NA
Text: have given the Democrats a beachhead

Speaker: NA
Text: which they would have been able to build on,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in time the Democrats would have be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come a significant third force in Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: politics, rather akin to the British Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats.

Speaker: NA
Text: I recall working quite closely with Gordon

Speaker: NA
Text: Bilney to ensure that the Democrats did not

Speaker: NA
Text: win that seat-in other words, that Janine

Speaker: NA
Text: Haines did not win. I can only say that, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the diminishing support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats, Janine Haines's failure to win

Speaker: NA
Text: that seat was a very significant development.

Speaker: NA
Text: If she had won that seat, I think the Democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever rats would have made a beachhead into the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives. I think she would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been a very significant and forceful

Speaker: NA
Text: figure in the House of Representatives. For

Speaker: NA
Text: those of us who have had significant Democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: rat votes in our own electorates, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been a very major problem for us in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of holding our seats. I have to confess

Speaker: NA
Text: some self-interest in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I think she was the most

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial and the most significant leader

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Democrats have had. She was

Speaker: NA
Text: a very good woman, a very honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: woman. I extend my condolences to her hus-

Speaker: NA
Text: band, Ian, and to her children, Bronwyn and

Speaker: NA
Text: Melanie.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: As a mark of respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: the memory of Janine Haines, I invite all

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members to rise in their places.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members having stood in

Speaker: NA
Text: their places-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I thank the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: Gwydir-Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister) (2.16 p.m.)-I inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that the Prime Minister will be absent

Speaker: NA
Text: from question time today, tomorrow and

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday. He is, as members know, travel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling to Laos to attend the ASEAN summit. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will answer questions on the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's behalf today and tomorrow. The Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer will answer questions on his behalf on

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday. I inform the House that the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Veterans' Affairs will be absent from

Speaker: NA
Text: question time today for family reasons. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs will answer

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on her behalf. I also inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that I will be absent from question

Speaker: NA
Text: time on Wednesday to attend to personal

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments. The Treasurer will answer

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on my behalf on Wednesday.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: 2.17 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Acting Prime Minister and Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Transport and Regional Services. Can the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister confirm that the guidelines for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Partnerships program require that

Speaker: NA
Text: formal applications must be made for the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding, that applications can be made on an

Speaker: NA
Text: application form obtained from the local

Speaker: NA
Text: ACC or from the Commonwealth Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Information Service and that all application

Speaker: NA
Text: forms are to be lodged with the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: department? Were these guidelines followed

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to all of the Regional Partnerships

Speaker: NA
Text: projects for which funding has been an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for his question. Broadly

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking, he has outlined the processes that

Speaker: NA
Text: apply when community groups want to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: for Regional Partnerships funding. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: I would make the point that this government,

Speaker: NA
Text: just like all political parties, does choose

Speaker: NA
Text: from time to time to make election commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which are not necessarily-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: You do; you did. You

Speaker: NA
Text: made a lot of them, and they were subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: no guidelines. Even Independents make

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments during an election campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, there is nothing unusual or im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proper about that. You made commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election campaign and so did we.

Speaker: NA
Text: For reasons of convenience and probity,

Speaker: NA
Text: many of those will be channelled through the

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise of the Regional Partnerships pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram section maintained in my department.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I make the point again. You

Speaker: NA
Text: made election commitments and every po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical party, I suspect, for decades has done

Speaker: NA
Text: so. There is nothing wrong or improper about

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Could I remind all

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members that I would like re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks to be directed through the chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy: Current Account Deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: My question without notice is to the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer. Would the Treasurer inform the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of today's balance of payments data? What

Speaker: NA
Text: are the economic implications arising from

Speaker: NA
Text: these data?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mackellar for her question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, the Australian Bureau of Statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: released the balance of payments for the Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember quarter of 2004. The current account

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit widened by $1.9 billion in the Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember quarter to $13.7 billion-around 6½

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of GDP. While import volumes only

Speaker: NA
Text: rose by 0.8 per cent, they are up 13½ per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent over the year. For the quarter, export

Speaker: NA
Text: volumes fell 3.2 per cent, but remain 4.7 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent higher over the year. In particular, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports of rural goods fell 3.9 per cent, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was driven by lower exports of wool and

Speaker: NA
Text: sheepskins. In addition to that, non-rural

Speaker: NA
Text: goods fell four per cent for the quarter. As

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia emerged from drought, we had a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good wheat crop in the earlier part of

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004. Indications for 2004-05 are that the

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat crop will be lower than it was for

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004, which means we are coming off a

Speaker: NA
Text: higher base in relation to rural commodities.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things that is undoubtedly

Speaker: NA
Text: lenging Australia's exports at the moment is

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of the Australian dollar, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently about 10c higher than its post-float

Speaker: NA
Text: average over the last 20 years in US dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: terms. This was the subject of discussion at

Speaker: NA
Text: the G20 meeting of finance ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: central bankers in Berlin last weekend. The

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, with its own current account

Speaker: NA
Text: problems, has the US dollar falling against

Speaker: NA
Text: most currencies in the world, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: euro and the yen. While that will be advanta-

Speaker: NA
Text: geous for the United States, those other cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rencies which are appreciating against a fal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling US dollar will, as a consequence, find

Speaker: NA
Text: that their export competitiveness has been

Speaker: NA
Text: affected and that will make things harder for

Speaker: NA
Text: their exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge that the level of the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rency has made things harder for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters. In part, this is because of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: modity prices but, largely, it is because

Speaker: NA
Text: falling US dollar which, as I said, is falling

Speaker: NA
Text: against the major currencies of the world. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly be helpful if that adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the US dollar were shared by a wider

Speaker: NA
Text: range of currencies than is currently the case

Speaker: NA
Text: at the moment. We expect that it will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: challenging year for exporters. As a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence, net exports will detract from the

Speaker: NA
Text: tional accounts, which are going to be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: leased on Wednesday of this week. It is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant that we make all efforts to keep our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy competitive so that Australia's ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports can cope with those difficult trading

Speaker: NA
Text: positions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: 2.22 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Acting Prime Minister and Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Transport and Regional Services. I refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the minister's funding announcement-not

Speaker: NA
Text: an election commitment but a funding an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement-on 24 September that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: chalernment had committed $4 million to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: the R.M. Williams bush centre in Eidsvold,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the seat of Hinkler. Can the minister con-

Speaker: NA
Text: firm the statement by the Chief Executive

Speaker: NA
Text: Officer of the Eidsvold Shire Council on 24

Speaker: NA
Text: November that funding had been approved

Speaker: NA
Text: even though ‘we haven't put an application

Speaker: NA
Text: in yet'? Why did the minister fund a project

Speaker: NA
Text: for which an application had not even been

Speaker: NA
Text: lodged?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: This particular pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, as the two members who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in it will know, had an extraordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nary, long history. It had been subjected to

Speaker: NA
Text: quite rigorous examination over a long pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod of time. It is a very good program. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would be interested to know whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition is going to go up

Speaker: NA
Text: there and tell people that it is not a good pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram and that it should not go ahead. The

Speaker: NA
Text: mayor has written, making it quite evident

Speaker: NA
Text: of a that he regarded an application as having

Speaker: NA
Text: been made. There is an enormous amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: information available on it. I am happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: table all of that information.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact remains that it is a quality pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram that the government, as part of its elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign, determined it would support,

Speaker: NA
Text: just as the Leader of the Opposition and his

Speaker: NA
Text: na- senior frontbench people wandered around

Speaker: NA
Text: the country giving clear indications of a very

Speaker: NA
Text: wide-ranging number of programs that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would support should the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: have chosen them for government. Just a few

Speaker: NA
Text: days ago the Leader of the Opposition said

Speaker: NA
Text: that one of the things he was going to do as

Speaker: NA
Text: soon as he got back here was to hold us to all

Speaker: NA
Text: of our election promises, so that we would

Speaker: NA
Text: commit ourselves to doing everything that

Speaker: NA
Text: we said we would do during the campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: We intend doing precisely that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is nothing illegitimate at all about

Speaker: NA
Text: us putting before the people an entire range

Speaker: NA
Text: of policy positions, from economic manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-where you did not do very much-

Speaker: NA
Text: social policy and a whole range of issues on

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign affairs right through to the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: how you might respond to good ideas that

Speaker: NA
Text: are thrown up by local communities. You

Speaker: NA
Text: found plenty of them, I would have to say. I

Speaker: NA
Text: could read out the list if you would like. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to know what sort of due process

Speaker: NA
Text: you thought they should go through, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the offer of $150 million to the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales government to fix the Murwil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lumbah-Casino railway line-a state gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment responsibility; they closed it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: only independent assessment of what that

Speaker: NA
Text: might cost to fix was done by Pricewater-

Speaker: NA
Text: houseCoopers. The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: offered his mate Mr Carr $150 million to do

Speaker: NA
Text: it. PricewaterhouseCoopers estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: $25 million was required and you were going

Speaker: NA
Text: to give Mr Carr $150 million. Where was the

Speaker: NA
Text: due diligence in that? A bit of a profit for

Speaker: NA
Text: your mate Bob Carr in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: presumably to fix up the transport mess he

Speaker: NA
Text: has in the Sydney basin. I reckon the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitments we made will stack up to a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: more scrutiny than those that you made, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have every intention of honouring the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments we made during the campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Latham- Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. The Acting Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said he was happy to table all the documen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation about the funding application for the

Speaker: NA
Text: R.M. Williams centre, so I ask him to do that

Speaker: NA
Text: for the benefit of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson-I am happy to make that

Speaker: NA
Text: available. I will pull it together and make

Speaker: NA
Text: available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport: AusLink

Speaker: NA
Text: question is addressed to the Acting Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. Would the Acting Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the House on the progress towards

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing the AusLink transport policy?

Speaker: NA
Text: What are the benefits of this policy?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: AusLink will revolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionise the way that this country faces its

Speaker: NA
Text: of transport task, which is growing very rapidly.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will provide Australia with a long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for our vital infrastructure in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: transport needs. I have to say that without a

Speaker: NA
Text: better way of doing it in the future we will

Speaker: NA
Text: sell Australians short. Under this program we

Speaker: NA
Text: have allocated some $12.5 billion over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next five years. In today's money that is

Speaker: NA
Text: more than twice what was spent on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy Mountains Scheme. As part of that

Speaker: NA
Text: process we will see in this country for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time an open, transparent transport fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing framework freed up of ad hoc and short-

Speaker: NA
Text: term decision making processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that a rapidly growing econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy is resulting in a very steep rise in the

Speaker: NA
Text: escalation of our transport task. At the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is building, in the future our roads will

Speaker: NA
Text: not cope with the level of freight that is be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing put on them, so it is essential that our rail

Speaker: NA
Text: network is brought up to scratch. The leasing

Speaker: NA
Text: of the interstate track in New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: for a period of 60 years, the commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend some $1.8 billion on it over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: five years and, in cooperation with the states

Speaker: NA
Text: to streamline and facilitate the access ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements, the safety arrangements and the

Speaker: NA
