Text: signalling arrangements across this creaking

Speaker: NA
Text: network will see a dramatic improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I make the point that we desperately

Speaker: NA
Text: need a nationally coordinated approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: our transport planning needs. We need ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: it quate resources. For reasons of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth, amenity, convenience and better en-

Speaker: NA
Text: vironmental outcomes, we need to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is done properly in the future. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the community wants to see a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasis on transport infrastructure and on

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure more generally, and I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the absence of a coherent trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port plan from the opposition during the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent campaign would hardly have helped

Speaker: NA
Text: them electorally. It is about time they came

Speaker: NA
Text: forward with a decent, coherent explanation

Speaker: NA
Text: as to how they will develop our transport

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure for the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: 2.29 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is again to the Acting Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Transport and Regional Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices. Can the minister inform the House

Speaker: NA
Text: which projects under the Regional Partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships program have been funded without

Speaker: NA
Text: applications being lodged in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: the guidelines?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able Leader of the Opposition for his ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The answer is: to this point in time,

Speaker: NA
Text: none. We have given election commitments;

Speaker: NA
Text: we will work those through in the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: way. Contrary to the impression being cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by some in the opposition-including

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator O'Brien with his 45 questions on

Speaker: NA
Text: notice-the answer is: to this point in time,

Speaker: NA
Text: none of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of South-East Asian Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: question is addressed to the Minister for For-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign Affairs. Would the minister inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of the significance of the ASEAN-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-New Zealand summit for Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's relationship with South-East Asia?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Boothby for his question. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government is delighted that the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister is able to attend the historic ASEAN-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-New Zealand summit, which will

Speaker: NA
Text: take place tonight and tomorrow in Vienti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ane. Amongst other things, this summit will

Speaker: NA
Text: mark the 30th anniversary of Australia be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming an ASEAN dialogue partner. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think I am right in saying that Australia was

Speaker: NA
Text: the first ASEAN dialogue partner.

Speaker: NA
Text: This summit is a key recognition not only

Speaker: NA
Text: of the importance of ASEAN to Australia but

Speaker: NA
Text: of the importance of Australia to ASEAN.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are optimistic that a key outcome of the

Speaker: NA
Text: summit will be the beginning of negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: towards establishing something that I think is

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely desirable-that is, an ASEAN-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-New Zealand free trade area or

Speaker: NA
Text: free trade agreement. That would build, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, on the strong commercial links that

Speaker: NA
Text: already exist between Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ASEAN countries, on the free trade agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments we have negotiated with Thailand and

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore and on the work we are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: with Malaysia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The summit is also an opportunity to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flect the depth and range of our ties with

Speaker: NA
Text: ASEAN, from counter-terrorism-Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and ASEAN signed a joint declaration on

Speaker: NA
Text: counter-terrorism on 1 July, and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: counter-terrorism memoranda of understand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with a number of ASEAN countries-to

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence and security relationships that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have built up, in different forms with dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent countries in ASEAN; with all of them

Speaker: NA
Text: we have some measure of a defence and se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity relationship. We have excellent coop-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration with ASEAN on drug trafficking and

Speaker: NA
Text: people-smuggling, to the extent that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: as good as stopped people-smuggling from

Speaker: NA
Text: being directed to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our people-to-people links have continued

Speaker: NA
Text: to grow, too-through students, for example.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are 75,000 students from ASEAN

Speaker: NA
Text: countries studying in Australia, and over

Speaker: NA
Text: 600,000 tourists from South-East Asia vis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ited Australia in 2003.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, we make a strong aid commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: every year to a number of ASEAN coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries-obviously, not to all of them. To those

Speaker: NA
Text: ASEAN countries that are eligible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: receipt of development assistance in 2004,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will be providing about $400 million

Speaker: NA
Text: worth of aid.

Speaker: NA
Text: This summit is an opportunity for heads of

Speaker: NA
Text: government, including our own, to draw to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether the threads of a very comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: and very successful relationship-one that

Speaker: NA
Text: has continued to build over many years. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that both sides of the House have been

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to the relationship, but equally-

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is important to remember this-it

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be a two-way relationship. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that we as a country have in recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated not just the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: ASEAN to Australia but the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to the ASEAN countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of South-East Asian Nations

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: 2.33 p.m.)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: his explanation that Australia could not enter

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation

Speaker: NA
Text: with ASEAN, because of the alliance rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionship that Australia has with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. Is the minister aware that Japan, a

Speaker: NA
Text: longstanding ally of the United States, signed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation with

Speaker: NA
Text: ASEAN in February this year? Is the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter aware that South Korea, another long-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing ally of the US, did the same on Sat-

Speaker: NA
Text: urday? Given that other longstanding allies

Speaker: NA
Text: of the US have signed the treaty, why won't

Speaker: NA
Text: the government abandon its Howard doctrine

Speaker: NA
Text: of regional military pre-emption and indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia will give positive consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: to acceding to the Treaty of Amity and Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation with ASEAN?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: The Labor Party had 13

Speaker: NA
Text: years in government to sign the Treaty of

Speaker: NA
Text: Amity and Cooperation with ASEAN, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party chose not to. The Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party then-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: I haven't finished yet.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor Party then had 8½ years in oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition to say it would sign the Treaty of

Speaker: NA
Text: Amity and Cooperation. This is just another

Speaker: NA
Text: example of a wasted 8½ years, I assume; you

Speaker: NA
Text: did not think of it in those 8½ years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The traditional Australian position on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaty of Amity and Cooperation has nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: to do with the notion of pre-emption-

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely nothing to do with it at all. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty based on a series of principles. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: of them are the principles of the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Charter, and one of the principles of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations Charter is the right to self-

Speaker: NA
Text: defence. It is nothing to do with the notion of

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-emption. Other principles that the Treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: of Amity and Cooperation is based on are,

Speaker: NA
Text: among other things, the so-called 10 princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ples of the Bandung Declaration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1950s. One of the components of the Band-

Speaker: NA
Text: ung Declaration was that governments that

Speaker: NA
Text: signed up to the Treaty of Amity and Coop-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration would abstain from the use of ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements of collective defence to serve the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular interests of any of the big powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bearing that in mind, successive Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian governments-not just this one-have

Speaker: NA
Text: interpreted that particular principle as one

Speaker: NA
Text: that would be inconsistent with the ANZUS

Speaker: NA
Text: alliance. That obviously has been one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons historically why Australian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have not signed the treaty. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: reason is that it is a treaty that contains a

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for noninterference in the internal

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs of other countries. Therefore, it raises

Speaker: NA
Text: questions about whether, if you signed the

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty and you meant to sign it in a genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: way-taking seriously the provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty-you would not interfere in the affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: of another country; you would not, for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, criticise Burma, Myanmar, for human

Speaker: NA
Text: rights abuses.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the traditional reasons why Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has not signed the treaty. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has not changed its position, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of those explanations. The reasons that

Speaker: NA
Text: Gareth Evans, Paul Keating and Bob Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: gave for not signing the treaty are the rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons we give today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of South-East Asian Nations

Speaker: Mr JULL
Text: 2.37 p.m.)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for Trade. What

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits are to be had by Australia from a

Speaker: NA
Text: free trade pact with ASEAN?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Fadden for his question. But

Speaker: NA
Text: firstly, I take the opportunity to congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: you, Mr Speaker, on your election to the high

Speaker: NA
Text: office of Speaker of the House of Represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives-I was not here for the last two days

Speaker: NA
Text: of the previous sitting week. The answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Fadden's question is very

Speaker: NA
Text: simple: more and better jobs for Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australian exporting industries. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the outcome of negotiating a free trade

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement with the 10 ASEAN countries will

Speaker: NA
Text: be. Of course, this has not just happened. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is the result of a lot of hard work by a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of people, particularly through the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's persistent trade diplomacy within

Speaker: NA
Text: the region. We started this process at

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of trade ministers in Singapore in 1999.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition member interjecting-

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Text: Who is that up on the back

Speaker: NA
Text: bench interjecting?

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Text: It is a senator. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: stranger in the House! We started this proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ess in 1999 in a meeting of trade ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have been building on the strength of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian trade diplomacy within the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion. We add this to the architecture of a free

Speaker: NA
Text: trade agreement with Singapore, with Thai-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and with the study that we are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: with Malaysia and China at the moment, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it sets us up with great opportunities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: coming years within the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are targeting in terms of strengthening

Speaker: NA
Text: and greater integration economically with the

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 ASEAN countries. Within those 10 coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries there is a population of 545 million con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers and a GDP of around $700 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: An FTA with the ASEAN countries will cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate jobs in Australia. It will help further ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pand Australia's exports to the region and,

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously, deepen our economic integration

Speaker: NA
Text: with the region. Regarding the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship, there is already a $43 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: two-way trade relationship with the 10

Speaker: NA
Text: ASEAN countries and a $46 billion two-way

Speaker: NA
Text: investment relationship. As I say, building

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the other bilateral negotiations that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have concluded in the region, this augurs

Speaker: NA
Text: well for improved exports within our

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbourhood in the east Asian region. An

Speaker: NA
Text: FTA between Australia, New Zealand and

Speaker: NA
Text: the ASEAN countries would complement our

Speaker: NA
Text: already profitable trade agenda in our pursuit

Speaker: NA
Text: of the multilateral outcomes of the Doha

Speaker: NA
Text: Round as well as our bilateral negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: that have already been concluded, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been adding their weight to the 1.4 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion new jobs that have been created in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy since our government

Speaker: NA
Text: a meet- was originally elected in 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: I go back to my starting point, for the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation of the member for Fadden. This

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome had its genesis in that meeting in

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore in 1999 where we moved on to

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate and conclude a closer economic

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership agreement with the ASEAN

Speaker: NA
Text: countries and things have now culminated in

Speaker: NA
Text: this summit in Vientiane at which the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is representing Australia. If the La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party had been in a position in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to do this, they would have. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: not and they did not.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy: Foreign Debt

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: 2.41 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice is directed to the Treasurer. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: it true that Australia's record $406 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign debt reported today is more than

Speaker: NA
Text: double the size it was in 1996, more than 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of GDP for the first time ever and

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $20,000 of debt for every man,

Speaker: NA
Text: woman and child? Treasurer, do you believe

Speaker: NA
Text: this continued growth in debt is sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: and what are its implications for interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for his question. I can give you

Speaker: NA
Text: the figures. In 1996, foreign debt was 39 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the Australian economy and today it

Speaker: NA
Text: is 50 per cent, so it has not doubled. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong in relation to that. Do I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia would be well served if the current

Speaker: NA
Text: account deficit were lower? Yes. I have made

Speaker: NA
Text: that point on a number of occasions. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: about the same level that it was back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1994, but there are important differences

Speaker: NA
Text: between now and 1994. The most important

Speaker: NA
Text: difference of course is that, back in 1994,

Speaker: NA
Text: budget deficit was 2.8 per cent of GDP-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, the Commonwealth was running down

Speaker: NA
Text: savings-whereas today the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is in surplus; that is, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth is adding to savings. Back in 1994,

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation was 3.9 per cent and, since I was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked about interest rates, back in 1994 the

Speaker: NA
Text: home mortgage variable interest rate was

Speaker: NA
Text: 10½ per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought I would refer to one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches that was made back in 1994 on this

Speaker: NA
Text: question of foreign debt. It always pays to

Speaker: NA
Text: acquaint yourself with history. It was by a

Speaker: NA
Text: young member for Werriwa, who was speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on the appropriation bills and was highly

Speaker: NA
Text: critical of the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor. There is no-one on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that would be critical of the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for O'Connor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I do thank the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Lilley for his ‘Kylie'.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 17 November 1994 the member for Wer-

Speaker: NA
Text: riwa got up in this House during that episode

Speaker: NA
Text: and said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for O'Connor ... has

Speaker: NA
Text: again displayed the opposition's confusion on

Speaker: NA
Text: economic policy and its occasional tendency to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards xenophobia on issues such as the current

Speaker: NA
Text: account deficit and foreign debt. The truth is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the current account deficit is the equivalent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital ... inflow. Capital inflow into Australia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge vote of confidence by international investors

Speaker: NA
Text: in the strength of our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: If that is the way the member for Werriwa

Speaker: NA
Text: saw it in 1994, today's figures must be an

Speaker: NA
Text: even huger vote of confidence. I asked ear-

Speaker: NA
Text: lier: would it be better if Australia's current

Speaker: NA
Text: account were lower? Yes. Would it be better

Speaker: NA
Text: if our exporters were more competitive? Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the key thing that is working against

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's exporters at the moment? The

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange rate. You cannot have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can remember the opposition coming into

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament, led by the member for Hotham,

Speaker: NA
Text: complaining when the Australian dollar was

Speaker: NA
Text: at 47c to the US dollar. Today it is at around

Speaker: NA
Text: 78c or 79c-that is double. That does affect

Speaker: NA
Text: your competitiveness and the competitive-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of Australia's exporters. That is why it

Speaker: NA
Text: is important that this economy be kept com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive. The day we hear about the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Labor Party supporting industrial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions reform to help Australia's exporters is

Speaker: NA
Text: the day that we will know the Australian La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party does intend to change its spots and

Speaker: NA
Text: does intend to support economic credibility

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Demographic Trends

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Text: 2.45 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer seen a Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: report highlighting the need for government

Speaker: NA
Text: action now to combat the long-term effects

Speaker: NA
Text: of demographic change? How is the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment responding, and what are the alter-

Speaker: NA
Text: native policies?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Corangamite for his ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. This is the government that, as part of

Speaker: NA
Text: its Charter of Budget Honesty, required an

Speaker: NA
Text: Intergenerational Report to be prepared for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time in 2002 and benchmarking of

Speaker: NA
Text: progress each five years thereafter. In addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to that, at the request of the Council

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Governments I asked the Produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity Commission to do its own projections

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the ageing of Australia's popuance,

Speaker: NA
Text: lation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The draft report of the Productivity Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission largely endorses the Treasury fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts and says that Australia's ageing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: population could open up a gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue and outlays-state and federal-of

Speaker: NA
Text: the dimension of around seven per cent in 40

Speaker: NA
Text: years time. This is because the work force

Speaker: NA
Text: age population in Australia is hardly going

Speaker: NA
Text: change but the number of people of retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment age is going to double, or more than

Speaker: NA
Text: double, over the next 40 years. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs in relation to medical care-not

Speaker: NA
Text: only because older people draw down more

Speaker: NA
Text: on medical care but because new drugs and

Speaker: NA
Text: new techniques are being invented-are go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to put considerable pressure on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth account.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the government doing to address

Speaker: NA
Text: these challenges? We are taking measures to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase participation amongst the work

Speaker: NA
Text: force population. We are taking measures to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase productivity. We have announced an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the preservation age for superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation to 60 and an increase in the age pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion age for women to 65. We announced at

Speaker: NA
Text: the last election a mature age tax offset to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage Australians aged 55 to remain in

Speaker: NA
Text: the work force. We have announced changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to

Speaker: NA
Text: base that scheme on a sustainable basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were a lot of opposition spokesmen

Speaker: NA
Text: and spokeswomen out on the weekend. One

Speaker: NA
Text: of them was the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. He spoke quite a lot of sense on

Speaker: NA
Text: the weekend: he went out and warned of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare Gold Labor Party policy, which

Speaker: NA
Text: would add a substantial burden to future fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral budgets. He was right about that. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has probably never been a more irresponsible

Speaker: NA
Text: of promise made. In the context of an ageing

Speaker: NA
Text: population and increasing health care, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was an offer, without private health insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: of free first-class private health care to

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody over 75-a cohort of people that

Speaker: NA
Text: we know is going to grow and grow over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next 40 years. There has probably never been

Speaker: NA
Text: a more expensive promise made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where does the Australian Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: stand on Medicare Gold today? When I was

Speaker: NA
Text: a kid there used to be an ad that said, ‘Don't

Speaker: NA
Text: wait to be told; you need Palmolive Gold.'

Speaker: NA
Text: to Don't wait to be told; ditch Medicare Gold.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Melbourne was out there

Speaker: NA
Text: belling the cat on the weekend. Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold is a promise which is irresponsible. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a promise which no government in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in 40 years, let alone 30 years or 20 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: would possibly be able to honour.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Labor Party have now

Speaker: NA
Text: conceded they lost the last election because

Speaker: NA
Text: they had no economic credibility. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: their own analysis. And the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party now say, ‘We are determined to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come credible.' You will not be credible if

Speaker: NA
Text: you maintain the policies that led to the loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of credibility. It is more than signing bits of

Speaker: NA
Text: cardboard. Economic credibility comes from

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. Until such time as the Australian La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party change their policy on Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold, change their policy on industrial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, change their policy on unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: and change their policy on the Pharmaceuti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal Benefits Scheme-which they opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: and then they supported and now they op-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard-What are you on about?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: That is what hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened in the campaign with co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions-one wonders where it is up to

Speaker: NA
Text: now. In the confused menagerie that the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party today represents, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition calls his economic

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesmen ‘roosters'. The member for Lyons

Speaker: NA
Text: calls the member for Grayndler a ‘mangy

Speaker: NA
Text: dog'. The member for Brand has his chief of

Speaker: NA
Text: staff out describing the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition as a ‘dead parrot'. Those of you that

Speaker: NA
Text: watch Monty Python, as I do, please go back

Speaker: NA
Text: and have a look at the video. On the week-

Speaker: NA
Text: end, a rooster declared a jihad on a dead par-

Speaker: NA
Text: rot! My head was spinning! This is the ani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal farm that the Australian Labor Party now

Speaker: NA
Text: represents. Until it has the opportunity to get

Speaker: NA
Text: some policy, it will not have economic

Speaker: NA
Text: credibility. Credibility comes from policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy: Foreign Debt

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: 2.52 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice is directed to the Treasurer. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask him whether he recalls making the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing statement when he was shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and a young member for Higgins:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has high foreign debt and because Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has a current account problem, that puts

Speaker: NA
Text: premium on Australian borrowings, that flows

Speaker: NA
Text: through and every Australian pays for the conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, do you still agree with that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I have already an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swered this question. Firstly, comparing the

Speaker: NA
Text: current account deficit in 2004 to the current

Speaker: NA
Text: account deficit in 1994: as I have already

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated, in 1994, when the current account

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit was 6½ per cent of GDP, the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: was in deficit to 2.8 per cent-that is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government was a borrower

Speaker: NA
Text: and a large reason for the run-down in sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. Now the Commonwealth government is

Speaker: NA
Text: a saver. The Commonwealth government is

Speaker: NA
Text: making no impact at all on foreign borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. Secondly, as I have already pointed out,

Speaker: NA
Text: the home mortgage variable interest rate was

Speaker: NA
Text: 10½ per cent compared to 7.05 per cent to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day. Interest rates were higher.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do want to make one other point. Back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1994 Australia's foreign currency borrowing

Speaker: NA
Text: credit rate had been downgraded not once

Speaker: NA
Text: but twice. It was downgraded in 1986 at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of ‘banana republic' and it was down-

Speaker: NA
Text: graded again in the late eighties. Since this

Speaker: NA
Text: government was elected, Australia's foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: currency borrowing credit rating has been

Speaker: NA
Text: revised upward not once but twice-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia now enjoys a AAA credit rating on

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign currency borrowings. What deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mines a premium on your borrowing is your

Speaker: NA
Text: credit rating. A credit rating allows a lender

Speaker: NA
Text: to trade off risk against margin. So, if your

Speaker: NA
Text: credit rating is down, the risk premium

Speaker: NA
Text: which a lender will want in turn to lend to

Speaker: NA
Text: you is higher. This is the government that

Speaker: NA
Text: recovered Australia's AAA credit rating in

Speaker: NA
Text: the international markets. That has made all

Speaker: NA
Text: the difference. That is one of reasons why

Speaker: NA
Text: mortgage interest rates today are 7.05 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent rather than 10½ per cent, which they

Speaker: NA
Text: were in 1994-95.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukraine: Election

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Text: 2.55 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Would the minister inform the House of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's position on recent political

Speaker: NA
Text: developments in the Ukraine?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: First, I thank the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Pearce for her question. I appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: the concern she shows about the situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukraine. Just before question time today I

Speaker: NA
Text: met with the Ambassador of Ukraine and

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed yet again the Australian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's deep concern about the irregularities

Speaker: NA
Text: which clearly took place in the Ukrainian

Speaker: NA
Text: presidential elections on 21 November. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: clear from the reports of international ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: servers that this election fell well short of

Speaker: NA
Text: international standards. There was a suspi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciously high voter turnout in several regions.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was fraudulent use of absentee voting.

Speaker: NA
Text: State employees were pressured to vote for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Yanukovich, the Prime Minister. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was abuse of state resources and overt media

Speaker: NA
Text: bias. In these circumstances Australia cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the official result. We cannot accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that this result reflects the will of the UkrainUnder

Speaker: NA
Text: ian people. I note-and, as members of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament, we should all note-that the Ukra-

Speaker: NA
Text: nian parliament has passed a resolution de-

Speaker: NA
Text: claring the results invalid. The supreme court

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Ukraine will consider today whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the general election commission acted prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erly in declaring Mr Yanukovich the winner.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can only make one other comment,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is that I would be pretty sure I spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of all members of this parliament if

Speaker: NA
Text: I said that we have been pleased to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Ukraine express their will in a very

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful way through demonstrations in

Speaker: NA
Text: Kiev and other parts of the country. We very

Speaker: NA
Text: much hope that the differences that exist in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukraine can be resolved satisfactorily and,

Speaker: NA
Text: more than that, they can be resolved accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the good principles of democracy and

Speaker: NA
Text: free and fair elections.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Vocational Education and

Speaker: Ms KATE ELLIS
Text: 2.57 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to the Minister for Vocational and

Speaker: NA
Text: Technical Education. Does the minister sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port special levies or taxes to fund industry

Speaker: NA
Text: strategies dealing with the acute national

Speaker: NA
Text: skill shortage?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Adelaide for her question. The short an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer is: no, we are not going down the path-

Speaker: NA
Text: way that the Australian Labor Party had in

Speaker: NA
Text: place where they were taxing businesses in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to try and drive a training agenda. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, this government is instead going down

Speaker: NA
Text: the path of encouraging good partnerships

Speaker: NA
Text: with industry to take some of the responsibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, along with the state and territory gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments, for the business of ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: more people are involved in taking up trade

Speaker: NA
Text: based apprenticeships around Australia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have had quite a deal of success in this. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen enormous numbers of new appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeships developed over the last few years.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party, the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of trade based apprenticeships plum-

Speaker: NA
Text: meted from 160,990 in 1990 to 107,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1994. Today there are 146,400 trade appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices in training. We are driving an agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: that is undoing a lot of the mess of the previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous government's neglect. Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: what we are finding-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga is interrupting, but there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: 250 per cent increase in the number of new

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships in her own electorate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other key point is that all around Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: today we have state governments driving up

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE charges-charges up front. The up-

Speaker: NA
Text: front fees that are charged to new apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: are going up all around the country. For in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, there has been a 50 per cent increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in South Australia and a 300 per cent in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in New South Wales. The Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Training government has driven them up as well. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the latest insult to injury has happened: the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bracks Labor government in Victoria now

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to charge apprentices $30 to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: their completion certificates. So here we

Speaker: NA
Text: have people who have put it all on the line,

Speaker: NA
Text: worked hard and gained an apprenticeship

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in order to get the piece of paper to say

Speaker: NA
Text: they have done the job, the Bracks govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment wants to charge them $30 for that cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tificate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I therefore welcome the member for Ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: laide's question, because it does raise the

Speaker: NA
Text: question-it is another one of those the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer would call a ‘Kylie', I suppose. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is time for the Leader of the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: pick up the phone and ring Steve Bracks, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier of Victoria, and tell him to ease the

Speaker: NA
Text: squeeze on apprenticeships and to end the

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Bracks whack'. But of course the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition probably cannot pick up that

Speaker: NA
Text: phone and guarantee he will get put through,

Speaker: NA
Text: so maybe a certain Labor senator from Victo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ria, Senator Conroy, can do it for him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment: Murray-Darling River

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Text: 3.00 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture,

Speaker: NA
Text: Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: update the House on the progress of the Liv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Murray initiative, especially with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to my seat of Barker and with reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: the premiers' withdrawal during the election

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Barker for his question. He will

Speaker: NA
Text: be aware that the Murray-Darling Basin has

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced the driest four years in recorded

Speaker: NA
Text: history, so the reserves of water in the basin

Speaker: NA
Text: are exceptionally low and it will not be pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible to meet all of the commitments to irri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gators and other users in the year ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nonetheless, the Murray-Darling Basin Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isterial Council is proceeding with plans to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop and implement the Living Murray

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative first step.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will be aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: six icon sites have been identified where 500

Speaker: NA
Text: gigalitres of water will be used to help im-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove the environmental health of the river.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those sites and the engineering works asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated with putting these projects together

Speaker: NA
Text: have been approved over recent months. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the meeting last Friday, ministers agreed on

Speaker: NA
Text: four packages of projects in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and Victoria to provide 240 gigalitres

Speaker: NA
Text: of the water intended for the first stage. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a very significant step. It is about half

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of Sydney Harbour to be available

Speaker: NA
Text: every year to improve the environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: health of the river, and it is around half of all

Speaker: NA
Text: the water that will be required for the first

Speaker: NA
Text: stage. So, well ahead of schedule, around

Speaker: NA
Text: half the water has already been identified for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Living Murray initiative, and there is

Speaker: NA
Text: about another 70 gigalitres available in pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects under development to help make this

Speaker: NA
Text: ambitious plan a reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is also important-and I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: System honourable member for Barker will be par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly pleased by this-is that none of

Speaker: NA
Text: these projects will require the commission to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the marketplace or distort the market.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will all come from savings through the

Speaker: NA
Text: system: the cooperation of the various juris-

Speaker: NA
Text: dictions and users of water to help deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: savings to benefit the environment. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant environmental project for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. As soon as the jurisdictions re-

Speaker: NA
Text: commit to the National Water Initiative it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be possible to roll out the environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: projects for these six icon ecological sites

Speaker: NA
Text: along the river and to help build a stronger

Speaker: NA
Text: and healthier river.

Speaker: NA
Text: Can I also mention that the meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted salinity targets for the various river

Speaker: NA
Text: systems in the Murray-Darling Basin area,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will release a salinity management

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy to help address this other key prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem in the Murray-Darling Basin region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I am sure the honourable member,

Speaker: NA
Text: along with other members from South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, would be interested to know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: council has committed a further $7.5 million

Speaker: NA
Text: towards maintaining the sand pumping and

Speaker: NA
Text: dredging project at the River Murray mouth.

Speaker: NA
Text: When there is no water, it is simply not pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for it to be flushed out naturally, so this

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive pumping and dredging arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will need to continue. Adequate budget

Speaker: NA
Text: funds have been provided to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the the mouth of the river is kept as healthy as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible in these dry times.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Vocational Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Training

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: 3.04 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to the Minister for Vocational and

Speaker: NA
Text: Technical Education. Is the minister aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that on 4 November the ACCC authorised an

Speaker: NA
Text: industry levy on bricks to address

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of skilled bricklayers and fund more

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices? Minister, won't this levy mean

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in cost to businesses and families?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why has the Howard government let a se-

Speaker: NA
Text: vere skill shortage develop and allowed a

Speaker: NA
Text: levy on families and businesses? In the light

Speaker: NA
Text: of the minister's earlier answer, what will

Speaker: NA
Text: do to stop the price of bricks increasing as

Speaker: NA
Text: the result of this new levy?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: I think the member

Speaker: NA
Text: has really asked the wrong minister, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: sense that the ACCC is not within my remit,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I am happy to check it all out. What I am

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly conscious of-and, naturally

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, concerned about-is that the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of the state governments' fee increases is

Speaker: NA
Text: driving up the cost to apprentices taking up

Speaker: NA
Text: new apprenticeships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin- Mr Speaker, I raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. The point of order is on relevance.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is all about a new industry levy to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The minister has only

Speaker: NA
Text: just started answering his question, so there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: Mr Speaker, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: also about the area of traditional trades, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which bricklaying is just one. The point that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party need to understand very

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly is that, as a direct result of Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government actions around various states of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, it has become harder for appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices to afford the cost of a new apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship. It is extremely important for the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party to understand the culture of what their

Speaker: NA
Text: own governments at the state level have ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually driven. We have done some work with

Speaker: NA
Text: Access Economics-and Access Economics,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, is by no means strange to those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite-and in fact we have had to revise

Speaker: NA
Text: downwards the projected increase in demand

Speaker: NA
Text: for vocational and technical education over

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2004-06 period from 2.9 per cent to 1.7

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's per cent in VET hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a result of factoring in the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in the costs of studying in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: get people such as bricklayers out into the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace. I am happy to look into the spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cifics the member has asked for but at the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of it those opposite need to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: he that there has been a cultural change in the

Speaker: NA
Text: work force today. Those opposite also need

Speaker: NA
Text: to understand that we are delighted to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on vocational and technical educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I think we have had more in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: week and a half than we have had in the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious 8½ years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Health: Services

Speaker: Dr WASHER
Text: 3.07 p.m.)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Minister for Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ageing. Would the minister update the

Speaker: NA
Text: House on how new technology is helping

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver better health care to Australians?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Moore for his question and I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: him on increasing his margin from six per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent to a very healthy 10.8 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: as many members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site have done in the recent election. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the most comprehensive major

Speaker: NA
Text: study of avoidable deaths in Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: health institutions suggested that 20 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of these were due to poor information or in-

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate record keeping. So an integrated

Speaker: NA
Text: electronic health record should mean better

Speaker: NA
Text: care for patients and it should mean lower

Speaker: NA
Text: costs to taxpayers and to consumers. It

Speaker: NA
Text: should mean less need for patients to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: records and to carry information around with

Speaker: NA
Text: them. It should mean fewer expensive and

Speaker: NA
Text: invasive diagnostic tests. It should mean less

Speaker: NA
Text: overservicing and it should mean less misuse

Speaker: NA
Text: of prescription drugs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just about all the computers on all the

Speaker: NA
Text: health professionals' desks right around our

Speaker: NA
Text: country are already linked via the Internet.

Speaker: NA
Text: The challenge is to try to create a secure

Speaker: NA
Text: tabase with secure transmissions so that pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients and health professionals can access

Speaker: NA
Text: information they need precisely when they

Speaker: NA
Text: need it. In the last budget, the government

Speaker: NA
Text: committed $128 million to prepare for a na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional HealthConnect roll-out. In Tasmania,

Speaker: NA
Text: they have just concluded a trial which has

Speaker: NA
Text: proven the technology and helped to demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strate the business case. I can inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moore and the House that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and the states have just es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablished a National E-Health Transition Au-

Speaker: NA
Text: thority with the task of trying to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: health records move out of the horse-and-

Speaker: NA
Text: buggy era. We have to ensure that our health

Speaker: NA
Text: record system, no less than our medical

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment, remains the very best in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Vocational Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Training

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: 3.10 p.m.)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Vocational and Technical

Speaker: NA
Text: Education. Is the minister aware that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Master Builders Associa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has forecast a 10 per cent price hike in

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of building or renovating a house

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the shortage of skilled labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: the increased cost of materials like bricks?

Speaker: NA
Text: Doesn't this mean that Australian families

Speaker: NA
Text: and businesses who are building or renovat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing are being forced to pay the price for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government's lack of action on Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's skills crisis? Don't Australian busiwas

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses and families need action from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government on skills now, not in

Speaker: NA
Text: another four years when the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: overdue and insufficient technical colleges

Speaker: NA
Text: will finally be fully in place?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: I will take that ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on housing costs and thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member very much for his question. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: true that, because unemployment is low in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, in some areas there are shortages

Speaker: NA
Text: of skilled labour. That can be looked at as a

Speaker: NA
Text: dabad thing in an economy or it can be looked

Speaker: NA
Text: at as a very positive thing, frankly. If we had

Speaker: NA
Text: the our choice between an oversupply of labour

Speaker: NA
Text: or a shortage of labour, we would probably

Speaker: NA
Text: take a shortage of labour because what that

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates is that people can find work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was not actually suffering from

Speaker: NA
Text: any skills shortages or any shortages of la-

Speaker: NA
Text: bour during the Labor Party's term in gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment when we had 11 per cent unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment. But, having said that, if you want

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that there are no bottlenecks in an

Speaker: NA
Text: economy it is important that you continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply skilled labour lest you get price pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sures in those areas. That brings into play

Speaker: NA
Text: two issues. One is this government's immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration program, which has been refocused

Speaker: NA
Text: on skilled immigration very deliberately. It

Speaker: NA
Text: contrasts with the Australian Labor Party's

Speaker: NA
Text: program, which was focused on family reun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ion. Second is the program that this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment announced to set up Australian techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal colleges.

Speaker: NA
Text: We announced that because, as the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said over and over again during the

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign, we want a system where

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian young people and their parents

Speaker: NA
Text: value a trade certificate as much as a univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity degree. The idea which was developed

Speaker: NA
Text: for a good period during the 1980s and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990s that every child should go to univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity was not serving our community well. It

Speaker: NA
Text: not in their interests and it was not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the economy. This government is

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that there are additional technical

Speaker: NA
Text: and trade training areas. We are stepping in

Speaker: NA
Text: where there has been a failure by the states

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are ensuring that there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong labour market. We will make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: demand is still strong because demand in the

Speaker: NA
Text: housing market has been a big part of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's success story and its recent economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth over the last eight years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation: Policy

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Text: 3.13 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is addressed to the Minister for Revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the House of the extent to which Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians are accessing the government's su-

Speaker: NA
Text: perannuation co-contribution scheme?

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Paterson for his question. I am pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House that the ATO has informed

Speaker: NA
Text: me that they are about to roll out the first

Speaker: NA
Text: tranche of payments of the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's co-contribution scheme. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: recently checked 1.25 million income tax

Speaker: NA
Text: returns for their eligibility for the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution. Of that 1.25 million, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to inform the House that some

Speaker: NA
Text: 215,000 middleand low-income earners

Speaker: NA
Text: will be receiving a co-contribution towards

Speaker: NA
Text: their retirement income.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is particularly good news because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not only doing something positive today,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is also giving an incentive to Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians to make provision for their retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: in years to come. The tax office estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: that $110 million will be injected into Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's superannuation as a result of these

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, which is an average of about $510

Speaker: NA
Text: per payment per person. To put this into the

Speaker: NA
Text: context, with this extra payment, a person on

Speaker: NA
Text: $28,000 over a 30-year working life will in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease their retirement balance by about

Speaker: NA
Text: $54,000 or potentially about $2,300 extra

Speaker: NA
Text: income in retirement, which is a great thing

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australians to look forward to.

Speaker: NA
Text: This morning I noticed in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Review that one of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: largest industry funds, the Australian Retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Fund, is planning a promotion in which

Speaker: NA
Text: one of its members describes the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution as ‘bloody brilliant'. Quite

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, I am sure the 215,000 Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: out there who are about to receive extra

Speaker: NA
Text: money through the Howard government's

Speaker: NA
Text: co-contribution would agree with the senti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that this is ‘bloody brilliant'. It means

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australians are being provided an incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive to make provision for themselves and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so, to have more secure superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Vocational Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Training

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: 3.16 p.m.)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is again to the Minister for Vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: and Technical Education. Is the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that skills growth as a driver of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity has plummeted 75 per cent in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 10 years and that Australia now has a

Speaker: NA
Text: severe skills shortage in key trades and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries? Isn't it true that under the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government around 40,000 Australians have

Speaker: NA
Text: been turned away from TAFE each year, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding 15,000 young people, and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: vast majority of secondary school students

Speaker: NA
Text: will miss out on a technical college place?

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, isn't Australia's skills crisis a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the Howard government's failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: create enough training opportunities and

Speaker: NA
Text: boost Australia's skill levels?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga has discovered the trades! The

Speaker: NA
Text: workers' party have discovered the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: skills that underpin Australia's economy!

Speaker: NA
Text: What is true is that in 1995 an estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: 89,300 individuals applied for but were un-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to get a place to study in a vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: education training course. Of those, 69,400

Speaker: NA
Text: were seeking access to a TAFE place. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1999 the level was 71,100-it had fallen-

Speaker: NA
Text: and 53,900 were seeking a TAFE place. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2003 the level had fallen to 55,400, of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: 45,900 were seeking a TAFE place.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the face of state governments lifting

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE fees, in the face of a decade or more

Speaker: NA
Text: of neglect from those opposite, this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has deliberately turned around the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance of training apprentices and people

Speaker: NA
Text: in traineeships. This government has made

Speaker: NA
Text: an enormous difference: from 141,000 peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple involved in vocational education and

Speaker: NA
Text: training, as apprentices and trainees, to

Speaker: NA
Text: 400,000. That is a fundamental change. Now

Speaker: NA
Text: let us look at it in dollar terms. The Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian government's contribution to states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories has grown from $777.9 million

Speaker: NA
Text: under Labor to $1.13 billion. In fact, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that drives that up, indexing the

Speaker: NA
Text: base to $1.154 billion under this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is an increase of over 45 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those statistics speak for which side of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics is focusing on the trades skills

Speaker: NA
Text: age, and has done for almost a decade, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to those who neglected it for over a

Speaker: NA
Text: decade. Those figures underscore the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that this side of Australian politics under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stands very clearly the way to guarantee on-

Speaker: NA
Text: going growth on top of the already tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous growth that we have. The Treasurer has

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined the enormous way in which this

Speaker: NA
Text: economy is demanding more and more peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple with more and more skills. This govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is addressing that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one last point, and this is where

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite have got the biggest problem

Speaker: NA
Text: of all. All members on this side know it, but

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite still have not cottoned onto it.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this side of the chamber we are not afraid

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian workers driving up their

Speaker: NA
Text: wages based on the productivity they are

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving. We are not afraid of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workers gaining an additional dividend in

Speaker: NA
Text: their pay packet because of the skills they

Speaker: NA
Text: have. Those opposite like to reward medioc-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity; we do not.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson- Mr Speaker, I ask that

Speaker: NA
Text: further questions be placed on the Notice

Speaker: NA
Text: Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Text: Page) (3.20 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Does the member

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Text: I do.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Text: On Thursday, 18 No-

Speaker: NA
Text: vember, the last sitting of this parliament, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Morning Herald published a story

Speaker: NA
Text: with the banner headline ‘Deputy PM named

Speaker: NA
Text: as bribe row flares'. Accompanying that

Speaker: NA
Text: story was a large photograph of me talking to

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for New England and the Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: shortuty Prime Minister was walking past. That

Speaker: NA
Text: photograph must have been taken on

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 17 November, at about two or

Speaker: NA
Text: three minutes to two, because that was the

Speaker: NA
Text: only time that I spoke to the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: New England. The photograph had on it a

Speaker: NA
Text: caption that read, ‘Whatever it takes'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for New England made a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement to this House at 7.30. So to tie the

Speaker: NA
Text: photograph and the story together is a breach

Speaker: NA
Text: of the rules as laid down by the Speaker. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cut-and-paste fabrication of the story for sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sational effect, with a conspiratorial refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, I believe must breach any journalistic

Speaker: NA
Text: ethics as well.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (3.21

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)- Mr Speaker, I wish to make a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Does the member

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I do.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Yesterday on the In-

Speaker: NA
Text: siders program Michael O'Connor of the

Speaker: NA
Text: forestry division of the CFMEU stated that I

Speaker: NA
Text: called members of his union ‘vandals' during

Speaker: NA
Text: an interview on the AM program. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: true. I have respect for all workers and have

Speaker: NA
Text: never criticised workers for doing the job

Speaker: NA
Text: they are paid to do. Companies and politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cians, not individual workers, determine en-

Speaker: NA
Text: vironmental practices.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: New England) (3.21

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)- Mr Speaker, I wish to make a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: Yes, I do.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: Before making the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal explanation, I would like to concur

Speaker: NA
Text: with the comments of the member for Page.

Speaker: NA
Text: That photograph was taken when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking to me about the health of the Hon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bob Katter before question time. In question

Speaker: NA
Text: time on 18 November 2004, in answer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: question from the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Deputy Prime Minister about com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments made to me in a conversation with me

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House relating to his contact with Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Greg Maguire, the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented this conversation. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, I was walking out of this place-I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: was probably during June ... and on the way out

Speaker: NA
Text: he-

Speaker: NA
Text: meaning me-

Speaker: NA
Text: motioned me over and said, ‘I understand you

Speaker: NA
Text: might want to talk to me.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Prime Minister's version of his

Speaker: NA
Text: response was:

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘No. What? I don't know anything about it.' I

Speaker: NA
Text: have no understanding whatsoever as to why he

Speaker: NA
Text: thought I might want to talk to him about it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: don't. I said to him: ‘No. If I want to talk to you

Speaker: NA
Text: at some point in the future, I'll get in contact.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are the words that the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister misrepresented in this House last

Speaker: NA
Text: week. This is a misrepresentation of that

Speaker: NA
Text: conversation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has explained where he has been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: No, I have not. My rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ollection of that conversation was that I said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘John, I understand you want to talk to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are saying in Tamworth that you are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying I won't talk to you. I'm more than

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to talk to you at any time.' Mr Ander-

Speaker: NA
Text: son then said, ‘You mean my meeting with

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Maguire,' to which I said, ‘Not only Greg

Speaker: NA
Text: Maguire but others in the community.' This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a correct account of that conversation.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged

Speaker: NA
Text: for presentation as follows and copies will be

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the appropriate ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: Human Rights: Falun Gong

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens and residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney resident David Liang, father of two, was

Speaker: NA
Text: shot in both feet only hours after he and eight

Speaker: NA
Text: other Australians arrived in South Africa to file a

Speaker: NA
Text: lawsuit against Chinese officials who were visit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing South Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: This proposed lawsuit charged China's Vice

Speaker: NA
Text: President Zeng and Minister of Commerce Bo

Speaker: NA
Text: with torture, genocide and crimes against human-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, committed according to Jiang Zemin's per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonally stated policies regarding Falun Gong to

Speaker: NA
Text: “Ruin their reputations, bankrupt them financially

Speaker: NA
Text: and destroy them physically,” as well as, “Killing

Speaker: NA
Text: them won't matter because their deaths will be

Speaker: NA
Text: counted as suicides.” Zeng and Bo have been

Speaker: NA
Text: still served with lawsuits during previous overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: visits for their pivotal role in prolonging the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: secution of Falun Gong in China.

Speaker: NA
Text: South African Police are investigating the inci-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent as attempted murder against an Australian.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians Terrorised

Speaker: NA
Text: Falun Gong practitioners have long been the vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tims of discrimination, harassment and assault

Speaker: NA
Text: from Chinese officials on Australian soil and

Speaker: NA
Text: worldwide. A known ‘blacklist' has been circu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated to prevent Falun Gong practitioners travel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling overseas. This incident in South Africa is the

Speaker: NA
Text: most severe case to date and marks a new level of

Speaker: NA
Text: violence in the persecution of Falun Gong practi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioners outside of China.

Speaker: NA
Text: YOUR PETITIONERS

Speaker: NA
Text: REQUEST THE HOUSE TO:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Pay close attention to the safety of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians, including Falun Gong practitioners,

Speaker: NA
Text: who face terrorist attacks by Jiang Zemin's

Speaker: NA
Text: faction within the Chinese Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: help prevent such terrorist activities.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Co-operate with authorities in South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: to thoroughly investigate this incident and

Speaker: NA
Text: bring to justice those responsible for this at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempted murder.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Condemn the acts of terrorism by Jiang

Speaker: NA
Text: Zemin's faction against Falun Gong practi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioners both inside and outside of China.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Albanese (from 701 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Andren (from 87 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Baldwin (from 151 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Bartlett (from 116 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Cadman (from 942 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Causley (from 141 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Annette Ellis (from 525 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Fitzgibbon (from 85 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hardgrave (from 168 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hartsuyker (from 96 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mrs Hull (from 112 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration: Asylum Seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House of Representatives in Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: Whereas the 1998 Synod of the Anglican Diocese

Speaker: NA
Text: of Melbourne carried without dissent the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘That this Synod regrets the Government's adop-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of procedures for certain people seeking po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical asylum in Australia which exclude them

Speaker: NA
Text: from all public income support while withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: permission to work, thereby creating a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: beggars dependent on the Churches and charities

Speaker: NA
Text: for food and the necessities of life;

Speaker: NA
Text: and calls upon the Federal government to review

Speaker: NA
Text: such procedures immediately and remove all

Speaker: NA
Text: practices which are manifestly inhumane and in

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases in contravention of our national obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: THEREFORE gations as a signatory of the UN Covenant on

Speaker: NA
Text: Civil and Political Rights.'

Speaker: NA
Text: We, therefore, the individual, undersigned atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: dees at St Mark's Anglican Church, Wonga Park,

Speaker: NA
Text: VIC, 3115, petition the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: in support of the above mentioned Motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: AND we, as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Andrews (from 7 citizens)

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: AND we, as in duty bound will ever pray.

Text: Immigration: Asylum Seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House of Representatives in Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: Whereas the 1998 Synod of the Anglican Diocese

Speaker: NA
Text: of Melbourne carried without dissent the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘That this Synod regrets the Government's adop-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of procedures for certain people seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: litical asylum in Australia which exclude them

Speaker: NA
Text: from all public income support while withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: permission to work, thereby creating a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: beggars dependent on the Churches and charities

Speaker: NA
Text: for food and the necessities of life;

Speaker: NA
Text: and calls upon the Federal government to review

Speaker: NA
Text: such procedures immediately and remove all

Speaker: NA
Text: practices which are manifestly inhumane and in

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases in contravention of our national oblifrom

Speaker: NA
Text: gations as a signatory of the UN Covenant on

Speaker: NA
Text: Civil and Political Rights.'

Speaker: NA
Text: We, therefore, the individual, undersigned

Speaker: NA
Text: dees at The New Community Church – Salvation

Speaker: NA
Text: Army, Carrum Downs, VIC, 3201, petition the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in support of the above

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned Motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: AND we, as in duty bound will ever pray.
