Speaker: NA
Text: Social Welfare: Reform

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: The very high incidence of abortion - one for

Speaker: NA
Text: every three live births in Australia today - and the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of health care monies to pay for the destruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the nation's future children through these

Speaker: NA
Text: abortions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: take necessary steps to direct those monies to

Speaker: NA
Text: helping mothers and babies instead.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Baldwin (from 1,458 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Cadman (from 623 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Jull (from 1,027 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Slipper (from 632 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health: Cancer Treatments

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens of Australia points

Speaker: NA
Text: out to the House that -

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. 1,400 Australians every year are diagnosed

Speaker: NA
Text: with a primary brain tumour, many of which

Speaker: NA
Text: are of the most lethal type called glioblas-

Speaker: NA
Text: toma multiforme grade iv;

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. At a major oncology conference held in June

Speaker: NA
Text: in the USA scientists reported the results of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Phase III trial of 573 patients with this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular tumour in 85 centres throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, Canada and Australia, which showed

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable improvements in the two-year

Speaker: NA
Text: survival of patients and better median sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vival and progression-free survival.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The trial involved concomitant use of radia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion therapy and the chemotherapy drug te-

Speaker: NA
Text: mozolomide (Temodar), and continuing use

Speaker: NA
Text: of the drug afterwards, resulting in an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the number of patients still alive at

Speaker: NA
Text: two years from 10% to 27%.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Minister and Government to take ur-

Speaker: NA
Text: gent and compassionate action to ensure that this

Speaker: NA
Text: new therapy is made available immediately as a

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidised benefit for all newly diagnosed brain

Speaker: NA
Text: tumour patients who have this particular type of

Speaker: NA
Text: tumour.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Baldwin (from 8 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Melham (from 33 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Nairn (from 24 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Quick (from 60 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade: Fur Imports

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition, of citizens and residents of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, is to call the attention of the House to the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational trade of dog and cat fur products and

Speaker: NA
Text: accessories, being sold in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Humane Society International has investigated

Speaker: NA
Text: and unearthed evidence of the appalling interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional fur trade, where dogs and cats are cruelly

Speaker: NA
Text: slaughtered by inhumane methods, with animals

Speaker: NA
Text: dying by slow suffocation, hanging, clubbing or

Speaker: NA
Text: beating to death. All these methods involved se-

Speaker: NA
Text: vere panic, trauma and needless prolonged suffer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. More than two million dogs and cats are

Speaker: NA
Text: killed each year for use in the international fur

Speaker: NA
Text: trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners request the House to send a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong message to this terrible industry, by ban-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning the importation of dog and cat fur products

Speaker: NA
Text: into Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Corcoran (from 107 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Hall (from 16 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Human Rights: Falun Dafa

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens and residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Falun Gong (also known as Falun Dafa), is a

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of meditation and exercises with

Speaker: NA
Text: teachings based on the universal principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: “Truthfulness-Compassion-Tolerance”, prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticed in over 60 countries world-wide and

Speaker: NA
Text: has roots in traditional Chinese culture - has

Speaker: NA
Text: been subject to a systematic campaign of

Speaker: NA
Text: eradication in China since July 1999;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) The Falun Dafa Information Center has veri-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied details of 890 deaths (as at 25/2/2004)

Speaker: NA
Text: since the persecution of Falun Gong in China

Speaker: NA
Text: began in 1999. In October 2001, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: Government officials inside China reported

Speaker: NA
Text: that the actual death toll was well over 1,600.

Speaker: NA
Text: Expert sources now estimate that figure to be

Speaker: NA
Text: much higher. Hundreds of thousands have

Speaker: NA
Text: been detained, with more than 100,000 being

Speaker: NA
Text: sentenced to forced labour camps, typically

Speaker: NA
Text: without trial;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) The implementation of this policy of eradica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion violates the Constitution of the People's

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic of China, the Universal Declaration

Speaker: NA
Text: of Human Rights, the International Covenant

Speaker: NA
Text: on Civil and Political Rights which China

Speaker: NA
Text: has signed, the Convention Against Torture

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Convention on the Prevention and

Speaker: NA
Text: Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, both

Speaker: NA
Text: of which China has signed and ratified; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) Australia is the elected Chair of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations Commission on Human Rights for

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 and the Commission will convene on

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 March 2004.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore request the house to

Speaker: NA
Text: initiate a resolution to condemn China's persecu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Falun Gong at the United Nations Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission on Human Rights and request China to:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. Unconditionally release all Falun Gong prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: titioners imprisoned for their spiritual beliefs,

Speaker: NA
Text: including those family members of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian citizens and residents currently detained;

Speaker: NA
Text: II. Allow unrestricted access into China to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations rapporteur on torture in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry out independent, third-party investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations on the persecution of Falun Gong

Speaker: NA
Text: practitioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Cadman (from 120 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hardgrave (from 15 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing: Aged Care

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of the undersigned shows:

Speaker: NA
Text: - concerned Australian citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: point out to the House of Representatives:

Speaker: NA
Text: Due the increasing shortfall between the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come available to deliver aged and commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity services and the rising costs of deliver-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing those services, Australia is facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: imminent collapse of the aged and commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity care system as we know it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your Petitioners therefore ask the House of Rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives to:

Speaker: NA
Text: - Replace the current system of indexing pric-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the aged and community care sector

Speaker: NA
Text: with a system which reflects the true in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in the costs of running aged and

Speaker: NA
Text: community care services.

Speaker: NA
Text: - Immediately inject $10 per day, per bed to

Speaker: NA
Text: restore the existing viability of residential

Speaker: NA
Text: care services.

Speaker: NA
Text: - Provide a 10 per cent increase in the prices

Speaker: NA
Text: paid for community care to ensure viability

Speaker: NA
Text: of these important services, which help keep

Speaker: NA
Text: our elderly and disabled in their own homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Andren (from 40 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health: Dental Services

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain electors of the Division of

Speaker: NA
Text: Calare draws to the attention of the House the

Speaker: NA
Text: deplorable state of Dental Health particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: among the lower income earners of the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. Your petitioners therefore pray that the

Speaker: NA
Text: House see fit to introduce legislation to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: Dental Health under the Medicare umbrella.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Andren (from 183 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration: Asylum Seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the House that the

Speaker: NA
Text: currently being held at Villawood Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: Detention Centre, Sydney, has been in detention

Speaker: NA
Text: since their arrival in Australia more than three

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago. The family of five -Manee Jezan,

Speaker: NA
Text: Shahla Nazari Zadh and their three children,

Speaker: NA
Text: Behnam, 18, Reem, 15, and Rana Jezan, 13 -are

Speaker: NA
Text: Iranian citizens and members of the Sabian Man-

Speaker: NA
Text: daean minority religious group. In the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court on 30 May 2003, Justice Richard Cooper

Speaker: NA
Text: found Iranian Mandaeans to be persecuted in their

Speaker: NA
Text: home country, not simply discriminated against as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Immigration and Multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous Affairs had asserted. Your peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioners therefore ask the House to call on the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of Immigration and Multicultural and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs to immediately release the

Speaker: NA
Text: Jezan family from detention and grant permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: residency, with a view to future Australian citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zenship.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Andren (from 20 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Pinner, Mr Kirk

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House of Representatives assembled in

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of citizens of Australia calls on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament to recognise:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Kirk Pinner is an Australian citizen who un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derwent an unfair trial in the USA. Evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: and fact were presented and ignored by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Kirk Pinner currently suffers from suspected

Speaker: NA
Text: tuberculosis, which was contracted in unhy-

Speaker: NA
Text: gienic conditions in the Ada County Jail,

Speaker: NA
Text: Idaho, USA. Kirk goes without treatment for

Speaker: NA
Text: this preventable disease. To continue to go

Speaker: NA
Text: untreated may amount to a death sentence at

Speaker: NA
Text: any stage for Kirk Pinner.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Kirk Pinner has applied for transfer under the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Transfers of Prisoners Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: in May 2004.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore ask the House to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: the immediate return of Kirk Pinner from USA

Speaker: NA
Text: under the transfer scheme and on humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: and health grounds. We ask the House to request

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard Government consent to the transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: of Kirk Pinner under provisions of 42 (b) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Transfer of Prisoners Act and he be returned to

Speaker: NA
Text: Jezan family, Australia and his family.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Baker (from 183 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare: Bulk-Billing

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: - That under proposed changes to Medicare,

Speaker: NA
Text: families earning more than $32,300 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: will miss out on bulk billing, and doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: will increase their fees for visits that are no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer bulk billed;

Speaker: NA
Text: - That the rate of bulk billing by GPs has

Speaker: NA
Text: plummeted by 11% under John Howard;

Speaker: NA
Text: - That more than 10 million fewer GP visits

Speaker: NA
Text: were bulk billed this year compared to when

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard came to office;

Speaker: NA
Text: - That the average out-of-pocket cost to see a

Speaker: NA
Text: GP who does not bulk bill has gone up by

Speaker: NA
Text: 55% since 1996 to $12.78 today;

Speaker: NA
Text: - That public hospitals are now under greater

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure because people are finding it harder

Speaker: NA
Text: to see bulk billing doctors.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore pray that the House takes urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: steps to restore bulk billing by general practitio-

Speaker: NA
Text: ners and reject John Howard's plan to end univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sal bulk billing so all Australians have access to

Speaker: NA
Text: the health care they need and deserve.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Crean (from 59 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra: Privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker of the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the House assembled in parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: the following issues to the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: - There is widespread concern that services

Speaker: NA
Text: and jobs will be cut back if the rest of Telstra

Speaker: NA
Text: is sold, particularly in outer

Speaker: NA
Text: ral and regional Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: - A fully privatised Telstra will focus on prof-

Speaker: NA
Text: its not people; shareholders will be more im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant than customers.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore pray that the House oppose any

Speaker: NA
Text: further attempts by the Liberal Party and Nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: als to sell Telstra.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Crean (from 43 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment: Myrmecia Pilosula

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament.

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, draw

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the House to the serious conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences of the allergic reaction to stings by the

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘hopper' or ‘jack jumper' ant, Myrmecia pilosula.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some 2-3% of the exposed population in southern

Speaker: NA
Text: and eastern Australia are known to exhibit allergic

Speaker: NA
Text: reactions to stings, many of these potentially le-

Speaker: NA
Text: thal. Some commonly prescribed medications

Speaker: NA
Text: may increase the danger. And yet many residents

Speaker: NA
Text: are unaware of the risks and some medical practi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioners uninformed. A desensitisation treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: has proven effective, yet no programs are in place

Speaker: NA
Text: to educate or desensitize victims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: will release resources to protect citizens, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly residents of South-Eastern areas from this

Speaker: NA
Text: danger.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Downer (from 340 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives. Parliament House

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petitioners as set out below who are mental

Speaker: NA
Text: health consumers and carers being residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hunter Electorate in the State of NSW.

Speaker: NA
Text: Brings to the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the undersigned petitioners request that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government reviews the process that

Speaker: NA
Text: delineates what drugs fall within the Pharmaceu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical Benefits Scheme to allow those in need ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to the medications that are proven to assist in

Speaker: NA
Text: the controlling of various forms of Mental illness

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the recommendations set by the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan, ruInsurance Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: These medications include Risperdal, Cozaril and

Speaker: NA
Text: Zyprexa for the reasons as described in the at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tached letter to the Hon Tony Abbott and enclosed

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Fitzgibbon (from 491 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health: After-Hours Services

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Request that the House take immediate action to

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee the ongoing funding to allow for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter GP Access After Hours to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide emergency after hours service to people

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Hunter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The After hours service offers a valuable service

Speaker: NA
Text: to the region and allows for greater access to

Speaker: NA
Text: medical treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore to respectfully request

Speaker: NA
Text: that the House do everything in their power to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the Hunter GP Access After Hours

Speaker: NA
Text: remains open.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Hall (from 301 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare: Belmont Office

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We the undersigned request that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: re-open a Medicare Office at Belmont as there is

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra: Privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: These petitioners of the Division of Shortland and

Speaker: NA
Text: adjoining areas are deeply concerned at any plans

Speaker: NA
Text: to further privatise Telstra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further privatisation of Telstra will result in

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of thousands more Telstra jobs, worsening

Speaker: NA
Text: services to regional and rural Australia, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of up to $1 billion a year for all Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: earned from Telstra profits.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe these profits, both now and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future, should be set aside to secure improved

Speaker: NA
Text: educational opportunities for our children, in-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists and doctors, and more money for rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional Australia.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's shares in Telstra and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual profits from Telstra be used for the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of all Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Welfare: Reform

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Petition of certain Pensioners of Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: draws the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: We the undersigned are old age pensioners. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have the house we live in and own one other

Speaker: NA
Text: house, which we use solely as holiday house. We

Speaker: NA
Text: make no income from either property.

Speaker: NA
Text: the As a result of significant movements in values of

Speaker: NA
Text: house prices the following consequences have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) We are affected by the asset thresholds,

Speaker: NA
Text: which unreasonably includes the holiday

Speaker: NA
Text: home, motor vehicle and furniture in the

Speaker: NA
Text: holiday home.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) We are penalised and part of our pension

Speaker: NA
Text: payments is deducted.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no reason why we should be penalised

Speaker: NA
Text: now that we are old age pensioners from continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to enjoy the benefits of our holiday homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nor should we be put in a position with draconian

Speaker: NA
Text: asset test to ultimately require us to sell our holi-

Speaker: NA
Text: day homes to loose our pension to help finance

Speaker: NA
Text: other sosial security programes. For to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: have this second home we worked twice as hard

Speaker: NA
Text: and contributed by paying twice as much taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: when we where young.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: adjust the Social Security laws to exclude the:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Holiday Home

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Furniture in the holiday home

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) The value of the motor car from the asset

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hunt (from 42 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Ballarat: Prisoners of War Memorial

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of certain citizens, being electors

Speaker: NA
Text: the Division of Ballarat and members and associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ates of the Ballarat, Victoria, branch of the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Air Force Association:

Speaker: NA
Text: Draws to the attention of the House that as proven

Speaker: NA
Text: loyal members of the Commonwealth Military

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces during the conflict known as World War

Speaker: NA
Text: Two and subsequently in such other emergency

Speaker: NA
Text: situations as the Commonwealth has been in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved we, like our predecessors, have at all times

Speaker: NA
Text: been prepared to serve wherever we were placed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the military and political authorities. Among

Speaker: NA
Text: us we include some who were incarcerated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy through no fault of their own. Indeed a

Speaker: NA
Text: large number were surrendered by their superiors,

Speaker: NA
Text: in theatres such as Singapore, Crete and Greece.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people of Australia can conclude only from

Speaker: NA
Text: the attitude and actions of the Australian Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment at the time and subsequently that those

Speaker: NA
Text: who were taken as prisoners of war are regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as the ‘forgotten ones', even though many of

Speaker: NA
Text: them suffered far greater privations for a longer

Speaker: NA
Text: period than many who continued to serve in ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive combat roles. That the Commonwealth Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has been reluctant to acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: role these servicemen and women have played is

Speaker: NA
Text: all too evident. No register was kept at the time of

Speaker: NA
Text: those so incarcerated and indeed even today there

Speaker: NA
Text: remain many who are unidentified. Whilst it is

Speaker: NA
Text: right and proper that those who died in the service

Speaker: NA
Text: of their country should be commemorated, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: convinced that similar recognition should be af-

Speaker: NA
Text: forded to those who went through a living hell as

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoners of war.

Speaker: NA
Text: To this end a Prisoners of War Memorial has now

Speaker: NA
Text: been erected in Ballarat, funded largely by public

Speaker: NA
Text: subscription, on which are permanently recorded

Speaker: NA
Text: the names of prisoners of war from throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who served their country in all wars

Speaker: NA
Text: from the formation of the Commonwealth up to

Speaker: NA
Text: the present. Thus the people of Australia have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen fit to recognise the role these men women

Speaker: NA
Text: played in wartime, even though successive Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments appear to have been embarrassed by

Speaker: NA
Text: their existence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst recognising that the Commonwealth Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has made a modest contribution to this

Speaker: NA
Text: of Memorial the amount palls into insignificance

Speaker: NA
Text: when compared with how much has been spent

Speaker: NA
Text: on other memorials both in Australia and over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners, the undersigned, therefore ask

Speaker: NA
Text: that the House demonstrate its recognition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: role these servicemen and servicewomen played

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia's history by Gazetting the Prisoners

Speaker: NA
Text: of War Memorial as a Federal shrine and by allo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cating a further sum of $290,000.00 to enable its

Speaker: NA
Text: completion to a fitting standard in its current set-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting at the heart of Australia's proud tradition of

Speaker: NA
Text: selfless service and democracy.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms King (from 67 citizens)

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force: Medals

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House of Representatives assembled in

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament;

Speaker: NA
Text: The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: That a citizen who serves to defend the country

Speaker: NA
Text: does so with the highest patriotic motives in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind. They know they could be called to serve in

Speaker: NA
Text: war and lay down their life. After that commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment they may leave the service without any tan-

Speaker: NA
Text: gible recognition being given to them. Unless a

Speaker: NA
Text: member receives a medal for overseas service

Speaker: NA
Text: their first chance of gaining a medal is for long

Speaker: NA
Text: service after 15 years service, if the member

Speaker: NA
Text: serves that long.

Speaker: NA
Text: The medal sought is not for service in the sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: long service but more for the individual who

Speaker: NA
Text: makes a commitment to serve the Nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your Petitioners pray that the House will institute

Speaker: NA
Text: a medal for two years full-time or part-time ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice in the Australian Defence Force from 1 Janu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary 1946 to the present and future servicemen and

Speaker: NA
Text: women who serve and protect our Nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mrs Moylan (from 20 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health: MRI Machines

Speaker: NA
Text: To the honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Federal Parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain residents of the State of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales draws to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House the refusal by the Federal Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: license a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Speaker: NA
Text: facility at the Concord Repatriation and General

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital denies equitable access to vital health

Speaker: NA
Text: services for cancer, heart, orthopaedic, burns and

Speaker: NA
Text: MS patients.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite a commitment by the NSW Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to purchase a MRI machine, Concord Hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: remains the only teaching hospital in Sydney not

Speaker: NA
Text: approved to provide MRI diagnostic services via

Speaker: NA
Text: the Medicare system.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means Concord's frailest patients are unable

Speaker: NA
Text: to locally access vital diagnostic services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners request the House to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: public's interest and provide equitable access to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Medicare system for inner western Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: residents by licensing MRI diagnostic services at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Concord Repatriation and General Hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Murphy (from 536 citizens)

Text: Social Welfare: Protection of Children

Speaker: NA
Text: To The Honourable The Speaker and the Mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the House of Representatives assembled

Speaker: NA
Text: in Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The undersigned petitioners wish to draw to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the House, the need for a Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: Children's Contact Service. We therefore pray

Speaker: NA
Text: that the House takes steps to ensure that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will fund this Service.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: only.

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture: Apple Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the House the decision by Bio-

Speaker: NA
Text: security Australia to permit the importation of

Speaker: NA
Text: apples from countries which have infestations of

Speaker: NA
Text: Erwinia amylovora (Fireblight). Biosecurity Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia admit infestation of Australian plants is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely, and have published “Fruit sourced from

Speaker: NA
Text: infected orchards have the potential to carry epi-

Speaker: NA
Text: phytic bacteria potential for spread – feasible

Speaker: NA
Text: potential for consequences – significant.” Pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished Biosecurity Australia February 2004.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your Petitioners therefore pray that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Rescind that decision by Biosecurity Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia-on environmental grounds as this pest

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be eradicated, or alternatively

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Legislate that all Australian citizens affected

Speaker: NA
Text: financially by the decision each year be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: imbursed for all costs associated with control

Speaker: NA
Text: of the disease, from the date of infestation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will include orchardists, nurserymen

Speaker: NA
Text: and gardeners.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Bruce Scott (from 1,197 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs: Aid

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the undersigned, respectfully request the

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the House of Representatives to note

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the last thirty years Australia's giving to

Speaker: NA
Text: development funding for needy countries has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen from 0.5% of Gross National Income (GNI)

Speaker: NA
Text: to 0.25% of GNI (Source: DAC Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation Reports 1982-2002).

Speaker: NA
Text: We further request Members of the House to take

Speaker: NA
Text: action which leads to an increase in Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: development aid to needy countries with the goal

Speaker: NA
Text: of returning funding to 0.5% of GNI, at least.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Kelvin Thomson (from 7 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Marriage Education in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament

Text: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the House to the fact that courses

Text: of Marriage Education (How to get married, How

Speaker: NA
Text: to stay Married and Parenting Responsibilities)

Speaker: NA
Text: are not being delivered-to Australia's Teenagers,

Speaker: NA
Text: the future Husbands and Wives of this Nation.

Text: We the undersigned respectfully sheweth that the

Speaker: NA
Text: omission of ‘Marriage Education' as the central

Speaker: NA
Text: issue in our school's ‘Sex Education' courses is

Speaker: NA

Text: & 109) and the directive of the Marriage Act

Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Vaile (from 69 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Education: Funding

Speaker: NA
Text: To the honourable Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Petition of certain citizens of Australia un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dersigned draws to the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: A well funded Public Education system is vital to

Speaker: NA
Text: the maintenance of a fair and democratic Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian society.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need our public schools to be well resourced.

Speaker: NA
Text: This requires the Federal Government to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a fairer model for funding Australian schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:

Speaker: NA
Text: Ensure that the funding policies of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government are reformed to provide in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased and fairer funding for public schools.

Text: by Mr Wakelin (from 72 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration: Asylum Seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives assembled in Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament:

Speaker: NA
Text: Schools This petition of the undersigned citizens of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia draws the attention of the House to the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of asylum seekers in Australia whose Tempo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rary Protection Visas are expiring and who are

Speaker: NA
Text: applying for Permanent Protection Visas.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are deeply concerned to hear that such people,

Speaker: NA
Text: as they apply for further protection, are being

Speaker: NA
Text: refused it. There is therefore an expectation that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be returned to where conditions are no

Speaker: NA
Text: better than when they were originally granted

Speaker: NA
Text: protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore request the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: urge the Australian Government to give sympa-

Speaker: NA
Text: thetic consideration to all asylum seekers who

Speaker: NA
Text: apply for further protection, and to take into con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration the parlous state of law and order in

Speaker: NA
Text: countries where asylum seekers are likely to be

Speaker: NA
Text: returned, at best, to further persecution, and

Speaker: NA
Text: probably, to their deaths.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Windsor (from 221 citizens)

Speaker: NA
Text: Address-in-Reply

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (3.31 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Few people in Australia would not acknowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge that the basis of the confidence that this

Speaker: NA
Text: country has experienced has been laid down

Speaker: NA
Text: by the government's building on the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic base that inspires confidence and

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to growth and future investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. The three per cent to four per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent growth over the last few years has been

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of that confidence. That was the

Speaker: NA
Text: nub-the crux-of the last election. From

Speaker: NA
Text: the day the election was called the electors

Speaker: NA
Text: were asking, ‘Can we maintain our confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence in light of the proposals put by both

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition and the Labor Party?' They

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at the certainty they were experienc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with interest rates and high levels of em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and with the capacity to invest and

Speaker: NA
Text: make decisions with certainty. They com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared that with the proposals being put for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward by the Australian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition had built on the lack of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fidence that brought about the change of

Speaker: NA
Text: government in 1996 with a plan for doing

Speaker: NA
Text: something about the massive debt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party had run up. The coalition came

Speaker: NA
Text: into office with a plan to reduce taxation and

Speaker: NA
Text: give back to Australian citizens more of their

Speaker: NA
Text: own hard-won savings. The coalition came

Speaker: NA
Text: into office with a plan so that Australia could

Speaker: NA
Text: be competitive and take up a role of chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenging those in the world who want to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pete against us in our markets and also ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pand local businesses so that export re-

Speaker: NA
Text: placement could take place purely by being

Speaker: NA
Text: more competitive. The coalition came to of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice with the promise and commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: quite reward effort and increase productivity, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that was carried out. Those were the key fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors that were evident from the day the last

Speaker: NA
Text: election was called. Growth, more jobs, fal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling unemployment, an increase in real

Speaker: NA
Text: wages, low cost of living increases and low

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates were all part of those factors.

Speaker: NA
Text: We came through a number of problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The economic downturn in Asia was a chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge for us to overcome. The worldwide

Speaker: NA
Text: terrorism that confronts us all and is with us

Speaker: NA
Text: today could have been a stalling factor, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: broke the confidence of countries with less

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in the future than Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: change in climatic circumstances brought

Speaker: NA
Text: real issues of concern to rural communities,

Speaker: NA
Text: as did a downturn in our export earnings

Speaker: NA
Text: from rural produce. The longer term impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of an ageing population with a work force

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained at about the current level but a

Speaker: NA
Text: need to expand our production and output is

Speaker: NA
Text: a longer term issue that is confronting us and

Speaker: NA
Text: is being dealt with by the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The confidence of Australians that the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition could handle the circumstances and

Speaker: NA
Text: had a track record that indicated that they

Speaker: NA
Text: could do that was compared with a whole list

Speaker: NA
Text: of ideas that came forward from the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. The coalition's ideas to provide a ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture age worker tax offset to make it more

Speaker: NA
Text: financially attractive for older Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: remain in employment on a full-time, part-

Speaker: NA
Text: time or casual basis was one idea presented

Speaker: NA
Text: at the election. The government's announced

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cuts would provide 80 per cent of tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers with a marginal tax rate of no more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 30 per cent. It was said that legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: would be introduced to give formal recogni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and protection to independent contrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors-the single contractors in building and

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and other industries who are the

Speaker: NA
Text: real generators of economic activity and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction in our community. The meeting of

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills needs of our community by invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing more in better quality tertiary and further

Speaker: NA
Text: education and the capacity and commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to build 24 Australian technical colleges ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tering for year 11 and year 12 students,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby lifting the skills base of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: were part of the attractive features that were

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged by Australians coming into

Speaker: NA
Text: the election. Working with parents, the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will invest directly in school infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure through an additional $1 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment over the next four years, work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing directly with schools and parents to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest in education to help address the short-

Speaker: NA
Text: falls that many state governments have failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to rectify in their own education programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was compared by electors to a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: range of ideas that started to emerge in De-

Speaker: NA
Text: cember 2003. It was not better highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere than in the Australian Financial

Speaker: NA
Text: Review, in an article on economics by David

Speaker: NA
Text: Bassanese. In his article, David Bassanese

Speaker: NA
Text: recounted some of the ideas that were com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing forward from the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at that time-and that were carried

Speaker: NA
Text: through into the election campaign. They

Speaker: NA
Text: created an air of confusion and uncertainty

Speaker: NA
Text: that, when balanced against the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: the community had in the coalition govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's management, forced the community

Speaker: NA
Text: to vote in a massive way for the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than for the ALP. That theme stayed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the electors right through the campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although many listened very carefully to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Leader of the Opposition said, he

Speaker: NA
Text: could not assure them that they should have

Speaker: NA
Text: the confidence to change their vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the ideas that came forward

Speaker: NA
Text: around 12 months ago were really interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, but they were such a mishmash that they

Speaker: NA
Text: caused Access Economics director Chris

Speaker: NA
Text: Richardson to say about the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition:

Speaker: NA
Text: He is an ideas man ... But ... too many ideas

Speaker: NA
Text: mean too many risks.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that that probably proved to be right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the ideas, which amounted to $6.5

Speaker: NA
Text: billion of spending over four years, included

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the baby bonus, changes to etha-

Speaker: NA
Text: nol subsidies and cutting fuel subsidies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Things that people had acknowledged as be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing important were played around with and

Speaker: NA
Text: then funds were redirected elsewhere. Fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: vouring tax cuts for those earning more than

Speaker: NA
Text: $80,000 a year did not seem consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party philosophy. The speedy release

Speaker: NA
Text: of federal land when demand is high was an

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting concept, but the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment holds little land compared with what is

Speaker: NA
Text: held by state governments. After all, the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government planning provisions would over-

Speaker: NA
Text: ride any federal government decisions in that

Speaker: NA
Text: area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The tweaking of immigration policy to

Speaker: NA
Text: boost incentives for migrants to settle outside

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney was an interesting idea. It has never

Speaker: NA
Text: worked anywhere in the world and would not

Speaker: NA
Text: work here either. Other ideas were: to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the superannuation contributions tax, to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide incentives for employee share owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and to provide matched savings ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: counts for low-income earners. If you are not

Speaker: NA
Text: earning much money, you do not have much

Speaker: NA
Text: to put into a savings account anyway. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not know quite how that would work. An-

Speaker: NA
Text: other idea was the beefing up of the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a mishmash of ideas that did not in-

Speaker: NA
Text: spire confidence, as compared with a steady

Speaker: NA
Text: program of confidence building that had

Speaker: NA
Text: been initiated by the coalition from the be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning of our term in office in 1996. On this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House we have worked consis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tently to build that confidence, to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the entrepreneurs, the small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: and the families of Australia have the confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: may dence to make decisions and invest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future, in their businesses, in their families,

Speaker: NA
Text: in their homes and in their neighbourhoods.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the confidence in the government that had

Speaker: NA
Text: been built up over that period of time was

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforced by a confused presentation from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is no more obvious than in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: of industrial relations, where productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: and real wages have risen massively under

Speaker: NA
Text: this government. That compares with a two

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent rise in real wages over a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 years under Labor and, generally, a very

Speaker: NA
Text: disheartened labour force which was more

Speaker: NA
Text: prone to strike and less happy with its em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment prospects than has been the experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence under this government. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureau of Statistics, in national accounts

Speaker: NA
Text: released in August 2004, showed that labour

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity grew by 3.8 per cent in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year. That is the largest increase

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity since the 4.3 per cent growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity in 1998. That just gives an idea

Speaker: NA
Text: of the trend-people working not harder but

Speaker: NA
Text: smarter and gaining better rewards for their

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts. Encouraging that attitude in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community has been a theme for this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. This is not a heavy-handed gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment but a light hand encouraging people

Speaker: NA
Text: in their workplace. That has borne fruit and

Speaker: NA
Text: has brought with it the confidence of growth

Speaker: NA
Text: and the confidence to re-elect the current

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The building industry, in particular, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the focus of economic and industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations reform. The Cole royal commission

Speaker: NA
Text: points to a number of areas where more re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form is needed. This government intends to

Speaker: NA
Text: go further in one area which I want to indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate as being significant. It is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: if the same sorts of practices and productiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity could be applied to commercial construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion as apply to residential construction

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a 25 per cent equivalent better out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come in commercial construction. The Cole

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commission identified shortcomings,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is this government's intention to move

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead and make further changes to both un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fair dismissal and the area of independent

Speaker: NA
Text: contractors.

Speaker: NA
Text: A survey conducted by the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne in 2002 found that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: state and federal unfair dismissal laws to

Speaker: NA
Text: small and medium business is about $1.3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion annually. It estimates the cost of the

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair dismissal process, both state and fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral, to be about 77,000 jobs. So we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of increasing the employment rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing unemployment by 77,000, through

Speaker: NA
Text: a simple change, not a harsh change. Note

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is not a harsh process, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 notifiable processes that are cemented in

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will remain there. They will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken out. It is the extraneous stuff that

Speaker: NA
Text: in makes it really hard for a small employer to

Speaker: NA
Text: get rid of somebody who is not performing,

Speaker: NA
Text: for fear of an unfair dismissal claim often

Speaker: NA
Text: running in the range of $10,000 to $20,000-

Speaker: NA
Text: something that small business cannot con-

Speaker: NA
Text: template and cannot take a risk on.

Speaker: NA
Text: More recently, the Sensis business index

Speaker: NA
Text: survey found that 28 per cent of small and

Speaker: NA
Text: medium businesses had decided not to take

Speaker: NA
Text: on additional employees because of the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of unfair dismissal action. The survey

Speaker: NA
Text: proved that this is a continuing concern for

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses in the building industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The independent contractors act will be initi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated after consultation with contractors.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are independent contractors who like

Speaker: NA
Text: the freedom to choose the working arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that suit them best. They do not want

Speaker: NA
Text: to be under the CFMEU. They want the free-

Speaker: NA
Text: that dom to make their own decisions about their

Speaker: NA
Text: hours and conditions of work. They do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be roped in by an aggressive union.

Speaker: NA
Text: there They do not want to be deemed employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: They want the freedoms that have been the

Speaker: NA
Text: very strength of the Australian residential

Speaker: NA
Text: construction industry-a strength that needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be extended.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other area in which I think the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament needs to give some lead is in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to urban water supply. I do not think there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a state government that is really tackling this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue in an effective way. I know it is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's constitutional responsibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity to supply water to the cities of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: but, of all organisations, the CSIRO seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: have done the most work to identify the dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficulties and propose solutions. Dr Grace

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitchell in a recent address in Canberra out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined a wide range of proven processes that

Speaker: NA
Text: can be beneficial in retaining water for reuse

Speaker: NA
Text: and for further conserving water on site. Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Grace Mitchell said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's self-sufficient suburb would have no

Speaker: NA
Text: potable water piped to homes and factories, and

Speaker: NA
Text: all residential, commercial and industrial waste

Speaker: NA
Text: water would be collected, treated

Speaker: NA
Text: a local waste water treatment plant.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is feasible, but it does sound radical.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within the Sydney region, stormwater from

Speaker: NA
Text: blocks of units and households is trapped

Speaker: NA
Text: but, in fact, none of that water is used on

Speaker: NA
Text: gardens or for domestic purposes. It is sent

Speaker: NA
Text: down the drain and out into the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Ocean. It seems a shocking waste. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that many within the nursery and building

Speaker: NA
Text: industries, as well as the residents of Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: think that Bob Carr's policy of ‘get used to

Speaker: NA
Text: it' is not good enough. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: Werriwa-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (3.47 p.m.)-On this day 150

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago more than 10,000 miners gathered

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Bakery Hill in Ballarat to protest their

Speaker: NA
Text: rights and demand democracy. At this meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, the Southern Cross flag was unfurled for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time, its dramatic design inspiring

Speaker: NA
Text: the miners to burn their licences and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue their campaign against unfair taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the unfair use of colonial power. The

Speaker: NA
Text: next day, Peter Lawler led a group of miners

Speaker: NA
Text: to Eureka, where they built their stockade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Three days later, on 3 December, the troops

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked and the battle of Eureka was fought

Speaker: NA
Text: out-one of the most important events and

Speaker: NA
Text: legends in the history of our country. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should not let this parliamentary week pass

Speaker: NA
Text: without honouring the significance of

Speaker: NA
Text: Eureka. It says so much about the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: character and identity: our love of the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: dog and support for those who have a go; our

Speaker: NA
Text: willingness to stand up for our rights, to not

Speaker: NA
Text: buckle in the face of authority; our tradition

Speaker: NA
Text: of defiance, dissent and the larrikin spirit that

Speaker: NA
Text: makes us truly Australian. This is why

Speaker: NA
Text: Eureka is often described as the birthplace of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian democracy, where we learn the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of human rights and the great

Speaker: NA
Text: values of a free society; that individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: should be able to express themselves freely,

Speaker: NA
Text: to protest and mobilise politically without

Speaker: NA
Text: being punished by the oppressive power of

Speaker: NA
Text: and recycled by the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Can I just say how glad I am that the spirit

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Eureka rebellion is alive in the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber today, with so many of the preselectors

Speaker: NA
Text: of Wentworth here to listen to the parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary debates. The spirit of rebellion was free

Speaker: NA
Text: in their own preselection decisions when

Speaker: NA
Text: they sent Peter King away, burning his min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers licence, and stood up for their rights to

Speaker: NA
Text: preselect a new member for Wentworth, from

Speaker: NA
Text: whom we are about to hear for the first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: An incident having occurred in the gal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lery-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins)-The gallery should come to order!

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: I welcome their applause

Speaker: NA
Text: because never have so many people from

Speaker: NA
Text: Vaucluse travelled so far to also listen to me

Speaker: NA
Text: in the parliamentary forum.

Speaker: NA
Text: An incident having occurred in the gal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lery-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition should be neither dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tracted nor overly encouraged by the gallery.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: I am reminded of the

Speaker: NA
Text: great words of John Lennon. Perhaps, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stead of applause, they could just jangle their

Speaker: NA
Text: jewellery and make their noise known

Speaker: NA
Text: around the chamber. Mr Speaker, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not well amused, but I hope they enjoy the

Speaker: NA
Text: following speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eureka also established the great Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian tradition of social diversity. Only two of

Speaker: NA
Text: the miners were said to be Australian born;

Speaker: NA
Text: others came from lands like California, Ire-

Speaker: NA
Text: land, Italy, Germany, Jamaica, China and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, Britain. In its diversity, its spirit

Speaker: NA
Text: its egalitarianism, this was the first multicul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural community in Australia and, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: violence of the stockade, it worked. It

Speaker: NA
Text: worked in its rich ethnic background and

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of common purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was the vision proclaimed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bakery Hill by the Italian rebel leader Raf-

Speaker: NA
Text: faelo Carboni, who called on the miners-

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of nationality, religion and col-

Speaker: NA
Text: our-to salute the Southern Cross as the ref-

Speaker: NA
Text: uge of all the oppressed from all the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries of the earth. It was a community of fair-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness, a community of nations. The miners of

Speaker: NA
Text: course had diverse backgrounds as trades-

Speaker: NA
Text: men, lawyers, doctors, sailors, farmers and

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanics. History tells us there was even a

Speaker: NA
Text: politician present at Eureka, the President of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria's Legislative Council, Sir John

Speaker: NA
Text: Palmer-not the first politician, of course, to

Speaker: NA
Text: have gone digging for gold nor the last. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: refrain from the obvious comment about the

Speaker: NA
Text: next speaker. It is a terrible shame that

Speaker: NA
Text: cians in the Howard government are not par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipating in the first sesquicentenary cele-

Speaker: NA
Text: bration of Eureka in Ballarat. The celebration

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be held this week, and of course the

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrations started last week. I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian government, the Ballarat Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil and also the member for Ballarat for par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipating in and organising such a great

Speaker: NA
Text: round of celebrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister obviously sees this as

Speaker: NA
Text: a Labor style celebration. But no one party

Speaker: NA
Text: has a final claim on Eureka. It is a political

Speaker: NA
Text: event that can be embraced by different parts

Speaker: NA
Text: of the spectrum. A campaign against high

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes and the oppressive power of the state

Speaker: NA
Text: are not uncommon themes for right of centre

Speaker: NA
Text: parties around the world, so why is it that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has effectively placed a boy-

Speaker: NA
Text: cott on the Eureka celebrations? In fact, one

Speaker: NA
Text: of his predecessors at the time of the centen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary of Eureka, in 1954, Prime Minister Men-

Speaker: NA
Text: and zies, who in fact went to school in Ballarat,

Speaker: NA
Text: described Eureka as a movement for the

Speaker: NA
Text: proper control of public finances. He would

Speaker: NA
Text: say that, of course. On our side of politics,

Speaker: NA
Text: the left of centre, we take inspiration from

Speaker: NA
Text: the struggle of the workers, the great nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: alism, the great patriotism of the movement

Speaker: NA
Text: and, of course, the struggle for democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: and human rights. So I say we should all

Speaker: NA
Text: share in the celebration of the Eureka spirit.

Speaker: NA
Text: As Australians, as patriots, we should all

Speaker: NA
Text: have the maturity and confidence in our own

Speaker: NA
Text: views and values to embrace the legend of

Speaker: NA
Text: Eureka.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is regrettable that the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has refused to fly the flag above Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: House and has rejected the member for Bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: larat's private members bill to give the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eureka flag official status. However, like the

Speaker: NA
Text: miners, we struggle on. I congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: state and local government authorities who

Speaker: NA
Text: will be flying the flag and the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: politiparliament who will display it in various

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the building. We, too, shall salute the

Speaker: NA
Text: Southern Cross. This boycott of Eureka high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lights one of the great flaws in the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government: its meanness and its divisive-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness-in this case expressed through its ig-

Speaker: NA
Text: norance of Australian political history. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is often fond of saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: the things that unite us as Australians are

Speaker: NA
Text: more important than things that divide us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, surely one of the things that unite the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation is our love of Australian history, our

Speaker: NA
Text: love of Australian culture and heritage, our

Speaker: NA
Text: love of the Eureka legend. It should have

Speaker: NA
Text: been celebrated by all the parties in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. We should all have been represented

Speaker: NA
Text: to share in the historical significance of that

Speaker: NA
Text: great event. But this is the meanness and

Speaker: NA
Text: divisiveness of the Howard government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This leads me to the second theme in this

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the address of the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General: the government's neglect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: education, training and skills development

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda-an area of meanness in the alloca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of public investment that is costing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia dearly. In fact, this great debate about

Speaker: NA
Text: education, training and skill development is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the longest-running debates in the

Speaker: NA
Text: history of the Howard government. Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: made the point in 1996 that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: was setting down a path of underinvestment

Speaker: NA
Text: in the basic skills of the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The biggest cut in the first budget of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard-Costello government was to educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Their biggest and harshest cut in that

Speaker: NA
Text: first budget was to education and training

Speaker: NA
Text: investments. We warned then of the folly of

Speaker: NA
Text: underinvesting in the skills of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people. The government's decision-the

Speaker: NA
Text: eightor nine-year underinvestment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills of the Australian people-defies the

Speaker: NA
Text: logic and the true meaning of the new econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The basic message heard by economists,

Speaker: NA
Text: financial experts and indeed workers right

Speaker: NA
Text: around the world is that jobs based on mus-

Speaker: NA
Text: cle and machine power are disappearing; the

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs of the future are coming from brain

Speaker: NA
Text: power. The best investment a nation can

Speaker: NA
Text: make in its future is to invest heavily in the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and capabilities of its people. The

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest mistake of the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: has been to ignore that lesson and underin-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest over eight or nine years. Of course, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are now seeing the critical skills shortage in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia damaging our prospects for future

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity. It gives the Labor Party no joy in

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing out this historic error-the failure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government over a long period of time to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest properly in skills-and now the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage is one of the greatest threats to our

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term prosperity as a nation. It is leading

Speaker: NA
Text: to capacity constraints, putting pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses and, of course, putting upward

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure on interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me just give the House some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: key figures. I welcome the fact that the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister is at the table. Earlier, in question time,

Speaker: NA
Text: he was trying to deny these basic realities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Skills growth, as a driver of productivity in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, has dropped 75 per cent in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years-that is a Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: statistic. The Australian Industry Group, in

Speaker: NA
Text: its submission to the Senate skills inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: reported that over half of the businesses sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: veyed face skills shortages in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely a government that cares about busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness capacity and economic expansion would

Speaker: NA
Text: be moving quickly to address this skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage, especially given its failure over the

Speaker: NA
Text: past eight or nine years. It is also estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that skills shortages will cost the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy $9 billion in lost output over the

Speaker: NA
Text: coming decade. That is the economic cost to

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation of the government's neglect: $9

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in lost output over the coming decade,

Speaker: NA
Text: with $20 billion worth of major infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture and resources projects in jeopardy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreover, there are currently between

Speaker: NA
Text: 18,000 and 21,000 unfilled vacancies for

Speaker: NA
Text: tradespersons in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hardgrave interjecting-

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: The minister says, ‘The

Speaker: NA
Text: government talks about trades.' Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: how about investing in the trades to fill the

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage? There are nearly 22,000 unfilled

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancies for tradespersons in Australia. If

Speaker: NA
Text: this government had been investing in trades

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of just talking about them over the

Speaker: NA
Text: last nine years that figure would not stand

Speaker: NA
Text: there as a major blockage to the prospects of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy. It is also estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the number of apprenticeships in tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional trades has dropped 15 per cent under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government. So there is a record

Speaker: NA
Text: of neglect, and all the minister can do in

Speaker: NA
Text: question time is make the cheapest points to

Speaker: NA
Text: try and overcome the neglect of the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government over a long period of time. What

Speaker: NA
Text: has been the government's response? What

Speaker: NA
Text: do we find in the Governor-General's ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress to the parliament? The government's

Speaker: NA
Text: plan is to build a series of federally con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trolled and run technical colleges to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: reinvent the wheel. The skills shortage is

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting Australia right now. We do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: four years to waste, four years to wait for

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of these technical colleges.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is wrong with investing in TAFE right

Speaker: NA
Text: now to build a world-class training and voca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional education system? Why wait four

Speaker: NA
Text: years, Minister? Why wait four years to

Speaker: NA
Text: solve a problem that threatens the prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian economy right now?

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister and the government need to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the neglect. They need to recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: these figures and they need to do better than

Speaker: NA
Text: a four-year wait to build the infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: and invest in the capacity of Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop their skills. What is wrong with in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vesting in TAFE right now? There is no need

Speaker: NA
Text: to reinvent the wheel. We need the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in TAFE right now. In fact, this would

Speaker: NA
Text: be the most efficient use of public money.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why reinvent the wheel and build a new sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem that involves duplication of resources,

Speaker: NA
Text: red tape, more administration and bureauc-

Speaker: NA
Text: racy? Isn't the whole purpose to get scarce

Speaker: NA
Text: public resources into the education and train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing system for the benefit of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people? So wouldn't it be wise for this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to not have to reinvent the wheel-a

Speaker: NA
Text: separate system with its own administration

Speaker: NA
Text: systems, its own bureaucracy and its own red

Speaker: NA
Text: tape? Why duplicate the system when we

Speaker: NA
Text: could invest in TAFE right now, put in the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal resources and build a world-class

Speaker: NA
Text: system?

Speaker: NA
Text: There are further problems with the dupli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, the reinvention of the wheel through

Speaker: NA
Text: these technical colleges. Will there be ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: creditation of courses for students? Say a

Speaker: NA
Text: student goes to year 11 in a technical college

Speaker: NA
Text: in a particular part of the country and then

Speaker: NA
Text: the family moves to another part of the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try where there is no federally run and man-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged college. Will there be accreditation of

Speaker: NA
Text: those courses when they go to the local

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE or the local school that specialises in

Speaker: NA
Text: the technical skills? Also, will there be port-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability for teaching staff? Will there be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: the sistency of the curricula between the various

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions? The minister just shakes his

Speaker: NA
Text: head. It is going to fall off soon. He does not

Speaker: NA
Text: know the answers to these basic propositions

Speaker: NA
Text: that are fundamental to solving the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: It defies the Prime Minister's own advice

Speaker: NA
Text: at the recent Local Government Association

Speaker: NA
Text: conference about the best way of getting a

Speaker: NA
Text: solution to a public policy problem. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Prime Minister said at the Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Association convention in Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra on 10 November:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... we really have a responsibility to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: present system of government work as efficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible and one of the ways in which we do

Speaker: NA
Text: that is to recognise that nothing is more destruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive of the efficient working of the present system

Speaker: NA
Text: of government than for any level to engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: cost shifting, to recognise that if you do have a

Speaker: NA
Text: division of responsibilities and particular levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: government are given resources they have a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility to use those resources wisely to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charge their responsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Applied to the skills shortage, applied to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of training and vocational education

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, that statement by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is a recommendation to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE: don't duplicate, don't cost-shift, don't

Speaker: NA
Text: reinvent the wheel; invest in TAFE right now

Speaker: NA
Text: to solve the critical skills shortage in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. That is Labor's approach. Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: approach is to ensure that in the future TAFE

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a world-class system, that we invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in it, that we build quality, that we build efficapability

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency, that we build the outcomes that are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed for a skills revival in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is talking about trades but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not investing in them, and it will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: a solution to the problem that we have right

Speaker: NA
Text: now until four years down the track, if and

Speaker: NA
Text: when these technical colleges are constructed

Speaker: NA
Text: and open.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's approach is to build a world-class

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE system, and I am sure that employers

Speaker: NA
Text: in small and large businesses right around

Speaker: NA
Text: the country looking for a solution right now

Speaker: NA
Text: would see the sense in our approach. There

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a lot of questioning of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's long delay in addressing this prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem; of the duplication; of the extra admini-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration and bureaucracy; and of the issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: portability and accreditation. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is yet to answer any of these questions,

Speaker: NA
Text: but right now businesses are looking for an

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to the skills shortage. Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: homebuyers of course want the skills short-

Speaker: NA
Text: age and the capacity constraints addressed so

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is less pressure on interest rates in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor support the TAFE system; we want

Speaker: NA
Text: to make it truly world class and we want to

Speaker: NA
Text: put it in the framework of lifelong learning.

Speaker: NA
Text: The skills of the Australian people rely on

Speaker: NA
Text: lifelong learning, not just at TAFE but right

Speaker: NA
Text: through the education system. Early child-

Speaker: NA
Text: hood development is the great area of under-

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and neglect by the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. They have been talking about an

Speaker: NA
Text: early childhood agenda for eight years but

Speaker: NA
Text: they are doing nothing. Labor want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: early childhood development extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: principles of public education into child care

Speaker: NA
Text: and preschool. We recognise that learning

Speaker: NA
Text: does not start on the first day of school; it

Speaker: NA
Text: starts on the first day of life. Around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, there is recognition that we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest early in our young people-invest

Speaker: NA
Text: early in their literacy, their skills and their

Speaker: NA
Text: and extend the principles of public

Speaker: NA
Text: education into the child-care and preschool

Speaker: NA
Text: system.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, too, Labor want to invest properly in

Speaker: NA
Text: our schools with a needs based funding sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem. Early development of skills and ensur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that every school in this country is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good school: this is the basis of Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: school funding policy. It defines a new na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional standard of resources and excellence

Speaker: NA
Text: for all Australian schools, government and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government, and then allocates funding

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of need, ensuring that 9½ thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sand underresourced schools can reach the

Speaker: NA
Text: new national standard as quickly as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government of course has attacked

Speaker: NA
Text: this policy for its reallocation of resources

Speaker: NA
Text: away from 67 wealthy schools identified in

Speaker: NA
Text: the election campaign-schools which have

Speaker: NA
Text: already exceeded the funding benchmark in

Speaker: NA
Text: their fee income alone. However, given the

Speaker: NA
Text: limited nature of government funding, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no logical alternative to this approach. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution is not only a fair policy; it is also

Speaker: NA
Text: the most efficient way of achieving a rigor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous national standard. Indeed, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: point in governments establishing a national

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to schooling unless they are willing

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect its integrity. The sooner all schools

Speaker: NA
Text: can reach an acceptable standard, the sooner

Speaker: NA
Text: governments can maximise the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: families in Australia that realise their aspira-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for the education of their children. The

Speaker: NA
Text: skills base would be set in the early years

Speaker: NA
Text: through school, and then they would build on

Speaker: NA
Text: that through a world-class TAFE system.

Speaker: NA
