Text: Labor's schools policy is not a punish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policy; it is an efficient and fair way of

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving a vital national goal: all schools

Speaker: NA
Text: offering their students a quality education

Speaker: NA
Text: and a decent start to life. In the name of

Speaker: NA
Text: uity, why should schools without libraries

Speaker: NA
Text: and computers wait any longer for fair fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing when schools with boatsheds and rifle

Speaker: NA
Text: ranges have been overfunded for quite some

Speaker: NA
Text: time? These are already successful schools

Speaker: NA
Text: and they would remain successful, with a

Speaker: NA
Text: high standard of classroom excellence, under

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are on about is an aspirational

Speaker: NA
Text: policy-aspirational not just for the few but

Speaker: NA
Text: for all parents and students;

Speaker: NA
Text: just for the King's School and Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: Grammar but for every Australian school.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is about defining a common standard, a

Speaker: NA
Text: national standard, and needs based funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for government and non-government schools

Speaker: NA
Text: alike. Why should people who do not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: school that is up to scratch because of under-

Speaker: NA
Text: resourcing wait any longer to realise their

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate aspirations for the skills develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of their children and the education of

Speaker: NA
Text: the next generation? Under this policy, 2½

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand needy private schools would bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit from the needs based funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beyond that-beyond early childhood de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment, needs based school funding and a

Speaker: NA
Text: world-class TAFE system-we need access

Speaker: NA
Text: and affordability in the higher education sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem in this country. Beyond that, we need a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to adult and community educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-to skills for life-through the renewal

Speaker: NA
Text: of education and vocational capacity across a

Speaker: NA
Text: full lifespan.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the critical issues. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: blending of economic and education policy;

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the area where the government has got it

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. These two issues need to come to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether. There is no more pressing issue for

Speaker: NA
Text: the management of the economy than the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills shortage. There is no more pressing

Speaker: NA
Text: area of government neglect than the underin-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in TAFE, the underinvestment in

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational education and training. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: eqbeen an historic underinvestment for eight or

Speaker: NA
Text: nine years, and that is why the figures are so

Speaker: NA
Text: bad. That is why we have the Australian In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry Group reporting that over half of the

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses surveyed in Australia face skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortages.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: The government back-

Speaker: NA
Text: bench think it is funny. They claim to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent business and trade interests, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not invest in the trades to overcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: aspirational not skills shortages.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister has no answer for these

Speaker: NA
Text: things. He cannot give a basic answer as to

Speaker: NA
Text: why the government will not invest in TAFE.

Speaker: NA
Text: He cannot give a basic answer as to why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to take four years to build the technical

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges. He cannot give a basic answer as to

Speaker: NA
Text: why they should try to reinvent the wheel

Speaker: NA
Text: with duplication, new bureaucracy and new

Speaker: NA
Text: administration. He cannot give answers

Speaker: NA
Text: about accreditation of courses or portability

Speaker: NA
Text: of staff. There is an answer, Minister, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is called TAFE. It is time that this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment invested in it properly and addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills shortage that way. These are the

Speaker: NA
Text: critical issues that come out of the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's address.

Speaker: NA
Text: I again welcome the preselectors of Wen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tworth to this fine chamber. I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the new member for Wentworth on his long

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle to arrive in this place; we look for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward with great interest and anticipation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the things that he is about to tell the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Wentworth, I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that this is the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's first speech. I ask the House to extend

Speaker: NA
Text: the usual courtesies.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth) (4.07

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I am proud and honoured to address

Speaker: NA
Text: this House today as the member for Wen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tworth, whose people I thank for the great

Speaker: NA
Text: trust they have reposed in me. Each of us

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to this House to represent our own

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, each unique, each making up

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-the home all of us are pledged to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve. Wentworth's green hills and golden

Speaker: NA
Text: beaches are strung like jewels between the

Speaker: NA
Text: harbour and the sea. From the tropical gullies

Speaker: NA
Text: of Bronte and Cooper Park to the urban bus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tle of Bondi Junction and Double Bay, from

Speaker: NA
Text: the sheltered rock pools of Watsons Bay to

Speaker: NA
Text: the thundering surf at Tamarama, Wen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tworth's geography is as varied and engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: as its people.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not a big place. You can paddle a surf

Speaker: NA
Text: ski from one end to the other in an hour,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is not a lot longer than it takes to drive

Speaker: NA
Text: in peak traffic. Wentworth's most endearing

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect is perhaps its least well known. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary to popular myth, our community is

Speaker: NA
Text: egalitarian, democratic and far from ho-

Speaker: NA
Text: mogenous. Like many of Wentworth's resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents, I grew up living in flats-mostly

Speaker: NA
Text: rented-and, in the style of the times, with

Speaker: NA
Text: small rooms running off a long, dark corri-

Speaker: NA
Text: dor. I did not feel deprived of anything-

Speaker: NA
Text: apart, perhaps, from a dog. I was rarely in-

Speaker: NA
Text: side. The best things in Wentworth-the

Speaker: NA
Text: waves at Bondi, the ducks at Centennial Park

Speaker: NA
Text: or even the brisk nor'easter whipping down

Speaker: NA
Text: the harbour on a summer's day-take no

Speaker: NA
Text: account of your bank balance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most mornings my father and I went for a

Speaker: NA
Text: swim at North Bondi Surf Club. The surf

Speaker: NA
Text: club showers were no respecters of rank or

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege. Our companions included judges

Speaker: NA
Text: and garbos, teachers and policemen and

Speaker: NA
Text: businessmen of all types-from shmattas in

Speaker: NA
Text: Surry Hills to high finance in Martin Place.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were surgeons whose hands saved

Speaker: NA
Text: lives and there were gentlemen whose cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: loused hands were used, in a rather emphatic

Speaker: NA
Text: manner, to collect debts for bookies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth was multicultural before the

Speaker: NA
Text: term was invented. Our prayers fly heaven-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward, not just in English but in the language

Speaker: NA
Text: of the New Testament at St George's Greek

Speaker: NA
Text: church, of the Old Testament at Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Synagogue and our many other shuls and, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you believe the Irish-and who would doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: them?-just once a year in the tongue of the

Speaker: NA
Text: angels themselves at St Patrick's in Bondi.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth has the largest Jewish commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity in our city. The community has grown

Speaker: NA
Text: stronger with successive waves of immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from Europe, from Russia, from Israel

Speaker: NA
Text: and from South Africa. Their generous

Speaker: NA
Text: community spirit, their family pride and tire-

Speaker: NA
Text: less enterprise are admired by all of us. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is a good friend of Israel, the Middle

Speaker: NA
Text: East's only democracy. We have been reso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lute in supporting Israel's right to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary steps to defend itself from terror.

Speaker: NA
Text: The death of Arafat has now opened up new

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for peace based on the road-

Speaker: NA
Text: map-two states within secure, internation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally recognised boundaries. We must hope

Speaker: NA
Text: and pray that all parties, in the words of King

Speaker: NA
Text: David's 34th Psalm, do not merely ‘seek'

Speaker: NA
Text: peace but ‘pursue' it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth is a federation seat and its rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives have been as distinguished as

Speaker: NA
Text: the great colonial statesman after whom it is

Speaker: NA
Text: named. The longest serving, Sir Eric Harri-

Speaker: NA
Text: son, was Sir Robert Menzies' deputy and a

Speaker: NA
Text: co-founder of the Liberal Party 60 years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: I salute all my predecessors and thank them

Speaker: NA
Text: for their service, which has set a high bar for

Speaker: NA
Text: my own.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was an only child, and my parents split

Speaker: NA
Text: when I was nine. My father, Bruce Turnbull,

Speaker: NA
Text: was a single parent for much of my child-

Speaker: NA
Text: hood. All divorces are difficult and painful.

Speaker: NA
Text: My parents' was no exception. My mother

Speaker: NA
Text: had moved overseas. My father and I moved

Speaker: NA
Text: into a smaller flat. Yet my father never spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: a critical word in my presence about my

Speaker: NA
Text: mother, nor she about him. He went to the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest pains to ensure, very successfully,

Speaker: NA
Text: that my mother and I remained on the most

Speaker: NA
Text: loving terms. I was very close to my parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: both of whom died long ago and far too

Speaker: NA
Text: young. I thank them for their great love.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will work here to defend and promote

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage and families. We must do more to

Speaker: NA
Text: help families stay together. When divorce

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs, we must do all we can to help par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents, no matter how bitter their differences,

Speaker: NA
Text: to support each other's vital role in the life

Speaker: NA
Text: their children. I am proud to be part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that has already made great

Speaker: NA
Text: strides to make family law more about fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies and less about divorce. But we must al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways remember that those of us with intact

Speaker: NA
Text: families owe as much to providence, or good

Speaker: NA
Text: fortune, as we do to commitment and in this,

Speaker: NA
Text: as in so many other areas of social policy, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not called to judge or preach, only to help

Speaker: NA
Text: and to heal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like most children who live in Wentworth

Speaker: NA
Text: my father chose to send me to an independ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent school. I boarded at Sydney Grammar

Speaker: NA
Text: from the age of eight as my father, a hotel

Speaker: NA
Text: broker, travelled around New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: on business. Sometimes when I was at home

Speaker: NA
Text: on school holidays he would take me with

Speaker: NA
Text: him, often to complete a stocktake before a

Speaker: NA
Text: pub was sold. I was counting beer glasses

Speaker: NA
Text: long before I was old enough to drink out of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. My father found paying the school

Speaker: NA
Text: fees was often a struggle, but he chose to

Speaker: NA
Text: postpone other things like buying a flat of

Speaker: NA
Text: our own so that I could go to the school he

Speaker: NA
Text: chose for me.

Speaker: NA
Text: This came back to me vividly when the

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign was in full swing and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party was declaring that so-called elite

Speaker: NA
Text: schools deserved little or no government

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. I knew exactly which parents that

Speaker: NA
Text: policy would hurt the most: the battlers, the

Speaker: NA
Text: renters, the Bruce Turnbulls of today, who

Speaker: NA
Text: choose to sacrifice personal comforts so they

Speaker: NA
Text: can give their children the education they

Speaker: NA
Text: have chosen for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I met the love of my life in 1978. Lucy

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes was 19 and I was 23. She was smart

Speaker: NA
Text: and happy. She shone with love and opti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mism, as she does today. I immediately pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed and, two years later, she relented and

Speaker: NA
Text: we were married. Lucy has been my partner

Speaker: NA
Text: in life and in love, in law and in business. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to all that, and bringing up our chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: of dren, she was the first woman to be Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord Mayor and then Lord Mayor of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: She oversaw the expansion of the city's

Speaker: NA
Text: boundaries into Kings Cross and Glebe, and

Speaker: NA
Text: her disarming charm and keen vision are

Speaker: NA
Text: sorely missed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lucy and our daughter, Daisy, who is at

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney University, are here today. Our son,

Speaker: NA
Text: Alex, also at University, is overseas watch-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing us on the Internet. Lucy's mother, Jo-

Speaker: NA
Text: anna, is with us today, as is her father, Tom

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes, and his wife, Chrissie. Tom was a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of this House for nine years and At-

Speaker: NA
Text: torney-General in the Gorton government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: could not have asked for a more loyal friend

Speaker: NA
Text: or a better role model.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apart from loading bananas in the city

Speaker: NA
Text: markets, my first real job was as a journal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ist-a political correspondent at state parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I suppose it was just downhill from

Speaker: NA
Text: that noble calling into 25 years of law and

Speaker: NA
Text: business. Lucy and I have found that much

Speaker: NA
Text: of our satisfaction in business has come from

Speaker: NA
Text: starting new enterprises: creating new jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and new markets for Australian technology.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our life's experience has been that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: little reward without risk. We believe Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's economy and prosperity depend on a

Speaker: NA
Text: culture of initiative and enterprise which

Speaker: NA
Text: supports Australians doing what we do

Speaker: NA
Text: best-having a go-and, when things do not

Speaker: NA
Text: succeed, getting up and having another go.

Speaker: NA
Text: Big public companies and multinationals

Speaker: NA
Text: are no strangers to the political process.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the smaller, newer and more entre-

Speaker: NA
Text: preneurial businesses often feel disconnected

Speaker: NA
Text: or crowded out. The cost of regulatory com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pliance falls especially heavily on small and

Speaker: NA
Text: medium sized businesses. We need to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that no regulation and no compliance burden

Speaker: NA
Text: is imposed on business unless it is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary and the policy objective cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved in any other way. I hope that my

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in the small and medium business

Speaker: NA
Text: sector will enable those men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: who are the very engine of our nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: growth to become better understood, as our

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament makes laws that affect them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe passionately that politics is for

Speaker: NA
Text: people. It is not an elite sport played only

Speaker: NA
Text: members of parliament. All my life I have

Speaker: NA
Text: practised active citizenship. It is why I first

Speaker: NA
Text: joined the Liberal Party in 1973. It is why I

Speaker: NA
Text: ran for parliament. It is why I have written

Speaker: NA
Text: and spoken, often controversially, on some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the big issues that await us in the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: decades. It is why I am a director of Clean

Speaker: NA
Text: Up Australia, our largest grassroots environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental action group. It is why for nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: eight years, as a private citizen, I was chairing

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the Australian Republican Move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am for the republic: Australia's head of

Speaker: NA
Text: state should be one of us. The republic de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate brought together many Australians from

Speaker: NA
Text: both sides of politics. The constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: convention, which sat in the Old Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: House and in which many in this room par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipated, was a splendid moment of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian democracy-when a common love of

Speaker: NA
Text: country cracked the frosted lens of partisan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship, and every speech on every side was

Speaker: NA
Text: from a patriotic heart.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within the lifetimes of most of us, and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly in the lifetimes of our children,

Speaker: NA
Text: world we know today will be transformed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Improved life expectancy and the sharp de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cline in fertility are resulting in the old and

Speaker: NA
Text: very old making up a larger percentage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's population, a slowdown-if not a

Speaker: NA
Text: decline-in the labour force and, in many

Speaker: NA
Text: countries, a decline in the overall population

Speaker: NA
Text: itself. In the developed world only the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States has a total fertility or birth rate

Speaker: NA
Text: at replacement level of 2.1. Ours is 1.7. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan and most of Europe it is 1.3 or lower.

Speaker: NA
Text: This phenomenon has been described as

Speaker: NA
Text: an ‘ageing population'. That is a glib and

Speaker: NA
Text: slippery euphemism. Societies such as those

Speaker: NA
Text: in Italy, Spain, Greece, Russia and many

Speaker: NA
Text: others in Europe with birth rates of 1.3 or

Speaker: NA
Text: lower are not ageing, they are dying. A popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation with a birth rate of 1.3 will, absent

Speaker: NA
Text: by immigration, shrink by 75 per cent over 100

Speaker: NA
Text: years. This would mean that if Italy, for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, has the same population in a century

Speaker: NA
Text: as it does today, less than a quarter of that

Speaker: NA
Text: future population will be the descendants of

Speaker: NA
Text: today's Italians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Can it be true that at the peak of our tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology and prosperity the western world is

Speaker: NA
Text: losing the confidence to reproduce itself?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are we witnessing the beginning of the dy-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the West? Certainly we are at a tipping

Speaker: NA
Text: point in our civilisation's story. Unless fertil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity rates dramatically improve then, in a cy-

Speaker: NA
Text: cle of loss and dislocation matched only by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Black Death in the 14th century, societies

Speaker: NA
Text: with birth rates substantially below replace-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment level will either dwindle into an insig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant fraction of their current numbers or

Speaker: NA
Text: be swamped by larger and larger waves of

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our welfare state was devised in days

Speaker: NA
Text: when fertility was higher, life expectancy

Speaker: NA
Text: was shorter, medical costs were lower and

Speaker: NA
Text: the percentage of the population over 65 was

Speaker: NA
Text: a fraction of what it is today. Within 40 years

Speaker: NA
Text: the the over 65s will double as a percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's population, from 12 to 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. In countries such as Japan with lower

Speaker: NA
Text: birth rates it will be closer to 40 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: China is not exempt; it may be the first

Speaker: NA
Text: try to get old before it gets rich.

Speaker: NA
Text: Demography is indeed destiny. America's

Speaker: NA
Text: global leadership is reinforced by its strong

Speaker: NA
Text: population. The Economist has estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: by 2050 the US population will not only

Speaker: NA
Text: have overtaken that of Europe but that the

Speaker: NA
Text: median age of Europeans will be 53-17

Speaker: NA
Text: years older than Americans and 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: older than Australians. These changes to our

Speaker: NA
Text: population and their consequence of very

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially increased demands on govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for health and aged care will preoccupy

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament and its counterparts in other

Speaker: NA
Text: nations for the rest of this century.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is well prepared to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: these challenges, as we have seen laid out in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer's groundbreaking Intergenera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Report of 2002. More than the leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship of any other developed country, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government has not only recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: these demographic changes and their impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations but moved to meet them. There is,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, no room for complacency. The

Speaker: NA
Text: demographic storm is coming. How hard it

Speaker: NA
Text: blows and how well our children weather it

Speaker: NA
Text: will depend in large measure on the deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions we take today and our maintaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: courageous and determined leadership of the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 8½ years. A strong Australia in a chang-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing world will be one committed to enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prise, self-reliance, economic growth and,

Speaker: NA
Text: above all, high productivity. It will be an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that recognises that we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in strengthening, promoting and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fending marriage and family life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sound economic management has reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: government debt to the lowest in the OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: and created the conditions for long-term sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable economic growth. Other countries

Speaker: NA
Text: combine soaring levels of government debt

Speaker: NA
Text: and unfunded pension and retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes. We, on the other hand, have a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and growing superannuation and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: counvestment savings culture. The continued

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion of savings and self-reliance will

Speaker: NA
Text: be of vital concern for this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Productivity Commission reminded

Speaker: NA
Text: us only last week, our economy is driven by

Speaker: NA
Text: three Ps: population, participation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: work force and productivity. With slow

Speaker: NA
Text: growth or no growth in the labour force, the

Speaker: NA
Text: only factor which can drive our economy this

Speaker: NA
Text: century will be improving productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be growing claims on govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in the years ahead; only higher pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity can generate the revenues to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no conflict between good public

Speaker: NA
Text: health and education on the one hand and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic reform and productivity on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other. Nothing increases choice or widens the

Speaker: NA
Text: horizons of families more than a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Indeed, without the tax revenues

Speaker: NA
Text: that only a strong economy can deliver and a

Speaker: NA
Text: government capable of keeping that econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy strong, even the warmest words and

Speaker: NA
Text: kindest hearts will bring cold comfort to the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged and the sick.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our birth rate is higher than that of most

Speaker: NA
Text: comparable countries, but it is in the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest that it decline no further and ideally

Speaker: NA
Text: increase. The government's family policies

Speaker: NA
Text: have already helped more parents have the

Speaker: NA
Text: families they want. But, just as the causes for

Speaker: NA
Text: this unprecedented decline in fertility are

Speaker: NA
Text: debatable, so are the appropriate policy re-

Speaker: NA
Text: vital sponses unclear. Over time some will be

Speaker: NA
Text: more effective than others. Pragmatism, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience and commonsense will be better

Speaker: NA
Text: guides than ideology. There is nothing any of

Speaker: NA
Text: us are likely to do which is more important

Speaker: NA
Text: for the future of this nation than raise chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren. Motherhood and fatherhood have been

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly devalued, and this has occurred to

Speaker: NA
Text: our grave cost. We must affirm that children

Speaker: NA
Text: are a social good and not merely a private

Speaker: NA
Text: optional pleasure. Australia's children are

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's future. They are our future. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must work to enhance rather than restrict

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians' work and family choices and

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that it is desirable for women, if

Speaker: NA
Text: they wish, to fulfil two goals: child-bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: and a career. Our society's survival depends

Speaker: NA
Text: on making it possible and easier for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: do both.

Speaker: NA
Text: More workplace flexibility with all it en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tails is not an option but a necessity, and not

Speaker: NA
Text: just for parents. The worthwhile objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: longer participation by older Australians in

Speaker: NA
Text: the work force will also require more flexible

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces. We have the technology. All that

Speaker: NA
Text: is required now is commitment and imagina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We need to continue to expand the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's skills based immigration program

Speaker: NA
Text: in addition to meeting our humanitarian ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ligations. Our immigration program is essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tially a recruiting exercise conducted in the

Speaker: NA
Text: national interest of Australia. It is a competipolling

Speaker: NA
Text: tive world and we want as many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's enterprising and energetic to join and

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen our Australian family.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we wish all other nations tranquil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lity and prosperity, the fact is that troubled

Speaker: NA
Text: times in other lands have brought many mi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants to Australia. The social problems aris-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from demographic change in other coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries are likely to bring many more highly

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified immigrants to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: More, perhaps, than any other people,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are particularly mobile and em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployable around the world. Already one mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion of us are working and living overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: High skills and easy familiarity with other

Speaker: NA
Text: cultures make Australians citizens of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. But immigration is a two-way street.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a revolving door, in fact. If we are un-

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive, if our economy falters and if

Speaker: NA
Text: our personal income tax rates remain rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively high or become higher, we run the

Speaker: NA
Text: very real risk that our best talent will leave,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in large numbers. In some recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand, for example, has suffered a net

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of nearly one per cent of its native born

Speaker: NA
Text: population.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just populations which are chang-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. So, apparently, is our weather. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: assume on the basis of current science that

Speaker: NA
Text: our world is getting warmer and our country,

Speaker: NA
Text: at least, drier. I am proud to be part of a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment which has led the way in the better

Speaker: NA
Text: management of our water resources. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time a federal government has shown it

Speaker: NA
Text: is prepared to take a leadership role to help

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the challenges of urban water supply

Speaker: NA
Text: and cleanliness.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Wentworth campaign was hard

Speaker: NA
Text: fought, which is no bad thing. The party's

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation was unstinting in its support, as

Speaker: NA
Text: were ministers, senators and members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nearly a thousand Liberals volunteered to

Speaker: NA
Text: work on our campaign and more than 600 on

Speaker: NA
Text: day. Our magnificent Young Liberals,

Speaker: NA
Text: some of them voting for the first time,

Speaker: NA
Text: worked side by side with veterans who had

Speaker: NA
Text: joined the party in Sir Robert Menzies' day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nearly 400 are here today and I thank them

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular for this very moving show of

Speaker: NA
Text: support. I thank all of our Liberal Party fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily from the bottom of my heart. I particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly thank our Prime Minister, John How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard. He provided every assistance we re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quested and much more. In Wentworth, as

Speaker: NA
Text: across the nation, he clearly set out the

Speaker: NA
Text: choice presented to the people. His disci-

Speaker: NA
Text: pline, leadership and teamwork delivered our

Speaker: NA
Text: victory. Finally, I thank my best advocates,

Speaker: NA
Text: Lucy, Daisy and Alex. Their love gave me

Speaker: NA
Text: the strength to run, their charisma made up

Speaker: NA
Text: for many of my shortcomings and their ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vocacy was as compelling as it was sincere.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Lingiari) (4.27 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: For the first time in my whole life in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, as I rose to my feet I was ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plauded. I want to thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth for bringing the good burghers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth to this House to give me that ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plause. I am pleased that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth has now initiated his contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in this chamber by making his first

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. I am sure that he will make many

Speaker: NA
Text: more, but in a sense none will be as impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant as the one he has made today. I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate him on his arrival in this place. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, we want to make sure that he is on

Speaker: NA
Text: the government side of the chamber for a

Speaker: NA
Text: very short space of time and that we see him

Speaker: NA
Text: relocated to the opposition benches after the

Speaker: NA
Text: next election. I am sure that there is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: high probability of that happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later in my contribution to this address-

Speaker: NA
Text: in-reply I want to address particular remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: to the contribution made by the new member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Goldstein in his first speech this morning.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will make those comments when I resume

Speaker: NA
Text: my contribution later this evening. Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: say, though, how pleased I am to be again

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing this parliament as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lingiari. It is, in my view, certainly the most

Speaker: NA
Text: diverse and dispersed electorate in this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. It includes not only all of the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory except Darwin and Palmerston but

Speaker: NA
Text: also the Christmas and Cocos islands. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: unquestionably a most diverse electorate. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is quite the opposite of the electorate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wentworth. I do not know the

Speaker: NA
Text: area of Wentworth, but I suspect it is less

Speaker: NA
Text: than 100 square kilometres. The area of my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, for the information of the good

Speaker: NA
Text: burghers of Wentworth, is 1.34 million

Speaker: NA
Text: square kilometres.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst it is possible for the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth to dawdle around his electorate in

Speaker: NA
Text: a day, walking and-depending on his state

Speaker: NA
Text: of mind-perhaps doing other things, in my

Speaker: NA
Text: own case it takes literally days to travel from

Speaker: NA
Text: one part of the electorate to another

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle. Of course, even by plane, to visit the

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas and Cocos islands requires a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. In a sense, that shows the contrast of

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorates that we represent in this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am extremely pleased-and I know the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is disappointed-at my return to

Speaker: NA
Text: this place with a dramatically increased ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jority. I am sure that must have been what

Speaker: NA
Text: the applause was all about-I cannot imag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ine what else it could have been. I note,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that those who were so vigorous in

Speaker: NA
Text: their applause have left before I have fin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished my contribution, and I cannot for the

Speaker: NA
Text: life of me understand why this could have

Speaker: NA
Text: happened! It must be the invitation list for

Speaker: NA
Text: the soiree which is about to take place in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Hall at the invitation of the new mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Wentworth. Oddly, I will not able to

Speaker: NA
Text: see the applause continued in that place be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause I was not invited. I am not sure if any-

Speaker: NA
Text: one-apart from the very close friends and

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues, the thousand members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party in Wentworth and the 600 who

Speaker: NA
Text: worked on election day-has been invited. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask my friends at the table: were you in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vited? Did you get an invitation to this little

Speaker: NA
Text: soiree?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelvin Thomson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: No-one did. I have to

Speaker: NA
Text: say-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Causley)-I think the member for Lingiari is

Speaker: NA
Text: straying from the point. I will draw him back

Speaker: NA
Text: to it.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: No, it is very impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant to me, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to how we spend our time in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. I will just say that I regret the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: we were not invited to continue our conver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation with the member for Wentworth's

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents. Mr Deputy Speaker, would you

Speaker: NA
Text: enlighten me as to whether or not to I have to

Speaker: NA
Text: if I use a terminate this discussion now?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I will ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodate the member for Lingiari. It being

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 4.32 p.m., the debate is interrupted in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the resolution agreed to on

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 November 2004. The debate is adjourned

Speaker: NA
Text: and the resumption of the debate will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made an order of the day for a later hour this

Speaker: NA
Text: day.

Speaker: NA
Text: GRIEVANCE DEBATE

Speaker: NA
Text: Question proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That grievances be noted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment: Climate Change

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Text: Lowe) (4.32 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the member for Lingiari and

Speaker: NA
Text: join with him in congratulating the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Wentworth on his first speech in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House. I am impressed that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth raised the issue of climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change, but I think he should get a copy of

Speaker: NA
Text: what I am about to say to establish the facts.

Speaker: NA
Text: However much the Howard government may

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate itself, there is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the government's policies, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly those concerning climate change, are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing no more than indolently and cynically

Speaker: NA
Text: setting aside some very serious concerns that

Speaker: NA
Text: will leave a cruel legacy for future genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Tragically, the Howard government is

Speaker: NA
Text: presiding over an unsustainable growth of

Speaker: NA
Text: fossil fuel consumption and, in so doing,

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteeing that Australia will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer damaging climate change from the

Speaker: NA
Text: effects of greenhouse gas emissions. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer any doubt that burning fossil fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: els-that is, coal, oil and natural gas-and

Speaker: NA
Text: releasing the resultant carbon dioxide into

Speaker: NA
Text: the atmosphere is increasing the average

Speaker: NA
Text: temperature of our planet.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government pretends the science be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hind the warnings of climatologists is unsup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported by facts and the vested interests that

Speaker: NA
Text: control the government's policies say policy

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to reduce carbon dioxide emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: would be too expensive. No matter what

Speaker: NA
Text: members of this government may want to

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, the natural forces that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: unleashed through releasing massive quanti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of greenhouse gases will have an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creasingly damaging impact upon the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and the quality of our life in our

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. Very few credible scientists now dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: count the reality of global warming. The

Speaker: NA
Text: number of reputable scientists who accept

Speaker: NA
Text: the evidence for global warming far out-

Speaker: NA
Text: weighs the few who remain unconvinced, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government acts as if the case

Speaker: NA
Text: for global warming is unproven and action to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce emissions of carbon dioxide can be

Speaker: NA
Text: put off indefinitely.

Speaker: NA
Text: Scandalously, the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: stubbornly refuses to recognise the serious-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of the threat posed by global warming.

Speaker: NA
Text: This only mirrors the arrogance of the Bush

Speaker: NA
Text: administration in the United States, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been accused by many eminent Ameri-

Speaker: NA
Text: can scientists of ‘predetermined, inflexible

Speaker: NA
Text: positions' on the dangers of climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Howard government's single proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: for dealing with carbon dioxide emissions-

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, geosequestration-is unproven and

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive and has not even been demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated at pilot plant scale. Moreover, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: only applicable to fixed sources such as

Speaker: NA
Text: power stations, leaving the bulk of emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: it is to be vented to the atmosphere.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only is the evidence for global warm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing beyond dispute, but levels of carbon di-

Speaker: NA
Text: oxide have reached a concentration where

Speaker: NA
Text: any further substantial increases could lead

Speaker: NA
Text: to drastic shifts in the world's climate and

Speaker: NA
Text: sea levels. I will state the evidence as it pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently stands. First, since the early 1800s the

Speaker: NA
Text: concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide

Speaker: NA
Text: has risen from 280 parts per million to the

Speaker: NA
Text: present level of 370 parts per million, an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of over 30 per cent. Second, the effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the rising carbon dioxide level has been to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the amount of solar radiation ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: sorbed by the earth compared to the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of heat radiation lost to space. Third, the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: balance between incoming solar energy and

Speaker: NA
Text: heat energy radiated from the earth is now

Speaker: NA
Text: between 0.5 and one watt per square metre of

Speaker: NA
Text: the earth's surface, approximately equal to a

Speaker: NA
Text: lit torch bulb on every square metre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: earth's surface, land and seas included.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fourth, the effect of this imbalance is being

Speaker: NA
Text: felt as global climate change and the ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: served changes are in agreement with well-

Speaker: NA
Text: tested climate models.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aside from endless droughts, the main

Speaker: NA
Text: concern is the rate at which the polar ice

Speaker: NA
Text: sheets will melt under the additional heat

Speaker: NA
Text: input caused by the imbalance between in-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming solar and outgoing heat radiation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect that this ice sheet melting will have

Speaker: NA
Text: upon global sea levels. The evidence that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been obtained from Antarctic ice cores gives

Speaker: NA
Text: us a grim warning of what may lie ahead if

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon dioxide levels continue to increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ice core data tells us that current average

Speaker: NA
Text: global temperatures have risen to be equal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest temperatures experienced since

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of the last ice age. An additional watt

Speaker: NA
Text: of imbalance between incoming solar energy

Speaker: NA
Text: and outgoing radiated heat energy will take

Speaker: NA
Text: temperatures to the levels of the warmest

Speaker: NA
Text: times that preceded the last ice age. Sea lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: els were then six metres higher than present-

Speaker: NA
Text: day sea levels-a disastrous increase, were

Speaker: NA
Text: such a change to occur in our lifetimes.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the government refuses to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon dioxide emissions, the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, with the significant exception of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, has moved to counter the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: precedented threat posed by global warming.

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia has formally ratified the Kyoto proto-

Speaker: NA
Text: col, and the protocol will become legally

Speaker: NA
Text: binding on 16 February 2005. The 30 indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trialised countries that have supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: protocol have committed to cutting their car-

Speaker: NA
Text: bon dioxide emissions to five per cent below

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990 levels by 2005. This is as much as 25

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent below current levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only four industrialised countries-

Speaker: NA
Text: Liechtenstein, Monaco plus Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States-remain outside Kyoto. That

Speaker: NA
Text: means that 61.6 per cent of the world's emis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions are covered by the Kyoto protocol. De-

Speaker: NA
Text: spite an ineffective campaign of obstruction

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Howard government, policies will be

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the protocol members to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the consumption of fossil fuels. Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia is excluded from Kyoto emissions trading

Speaker: NA
Text: and will suffer trade restrictions because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's opposition to the protocol.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effect on Australia's balance of trade

Speaker: NA
Text: will be serious, with significant impacts on

Speaker: NA
Text: the coal exports that are presently our largest

Speaker: NA
Text: earner and which generated an income of

Speaker: NA
Text: $A13.5 billion in 2001-02. Nearly half of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's coal exports are burned in over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas power stations, and measures that will

Speaker: NA
Text: soon be introduced to reduce emissions from

Speaker: NA
Text: these power stations will have a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on our coal export earnings. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: recently seen for myself an Australian de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed and built large-scale solar collector

Speaker: NA
Text: that is specifically designed to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of coal used in existing power sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. This is located near Liddell power sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, where solar power is intended to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: place 50 megawatts of fossil fuel power at

Speaker: NA
Text: Liddell, and I pay tribute to Dr David Mills,

Speaker: NA
Text: whom the member for Wills knows.

Speaker: NA
Text: This technology has attracted great inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est here and overseas and, despite a derisory

Speaker: NA
Text: level of support for renewable energy from

Speaker: NA
Text: this government, solar energy will replace

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing quantities of coal-fired electricity

Speaker: NA
Text: generating capacity. Solar augmentation

Speaker: NA
Text: could presently displace half of the coal used

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australian power stations and, with high-

Speaker: NA
Text: temperature storage, these inexpensive Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian designed solar power collectors could

Speaker: NA
Text: replace virtually all coal fired generators in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. These solar collectors if sold over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas could also displace much of the coal

Speaker: NA
Text: exported from Australia while at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time producing a replacement income in the

Speaker: NA
Text: form of high technology sales to countries

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned to reduce carbon dioxide emis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government makes much of the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: that it claims would have to be borne if ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fective measures to reduce carbon dioxide

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions were to be enforced in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the government neglects to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count for the enormous subsidies that en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage fossil fuel consumption. In 1999,

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Quiggin, Australian Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Council Senior Research Fellow at James

Speaker: NA
Text: Cook University, demonstrated that, under

Speaker: NA
Text: the GST, the net subsidy for road transport

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel is approximately $2.2 billion per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to this amount, other fuel subsicomment

Speaker: NA
Text: dies include the approximate $1.4 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: annum for the Diesel Fuel Rebate and the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of $2.6 billion recently incurred

Speaker: NA
Text: to prevent the GST adding to fuel price rises

Speaker: NA
Text: for ordinary consumers. This amounts to

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately $4 billion per year in subsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dies for fossil fuel use, and yet the governobviously

Speaker: NA
Text: ment claims that measures to reduce fossil

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel consumption are too expensive to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: template. To this sum one should add an ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional $500 million per annum handed to

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasers of the many gas-guzzling four-

Speaker: NA
Text: wheel drive vehicles. This money should be

Speaker: NA
Text: used to encourage Australians to buy more

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel-efficient vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: The former Minister for the Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Heritage, Dr Kemp, warned that carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: dioxide emissions had to be reduced by 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent if a disaster were to be averted.

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt this advice did not fit ‘predetermined,

Speaker: NA
Text: inflexible' positions, so Dr Kemp was dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: patched. Yet cuts in emissions of this order

Speaker: NA
Text: from electricity generation and transport

Speaker: NA
Text: alone are possible. Solar thermal electricity

Speaker: NA
Text: generators can now reliably replace coal

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity at competitive prices and could

Speaker: NA
Text: cut total emissions by 40 to 50 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: fordable hybrid vehicles with double the fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: economy of conventional cars and electrifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of the trunk railway routes together

Speaker: NA
Text: with the transfer of the majority of freight to

Speaker: NA
Text: railways could halve carbon dioxide releases

Speaker: NA
Text: from the transport sector, which presently

Speaker: NA
Text: produces one-third of total emissions. These

Speaker: NA
Text: measures are affordable, are being intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced in other parts of the world and are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed as a matter of urgency if a climatic

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster is to be forestalled. I ask: what sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of catastrophe does Australia have to face

Speaker: NA
Text: before the government will act?

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Taxation Office: Inspector-

Speaker: NA
Text: General of Taxation

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Text: Canning) (4.41 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: grieve for the Australian taxpayer. I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: on the recent report by Mr David

Speaker: NA
Text: per Vos, the inaugural Inspector-General of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation, into the Australian Taxation Of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice's administration of the general interest

Speaker: NA
Text: charge or GIC. In doing so, I would firstly

Speaker: NA
Text: like to extend my personal thanks to Mr Vos

Speaker: NA
Text: for the extensive and detailed work he has

Speaker: NA
Text: done to provide the government

Speaker: NA
Text: with this report. Its conclusions have been

Speaker: NA
Text: reached as a result of detailed investigation

Speaker: NA
Text: and analysis of administrative matters. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Vos has also taken time to get out of his of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice and meet with practitioners and taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers to get the feel of what the real effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: this tax penalty regime is on ordinary Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a vivid contrast to the complete fail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure of the tax office to meet its obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: and do the same. Indeed, some of Mr Vos's

Speaker: NA
Text: No key findings are for the ATO to do what it

Speaker: NA
Text: promised to do in the much vaunted Taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers' Charter-a document proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: ATO, written by the ATO and claimed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: ATO to be its standard for dealing with tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers' affairs. Unfortunately, as Mr Vos

Speaker: NA
Text: fire points out, the ATO has failed to examine

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' individual circumstances and has

Speaker: NA
Text: Aftaken what it considers to be an administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively efficient global view of everyone on

Speaker: NA
Text: certain arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we already know, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Ombudsman concluded in 2001 that the ATO

Speaker: NA
Text: breached the Taxpayers' Charter by its fail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure to take the individual circumstances of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers into account in mass marketed ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements. We can see from the inspector-

Speaker: NA
Text: general's findings that nothing has changed.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the commissioner reverses his view on

Speaker: NA
Text: an investment product, he just gets out a cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: culator and the investor list, presses a mail-

Speaker: NA
Text: merge button and everybody involved is

Speaker: NA
Text: automatically a tax cheat.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it would be no surprise to members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House that the commissioner considers

Speaker: NA
Text: with contempt the informed and independent

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion of the Inspector-General of Taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: to have as little relevance as the views of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ombudsman. Mr Vos is in distinguished

Speaker: NA
Text: company-most of the members of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House and the other place have been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: buffed and told at some stage by the ATO to

Speaker: NA
Text: butt out. The professional bodies, the taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers association, the Law Council, have all

Speaker: NA
Text: have had their representative views scorned.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems the concerns of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: himself have been summarily dismissed. And

Speaker: NA
Text: now, the much anticipated circuit breaker in

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem of tax administration, the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's personal solution, the Inspector-

Speaker: NA
Text: General of Taxation, has been put in his

Speaker: NA
Text: place and stared down. The inspector-general

Speaker: NA
Text: has found in his report that the ATO is treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing taxpayers inconsistently and therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: unfairly in the way concessions are allowed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us make this point up front. The for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mer Assistant Treasurer, Senator Helen

Speaker: NA
Text: Coonan, was forced to investigate this re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view in November 2003 for only one rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son-the universal condemnation and criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism of the ATO's handling of the EBA is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sue. As the dispute lengthened, it became

Speaker: NA
Text: more obvious to MPs and the government

Speaker: NA
Text: that the commissioner's actions were incon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistent and of serious concern. An inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: into the application of the GIC, in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: as it related to EBA taxpayers, was the inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent and competent view that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment could rely on.

Speaker: NA
Text: In March 2004 the PM encouraged mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of this House who had approached him

Speaker: NA
Text: with demands for intervention to wait for this

Speaker: NA
Text: report, as it would provide the government

Speaker: NA
Text: with the clearest view and the best solution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, the umpire has ruled, and taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: have accepted his view-the commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: should allow all taxpayers in the arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments under review to receive the same con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions as those in mass marketed arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. To remind members of those terms,

Speaker: NA
Text: they were as follows: no penalties; no inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: the est; allowance of a deduction for the cash

Speaker: NA
Text: component; and a five-year period to pay the

Speaker: NA
Text: settled debt, with the first two years interest

Speaker: NA
Text: free. But the commissioner has rejected the

Speaker: NA
Text: inspector-general's findings in this regard,

Speaker: NA
Text: and his reasons for rejecting them are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded in the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: However-and this is a very telling

Speaker: NA
Text: point-the report also includes the inspector-

Speaker: NA
Text: general's secondary comments on the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner's reasons, and guess what: he re-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects them. Not only does he reject them; he

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly states that some of the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner's contentions are just plain wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here are three examples: firstly, the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner claims that interest remission provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions do not provide him with an ‘unfettered

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion' to remit interest and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to remit can only be activated in ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptional circumstances. The IGT says that is

Speaker: NA
Text: just plain wrong. The remission power con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains no express requirement that is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: exercised only in special or exceptional cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances. Furthermore, the IGT states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The approach by the Commissioner would seem

Speaker: NA
Text: to unnecessarily restrict the operation of the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cretionary power afforded by Parliament to remit

Speaker: NA
Text: the interest charge.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the commissioner claims that a no

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty, no interest outcome would ‘signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly impact on the future health and integ-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity of the tax system'. The IGT says that is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. The remissions for mass marketed

Speaker: NA
Text: investors, of which there were significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: more than those in the EBAs, have had no

Speaker: NA
Text: adverse consequences. The IGT also notes

Speaker: NA
Text: that the ATO itself regarded EBAs to be mass

Speaker: NA
Text: marketed arrangements until April 2001,

Speaker: NA
Text: when it reduced interest for some of the mass

Speaker: NA
Text: marketed taxpayers, and provides evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: that internally the ATO actually still regards

Speaker: NA
Text: EBAs as a form of mass marketed invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, the commissioner claims that

Speaker: NA
Text: EBA taxpayers are different to mass mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: keted taxpayers and therefore do not warrant

Speaker: NA
Text: the same settlement. The IGT rejects this

Speaker: NA
Text: claim and notes that he prefers the submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions made to him by other parties that the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioner's views are incorrect. Not only

Speaker: NA
Text: that, the inspector-general pointed out that

Speaker: NA
Text: mass marketed products for which the set-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlement was provided could only lay claim to

Speaker: NA
Text: five or six ATO rulings in their favour over a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of several years. EBA products were

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of over 60 ATO rulings and ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vance opinions in their favour. Those 60-plus

Speaker: NA
Text: rulings and opinions, along with the chaos in

Speaker: NA
Text: the rulings section at the ATO, mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers and their advisers still have to take

Speaker: NA
Text: the ‘she loves me, she loves me not' ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to planning their tax and business

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Vos is quite clear and firm in his find-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. Taxpayers in EBAs, retirement villages,

Speaker: NA
Text: equity linked bonds and securities lending

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements deserve the same treatment as

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers in mass marketed arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now associated with that finding are other

Speaker: NA
Text: findings about the ATO's administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: the GIC, many of which the commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: has reluctantly agreed to take on board. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Vos's independence and clear views are ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously recognised by the commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: when it suits him. But these issues will only

Speaker: NA
Text: affect taxpayers in the future. EBA taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: are being pushed to insolvency by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner because he refuses to accept any

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for the failures of his office.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why this parliament must act. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament I wish to place on the

Speaker: NA
Text: record that I am personally offended and

Speaker: NA
Text: dismayed by the commissioner's written

Speaker: NA
Text: comments in a letter to the inspector-general,

Speaker: NA
Text: dated 8 July 2004, and incorporated into the

Speaker: NA
Text: report as appendix 1. The commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: claims that the health and integrity of our tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system is jeopardised when lobbying suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessfully achieves favourable settlements

Speaker: NA
Text: that he describes as being ‘not otherwise jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tified'. He is wrong. The commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: stands alone in his views that the settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: is not justified. No member of this House, or

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed of the other place, who is dedicated to

Speaker: NA
Text: representing their constituents in this, the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest court in the land, will ever counte-

Speaker: NA
Text: nance the view of any bureaucrat, no matter

Speaker: NA
Text: how senior, that constituents are not entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to have their parliamentary representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: lobby on their behalf to bring reason and

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness to a situation where both are so

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly absent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, members who are very seri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously concerned about this matter are pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posing a private member's bill that will

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve two outcomes: firstly, it will require

Speaker: NA
Text: the commissioner to act on the IGT's find-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings in this report and implement the mass

Speaker: NA
Text: marketed settlement provisions in full for all

Speaker: NA
Text: the affected taxpayers currently in dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: with EBAs, retirement villages, equity linked

Speaker: NA
Text: bonds and securities lending arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will bring these disputes to an end im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately. The primary tax will be paid; the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Court and Administrative Appeals

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal calendars will be cleared; further

Speaker: NA
Text: futile expenses and suffocating pressures on

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses and families involved will disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pear; and a clear view of the future will en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able all parties, including the ATO, to move

Speaker: NA
Text: forward. ATO staff currently deployed in

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetuating this unholy mess can be reas-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to more productive tasks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the bill will include overriding

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions to limit the commissioner's ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to retrospectively apply a changed view or

Speaker: NA
Text: amended policy or procedure to situations

Speaker: NA
Text: where the law or its administration by the

Speaker: NA
Text: ATO is unclear. Taxpayers will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: lodge a disclosure statement with a return

Speaker: NA
Text: where they and their advisers are of the view

Speaker: NA
Text: that specific components of their tax affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: in the relevant income year are not clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: defined in the statutes or are not the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of ATO practice statements. Such disclosure

Speaker: NA
Text: statements will be required to be accompa-

Speaker: NA
Text: nied by competent professional opinions that

Speaker: NA
Text: support the taxpayer's interpretation, as are

Speaker: NA
Text: presently recognised by government and

Speaker: NA
Text: business alike. Where such disclosure state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are lodged and, no more than two

Speaker: NA
Text: years after lodgment, a subsequent ATO ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: amination concludes that tax deductions or

Speaker: NA
Text: income exemptions are not allowable, the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: in question will then be payable, subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing appeal provisions. However, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be exempted from penalties, the GIC

Speaker: NA
Text: and the part IVA anti-avoidance provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also incorporate measures to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the revenue from taxpayers who at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempt to abuse its effective safety net as a

Speaker: NA
Text: form of statutory tax deferral. The effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: such provisions will be to prevent the penal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ising of taxpayers when best advice is ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained and followed, provided that the ATO

Speaker: NA
Text: is kept informed and is aware of the details

Speaker: NA
Text: of the arrangements. Suffice to say the train

Speaker: NA
Text: of global disputes that have dogged our tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system over the past few years would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have occurred had these measures been in

Speaker: NA
Text: place.

Speaker: NA
Text: These matters should not have to be dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with by the parliament, and they would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be if the ATO had done their job in a timely

Speaker: NA
Text: manner or agreed to accept the inspector-

Speaker: NA
Text: general's independent findings. However, as

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the taxpayers of this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: we are obligated to stop this mistreatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: our constituents by the means available to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans: Health Services

Speaker: Mr EDWARDS
Text: Cowan) (4.51 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to raise a serious issue today relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: one of my constituents. It is an issue which

Speaker: NA
Text: also impacts on the broader veteran commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. In this instance, I have been contacted

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Con Sappelli JP, who set out a very

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning experience he had recently fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing a heart attack. Mr Sappelli suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: this attack in September, at about 2.30 in the

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon. I quote from a letter he wrote to

Speaker: NA
Text: me:

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a returned serviceman with private health

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance. As a result of a heart attack in the af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternoon from 1830hrs that Tuesday I found my-

Speaker: NA
Text: self on a merry go round of hospitals until an

Speaker: NA
Text: eventual permanent bed was found for me at

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Hospital at 1430 on Wednesday 8th.

Speaker: NA
Text: When picked up by an ambulance that Tuesday

Speaker: NA
Text: evening I was informed that Joondalup Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Campus (the nearest facility) was full and on ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice from the paramedics QEII was the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended destination. Having received the neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary medical care to ensure my wellbeing at QEII

Speaker: NA
Text: I requested to be sent to the repatriation hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: as my heart condition is an accepted condition by

Speaker: NA
Text: DVA so doing my request to be taken to repat.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I was informed that there were no beds

Speaker: NA
Text: available, then a request for St John of God

Speaker: NA
Text: Subiaco, ditto. I was then informed that a bed

Speaker: NA
Text: would be found within Sir Charles Gairdner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wrong again.

Speaker: NA
Text: A bed was eventually found at Murdoch at

Speaker: NA
Text: 0100 on the morning of Wednesday 8th Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, after further tests to ensure my well being I

Speaker: NA
Text: was eventually transferred to Mount Hospital at

Speaker: NA
Text: 1430 that Wednesday. With the exception of the

Speaker: NA
Text: time at Murdoch I was on a stretcher until a bed

Speaker: NA
Text: became available at Mount some 20 hours after

Speaker: NA
Text: being picked up by the ambulance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The requirements by DVA are that should you

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to partake of the services other than those

Speaker: NA
Text: approved by them without permission from them,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost for those services becomes a liability to

Speaker: NA
Text: the patient and in my case my private fund. What

Speaker: NA
Text: would have occurred had I not been privately

Speaker: NA
Text: insured, would I have remained on a trolley in a

Speaker: NA
Text: casualty ward waiting to either die or wait until a

Speaker: NA
Text: suitable bed vacancy became available in the ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriately approved facility in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: DVA protocol.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last thought in a persons mind when a cri-

Speaker: NA
Text: sis occurs requiring intensive care is to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: mission from a bureaucracy as to whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: will accept any cost incurred by the said crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: a consequence the entire doctors, hospital and

Speaker: NA
Text: ambulance accounts (a substantial amount) with

Speaker: NA
Text: the exception of the initial ambulance from home

Speaker: NA
Text: to QEII (paid by DVA) were paid by my health

Speaker: NA
Text: fund with some out of pocket cost paid by myself.

Speaker: NA
Text: One could say that ultimately that is why one has

Speaker: NA
Text: private health insurance, the fact that my medical

Speaker: NA
Text: condition is an accepted condition by DVA, by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of principal they should be responsible for all

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts, irrespective of whether the medical care

Speaker: NA
Text: provided was by an approved establishment or

Speaker: NA
Text: not.

Speaker: NA
Text: Especially given that the majority of private

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital has similar charges, Hollywood although

Speaker: NA
Text: a repatriation hospital, it is foremost a private

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where there are not sufficient hospital beds

Speaker: NA
Text: available within the medical system, which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: a situation or fault of my making, the system

Speaker: NA
Text: should be flexible enough to allow a person to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a decision, which is in his or her best

Speaker: NA
Text: est without having to seek prior permission as to

Speaker: NA
Text: which DVA approved facility is most appropriate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think Mr Sappelli raises a number of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant issues in his letter. Firstly, I was un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the impression that Hollywood Private

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital was supposed to give priority to

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans, and I am surprised that he was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fused admission. Hollywood Private Hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: has a very good reputation amongst the vet-

Speaker: NA
Text: eran community, and I can fully understand

Speaker: NA
Text: why a veteran would want to go to Holly-

Speaker: NA
Text: wood hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the issue that Mr Sappelli raises

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to veterans needing private health

Speaker: NA
Text: cover is certainly one which is causing con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern to many veterans, given the demise of

Speaker: NA
Text: the gold card. Indeed, what would have hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened had Mr Sappelli not had private health

Speaker: NA
Text: cover? Traditionally, in this nation, veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: who have Department of Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted war caused disabilities or illness

Speaker: NA
Text: have had those conditions treated at the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pense of DVA. In recent years, however, our

Speaker: NA
Text: per- nation appears to be turning its back on the

Speaker: NA
Text: proper care of veterans. Many veterans are

Speaker: NA
Text: As now faced with the dilemma of whether or

Speaker: NA
Text: not they should take out private health cover

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure they get treatment for conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted as war caused. What a disgraceful

Speaker: NA
Text: situation this is!

Speaker: NA
Text: Are men and women who have served this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation and who have suffered medical condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions as a result of that service no longer en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled to have those conditions treated

Speaker: NA
Text: through DVA? When did this change come

Speaker: NA
Text: about? Has it come about by way of gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment policy change or by way of sheer

Speaker: NA
Text: neglect of our duty of care to our nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans? I suspect it is the latter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say that because many veterans will now

Speaker: NA
Text: tell you that accessing medical care with the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of a DVA card-gold or white-is be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming increasingly difficult, and this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation that the government must address.

Speaker: NA
Text: inter- Why should Australia's ageing veterans have

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry the cost of their own medical care,

Speaker: NA
Text: and why should they be forced to accept sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond-rate treatment by this nation when they

Speaker: NA
Text: gave the nation first-class service in the

Speaker: NA
Text: prime of their youth?

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to take this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: compliment Blue Ryan, the National Presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent of the TPI Association, for his dedica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the cause of his members and for his

Speaker: NA
Text: personal commitment to Australia's sick,

Speaker: NA
Text: ageing and disabled veterans and T&PIs and

Speaker: NA
Text: their families. I know the issue I have raised

Speaker: NA
Text: here today is one of great concern to Blue

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryan and his members because it goes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: heart of their wellbeing. I say to Blue Ryan:

Speaker: NA
Text: Blue, keep up the good work. I call on the

Speaker: NA
Text: veteran community to get behind the likes of

Speaker: NA
Text: Blue Ryan and Tim MCCombe and Graham

Speaker: NA
Text: Walker from the Vietnam Veterans Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and be prepared to unite and fight to

Speaker: NA
Text: restore the principle of proper medical care

Speaker: NA
Text: for our veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: Next year we will have numerous celebra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to mark the 90th anniversary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: landing at Gallipoli and the 60th anniversary

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ending of World War II. I just want to

Speaker: NA
Text: pose this question: how can we possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: mark these significant hallmarks of our his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory with any integrity or sincerity at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when we are downgrading medical care for

Speaker: NA
Text: our ageing veteran community? Mr Sappelli

Speaker: NA
Text: said that this is a matter of principle. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed a matter of principle, and while I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the current minister is only new in

Speaker: NA
Text: the job I call on her to redress this serious

Speaker: NA
Text: and disgraceful situation as a matter of priorCoast

Speaker: NA
Text: ity.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, we in this nation have had a

Speaker: NA
Text: very strong commitment over a long period

Speaker: NA
Text: of time to the men and women of this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: who have gone overseas and served this na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the armed forces and who in so do-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing-usually in the prime of their life-have

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately paid a heavy penalty in later years

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result in terms of their health due to

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of war caused disabilities and war

Speaker: NA
Text: caused illnesses. It is not good enough for

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation to now turn its back on those ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vicemen and their families, particularly as

Speaker: NA
Text: many of those service men and women are

Speaker: NA
Text: now ageing and in greater need of care and

Speaker: NA
Text: medical support than at any other time of

Speaker: NA
Text: their life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunshine Coast Regional Organisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Councils

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: Fisher (5.01 p.m.)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: today to salute the work being carried out by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunshine Coast Regional Organisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Councils, generally known as SunROC. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have long been on the record as supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: the amalgamation of the City of Caloundra,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Shire of Noosa and the Shire of Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: roochy so that the Sunshine Coast would be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to portray itself as a strong, united re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion and be best able to advertise the won-

Speaker: NA
Text: derful opportunities we have in our area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, if we were one local authority we

Speaker: NA
Text: would be able to deal with all levels of gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in a very effective way. Having said

Speaker: NA
Text: that, at this point in time we do not have one

Speaker: NA
Text: council on the Sunshine Coast, so SunROC,

Speaker: NA
Text: although somewhat of a halfway house, is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing an excellent job in the interim.

Speaker: NA
