Text: SunROC is a voluntary regional organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of councils for the Sunshine Coast, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the three local authorities I mentioned a mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ago as its members. SunROC places an

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasis on the development of infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture to underpin the growth of the Sunshine

Speaker: NA
Text: region economically, socially and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: vironmentally. SunROC has a specific role,

Speaker: NA
Text: function and purpose. It is the pre-eminent

Speaker: NA
Text: government liaison organisation for the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional interests of the City of Caloundra and

Speaker: NA
Text: the shires of Maroochy and Noosa. Through

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible and proactive lobbying and council

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation, SunROC aims for the Sunshine

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast to have the best physical infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: the of any region in Australia. Achieving that

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent level of physical infrastructure will

Speaker: NA
Text: in turn create the highest standards of eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic, environmental and social infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture for the region and the best quality of life

Speaker: NA
Text: for citizens of the Sunshine Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: The chairmanship of SunROC is rotated

Speaker: NA
Text: between the three mayors. The current

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman is Councillor Don Aldous, Mayor

Speaker: NA
Text: of the City of Caloundra, and in May 2002

Speaker: NA
Text: SunROC appointed its first executive direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor, Mr Graeme Pearce, to manage the or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: SunROC has recently released three

Speaker: NA
Text: groundbreaking studies which will outline

Speaker: NA
Text: key strategies to manage future growth

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the Sunshine Coast region. The

Speaker: NA
Text: three commissioned studies include regional

Speaker: NA
Text: economic development, the knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and land transportation-SunTran.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Sunshine Coast Regional Economic De-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment Strategy is designed to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear direction for the future by documenting

Speaker: NA
Text: coordinated action plans that promote and

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate regional prosperity. The study idenstudy

Speaker: NA
Text: tifies priorities to encourage investment and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment growth while ensuring that the

Speaker: NA
Text: region's unique attributes are protected and

Speaker: NA
Text: capitalised upon for all sections of the Sun-

Speaker: NA
Text: shine Coast community, especially small and

Speaker: NA
Text: home based businesses and professional and

Speaker: NA
Text: other service providers, as well as all forms

Speaker: NA
Text: of entrepreneurial and export business activ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity. The aim is the very achievable creation

Speaker: NA
Text: of 30,000 sustainable jobs in the region over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 25 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The knowledge economy strategy re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponds to a core element of the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development strategy: knowledge industry

Speaker: NA
Text: employment growth. Future economic pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: perity for Australia as a whole, and not least

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunshine Coast, will rely on this impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant sector. Most local industries around

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, but particularly the knowledge based

Speaker: NA
Text: industries, are increasingly advised to coor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dinate within regional clusters to maximise

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities and outcomes. If these local

Speaker: NA
Text: industries are to transform themselves into

Speaker: NA
Text: regional industry clusters then the following

Speaker: NA
Text: issues need to be addressed and provided for:

Speaker: NA
Text: research support, skills development and

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive physical infrastructure. An impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant part of SunROC's studies has focussed

Speaker: NA
Text: on the practical aspects of SunROC provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing support to the public sector in the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of research and skills development and also

Speaker: NA
Text: focussing on potentially assisting the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search of tertiary institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional physical infrastructure is the fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cus of the third of SunROC's groundbreak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing studies. The transportation, or SunTran,

Speaker: NA
Text: study is one of the first steps towards ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing regional transport issues on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunshine Coast. SunTran is the first major

Speaker: NA
Text: transport study for the region. Its completion

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide transport strategies that are ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: solutely vital to the future of the Sunshine

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast. Some of the key issues and findings

Speaker: NA
Text: that were identified in stage 1 of the SunTran

Speaker: NA
Text: include that car travel is the dominant

Speaker: NA
Text: mode of transport on the Sunshine Coast-

Speaker: NA
Text: by 79 per cent; that the current share of

Speaker: NA
Text: scheduled public transport is only around

Speaker: NA
Text: one per cent of travel, which falls signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly below the overall public transport

Speaker: NA
Text: mode share target for south-east Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: of 6.5 per cent of all trips by 2011; that a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant change in public transport in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment strategy and policy measures by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state government would be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to achieve a material impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of private vehicle use; and that en-

Speaker: NA
Text: hancing the cycle and pedestrian network

Speaker: NA
Text: would provide a platform towards decreasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the dominance of private motor vehicle use.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the key issue identified that underpins

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the above is that, for the population of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aus- the Sunshine Coast region and its demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphic, there is a low level of public trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port provided by the Beattie state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Stage 2 of SunROC's land transporta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion study will review the variety of transport

Speaker: NA
Text: options available to the region, and stage 3

Speaker: NA
Text: will cover a raft of recommendations of

Speaker: NA
Text: which I sincerely hope the Queensland state

Speaker: NA
Text: government will closely take note. Both are

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be completed by mid-2005.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to underline the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: each of the three studies outlined above are

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the project known as Vision 2025-

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunshine Coast Economic Development

Speaker: NA
Text: and Integrated Transport Strategy Project.

Speaker: NA
Text: The project has been supported by funding

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian government under our

Speaker: NA
Text: very successful Regional Partnerships pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram. The three studies also have the support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the three local councils of Caloundra City

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Maroochy and Noosa shires. I men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned the chairman of SunROC, Don

Speaker: NA
Text: Aldous, who is also Mayor of Caloundra

Speaker: NA
Text: City Council; also involved are Councillor

Speaker: NA
Text: Bob Abbot, the mayor of Noosa, and Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cillor Joe Natoli, the mayor of Maroochy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The councils, together with SunROC, will

Speaker: NA
Text: work collaboratively with the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government on the outcomes of these stud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. It is also expected and hoped that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state government, tertiary insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions and the private sector will become

Speaker: NA
Text: closely involved with the strategic project to

Speaker: NA
Text: further develop investment and growth in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunshine Coast and region without compro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mising the unequalled and enviable lifestyle

Speaker: NA
Text: that residents currently enjoy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I therefore publicly call on the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Beattie government to assist SunROC with

Speaker: NA
Text: the coordination and implementation of this

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy, in line with other recently com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted strategic work in the regional area. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is essential that we get the strategic action

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for the future development of the Sun-

Speaker: NA
Text: shine Coast region absolutely right and that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is efficiently implemented. With record

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of new residents moving to Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland's south-east region each month, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: crucial that at this time, at this stage,

Speaker: NA
Text: visage the physical, social and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the region correctly and ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriately.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that, to this end, it is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed that an overseeing committee within

Speaker: NA
Text: SunROC be established that will take car-

Speaker: NA
Text: riage of the overseeing of the following

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks: to agree on the top 10 most important

Speaker: NA
Text: regional strategies to be implemented over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next three years and to review the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gress of these actions at each stage; to work

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Queensland Office of Urban Man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement on the implementation of the South

Speaker: NA
Text: East Queensland Regional Plan; to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that adequate resources are allocated from all

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of government to these projects; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: as is always necessary with such organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions with strategic plans, to coordinate ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vocacy for the region and to assist member

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations with the government and

Speaker: NA
Text: community liaison activities, primarily by

Speaker: NA
Text: building stronger partnerships with Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland state and Australian government repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives to ensure the ongoing partnership

Speaker: NA
Text: among the three tiers of government. I there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore commend the excellent work that these

Speaker: NA
Text: three studies by SunROC represent and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute towards the future prosperity and sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability of the Sunshine Coast and region.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said before, with so much population

Speaker: NA
Text: and economic growth in the region and with

Speaker: NA
Text: so much interest in the Sunshine Coast from

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia and around the world, the

Speaker: NA
Text: future that we imagine must be strategically

Speaker: NA
Text: developed and appropriately, intelligently

Speaker: NA
Text: and sensitively implemented. Any failure in

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment may have serious consequences in

Speaker: NA
Text: the decades to come and for future genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. All levels of government representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunshine Coast have a responsibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the future sustainability of lifestyle

Speaker: NA
Text: and economic progress. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the role carried out by Mr Tony

Speaker: NA
Text: we enLong, a Sunshine Coast businessman, with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to what SunROC is currently achiev-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I am very pleased to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian government have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: our share of the responsibility seriously and

Speaker: NA
Text: have worked in partnership with SunROC

Speaker: NA
Text: and its member organisations. We will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to do so. All the relevant government

Speaker: NA
Text: members-I am one of them-from each

Speaker: NA
Text: sphere must ensure that we continue to get

Speaker: NA
Text: on board with these strategies so that we may

Speaker: NA
Text: together achieve an even better future for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunshine Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith)

Speaker: NA
Text: Airport

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Text: Calare) (5.11 p.m.)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: today to grieve for the future of regional

Speaker: NA
Text: services in this country and specifically the

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of our biggest regional

Speaker: NA
Text: gional Express, in its efforts to secure fair,

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable and competitive access to facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties at Sydney's monopoly-owned Kingsford

Speaker: NA
Text: Smith airport. I know my concerns are

Speaker: NA
Text: shared by others in this place, especially my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues from regional and rural elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ates.

Speaker: NA
Text: In early November this year, the Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Summit 2004 was held in Canberra. The

Speaker: NA
Text: summit was attended by interested parties

Speaker: NA
Text: from business, government, the airlines and

Speaker: NA
Text: the airports. I was not able to attend the

Speaker: NA
Text: summit, but I did make a submission for its

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration delivered by my senior staffer

Speaker: NA
Text: as an observer, largely based on the inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: by the House of Representatives Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Transport and Regional Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, of which I was a member, into re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional air services in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee's report, Regional aviation

Speaker: NA
Text: and island transport services: making ends

Speaker: NA
Text: meet, was tabled in October-November last

Speaker: NA
Text: year. At recommendation 22, the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: urged the Commonwealth government to

Speaker: NA
Text: retain its current measures to ensure regional

Speaker: NA
Text: airlines have access to Sydney airport and

Speaker: NA
Text: other capital city airports. I stated in my

Speaker: NA
Text: submission that, on reflection of industry

Speaker: NA
Text: trends since the tabling of the Making ends

Speaker: NA
Text: meet report, it might have been advisable for

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee to have qualified this recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation to ensure fully competitive access

Speaker: NA
Text: to Sydney and other capital city airports.

Speaker: NA
Text: Smooth connections and adequate facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties are important for business travellers and

Speaker: NA
Text: tourists alike. My colleague the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Riverina emphasised the importance of ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess for regional carriers to the major air-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports in her address to the summit, describ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Sydney airport as a gateway to her elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate and rural Australia as a whole, which

Speaker: NA
Text: air indeed it is. The summit, chaired by former

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Transport and Regional Devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: airline, Reopment John Sharp, resolved:

Speaker: NA
Text: Provision should be made in legislation for fair,

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable and competitive access of airlines to

Speaker: NA
Text: landing, airside terminal and landside facilities in

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australian Airports.

Speaker: NA
Text: The summit also resolved that, in the event

Speaker: NA
Text: of an access dispute, there should be a legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated independent mechanism for review and

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, Regional Express, our largest

Speaker: NA
Text: regional carrier, could benefit from such leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation. Rex, as the airline is known, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been served notice to vacate its gate, gate 39,

Speaker: NA
Text: by 30 November-that is tomorrow. To fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther complicate this situation, the business

Speaker: NA
Text: lounge at gate 39 that Rex has used since it

Speaker: NA
Text: began operations has been leased to a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitor airline for 17 years. This is despite

Speaker: NA
Text: public comment by Sydney Airports Corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration CEO Max Moore-Wilton to central

Speaker: NA
Text: west New South Wales's local ABC that Rex

Speaker: NA
Text: could keep its lounge if it wanted to. Rex has

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied gate 39 and its lounge since the

Speaker: NA
Text: collapse of Ansett on a nominal lease of $1

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum to maintain regional air services

Speaker: NA
Text: in what was then a difficult environment for

Speaker: NA
Text: all airlines, let alone a new regional carrier.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rex has grown into a commercially viable

Speaker: NA
Text: airline, turning an operating profit of just

Speaker: NA
Text: over $1 million last year. It carries half a mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion passengers a year on some 80 flights a

Speaker: NA
Text: day and has almost 2,000 lounge members

Speaker: NA
Text: and corporate clients making use of its facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for business travellers. Regional Express

Speaker: NA
Text: was more than willing and able to enter into

Speaker: NA
Text: a commercial lease arrangement to retain the

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities that have been an integral part of

Speaker: NA
Text: growth to date and are very much part of its

Speaker: NA
Text: business plan for the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: As events transpired, Rex did not get the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to put in a tender to retain those

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities. Despite its efforts to negotiate

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent facilities since February this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: Rex has only managed to achieve some cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainty about its gate and lounge facilities this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning, after a lot of heartache, negotiation

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, stonewalling at times by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Airports Corporation, which has of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fered Rex exclusive use of gate 47. Rex has

Speaker: NA
Text: also successfully come to an arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: with Virgin Blue and the SACL to extend its

Speaker: NA
Text: use of the gate 39 business lounge for three

Speaker: NA
Text: months while a new lounge is being con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structed.

Speaker: NA
Text: While all this is a welcome development,

Speaker: NA
Text: coming late in the day, Rex has only been

Speaker: NA
Text: offered a three-year tenure on its new gate

Speaker: NA
Text: and lounge at this stage. The uncertainty sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounding access arrangements that Rex has

Speaker: NA
Text: endured since February is not something the

Speaker: NA
Text: airline wants to go through every few years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The downgrading of Rex's gate and facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: would have had a negative impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: airline's operations, with increased conges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from a shared gate, the need to bus all its

Speaker: NA
Text: passengers to aircraft, and increased staffing

Speaker: NA
Text: costs due to the need to operate on two levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of the terminal with a lounge 400 metres

Speaker: NA
Text: away from the departure gate. Further, if Rex

Speaker: NA
Text: had not reached a satisfactory arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: today for continued use of the lounge, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have been able to meet its contrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tual obligations to its lounge members and

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate clients. According to the airline,

Speaker: NA
Text: this would have resulted in the withdrawal of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Canberra-Sydney service at the very

Speaker: NA
Text: least.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are real risks for all regional air-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines and underline the need for a close regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: latory watch on the domestic airline industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the new airport ownership regime. The

Speaker: NA
Text: its key regional player, with an operating profit

Speaker: NA
Text: of over $1 million and showing every sign of

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy growth into the future, was at risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: being severely marginalised-and, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest, is still at risk of long-term margin-

Speaker: NA
Text: alisation-by the apparent unwillingness of

Speaker: NA
Text: the owners of Sydney airport to negotiate a

Speaker: NA
Text: lease for it to retain its facilities on a long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term basis. With Australia's largest regional

Speaker: NA
Text: airline under such pressure, I cannot empha-

Speaker: NA
Text: sise enough the importance of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth government adopting the recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations of the Regional Air Summit 2004 in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to access to capital city airports. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: stress the recommendation of that parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary report adding that there must be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive access, not just access, to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not have the emergence of a dominant

Speaker: NA
Text: two in the domestic airline industry in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, with the rest pushed to the fringes

Speaker: NA
Text: with no capacity to grow or take on the lar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ger airlines at some point.

Speaker: NA
Text: The summit resolved that there must a

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative solution to the access issue and an

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate review of what constitutes fair,

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable and competitive access. Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Warren Pengilley argued very forcibly that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a case for legislation to guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: fair and competitive access to not only Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney airport but other capital city airports.

Speaker: NA
Text: One issue he raised was that section 46 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Act, dealing with misuse of

Speaker: NA
Text: market power, does not apply to access situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, because the airlines and the airports

Speaker: NA
Text: are not actually competitors. Further, guaran-

Speaker: NA
Text: teeing fair access in legislation could well be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded not as anticompetitive but as having

Speaker: NA
Text: procompetitive benefits encouraging regional

Speaker: NA
Text: players and delivering considerable benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: to regional and rural areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was supported by a paper delivered

Speaker: NA
Text: to the summit by National Economics, which

Speaker: NA
Text: found regional aviation to be vital for the

Speaker: NA
Text: social and economic wellbeing of regional

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. Indeed, communities with

Speaker: NA
Text: regular air services enjoy economic growth

Speaker: NA
Text: almost double that of those communities

Speaker: NA
Text: without such services. These regional ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices would also be served by the establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of an aviation ombudsman, as recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended by the summit. The ombudsman

Speaker: NA
Text: would be charged to investigate and mediate

Speaker: NA
Text: in disputes between aviation industry play-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers. In a complex regulatory environment

Speaker: NA
Text: which is becoming increasingly cutthroat, I

Speaker: NA
Text: can only agree with the summit that an om-

Speaker: NA
Text: budsman similar to the office created for the

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications industry is a common-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense and proactive measure for the aviation

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. The recommendations of the sum-

Speaker: NA
Text: mit provide what would be a working

Speaker: NA
Text: framework to improve the viability of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional services for rural and regional Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, and I urge the Minister for Transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services to support their adoption

Speaker: NA
Text: by the parliament under the guidance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs: Palm Island

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Text: Herbert) (5.20 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The shocking events of last Friday on Palm

Speaker: NA
Text: Island in North Queensland underscore a

Speaker: NA
Text: dysfunctional community in disarray, a

Speaker: NA
Text: community that has to be helped. In all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: words that have been said and written about

Speaker: NA
Text: the riot on Palm Island, I have not been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to find any talk about the real solution that

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be faced. This is a community of 42

Speaker: NA
Text: different tribes that has lost its cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: tage and will continue to spiral downwards if

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous leaders and governments do not

Speaker: NA
Text: face this core problem. With 86 years of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience, just how long is it going to take all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to conclude that Palm Island is

Speaker: NA
Text: not viable, and never will be, while it sits as

Speaker: NA
Text: an out of sight, out of mind, welfare-

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent community? It will remain a

Speaker: NA
Text: community where alcoholism, domestic vio-

Speaker: NA
Text: lence, drugs, health problems, unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, housing, sense of self-worth and liter-

Speaker: NA
Text: acy standards may be the worst in the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 42 tribes and their leaders on the is-

Speaker: NA
Text: land have had ample time to do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about the hopelessness that pervades the

Speaker: NA
Text: community. They have had more than

Speaker: NA
Text: enough money, yet nothing changes, year

Speaker: NA
Text: after year. Since 1998, when I came to un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand Palm Island, I have been supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: an integrationist model-a model that has

Speaker: NA
Text: worked well on the mainland. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: 8,000 Indigenous Australians in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate of Lindsay, the majority living in the cit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies of Townsville and Thuringowa. Those on

Speaker: NA
Text: the mainland do not share the lack of self-

Speaker: NA
Text: esteem, the domestic violence, the lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: job opportunities, the lack of housing and the

Speaker: NA
Text: poor education that typify the Palm Island

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier Beattie's five-point plan, an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced yesterday when he went to the is-

Speaker: NA
Text: land, has to be seen for what is-a recipe for

Speaker: NA
Text: more of the same. The Indigenous people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Palm Island do aspire to be better, and I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that the key to that is the current review

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Queensland government Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Land Act. I strongly support making changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to land tenure on Palm Island. It is the key to

Speaker: NA
Text: improving the self-esteem of islanders and to

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing about local integration. It will pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide an opportunity for economic participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and home ownership; something island-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers cannot even dream about under the deed

Speaker: NA
Text: heriof grant in trust tenure. Presently islanders

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot own their own home or their own

Speaker: NA
Text: land, so they do not have any equity and

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot get a business loan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland government will say,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘This is all too difficult,' and ask, ‘How

Speaker: NA
Text: would we ever handle freeholding the town-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship areas? How would we ever handle the

Speaker: NA
Text: tenure on the balance of the island?' But I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the Queensland government of two

Speaker: NA
Text: things: firstly, failure to act will see Palm

Speaker: NA
Text: Island stay the way it is and, secondly, Abo-

Speaker: NA
Text: riginal people I talk to want this to happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most costly mistake that we could make

Speaker: NA
Text: now would be to continue to think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of infrastructure and the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of a coordinated program delivery strat-

Speaker: NA
Text: egy on Palm Island will solve the social, po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical, cultural and economic issues impact-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing upon the residents there.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind the House of the history of Palm

Speaker: NA
Text: Island. The settlement was established in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1918 as a government reserve under the 1897

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals Protection and Restriction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sale of Opium Act. This enabled local police

Speaker: NA
Text: protectors throughout Queensland to remove

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people

Speaker: NA
Text: to reserves. Palm Island was established in

Speaker: NA
Text: the early days as an Aboriginal penal settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. That is how representatives of some 42

Speaker: NA
Text: tribes came to be taken to the island and to

Speaker: NA
Text: form the core of the problem that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following last Friday's riots no-one mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: understands the need for the community to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a whole lot of healing, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government cannot do that for the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. We understand that the islanders need to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with their historical issues and that govservices.

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments need to look differently at how we

Speaker: NA
Text: do business with the island community. For

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's part, we can get our sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems operating better and our service sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems sorted out, but the answer is not in

Speaker: NA
Text: plane loads of bureaucrats going to Palm

Speaker: NA
Text: Island trying to interfere with the rebuilding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community. Unfortunately, Palm Is-

Speaker: NA
Text: land does not have the cultural authority of

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional owners that is found in other

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. This is the result of its history.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an artificial community. People have lost

Speaker: NA
Text: their way. Young people these days have no

Speaker: NA
Text: idea where they have come from or what

Speaker: NA
Text: their culture is.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the immediate term I am concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about the influx of strangers who are now

Speaker: NA
Text: arriving daily on the island and what they

Speaker: NA
Text: will bring to the community. This is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: time for radicalism. Out of respect for Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Doomadgee's family, I ask that people re-

Speaker: NA
Text: main calm. I am encouraged that the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian government's new arrangements for the

Speaker: NA
Text: disbandment of ATSIC will see many prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems in Indigenous affairs sorted out. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a welcome response from Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous leaders, but governments can only do

Speaker: NA
Text: so much. In the end the community needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: do a lot more.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the years there have been many re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports on the conditions of Palm Island and

Speaker: NA
Text: what to do about them. They reaffirm time

Speaker: NA
Text: and time again that the way forward must

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the contemporary issues facing

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal people, that they are linked to

Speaker: NA
Text: history and that any response needs to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress that history. Residents of Palm Island

Speaker: NA
Text: have said on many occasions that the lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: an economic base and limited employment

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities perpetuate the continued de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence on governments for funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: basic services. This results in residents who

Speaker: NA
Text: find themselves living below the poverty line

Speaker: NA
Text: in inadequate housing with minimal support

Speaker: NA
Text: Most residents resent this situation

Speaker: NA
Text: and see economic development as the only

Speaker: NA
Text: means of breaking the welfare cycle. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: why I believe that the integration model I

Speaker: NA
Text: have rearticulated today is the only way for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward for islanders to be able to live a decent

Speaker: NA
Text: life free from the scourge of Third World

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been travelling to Palm Island for

Speaker: NA
Text: nine years. I despair when I go there and I

Speaker: NA
Text: see the way that the people live: garbage

Speaker: NA
Text: strewn about the main town centre, homes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are destroyed, four families living in one

Speaker: NA
Text: home, alcoholism and domestic violence-

Speaker: NA
Text: and on it goes. We have to change it. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a responsibility as community leaders

Speaker: NA
Text: to articulate the way to change. As much as

Speaker: NA
Text: many islanders will perhaps say that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty radical, it is the only way it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: change. Otherwise, we will be here in 100

Speaker: NA
Text: years time and it will still be the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: I certainly would like to see the integra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Palm Island into mainstream Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia as the way forward. I do not ever again

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see headlines such as the one we saw

Speaker: NA
Text: in Saturday's Townsville Bulletin which said,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Palm Island Explodes. Police station, court-

Speaker: NA
Text: house torched'. I do not ever want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: headlines such as we have seen today on

Speaker: NA
Text: ABC News Online: ‘Angry scenes at Palm Is

Speaker: NA
Text: court hearing'. It was a disgraceful situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The media tell me that even on the mainland

Speaker: NA
Text: in the court they were concerned for their

Speaker: NA
Text: safety. This is Australia. This is no place for

Speaker: NA
Text: the violence that has erupted in the north in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last few days. There is no place for future

Speaker: NA
Text: violence. I certainly hope that the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders know and understand that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition government believe Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Australians, wherever they live, should

Speaker: NA
Text: have the same opportunities as other Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians to make informed choices about their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives, to realise their full potential in what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever they choose to do and to take responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for managing their own affairs. In that

Speaker: NA
Text: sense, we will spend thousands of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in the coming financial year on In-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous specific programs. While much has

Speaker: NA
Text: been achieved, Australians all want better

Speaker: NA
Text: results. We can get better results. I encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: the Palm Island community to think deeply

Speaker: NA
Text: about a new land tenure model which will

Speaker: NA
Text: see an integration into mainstream Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and stop the terrible dysfunctional commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity that currently exists 70 kilometres north-

Speaker: NA
Text: west of Townsville.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: New England) (5.30

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)- Mr Deputy Speaker Beazley, I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate you on your first appearance as

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. K.C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley)-I got it for free, mate; don't worry

Speaker: NA
Text: about me!

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: I grieve today, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: call for a parliamentary inquiry-preferably

Speaker: NA
Text: a Senate inquiry-into the various allega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions that I made in this House last Wednes-

Speaker: NA
Text: day night and into the broader implications

Speaker: NA
Text: of government funding and political precon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions that are being placed on various

Speaker: NA
Text: packages of government funding, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly Regional Partnerships program ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements. There was some cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: examination during question time today re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lating to that particular issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is very important that a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of things be placed on record in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police inquiry into the

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations and the people that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: named recently and in terms of the much

Speaker: NA
Text: broader issue of funding arrangements, min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isterial ethics, the rights of a member of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament to represent, and the various political

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions that are being placed on financial

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements through the Regional Partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The date 20 September is very clear in my

Speaker: NA
Text: memory, because it is the day that the funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: was conducted for the Independent member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dubbo. He was a good friend of mine. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to see the member for Parkes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber, because he, like me, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrating the victory of the new member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dubbo, Dawn Fardell. I am delighted that

Speaker: NA
Text: she had a very good win in the Dubbo by-

Speaker: NA
Text: election last Saturday. On my way back from

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony MCGrane's funeral on 20 September, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was phoned by various media people from

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. It had become public knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: that I had been approached by an intermedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary for two political players with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: requesting me to vacate the premises as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for New England. That was the first

Speaker: NA
Text: day that particular issue became public. The

Speaker: NA
Text: next day-or it may have been the day af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter-the Australian Labor Party referred it to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Electoral Commission and on

Speaker: NA
Text: to the AFP for investigation as a breach of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Electoral Act under the bribery provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions.

Speaker: NA
Text: At no stage did I mention any names. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, at that stage I refused to mention names,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I saw it as a piece of political stupidbeen

Speaker: NA
Text: ity. That night, there were a number of abu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive phone calls made to a number of people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of them were from one Greg Maguire,

Speaker: NA
Text: who was subsequently-after my speech last

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday-recognised as the man who

Speaker: NA
Text: was the intermediary. It was obvious at that

Speaker: NA
Text: stage that Mr Maguire had recognised him-

Speaker: NA
Text: self as the messenger, even though no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: had been named. A few days later, the Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: uty Prime Minister, John Anderson, made a

Speaker: NA
Text: phone call to Mr Maguire. The message con-

Speaker: NA
Text: veyed in that phone call was, ‘Get your mate

Speaker: NA
Text: to pull back'-remember that this was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: middle of an election campaign-‘this is

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger than all of us.' Some would ask, quite

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly, how I know that. I know it because

Speaker: NA
Text: Greg Maguire told me that the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister had rung him.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the sorts of facts that need to

Speaker: NA
Text: come out in an inquiry. They could not come

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the AFP inquiry because that inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: was very narrow, in that it looked at a breach

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Electoral Act, and the questioning was

Speaker: NA
Text: very narrow. It was based on one conversa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the various witnesses to that conver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation. I was not at all surprised when the

Speaker: NA
Text: AFP found that there was not a prima facie

Speaker: NA
Text: case to answer in terms of proceeding to a

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal charge. As I mentioned in my

Speaker: NA
Text: speech last Wednesday night, up until that

Speaker: NA
Text: time John Anderson had spent a lot of time in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. After that, he was very rarely

Speaker: NA
Text: there; I think he came back on one occasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went off to places further north-mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate of Kennedy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The broader issues that I spoke about ear-

Speaker: NA
Text: lier are the preconditions for funding-the

Speaker: NA
Text: political benefit as opposed to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: good. I will not go through them this after-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon, but they have been outlined on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 7.30 Report and Lenore Taylor had a good

Speaker: NA
Text: article in the Financial Review last week.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was essentially about a whole range of

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Partnerships programs that have

Speaker: NA
Text: abused in some sense-not in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits or multiplier effect of some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those programs. I think the equine centre is a

Speaker: NA
Text: classic example. It is a great program and I

Speaker: NA
Text: am glad it is funded, but there were political

Speaker: NA
Text: preconditions put on in a number of these

Speaker: NA
Text: cases. Another example is the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: New England cash for comment scandal that

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred some months ago in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other examples in other electorates

Speaker: NA
Text: across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call on the parliament, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate, to conduct an inquiry into these mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. There are some very broad matters relat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to not only the bribery issue but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader issue of political compromise in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to the funding of particular Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Partnerships packages. At that inquiry, the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who were witnesses to the various

Speaker: NA
Text: events that I discussed last week are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to present their evidence and to be

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-examined. For the life of me, I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: work out why Mr Anderson and Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Sandy Macdonald are afraid of an inquiry. If

Speaker: NA
Text: I am the one who has wronged in this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular issue, as they keep claiming, why not

Speaker: NA
Text: barbecue me on the floor of some inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: and pull me to pieces? Why are they afraid

Speaker: NA
Text: of having an inquiry into this incident? Why

Speaker: NA
Text: are they afraid of the truth? Why do they

Speaker: NA
Text: hide behind that very narrow interpretation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the AFP? They may well have known

Speaker: NA
Text: about that result before the AFP came out. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know that. But I do know, as one who

Speaker: NA
Text: was interviewed, that it was a very narrow

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into a section of the Electoral Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Are they prepared to make their phone re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cords available? Is the Deputy Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter prepared to make his phone records from

Speaker: NA
Text: that period of time available? I am quite pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to make available my records which

Speaker: NA
Text: will trace the phone calls I made. Is the Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: uty Prime Minister willing to make those

Speaker: NA
Text: phone call records available?

Speaker: NA
Text: Another issue that has come to light in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last week is that of the Bundarra Grace

Speaker: NA
Text: Munro aged care facility. It goes to the heart

Speaker: NA
Text: of this issue and the right of the MP to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: out his job. I wrote to the aged care minister

Speaker: NA
Text: some time ago, inviting her to open the

Speaker: NA
Text: Grace Munro aged care facility. She wrote

Speaker: NA
Text: back suggesting that she could not be there

Speaker: NA
Text: but that Senator Macdonald would be her

Speaker: NA
Text: representative. A draft program was put out

Speaker: NA
Text: with a number of official parties, some of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom were to speak, of which I was one. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had quite a bit to do with this project. I

Speaker: NA
Text: received a letter on Friday from Robert Ful-

Speaker: NA
Text: cher-who in my view is a very good gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral manager-of Uralla Shire Council, the

Speaker: NA
Text: hosts of this particular function. They de-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve great credit for the work they have put

Speaker: NA
Text: in. Robert Fulcher wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: Dear Tony,

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth government has advised that

Speaker: NA
Text: its representative-

Speaker: NA
Text: the name is not written here but Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Macdonald is the representative-

Speaker: NA
Text: has advised that its representative at the official

Speaker: NA
Text: opening of the Grace Munro Centre does not wish

Speaker: NA
Text: for you to be part of the official party or the offi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial speeches. The mayor, Councillor Ron Filmer,

Speaker: NA
Text: has asked me to tell you that he regrets to advise

Speaker: NA
Text: you that the council will need to comply with the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's wishes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that goes to the heart of this very is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sue. I seek leave to table the document.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: I also seek leave to ta-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble the cash for comment documents in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the University of New England and

Speaker: NA
Text: the preconditions that were placed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement of that funding and subse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent political ramifications associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: the University of New England.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Text: I will not have time to

Speaker: NA
Text: go through that particular part of the issue. In

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, I would ask the parliament not to

Speaker: NA
Text: be afraid of inquiring into this issue. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are much broader ramifications of this than

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues that I raised last week. The issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: truth was raised last week, and the truth has

Speaker: NA
Text: not yet been told. I think that one of the ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jor jobs of this parliament, and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate, is to spend time on ascertaining

Speaker: NA
Text: the truth, and to allow the witnesses to those

Speaker: NA
Text: conversations-and others who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: privy to various funding arrangements and

Speaker: NA
Text: preconditions across Australia-the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to put their cases, to be cross-examined

Speaker: NA
Text: and to be torn apart if that is what is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired. As I said earlier, why are Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Macdonald and Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Anderson afraid of the truth of this issue?

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr JOHN COBB
Text: Parkes-Parliament-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary Secretary to the Minister for Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: and Regional Services) (5.40 p.m.)-What

Speaker: NA
Text: we have today is a further attempt by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for New England to discredit the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of commitments under Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Partnerships during an election campaign. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, it is an attempt to discredit the Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Partnerships process.

Speaker: NA
Text: The normal assessment process, which he

Speaker: NA
Text: could find out about quite easily if he wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: to, revolves around two different criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: When a commitment is made in a very nor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal way during an election it is made on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis that it is a project that will achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: those things which Regional Partnerships set

Speaker: NA
Text: out to do: to help that area either in a social

Speaker: NA
Text: way or in an economic way. The social out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes we look for are things like medical

Speaker: NA
Text: centres, which will have a prolonged, sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable benefit for the region. In terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic outlook, we are looking to create

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. If it is an election promise then-as I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure the member for New England is to-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally aware-it still has to go through due

Speaker: NA
Text: process and it still has to meet the criteria for

Speaker: NA
Text: government programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The motivation we have here-and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: go into that a little later-of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: New England is not about the Regional Part-

Speaker: NA
Text: nerships program; it is a totally political mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivation. The normal practice, the procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: by which regional partnerships happen dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing election campaigns, is to make that

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that due diligence will be done

Speaker: NA
Text: following the election-before the project is

Speaker: NA
Text: funded and before it is signed off. Then it is

Speaker: NA
Text: finally approved; it is a straightforward, open

Speaker: NA
Text: and totally accountable process for commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities and regions. As I said, it is about delivgional

Speaker: NA
Text: ering economic growth and sustainable,

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term community outcomes. This gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is very proud of the record of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional partnerships. There probably has

Speaker: NA
Text: never been a better program to help commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities which have problems of isolation or

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an attempt by the member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England to get himself out of a hole. He

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned just a while ago that during the

Speaker: NA
Text: election he made an attack on the person

Speaker: NA
Text: who is probably second to none in this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament for his reputation for integrity, hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: esty and trustworthiness. So strong is his

Speaker: NA
Text: reputation that the media and even the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition know full well that the Acting Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is not subject to acts of corruption

Speaker: NA
Text: or acts of bribery and is probably the most

Speaker: NA
Text: honest person in this House. He is, without

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt, a paragon of propriety and integrity,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I have no doubt the member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England is well aware of that, but he made

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations off the cuff to the media during

Speaker: NA
Text: the election and then tried to laugh it off

Speaker: NA
Text: when he realised he had perhaps started

Speaker: NA
Text: something he could not stop. When the La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party then demanded that the AFP look

Speaker: NA
Text: into it, he thought, ‘How do I get out of this?'

Speaker: NA
Text: What he did then was to go on the attack. He

Speaker: NA
Text: picked the wrong person to attack. When he

Speaker: NA
Text: really fell flat on his face was, first, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: person he alleged to be the carrier of this

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged corruption refuted it in the open in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tamworth and then again when, lo and be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hold, the AFP looked at the situation and said

Speaker: NA
Text: there was no case to answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: What was the member for New England

Speaker: NA
Text: to do at that point? He had made a fool of

Speaker: NA
Text: himself; he suddenly realised that the me-

Speaker: NA
Text: dia-everybody-knew he was attacking a

Speaker: NA
Text: man who nobody believed for one second

Speaker: NA
Text: was guilty of any of the things that the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for New England accused him of. What

Speaker: NA
Text: did he do then? He decided, ‘I'll attack Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: Partnerships. I'll try to make out that

Speaker: NA
Text: there's a corrupt political basis by which

Speaker: NA
Text: these are done.' There is no political or cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupt basis involved here. It is a very straight-

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, clear process by which these pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams are put forward and signed off. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are done by an area consultative committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: a department and the proponent themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you look at the way in which these pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects are put around Australia, they go to op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position seats, they go to independent seats

Speaker: NA
Text: and, yes, they go to government seats.

Speaker: NA
Text: Probably the main reason why the majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of the projects go to government seats is that

Speaker: NA
Text: most regional seats are held by the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government. So I think mathematics proves

Speaker: NA
Text: that what should happen does happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that what the member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England has done in attacking one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: better programs the government has ever

Speaker: NA
Text: come up with-simply because he was try-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, under privilege of the House, to attack a

Speaker: NA
Text: man whose integrity has never been ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned-is probably one of the lowest things

Speaker: NA
Text: I have ever seen in three years in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why he is in trouble: he did it and he

Speaker: NA
Text: knows it was wrong. I think the constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: of New England have a lot of questions to

Speaker: NA
Text: ask a member who, instead of doing his job

Speaker: NA
Text: in representing them and trying to get pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects for them, has stooped to attacking the

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Prime Minister, who, as I have said

Speaker: NA
Text: and will repeat in any forum, has an integrity

Speaker: NA
Text: that is respected by everyone in this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the possible exception of a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: independents.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say, too, that in this last

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Calare has questioned the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priety of the Regional Partnerships program.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find that strange. I find it strange that he

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in some sense, the member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England are aware of the program at all. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Prime Minister, the parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary previously assisting the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Transport and Regional Services and me,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the short time I have been in this role,

Speaker: NA
Text: have never seen one letter of support from

Speaker: NA
Text: either the member for New England or the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Calare for any Regional Partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships program in their electorates. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: they would be far better off to get around,

Speaker: NA
Text: look after their electorates, support their

Speaker: NA
Text: ACC and support the proponents who are

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for projects to help their communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties either socially or economically, rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than try to bring down somebody whose in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegrity has never before been questioned in

Speaker: NA
Text: his 15 or 16 years in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that the member for New Eng-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and the member for Calare go back to

Speaker: NA
Text: their electorates and do their jobs. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the member for New England would do

Speaker: NA
Text: if he were going to be serious after pulling

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the lowest acts we are ever likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: see in this place-using parliamentary privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege and not waiting for the finding of the

Speaker: NA
Text: AFP when he could have quite easily done

Speaker: NA
Text: so; but, no, he wanted to get out there and try

Speaker: NA
Text: and besmirch someone whose reputation he

Speaker: NA
Text: can only aspire to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say that rural and regional Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is very well served by a program which

Speaker: NA
Text: has stood the test of some 18 months. Like

Speaker: NA
Text: its predecessor, the Regional Solutions Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, it is delivering to country Australia. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a great pity that one member in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: is putting a desire to see himself on the front

Speaker: NA
Text: pages of newspapers over the top of decency

Speaker: NA
Text: and over the top of a program which has al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready helped his electorate some nine times

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last 18 months and helped Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: week the the tune of over $100 million so far.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will mention one other thing, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Calare was talking about during

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate: regional aviation. This govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done an incredible amount to help

Speaker: NA
Text: regional aviation, including capping landing

Speaker: NA
Text: charges at Sydney airport, quarantining land-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing slots, exempting small regional airlines

Speaker: NA
Text: like Rex from en route air traffic control

Speaker: NA
Text: charges and subsidising regional charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rex airlines itself acknowledges that without

Speaker: NA
Text: this government's assistance there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: no Rex. This government will look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the regional aviation

Speaker: NA
Text: summit, but it is wrong to suggest, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Calare does, that all problems

Speaker: NA
Text: can be fixed by more and more regulation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations and Financial Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Appointment

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. K.C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley)- Mr Speaker has received a mes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sage from the Senate concurring with the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions of the House and transmitting a

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed variation to paragraph (a) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution of appointment of the Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Joint Committee on Corporations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the message be considered at

Speaker: NA
Text: the next sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Committees

Speaker: NA
Text: Appointment

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. K.C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley)- Mr Speaker has received a mes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sage from the Senate concurring with the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions of the House relating to the ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointment of the following joint committees:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Crime Commission;

Speaker: NA
Text: Electoral Matters;

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade;

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration;

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital and External Territories;

Speaker: NA
Text: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres

Speaker: NA
Text: Strait Islander Land Fund; and

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaties.

Speaker: NA
Text: GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S SPEECH

Speaker: NA
Text: Address-in-Reply

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Lingiari) (5.52 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker Beazley, may I say what

Speaker: NA
Text: a privilege it is to see you in this august

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. K.C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley)-You may say that anytime you

Speaker: NA
Text: like.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Congratulations on

Speaker: NA
Text: your elevation. I am sure you will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to use your experience and that you will do

Speaker: NA
Text: this job with a great deal of professionalism

Speaker: NA
Text: and aplomb.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Thank you

Speaker: NA
Text: very much.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: I am looking forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to the wise decisions which you will make.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: That is right,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will sack you at the drop of the hat if

Speaker: NA
Text: you give me any trouble at all.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Prior to the debate be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing interrupted, I was privileged to be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber at the end of the contribution from

Speaker: NA
Text: new member for Wentworth. I received a

Speaker: NA
Text: standing ovation as I stood up-or at least I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought I did. But then it dawned for me that

Speaker: NA
Text: it really was for the member for Wentworth

Speaker: NA
Text: and what he had to say and that the 400 in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vited guests who had come down from Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney to hear his speech were not, in fact, ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plauding me-which was a great disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointment to me-but him. I am not disillu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioned, however, because I know they are

Speaker: NA
Text: still around and there is time for conversion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did point out to them, and I hope they go

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the electorate of Wentworth know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, that there is a very valid expectation on

Speaker: NA
Text: my behalf and that of others on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber that the member for Wentworth

Speaker: NA
Text: will occupy that seat he sits on on that side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the chamber for only a short time, three

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and then, unless the government de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termines it wants to have an election before

Speaker: NA
Text: then, we will see the member for Wentworth

Speaker: NA
Text: experience the vagaries-if I might describe

Speaker: NA
Text: posiit in that way-of the opposition benches. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure he will have a long and successful

Speaker: NA
Text: political career, but I hope that the electors of

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth will not be too disappointed

Speaker: NA
Text: when he is not in government after the next

Speaker: NA
Text: election.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to raise some issues about the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion result and in particular the result in my

Speaker: NA
Text: own electorate. I described my electorate in

Speaker: NA
Text: my previous short contribution. I compared it

Speaker: NA
Text: to the member for Wentworth's electorate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know the area of the Wentworth elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate, perhaps the clerks could tell me, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: suspect it is less than 100 square kilometres;

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps it is a lot less than that. My own

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you well

Speaker: NA
Text: know, is diverse, disparate, dispersed and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.34 million square kilometres. It comprises

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Indian Ocean, with which you are famil-

Speaker: NA
Text: iar, and all of the area of the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory except Darwin and Palmerston. A major

Speaker: NA
Text: element of the electorate of Lingiari is that in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of 40 per cent of its constituents are

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Australians. It is a unique elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate in that respect, if for no other reason;

Speaker: NA
Text: but its geography and demography make it

Speaker: NA
Text: unique in any event.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank the people of Lingiari for

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsing me again as their representative in

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber. I would point out that I am one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the few people on this side of the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: who achieved a reasonably significant swing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am now sitting on almost 58 per cent-57.7

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent-which is, for me, a reasonable lux-

Speaker: NA
Text: ury compared with the margin I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: used to. From my own perspective, it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant result. In the seven elections I

Speaker: NA
Text: have now contested, this is the first time I

Speaker: NA
Text: have won the vote in Alice Springs. It is sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant that, of the 24 static booths in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, I achieved swings in 18. Across

Speaker: NA
Text: the 270 mobile polling places our average

Speaker: NA
Text: vote was 79 per cent, almost 80 per cent, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that itself was a swing to us. In any event, it

Speaker: NA
Text: showed the confidence not only of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the bush and remote communities but also

Speaker: NA
Text: of people in the towns who voted for us and

Speaker: NA
Text: gave us their support. I am very grateful and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, thankful for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank all of those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed to the campaign-the campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, the volunteers, my family and all

Speaker: NA
Text: the others, too many to name, who make an

Speaker: NA
Text: election possible in terms of a candidate's

Speaker: NA
Text: success or otherwise. It is absolutely true in

Speaker: NA
Text: my case that without the work of dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteers, many of whom took in this last

Speaker: NA
Text: election more than a week off work to do the

Speaker: NA
Text: mobile polling, I would not win. It is just

Speaker: NA
Text: physically impossible to get around and do

Speaker: NA
Text: all the things you need to do with the turnout

Speaker: NA
Text: to a poll. It is a taxing exercise in the elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate and I would never be successful were it

Speaker: NA
Text: not for the commitment of those people, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to place on the record my thanks to

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I also want to point out that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Lingiari had a very good reason not to

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for the government. Part of that was our

Speaker: NA
Text: positive plan and vision for Northern Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. It is clear that they wanted major im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provements in infrastructure. They wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: and still want the government to keep Telstra

Speaker: NA
Text: in majority public ownership and to force

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra to focus on the telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of remote towns and communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again I will juxtapose my electorate with

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Wentworth's. The telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications difficulties that confront people

Speaker: NA
Text: who live in remote Australia are probably

Speaker: NA
Text: incomprehensible to most of the electors of

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth. I think this is a problem the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party has. It is clear that The Nationals

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the implications of this proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: sale of Telstra and are concerned about it. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a fact that individuals from cockies corner

Speaker: NA
Text: who are members of that party have been

Speaker: NA
Text: brave enough to stand up and say on a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of occasions to the party, ‘We don't want

Speaker: NA
Text: you to pursue the full sale of Telstra.' I will

Speaker: NA
Text: be pushing that issue strongly. Whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: government can argue all it likes about what

Speaker: NA
Text: it believes its mandate might be, I know the

Speaker: NA
Text: directions I have from the people of Lin-

Speaker: NA
Text: giari-and they are to oppose vehemently

Speaker: NA
Text: the further sale of Telstra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, there are other significant is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues, such as the shocking state of the Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory's roads. I have raised that in this cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber on many occasions, and I will not go

Speaker: NA
Text: through the details of it now. I will just note

Speaker: NA
Text: that the previous speaker in this place, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parkes, was talking about the

Speaker: NA
Text: statements made about government pork-

Speaker: NA
Text: barrelling. Let me be very clear that the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for roads through the last parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: was skewed monumentally towards govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment electorates. My own electorate, which

Speaker: NA
Text: arguably has the worst roads in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: was very underresourced in comparison to

Speaker: NA
Text: those other electorates-and I name particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the member for Gwydir's electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: because under the Roads to Recovery pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram an electorate one-tenth the size of the

Speaker: NA
Text: seat of Lingiari received over twice the fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for roads. There are in the seat of Lin-

Speaker: NA
Text: giari 9,000 kilometres of roads on unincorpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rated land-dirt roads that link small, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote, isolated communities, and at many

Speaker: NA
Text: times during the year, particularly in the wet

Speaker: NA
Text: season, many of these communities cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: use the roads. This compounds the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: living in these places and places an addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional burden on the communities. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: something the government has thought

Speaker: NA
Text: through, and I maintain the view that this has

Speaker: NA
Text: been an exercise in pork-barrelling. The

Speaker: NA
Text: funding has been skewed. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: has used the formula, but the funding has

Speaker: NA
Text: been skewed monumentally towards gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment electorates-principally National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party electorates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there is the neglect of public health

Speaker: NA
Text: and bulk-billing. Mr Deputy Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley, you live in a very fine city. I imag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ine that you could drive from your home and

Speaker: NA
Text: within five or six kilometres come to a bulk-

Speaker: NA
Text: billing doctor. In my electorate of 1.4 million

Speaker: NA
Text: square kilometres, there is only one private

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk-billing medical practice in the top end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Territory. We pay the highest fees for

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations of anywhere in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: average consultation fee is $52. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for health and the government come in here

Speaker: NA
Text: saying what they are doing for the bush. I

Speaker: NA
Text: can tell you what they are not doing: they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not delivering accessible health services-

Speaker: NA
Text: and parents are choosing not to take their

Speaker: NA
Text: children or themselves to the doctor because

Speaker: NA
Text: they simply cannot afford it, because they do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have access to bulk-billing private medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal practices. That is another reason why the

Speaker: NA
Text: community was not going to vote for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government and was pleased to support me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there is the question of schools, both

Speaker: NA
Text: public and private, being resourced at a level

Speaker: NA
Text: which will give kids in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory the same learning opportunities as those

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by other Australian children. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: address that issue in another debate in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place which is coming up in the next day or

Speaker: NA
Text: so, because the absolute disadvantage suf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fered by Indigenous Territorians in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: public education is largely a direct result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the neglect of governments. I want to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: point about the member for Goldstein's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution earlier today. I know we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to interject during members' first

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches, but his very simplistic analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: the concerns of Indigenous Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for public policy in Indigenous Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia needs some detailed comment. If I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have time today, at some later point I will

Speaker: NA
Text: address that in great detail. What it demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated was the sort of ignorance that is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: petrated by the conservatives in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: about the state of Indigenous affairs. His

Speaker: NA
Text: comment was-and it is worth while reading

Speaker: NA
Text: this bit:

Speaker: NA
Text: The chilling fact is that the very fabric of a proud

Speaker: NA
Text: and fascinating culture, many thousands of years

Speaker: NA
Text: in the making, has been brought to its knees in

Speaker: NA
Text: less than 30 years by well-intentioned but seri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously misguided policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know where this bloke comes from,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he is clearly ignorant of Australian his-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory and has no understanding of the history

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian public policy, of the concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: and aspirations of Indigenous Australians or

Speaker: NA
Text: of what they have been saying to successive

Speaker: NA
Text: governments over the last 30 years. If he had

Speaker: NA
Text: any knowledge whatsoever, he would say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the reason these people are in such dire

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty is not only because of poor public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy but also because of the failure to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cept the legitimate demands made by Indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous Australians on the Australian commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to have their citizenship rights recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised. One of the real problems is that those

Speaker: NA
Text: citizenship rights are not properly recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised. In many parts of Australia, and cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly in my own electorate, where there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: $850 million shortage of housing in the bush,

Speaker: NA
Text: where people live 20 or 30 people to a home,

Speaker: NA
Text: and where there are no high schools or em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment opportunities, people like the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Goldstein choose to blame the

Speaker: NA
Text: victims. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that that is a foolish way to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: I lastly want to address very quickly the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of the redistribution. We had a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution before the last election, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: was said that the seat of Lingiari and the seat

Speaker: NA
Text: of Solomon would need to be combined into

Speaker: NA
Text: one seat. As a result of an inquiry by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Committee on Electoral Matters in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, it was agreed to make a recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that they should look at the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the quota was applied to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory would maintain two

Speaker: NA
Text: seats for the last election. I have had the

Speaker: NA
Text: liamentary Library look at the result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: election and what the determination might be

Speaker: NA
Text: for any future redistribution based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: projected population figures for June 2005.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sadly, we have something which deeply con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns me and will come as no surprise be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause, on the population figures that are be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing estimated, we will again be facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of one seat for the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory. That will be a tragedy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the member for Solomon is not in

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber, but let me make it very clear to

Speaker: NA
Text: him that, on the basis of the last election, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you combined the votes of the seats of

Speaker: NA
Text: Solomon and Lingiari I would still be the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for the Northern Territory and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Solomon would not be gracing

Speaker: NA
Text: us with his presence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelvin Thomson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: That is right. If we go

Speaker: NA
Text: back to one seat, I anticipate he will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: here. So I imagine the government members,

Speaker: NA
Text: and not least the member for Solomon, will

Speaker: NA
Text: be considering ways in which they can se-

Speaker: NA
