Text: cure the two seats. The only way I think they

Speaker: NA
Text: can do it is to guarantee by legislation that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory has a minimum of two

Speaker: NA
Text: seats. That is the only way. In my view, they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot validly argue, using the criteria which

Speaker: NA
Text: are established under the electoral act, that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can fiddle with the statistics in a way

Speaker: NA
Text: which could give us two seats, even though

Speaker: NA
Text: we have grave concerns about the accuracy

Speaker: NA
Text: of that data.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to place on the record my deep

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that the possibility of us going back

Speaker: NA
Text: to one seat is really on the agenda. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that should challenge the minds of

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of the Northern Territory and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed the Northern Territory government-

Speaker: NA
Text: which I am sure it will. I can imagine the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Solomon ferreting away to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that he can maintain the two seats. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want the two seats, but I am not afraid of

Speaker: NA
Text: Pargoing back to one seat because, if we go

Speaker: NA
Text: back to one seat, there will be one member

Speaker: NA
Text: here, and it will not be him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: I am pleased to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have the support of my colleagues. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am glad they are here. Normally they would

Speaker: NA
Text: not front. I stood up to give this speech and I

Speaker: NA
Text: was applauded. I have come in here and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a crowd. The gallery is almost full. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have come in here and they are back to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port me again. That is a great privilege.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Prospect, I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members that this is his first

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. I therefore ask that the usual courte-

Speaker: NA
Text: sies be extended to him.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: Prospect) (6.08 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: From the high rises of Fairfield to the farms

Speaker: NA
Text: of Kemps Creek, Prospect is a diverse and

Speaker: NA
Text: exciting community. It is the community that

Speaker: NA
Text: I grew up in, and it has given me enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities. It is an honour to represent my

Speaker: NA
Text: community in this House as the third mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Prospect.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1788 Captain Arthur Phillip and Watkin

Speaker: NA
Text: Tench stood on a hill west of the settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: at Sydney Cove. They agreed that the area

Speaker: NA
Text: that they could see from the hill was fertile

Speaker: NA
Text: and had good prospects. Accordingly, the hill

Speaker: NA
Text: and the region that they surveyed came to be

Speaker: NA
Text: known as Prospect. Governor Phillip was

Speaker: NA
Text: right about the area having good prospects,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I am sure he would not recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: multicultural city that has developed in its

Speaker: NA
Text: fields. Families who have lived in Prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: for six generations have welcomed recent

Speaker: NA
Text: arrivals who have struggled over oceans to

Speaker: NA
Text: get here and make our area their home.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is appropriate tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: to the second member for Prospect, the Hon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janice Crosio. Janice was a larger than life

Speaker: NA
Text: figure in our electorate. She had a remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able knack of reading the mood of her con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents and representing their views here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra with a loud, booming voice to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that they were heard. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: Janice Crosio, and I will not attempt to be. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am a different person with a different style.

Speaker: NA
Text: But if I can read the views of the electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: and represent their views here as well as she

Speaker: NA
Text: did over so many years, I will be doing well

Speaker: NA
Text: as a member of this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the people of Prospect for their

Speaker: NA
Text: support on 9 October. I said all through the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign that I did not take their support for

Speaker: NA
Text: granted and that I would be treating the seat

Speaker: NA
Text: like it was marginal. This was not spin and it

Speaker: NA
Text: remains my approach. I do not, and never

Speaker: NA
Text: will, take the support of the people of Pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect for granted, and I will be working to

Speaker: NA
Text: retain and increase their support over the

Speaker: NA
Text: coming years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the men and women of Labor-the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of Fairfield, Greystanes, Smithfield

Speaker: NA
Text: and St Clair Colyton branches who worked

Speaker: NA
Text: hard on election day, many of them all day. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure the House will not mind me ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledging just a few people who worked

Speaker: NA
Text: above and beyond the call of duty in the

Speaker: NA
Text: lead-up to the campaign: Rolando Atienza,

Speaker: NA
Text: Rodolfo Dimitui, Ninos Khoshaba, Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Dumbrell, Gino Coeira, Tim MCPhail, Jim

Speaker: NA
Text: Hanna and Albert Mooshi. I also thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: senior vice-president of the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales branch of the ALP, Bernie Riordan,

Speaker: NA
Text: the general secretary, Mark Arbib, and John

Speaker: NA
Text: Azarias, Paul Binsted and Gabbie Trainor for

Speaker: NA
Text: their support. My gratitude also goes to some

Speaker: NA
Text: of my new colleagues who lent me advice

Speaker: NA
Text: and assistance. I thank the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position, the members for Barton, Perth,

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley, Hunter, Fowler and Chifley and also

Speaker: NA
Text: that I pay tribute Senator Conroy.

Speaker: NA
Text: My involvement in politics did not begin

Speaker: NA
Text: when the six-week campaign began. I joined

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party 17 years ago and was elected

Speaker: NA
Text: to Fairfield Council in 1995. Over that time,

Speaker: NA
Text: there were three people in particular who

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken every opportunity to support me

Speaker: NA
Text: and to urge me on to eventually become the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Prospect. I did not need much

Speaker: NA
Text: urging. However, I do very much appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: the support of Anwar Khoshaba, Claro Cruz

Speaker: NA
Text: and Carl Scully. Three more fiercely loyal

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals you could not hope to meet. An-

Speaker: NA
Text: war Khoshaba will not mind me saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: he often drives me to distraction with his

Speaker: NA
Text: views on many issues, but I will always ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate his passionate loyalty to me. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Hon. Carl Scully has also been a constant

Speaker: NA
Text: supporter and confidant over those years. I

Speaker: NA
Text: had the pleasure of being his chief of staff

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last four years. He knows the stresses

Speaker: NA
Text: and strains on somebody who hopes to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent their area in parliament. He has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: great friend and supporter, and I am glad he

Speaker: NA
Text: could join us in the gallery tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: In politics, as in life, personal friends

Speaker: NA
Text: provide emotional sustenance in the bad

Speaker: NA
Text: times and share the joy in the good times. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been fortunate to have a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: friends who have been a wonderful support.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an honour to call them friends. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them are political, some very definitely are

Speaker: NA
Text: not. Tonight in my first contribution to this

Speaker: NA
Text: House, I would like to place on record my

Speaker: NA
Text: thanks to Chris Russell, Brent and Tessa

Speaker: NA
Text: Thomas, Charlie Monti, Greg Lozelle,

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert, Peter Presdee, Chris Minns, Anna

Speaker: NA
Text: Collins and Matt Brown.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, there is one other friend I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to mention. For many years I

Speaker: NA
Text: shared my hopes and aspirations with Ed

Speaker: NA
Text: Husic. We compared notes, we shared disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointments, we celebrated victories and we

Speaker: NA
Text: helped each other. We debated policies and

Speaker: NA
Text: we incubated ideas to improve the lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Sydney. My one regret tonight is

Speaker: NA
Text: that he listens from the gallery and not from

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber. He will one day join us in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, and Australia will be the better

Speaker: NA
Text: for his contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: I of course want to make mention tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: of my parents. Ross and Christine Bowen

Speaker: NA
Text: taught me many things. They taught me not

Speaker: NA
Text: by lessons or homilies but simply by exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple. They taught me to avoid pretension, to

Speaker: NA
Text: work hard and to do what I believe to be

Speaker: NA
Text: right, regardless of the personal conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences. They tell me they are proud of me,

Speaker: NA
Text: and tonight I tell the House that I am proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final person I want to mention tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: is my wife, Rebecca. We met at a New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales conference of the Labor Party, but our

Speaker: NA
Text: life has grown to encompass so much more

Speaker: NA
Text: than politics. She has been a wonderful sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porter. We are now building a house together

Speaker: NA
Text: in Smithfield, at the foot of Prospect Hill,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are soon to bring a little girl into the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. Rebecca has supported my aspirations

Speaker: NA
Text: can in every way possible, and I am looking for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward to spending the rest of my life with her.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a new Labor member of this House, I

Speaker: NA
Text: see my role as being a voice for the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have no other voice in the national po-

Speaker: NA
Text: litical debate. Australia is one of a small

Speaker: NA
Text: number of states throughout the world that is

Speaker: NA
Text: constituted as a Commonwealth. The term

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Commonwealth' was chosen not only to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent that the government was based on

Speaker: NA
Text: the common consent of the people but also to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent those almost unique Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: attributes of fairness and tolerance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome the debate on moral values in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House and across the country. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to stand behind the moral values of

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness and tolerance, and to argue for them

Speaker: NA
Text: vigorously. I say this about the morals de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate: bring it on. It is not enough to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about family values. Fixing things like the

Speaker: NA
Text: family debt trap, and providing more incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives for people to go from welfare to work,

Speaker: NA
Text: are important too. I am happy to argue that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can be, and must be, an efficient and

Speaker: NA
Text: modern economy which still has fairness and

Speaker: NA
Text: tolerance as the basis of our Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can be a productive economy which has

Speaker: NA
Text: protections built in for people who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: unfairly dismissed. We can be a nation that

Speaker: NA
Text: trades successfully with different nations

Speaker: NA
Text: across the world, but that does not mean we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot stand up and be counted against

Speaker: NA
Text: abuses of human rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to create more wealth, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to share it fairly amongst the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have contributed to its creation. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: long had a policy interest in wealth creation

Speaker: NA
Text: through Australia becoming a leading-edge

Speaker: NA
Text: country in the field of research and develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Between 1983 and 1994 our national

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of research and development trebled.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the decade prior to that, research and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment had been declining, and our levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of R&D are only now returning to the levels

Speaker: NA
Text: that we had when the Keating government

Speaker: NA
Text: lost office. The increase in R&D during the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke and Keating years did not just hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pen. This is one example of where govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment programs can have a remarkable im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pact. The 150 per cent research and devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment concession and the R&D syndication

Speaker: NA
Text: program had a real benefit and a beneficial

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on our levels of research; but more

Speaker: NA
Text: than that, they had a real impact on our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. We can strengthen our trading po-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, embracing high value added goods

Speaker: NA
Text: that cushion us against future downturns in

Speaker: NA
Text: our terms of trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am always amazed by the skills the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people possess. There is absolutely no

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why we cannot compete with any

Speaker: NA
Text: other country in the world when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: our technological skills. Australian research

Speaker: NA
Text: has traditionally been very strong in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fields of environmental science and biology.

Speaker: NA
Text: This stands us in good stead to capitalise on

Speaker: NA
Text: the growth in the emerging field of biotech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology. I fear that an ideological culture that

Speaker: NA
Text: opposes government involvement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy may see us miss many more oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities in this field. We need to support our

Speaker: NA
Text: universities as they incubate talent and ideas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently I was concerned to read of an

Speaker: NA
Text: idea floated by the Minister for Education,

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Training to establish universities

Speaker: NA
Text: without research departments. A university is

Speaker: NA
Text: not there just to communicate knowledge; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is there to create knowledge. It is there to

Speaker: NA
Text: foster a culture of innovation and excellence

Speaker: NA
Text: in the national interest. And that is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: our traditional universities in the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. Some of the best research universities in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world are not in the capital cities but in

Speaker: NA
Text: the regions. Good research at universities

Speaker: NA
Text: that can be considered amongst the best in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world is not some elite distraction from

Speaker: NA
Text: the main game of the economy; it is essential

Speaker: NA
Text: for a modern, cutting-edge economy, which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can become.

Speaker: NA
Text: I represent an area of blueand white-

Speaker: NA
Text: collar workers, farmers and small business

Speaker: NA
Text: people. This nation's industrial relations pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy must strike a balance between a modern,

Speaker: NA
Text: highly productive economy and protection

Speaker: NA
Text: for people who are in an unequal bargaining

Speaker: NA
Text: position with their employer-people strug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gling to find a voice. What we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced into the industrial relations sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem over the last eight years has not always

Speaker: NA
Text: meant more choice. I have seen, first-hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of intimidation and an unequal bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining system which does not promote a

Speaker: NA
Text: more productive and cooperative Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: support a decentralised bargaining system

Speaker: NA
Text: that empowers the enterprise-it was, after

Speaker: NA
Text: all, Labor which pioneered this approach-

Speaker: NA
Text: but it must be the enterprise that is empow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered, and not one half of the bargaining unit

Speaker: NA
Text: over the other.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned earlier that I represent in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House many small business owners. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months leading up to the election, I door-

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked nearly 10,000 houses throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. Of course, in that project I

Speaker: NA
Text: came across many small business people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Small business people are working families

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling just like any other working family.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not one small business owner raised with me

Speaker: NA
Text: the need to provide them with an exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: from the unfair dismissal laws. None of them

Speaker: NA
Text: said to me, ‘Can I please have the power to

Speaker: NA
Text: sack somebody unfairly?' However, many

Speaker: NA
Text: raised with me the need to reduce the oner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous burden of the GST and other paperwork

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance costs. They also raised with me

Speaker: NA
Text: citthe need for support in their dealings with

Speaker: NA
Text: franchisers and landlords. Many small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness owners find themselves in unequal bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining positions, just like other members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the work force. I include small business peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in the category of people struggling to

Speaker: NA
Text: find a voice in the national debate. I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: paying particular attention to the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: and aspirations of small business people dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing my time in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Inequity is not just a matter of economics.

Speaker: NA
Text: As mayor of Fairfield, and then as president

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Western Sydney Regional Organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Councils, I spent a lot of time dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the concept of ‘place'. A community

Speaker: NA
Text: can have its spirit lifted and its quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: improved by an effort to improve its urban

Speaker: NA
Text: environment. We often hear of our more af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fluent areas being described as ‘leafy', but

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no reason why an area that could

Speaker: NA
Text: never be described as ‘affluent' should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: described as ‘leafy'. There is no reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: our public spaces and shopping centres can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not be places for cultural enrichment, instead

Speaker: NA
Text: of unattractive and barren wastelands. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in Cabramatta has shown that the

Speaker: NA
Text: urban environment is important. Law en-

Speaker: NA
Text: forcement experts have said that the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfield council in improving place man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement and the urban amenity has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: vital factor in reducing crime in Cabramatta.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it was not this alone that reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: crime: a very significant police effort has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the main focus. But the Australian peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple have consistently identified law and or-

Speaker: NA
Text: der as their major concern, and any steps

Speaker: NA
Text: which make a contribution to reducing crime

Speaker: NA
Text: must be welcomed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not regard this as exclusively a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: for local government. I believe that state and

Speaker: NA
Text: federal governments can do more when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to the urban environment. When I was

Speaker: NA
Text: mayor, I saw first-hand how much can be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved with a relatively small outlay of

Speaker: NA
Text: money, but I also saw how hard it is, for a

Speaker: NA
Text: council struggling with so many commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, to find that money. This nation des-

Speaker: NA
Text: perately needs the re-establishment of a fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral department of urban affairs and a return

Speaker: NA
Text: to federal involvement in urban affairs, along

Speaker: NA
Text: the lines of the previous government's suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful Better Cities Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to being a voice for those without a

Speaker: NA
Text: voice, I believe a particular obligation falls

Speaker: NA
Text: on me-along with my friend the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Fowler-as the representative of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most culturally diverse area in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of various cultural groups who

Speaker: NA
Text: have settled in the seat of Prospect have

Speaker: NA
Text: taught me more than any textbook ever could

Speaker: NA
Text: life about the preciousness of human rights. To

Speaker: NA
Text: talk to someone who has had all three of his

Speaker: NA
Text: daughters executed gives you a very keen

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciation of the need to take a robust ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to human rights. A breach of human

Speaker: NA
Text: rights anywhere is an attack on human rights

Speaker: NA
Text: everywhere. To paraphrase Elie Wiesel:

Speaker: NA
Text: when human rights are under attack we must

Speaker: NA
Text: interfere. As an opposition backbencher, I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have any illusions that I will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a great material difference in this re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard. However, I do want to make this one

Speaker: NA
Text: pledge: I will never be silent. Quiet and dip-

Speaker: NA
Text: lomatic representations in the corridors of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House will sometimes be the most ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriate way of dealing with a matter. At

Speaker: NA
Text: other times, perhaps, a louder approach will

Speaker: NA
Text: be necessary. Either way, I will not be silent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of all religions or philosophies

Speaker: NA
Text: should be able to practise their beliefs in

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom. I include in this a group like Falun

Speaker: NA
Text: Gong, which has as its creed truth, forbear-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance and tolerance. They do not deserve to

Speaker: NA
Text: be tortured for espousing such basic beliefs

Speaker: NA
Text: as these. I will not be silent on the unspeak-

Speaker: NA
Text: able suffering and heartache that is occurring

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Darfur region of Sudan. This suffering

Speaker: NA
Text: receives almost no attention in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: media but it is the biggest humanitarian crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: of the last 10 years. In an area as large as

Speaker: NA
Text: France, 70,000 human beings have lost their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives to a combination of hunger, disease and

Speaker: NA
Text: murder. If an event even 10 per cent as hor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rendous as this occurred in a Western country

Speaker: NA
Text: we would see massive coverage and massive

Speaker: NA
Text: action from the governments of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently in Prospect we have received our

Speaker: NA
Text: latest round of migration refugees from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sudan. It gives me an enormous sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: pride as I walk around Fairfield to see small

Speaker: NA
Text: Sudanese children in the uniforms of Fair-

Speaker: NA
Text: field Primary School. These children have

Speaker: NA
Text: endured far more in their little lives than

Speaker: NA
Text: most of us will have to endure if we live to

Speaker: NA
Text: old age. Yet, they are relatively lucky; hun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dreds of thousands of others are not. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be silent on human rights in places like

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam or Myanmar or anywhere else in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. To have somebody imprisoned for a

Speaker: NA
Text: crime of ‘disrespecting democratic freedoms'

Speaker: NA
Text: for expressing their democratic view is

Speaker: NA
Text: something I can never be silent about. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve Australia and individual members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House need to keep open the lines of

Speaker: NA
Text: communication with the governments of all

Speaker: NA
Text: nations. But we must have human rights as

Speaker: NA
Text: our highest priority in these discussions. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: nation we must say: ‘Here we stand; we can

Speaker: NA
Text: do no other.'

Speaker: NA
Text: When my time in this House comes to an

Speaker: NA
Text: end I hope it will be judged to have been a

Speaker: NA
Text: success. The definition of success that I will

Speaker: NA
Text: be applying when I come to judge my time in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House is one that was written a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time ago by Ralph Waldo Emerson, who was

Speaker: NA
Text: at one stage Chaplain of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of another commonwealth-that

Speaker: NA
Text: of Massachusetts. These are words that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have found inspiring for a long time and I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to share them with the House to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night:

Speaker: NA
Text: To laugh often and much; to win the respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: intelligent people and the affection of children; to

Speaker: NA
Text: earn the appreciation of honest critics and endure

Speaker: NA
Text: the betrayal of false friends; to appreciate beauty;

Speaker: NA
Text: to find the best in others; to leave the world

Speaker: NA
Text: better, whether by a healthy child, a garden patch

Speaker: NA
Text: or a redeemed social condition; to know that even

Speaker: NA
Text: one life has breathed easier because you have

Speaker: NA
Text: lived. This is to have succeeded.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the test that I will apply to myself

Speaker: NA
Text: when my time in this House comes to an

Speaker: NA
Text: end. I thank the House for its courtesy.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Hasluck, I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members that this is his first

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. I therefore ask that the usual courte-

Speaker: NA
Text: sies be extended to him.

Speaker: Mr HENRY
Text: Hasluck) (6.26 p.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: word ‘privilege' is often used too easily. But

Speaker: NA
Text: as I sat down to write this first speech, and

Speaker: NA
Text: now as I stand here to deliver it, I can think

Speaker: NA
Text: of no better word. If it is, as I believe, a

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege to be an Australian citizen, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply conscious of what a privilege it is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be elected to our parliament. So it is with

Speaker: NA
Text: great pride and gratitude that I embark on my

Speaker: NA
Text: new role representing the community that

Speaker: NA
Text: my family and I have called home for 20

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and which our electoral system now

Speaker: NA
Text: calls the seat of Hasluck. In my sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude my thoughts have turned to many

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people who have contributed to my

Speaker: NA
Text: presence here today. First of all, may I pay

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to the family and to all of the values

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with it in Australian life. In par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular, I pay tribute to my family. My ever-

Speaker: NA
Text: lasting appreciation goes to my late parents

Speaker: NA
Text: for their support and for their many sacrifices

Speaker: NA
Text: in bringing into this world my two brothers

Speaker: NA
Text: and me. I wish they could all be here today

Speaker: NA
Text: as I know that they would be bursting with

Speaker: NA
Text: pride. Sadly, my mother passed away less

Speaker: NA
Text: than one year ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: This memory provides some poignancy as

Speaker: NA
Text: I stand here today in Parliament House. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: 62 years ago, as a young, vibrant woman, my

Speaker: NA
Text: mother worked in Canberra as a typist in the

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit Attorney-General's Department. My father,

Speaker: NA
Text: like very many young men and women of the

Speaker: NA
Text: time, left school and enlisted to serve his

Speaker: NA
Text: country. During that time of war, he experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced being torpedoed off Cyprus, being

Speaker: NA
Text: wounded by a landmine in Borneo and he

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered his share of hardships in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea. My father was uncomplaining, in

Speaker: NA
Text: spite of his experiences. He got on with the

Speaker: NA
Text: job of securing a future for himself and his

Speaker: NA
Text: young family. He and my mother were typi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal of their time. They were both committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensuring that their three sons had the best

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities in education and life-perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: that is something that I did not fully appreciand

Speaker: NA
Text: ate at the time. With commitment and persis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence my father's ambition to be a solicitor

Speaker: NA
Text: was realised after he achieved the age of 50.

Speaker: NA
Text: For me, his efforts have been a guiding light.

Speaker: NA
Text: His commitment and persistence-those

Speaker: NA
Text: qualities of never giving up-have also sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained me in the course of my life. I also rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognise the wonderful influence of my two

Speaker: NA
Text: brothers, Robert and Keith, in shaping my

Speaker: NA
Text: early life and, more recently, in shaping their

Speaker: NA
Text: respective families.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also sincerely thankful for the sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of many people who gave freely of their

Speaker: NA
Text: time, expertise, experience and kindness

Speaker: NA
Text: from preselection and along the path to elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. There are too many people to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: them all in this speech but I must specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: mention Helen Leslie, who gave so selflessly

Speaker: NA
Text: of her time and energy for several long

Speaker: NA
Text: months. My campaign committee were sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond to none, led by Barry MACKinnon and

Speaker: NA
Text: ably supported by Andrew Reynolds, Helen

Speaker: NA
Text: Morton, Graeme Harris, Nick Braining, Sue

Speaker: NA
Text: Wood, Heather Gilmour, Norm Haywood

Speaker: NA
Text: and Peter Stewart. I send a very special thank

Speaker: NA
Text: you to the many helpers-some 400-on

Speaker: NA
Text: election day and all those from the Hasluck

Speaker: NA
Text: division for their support.

Speaker: NA
Text: A real stalwart was Senator elect Judith

Speaker: NA
Text: Adams, who worked tirelessly for many

Speaker: NA
Text: months on my behalf. Senator Alan

Speaker: NA
Text: Eggleston, as patron senator for Hasluck,

Speaker: NA
Text: was also available to lend an ear and provide

Speaker: NA
Text: practical support. Thank you, Alan. Thanks

Speaker: NA
Text: also to Senators Ellison and Campbell for

Speaker: NA
Text: their support and encouragement during the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of the campaign and a special thanks

Speaker: NA
Text: to Senator Ross Lightfoot, who encouraged

Speaker: NA
Text: me to throw my hat in the ring and run for

Speaker: NA
Text: preselection, for his ongoing support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of all, however, my gratitude and my

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of living a truly privileged life is al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways due to my four wonderful daughters,

Speaker: NA
Text: Nellandra, Hannah, Harriette and Hillary,

Speaker: NA
Text: the love of my life, Mary, my wife. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to acknowledge them in the gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: today. The path to standing here as a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliament would have been very different

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed without their generosity of spirit, un-

Speaker: NA
Text: failing support and invaluable sense of hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: mour.

Speaker: NA
Text: The seat of Hasluck lies to the east of

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth, encompassing a unique mix of outer

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan suburbs. Hasluck first became a

Speaker: NA
Text: federal seat at the 2001 election and was

Speaker: NA
Text: named after the highly respected and influen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial Liberals Sir Paul and Dame Alexandra

Speaker: NA
Text: Hasluck. Dame Alexandra was a noted histo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rian and Sir Paul succeeded in several ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: reers, including as a journalist, diplomat,

Speaker: NA
Text: academic and bureaucrat, before being

Speaker: NA
Text: elected as a federal member of parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1949. During his time in successive Menzies'

Speaker: NA
Text: governments he held the portfolios of Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories, Defence and External Affairs. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Haslucks were known to people of all politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal persuasions as deeply intelligent and

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Paul was appointed Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1969 and served until 1974. His standing

Speaker: NA
Text: in public life and his reputation was as a

Speaker: NA
Text: well-informed, thoughtful man of enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity. He is fondly remembered by all

Speaker: NA
Text: who knew him in and out of parliament and

Speaker: NA
Text: on both sides of the House. These themes of

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the local and national com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities in which I belong and of honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able partisanship within the Liberal Party are

Speaker: NA
Text: aspirations for my own service in parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: If my contribution can be even a fraction of

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the Haslucks I will be very proud in-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The part of the nation I am here to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent is in many ways a true microcosm of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It reaches from the hills suburbs of

Speaker: NA
Text: Lesmurdie, Kalamunda and Gooseberry Hill

Speaker: NA
Text: north-west to the historic township of Mid-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and Guildford and south to the newer

Speaker: NA
Text: city of Gosnells. It encompasses rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: semirural communities, industrial hubs of

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday and today, vital transport indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries, tourism, hospitality, vineyards, or-

Speaker: NA
Text: chards and market gardens. People from over

Speaker: NA
Text: 70 different countries and nationalities live in

Speaker: NA
Text: both charming older residential suburbs un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dergoing rejuvenation and a wide range of

Speaker: NA
Text: newer residential developments. It is a seat

Speaker: NA
Text: blessed with several important conservation

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, including national parks and state for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests, many of Western Australia's most im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant wetlands and both the major water-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways for Perth-the Canning and Perth's

Speaker: NA
Text: signature river, the Swan, flow through Has-

Speaker: NA
Text: luck.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the election campaign started I

Speaker: NA
Text: spent almost a year meeting and listening to

Speaker: NA
Text: as many members of the Hasluck community

Speaker: NA
Text: as I could. Devoting myself to this gave me a

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful opportunity to learn what my

Speaker: NA
Text: community's hopes and concerns really

Speaker: NA
Text: were. People told me of their worries for

Speaker: NA
Text: their businesses, for their children's educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, for their health care, for their safety

Speaker: NA
Text: for their environment. Of particular concern

Speaker: NA
Text: to me were the numbers of people who had

Speaker: NA
Text: found the public sector unresponsive in

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting or addressing their needs. While

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the issues raised were in a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: context, there were many local community

Speaker: NA
Text: examples where concerns for health, welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: and safety appeared to be ignored. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to refer to some of these.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kalamunda District Community Hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pital is an example. Over 95 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: residents of the serviced area wish to retain

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity and obstetric services at this hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal. It has an exemplary health and safety

Speaker: NA
Text: record, and I am committed to supporting it

Speaker: NA
Text: and the community's efforts to retain the full

Speaker: NA
Text: range of services currently delivered. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: issues include safe school crossings for Wat-

Speaker: NA
Text: tle Grove and Helena primary schools and

Speaker: NA
Text: ablution blocks for Gosnells and High Wy-

Speaker: NA
Text: combe primary schools, just to mention a

Speaker: NA
Text: few. In raising some of these concerns it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that I also mention the wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: job being done by so many volunteers on

Speaker: NA
Text: P&C committees, in welfare organisations,

Speaker: NA
Text: in community care groups and in sporting

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations. These volunteers and these

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations make our communities what

Speaker: NA
Text: they are today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like Sir Paul Hasluck, I too have enjoyed

Speaker: NA
Text: a diverse career before this new role. I began

Speaker: NA
Text: my working life as a jackeroo and went on to

Speaker: NA
Text: gain unforgettable experiences working on

Speaker: NA
Text: farming properties in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and Western Australia and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural industry in general. I then was

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate to have opportunities to work in the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction industry, establishing my own

Speaker: NA
Text: building and concrete-drilling and sawing

Speaker: NA
Text: company, which in turn led to me becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in a company developing oilfield

Speaker: NA
Text: production technology in the USA.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the past 18 years I have been working

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the building and construction sector with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Master Plumbers and Mechanical Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices Association and the Master Painters,

Speaker: NA
Text: Decorators and Signwriters Association, rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resenting the needs of their respective mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: berships. This has involved me in the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment of the plumbing industry at state,

Speaker: NA
Text: national and global levels. I have gained

Speaker: NA
Text: enormously from these experiences, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have included establishing an award-winning

Speaker: NA
Text: industry based vocational training centre,

Speaker: NA
Text: creating public-private partnerships to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote water and energy efficiency strategies

Speaker: NA
Text: for our communities and playing a key role

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry reform. I have enjoyed over 40

Speaker: NA
Text: years working in and with small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Far more than being a privilege, being a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament is a responsibility-a

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to contribute to the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: our nation, a responsibility not to be squan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dered. There are many challenges facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community at the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 21st century. I hope to contribute posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively to as many of these as I can. I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: take this opportunity to raise those important

Speaker: NA
Text: issues particularly close to my heart: the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge of how we manage our water re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources for future generations and the chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge of how we skill and train ourselves and

Speaker: NA
Text: our people for the future world of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will start with water. The world has only

Speaker: NA
Text: the same amount of water as it did at the be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning of human civilisation, but now our

Speaker: NA
Text: global population is approaching six billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a sobering fact indeed that only a tiny

Speaker: NA
Text: fraction of one per cent of all the water on

Speaker: NA
Text: earth is both suitable and available for hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: man consumption. Our expectations of water

Speaker: NA
Text: use have increased dramatically in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: generations. There are more of us than ever

Speaker: NA
Text: before, and each of us uses more water than

Speaker: NA
Text: our predecessors would have dreamt of. This

Speaker: NA
Text: situation cannot continue and is only exacer-

Speaker: NA
Text: bated by changes in rainfall patterns and the

Speaker: NA
Text: dryland salinity now affecting much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's land.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is now abundantly clear that we as a

Speaker: NA
Text: community must embark on an unprece-

Speaker: NA
Text: dented combined national effort addressing

Speaker: NA
Text: how we manage, protect, use and share this

Speaker: NA
Text: most precious of the land's natural resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be no magic bullet, no easy solu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, but efforts are starting, and many fresh

Speaker: NA
Text: and worthy new approaches are being pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed. It is well recognised that Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: the driest inhabited continent on earth, ensurmuch

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that issues of water supply, management,

Speaker: NA
Text: use and reuse are a priority on the public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy agenda. It is therefore very pleasing to

Speaker: NA
Text: see that the Prime Minister of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: has identified water as a top personal priority

Speaker: NA
Text: for this term of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that water and its provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to our human population will be one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the greatest challenges facing not only Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia but the world in the 21st century. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been reported that more than 2.6 billion peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple do not have adequate access to fresh wa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and sanitation and that thousands of peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple across the world die on a daily basis as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of this deprivation and inadequacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Human life is not possible without fresh wa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. We in Australia are somewhat more for-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate; although, following a series of

Speaker: NA
Text: droughts and an increasing urban population

Speaker: NA
Text: and demand on our agricultural industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are facing a critical challenge to our wa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter supply. It is very gratifying to see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government has already moved to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish the National Water Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be charged with driving reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all must ensure that we stimulate our

Speaker: NA
Text: communities and industries to come up with

Speaker: NA
Text: innovations in addressing water use. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Green Plumber program, developed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Master Plumbers Association, is one exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple of how industry and community can play

Speaker: NA
Text: a proactive role in this process. We need to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at new ideas and innovation-such as

Speaker: NA
Text: harvesting stormwater from our cities-and

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsider our approach to potable water and

Speaker: NA
Text: its distribution; the quality of water require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for industrial purposes; recycling and

Speaker: NA
Text: reusing grey water for domestic and indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial use; improvements to irrigation tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: niques and infrastructure; the active use of

Speaker: NA
Text: aquifers for water storage; and the construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of new water transport facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Western Australia, these options excite

Speaker: NA
Text: community interest and support. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are many ideas on the drawing board, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: in my home state the suggested pipeline from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kimberleys to Perth and the planned de-

Speaker: NA
Text: salination plant for Cockburn Sound, south

Speaker: NA
Text: of Perth. All of these options need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluated-carefully and thoroughly. Rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than being skewed by self-interest, all of

Speaker: NA
Text: these options need to be carefully and thor-

Speaker: NA
Text: oughly evaluated, with one eye firmly fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cused on the needs of future generations,

Speaker: NA
Text: families, business, industry and communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like many with more expertise than I can

Speaker: NA
Text: claim, I have serious concerns about the wis-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom of some of these projects. A desalina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion plant, for example, is extremely expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive to build, has a high energy cost and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore also has significant greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences. It also raises the prospect of

Speaker: NA
Text: local environmental degradation through

Speaker: NA
Text: hypersalinity. A pipeline would appear to be

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive, but would today's investment

Speaker: NA
Text: costs be seen that way in 50 or 100 years

Speaker: NA
Text: time? Where would we be today without

Speaker: NA
Text: C.Y. O'Connor's pipeline from Perth to Kal-

Speaker: NA
Text: goorlie, this year celebrating 100 years? I am

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted to now be part of a federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment team that has already been active on

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue. However, I am disappointed that,

Speaker: NA
Text: given the challenges we face in Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia with water supply and management,

Speaker: NA
Text: the WA government has chosen to go it

Speaker: NA
Text: alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue of vocational training may seem

Speaker: NA
Text: unrelated to that of water, but the underlying

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge is how our community chooses to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond. Apprenticeship training has an even

Speaker: NA
Text: longer history than academic institutions and

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to be an invaluable learning tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and employment pathway in our society.

Speaker: NA
Text: In spite of this tradition, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: serious national skills shortage. In my own

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Hasluck, we particularly need

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanics, welders, fitters and building

Speaker: NA
Text: trades men and women. Those of us who

Speaker: NA
Text: have an appreciation and empathy for trades

Speaker: NA
Text: and apprenticeship training and the huge

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution that trades have made to indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals, communities, businesses, employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and indeed our nation were delighted to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the Prime Minister say, ‘I want to see an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia where a trade apprenticeship is just

Speaker: NA
Text: as valued as a university degree.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The record of the Howard government in

Speaker: NA
Text: the area of vocational and apprenticeship

Speaker: NA
Text: training speaks for itself: 416,800 new ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices and trainees in training at the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the March quarter 2004; 282,800 com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mencements in the 12 months ending March

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004, up from the previous year; 132,000

Speaker: NA
Text: completions in the 12 months to March

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004, up a massive 12 per cent from the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious year. These statistics are a clear indica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that the policies of the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are working.

Speaker: NA
Text: The election commitments made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and the government will also

Speaker: NA
Text: make a significant contribution to further

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the intake of new apprentices and

Speaker: NA
Text: trainees over the next three years. In particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar, the establishment of 24 Australian tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical colleges will make a very positive con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution to attracting greater involvement by

Speaker: NA
Text: school leavers in trade training and a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: participation by industry in skilling Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians. The need to create an effective alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive to TAFE colleges in delivering industry

Speaker: NA
Text: specific skills has been demonstrated with

Speaker: NA
Text: the advent some years ago of industry spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cific training centres. This is an area that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had some experience in, having been

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for establishing and operating

Speaker: NA
Text: MPA Skills in Western Australia, specialising

Speaker: NA
Text: in training for plumbing and painting appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices and skill enhancement programs for

Speaker: NA
Text: is facing a trades men and women.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is fair to say that one of the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges facing our vocational training

Speaker: NA
Text: system is that of the Commonwealth-state

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship and the bureaucracy associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with it. At a time of national skills shortages,

Speaker: NA
Text: we simply cannot afford this. Programs such

Speaker: NA
Text: as User Choice which should be providing

Speaker: NA
Text: training options for apprentices and employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers alike have been severely curtailed, adding

Speaker: NA
Text: to the confusion and bureaucratic maze em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers are expected to work their way

Speaker: NA
Text: through to make a considerable investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in training for the benefit of their business

Speaker: NA
Text: and also for the continued economic sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability and benefit of Australia. The leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship role of the Prime Minister and his gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in introducing Australian technical

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges will go a long way to overcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: this unnecessary impasse in state and Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth funding arrangements for voca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional training.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I do have a concern that not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough employers are investing in training

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices. I believe that this is caused by a

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of real incentive, poaching of appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices, and the real cost of investing in train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for individual employers. Perhaps we

Speaker: NA
Text: should consider that, for those employers

Speaker: NA
Text: who invest in skilling Australia, such in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestments be treated in the same way that we

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage companies to participate in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search and development. If it is recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: that research and development is a driver of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth, skilling Australians is es-

Speaker: NA
Text: sential for our continued economic growth. It

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore stands to reason that a tax incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: in the form of a tax concession has the poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial to be a more realistic and simple incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive to encourage employers to train appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices. Without a simple incentive for private

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in education and training, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: probable that we will continue to face skill

Speaker: NA
Text: shortages. Indeed, if we consider our ageing

Speaker: NA
Text: work force across most industry sectors,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an urgent need to attract greater in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment in training.

Speaker: NA
Text: As well as attracting new entrants to the

Speaker: NA
Text: trades from the school sector, we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider reskilling those already in the work

Speaker: NA
Text: force who are underemployed or facing re-

Speaker: NA
Text: dundancy from their current employment. As

Speaker: NA
Text: our work force ages, this strategy will only

Speaker: NA
Text: become more important and more urgent. As

Speaker: NA
Text: with all things that should be seen as invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, the sooner we begin, the easier and

Speaker: NA
Text: more effective our efforts will be. While an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual must accept some responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for ongoing skill development during their

Speaker: NA
Text: working life, it is not an issue for them alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increasing rate of change in technical

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and knowledge and the continuous

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the business environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace suggests the need for ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational training. Those businesses that

Speaker: NA
Text: adapt more readily to this could achieve a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant competitive advantage. The proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ess of continuous learning and our attitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: lifelong learning needs to move beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric to the point that it is built into our

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces, schools and communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, much more needs to be done

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure the industry relevance, knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: and skills of trainers and lecturers who play

Speaker: NA
Text: such an important role in influencing the

Speaker: NA
Text: next generation and subsequent generations

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's work force. This will require a

Speaker: NA
Text: structured process aimed at ensuring both a

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent industry interface during the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of a trainer's working life and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuous industry specific skills development.

Speaker: NA
Text: In talking about vocational training we

Speaker: NA
Text: should also acknowledge the significant con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution that group training companies have

Speaker: NA
Text: made to the contemporary evolution and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment of apprenticeship training and

Speaker: NA
Text: traineeships in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final challenge I wish to raise here to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day is the question of how we can better

Speaker: NA
Text: support small business. This is the sector that

Speaker: NA
Text: most truly underpins our economic capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, our Australian way of life. The

Speaker: NA
Text: small business sector is full of some of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's most self-reliant, innovative and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: trepreneurial people. They create employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and build both individual and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity from the smallest of our country

Speaker: NA
Text: towns to the biggest of our cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recent figures indicate that Australia now

Speaker: NA
Text: boasts a significant increase in the self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed. This is a telling statistic, reflect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing what individuals are actually looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: in their working lives. It has been predicted

Speaker: NA
Text: that over the next 30 years or so the majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of the work force will be self-employed, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: we still allow excessive regulation and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pliance requirements to stand in the way of

Speaker: NA
Text: these people and their aspirations. We oblige

Speaker: NA
Text: people to operate within a regulated labour

Speaker: NA
Text: market with restrictive award conditions that

Speaker: NA
Text: are in nobody's long-term interests, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: leave them vulnerable to unfettered access

Speaker: NA
Text: and disruption by representatives of unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In focusing on the tiny number of em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers that may not do the right thing, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are systematically and consistently penalis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing tens of thousands of employers who do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Add to this the fact that the complexity and

Speaker: NA
Text: level of our taxation, including the cumula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive effect of many individual taxes on busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses, act as a powerful disincentive to

Speaker: NA
Text: business growth and to employment. Count-

Speaker: NA
Text: less people are missing out on jobs that are

Speaker: NA
Text: simply not being created.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we do about water, training and

Speaker: NA
Text: small business are just three of the important

Speaker: NA
Text: questions facing us as a nation. Each of these

Speaker: NA
Text: is close to my heart and important to my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. Each is something I hope to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to make a positive contribution towards

Speaker: NA
Text: while I represent all the people of the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Hasluck, without fear or favour. It

Speaker: NA
Text: because of them that I stand here today, inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribably proud to be the federal member for

Speaker: NA
Text: the seat of Hasluck during this, the 41st Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Parliament. I thank the House for its

Speaker: NA
Text: indulgence.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Braddon, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to acknowledge the presence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: President of the Senate. Before the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Braddon commences, I remind the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is his first speech and I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to extend the usual courtesies.

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Text: Braddon) (6.51 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker may I, at the outset, congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: you on your election and Mr Deputy Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: and Mr Second Deputy Speaker on their re-

Speaker: NA
Text: election. It is with a deep sense of pride that I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise in this chamber to address the House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know I share that feeling with everyone here,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially the recently elected new members

Speaker: NA
Text: on both sides. We have a sense of great privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege at being elected to represent our con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the great constitutional debates of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1890s, our founding fathers discussed

Speaker: NA
Text: what to call the main elected chamber of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospective federal government. A number of

Speaker: NA
Text: names were considered, but the greatest sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port went to adopting the name ‘House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives'. This was a deliberate step.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new Australian parliament could have

Speaker: NA
Text: chosen a neutral term, such as ‘house of as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sembly' or adopted the style of many Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean parliaments and used ‘house of dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gates'. Yet the founders had no doubt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: main responsibilities of the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new federal house of government were to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent their constituents; their needs, their

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns and their aspirations.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of those founding fathers was the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian statesman Sir Edward Braddon.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was a distinguished colonial premier of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania and represented Tasmania at sev-

Speaker: NA
Text: is eral federal conventions. In 1903 Sir Edward

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon-who, coincidentally, was at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time a neighbouring farmer of my paternal

Speaker: NA
Text: great-grandfather-was elected the first

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wilmot, but he died a year later,

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1904. Some public minded local landown-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers subsequently set aside some land on a

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage point near Forth, a small town be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween Devonport and Burnie. This land is

Speaker: NA
Text: called Braddon's Lookout and commands a

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent view of much of the north-west

Speaker: NA
Text: coast and Bass Strait. The lookout is above

Speaker: NA
Text: Lillico Beach, named after my maternal fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: bears, who first settled this land in 1865. It

Speaker: NA
Text: important to remind ourselves of this be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we do not often remember those peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple who got together to write our Constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and it is right that we honour them.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1903 the north-west federal seat was

Speaker: NA
Text: known as Darwin because Charles Darwin's

Speaker: NA
Text: famous ship the Beagle dropped anchor on

Speaker: NA
Text: the north-west coast to replenish supplies of

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh water during its voyage to the Southern

Speaker: NA
Text: Ocean. The first member for Darwin was the

Speaker: NA
Text: flamboyant King O'Malley. O'Malley was

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister for home affairs at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: when Canberra was chosen as the future site

Speaker: NA
Text: of the federal capital in 1913 and was in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: the longest living member of the first federal

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament when he died in 1953. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent member was Sir George Bell, who

Speaker: NA
Text: became Speaker of the House of Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives and a significant parliamentarian. A

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful part of my electorate, Bell's Parade,

Speaker: NA
Text: near Latrobe-where I spent many happy

Speaker: NA
Text: hours as a child-is named in his memory.

Speaker: NA
Text: But perhaps the most famous of my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors in this seat is the Hon. Dame

Speaker: NA
Text: Enid Muriel Lyons, widow of the distin-

Speaker: NA
Text: guished Tasmanian who became Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister, Joe Lyons. Dame Enid was member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin from 1943 to 1951, when she was

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to retire because of ill health. Dame

Speaker: NA
Text: Enid is well known as the first woman to

Speaker: NA
Text: become a member of this House, represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing first the United Australia Party and, when

Speaker: NA
Text: it was founded, the Liberal Party. She was

Speaker: NA
Text: also the first woman to become minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Crown, serving in the Menzies govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment from 1949 to 1951 as Vice-President of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Executive Council. Her late husband had

Speaker: NA
Text: held that same portfolio, and I think this

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the only occasion when a husband

Speaker: NA
Text: and wife have shared such an achievement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although her health forced Dame Enid to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave the parliament in 1951, she continued a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant role in public life over the next 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years, serving as a commissioner of the ABC

Speaker: NA
Text: is and fulfilling many public engagements. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: child growing up in Devonport, I have fond

Speaker: NA
Text: memories of watching Dame Enid piloting

Speaker: NA
Text: her grey Humber car through the streets, and

Speaker: NA
Text: of dodging it at times. She was known and

Speaker: NA
Text: loved by many.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1955, when Aubrey Luck was the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral member, the parliament passed a resolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion changing the name of the seat from

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin to Braddon. Aubrey held many pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic offices during and after his parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: term, including a very important position as

Speaker: NA
Text: a very popular patron of the Devonport

Speaker: NA
Text: Football Club. I played for the club for a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of seasons and was fortunate to be

Speaker: NA
Text: captain, play in two premierships and repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent Tasmania. I remember Mr Luck as a

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive presence and a friend of my par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two of my other distinguished Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors were Ray Groom, a former

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent footballer who held the seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon from 1975 to 1984, served as a min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister in the Fraser government and later held

Speaker: NA
Text: office as Premier of Tasmania; and Chris

Speaker: NA
Text: Miles, who was the Braddon MP from 1984

Speaker: NA
Text: to 1998 and was Parliamentary Secretary to

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet in the first Howard government. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the new member for Braddon, I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: conscious of the legacy of previous federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal parliamentarians who have so ably

Speaker: NA
Text: represented the electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe I am fortunate, although some

Speaker: NA
Text: members of my family would say that is de-

Speaker: NA
Text: batable, to have some political blood running

Speaker: NA
Text: through my veins. My great-uncle Elliott

Speaker: NA
Text: Lillico was member for Meander in the Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: manian Legislative Council and then a Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral senator for Tasmania for 15 years before

Speaker: NA
Text: retiring in 1974. My maternal great-

Speaker: NA
Text: grandfather was Sir Alexander Lillico, a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Tasmanian Legislative Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil for some 30 years-a record which still

Speaker: NA
Text: stands today. Sir Alexander entered parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as an unassuming farmer who, it is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: corded, ‘had neither the benefit of oratory

Speaker: NA
Text: nor of high education'. His main quality was

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity, and I believe that is a special

Speaker: NA
Text: that is missing in many sectors today.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1944 the Labor government wanted the

Speaker: NA
Text: states to transfer certain powers to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. This was supported by each state

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament except the Tasmanian Legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: Council. The Tasmanian upper house was

Speaker: NA
Text: split 10-8, with Sir Alexander Lillico leading

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition. Dr Evatt was despatched by

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Curtin to Tasmania to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: support for that bill. This became known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Evatt versus Lillico affair. Evatt failed

Speaker: NA
Text: persuade the Tasmanians to change their op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position. Frustrated, he put the powers bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: a referendum. It was rejected by every state

Speaker: NA
Text: except South Australia, where it passed by

Speaker: NA
Text: only a slim margin. This is a lesson well

Speaker: NA
Text: worth recording. The instinct of a small mi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nority to oppose something thought desirable

Speaker: NA
Text: by almost every other parliamentarian in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was proven to be in fact consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the overwhelming view of the elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate. It is a very important reminder, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: that we must always keep in touch with our

Speaker: NA
Text: electors. They are, after all, our employers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: swore the oath of allegiance as the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Braddon somewhat daunted by the list of

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors who have held this seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was born in Devonport and raised along

Speaker: NA
Text: with my three elder sisters on the family

Speaker: NA
Text: farm nearby. When attending school in De-

Speaker: NA
Text: vonport I was a restless young man who pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred learning by doing rather than in the

Speaker: NA
Text: classroom. Consequently, I left after grade

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 to train as a carpenter and joiner, and ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained a trade certificate at the Devonport

Speaker: NA
Text: Technical College. After a period, and with

Speaker: NA
Text: counsel from my previous teachers, I decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to further my studies at the Tasmanian State

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute of Technology and later at the Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity of Tasmania. I completed a Bachelor

Speaker: NA
Text: of Education and subsequently was em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed as a secondary teacher in Tasmanian

Speaker: NA
Text: high schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: I then made a career choice to pursue fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: asset ther studies in commerce and law and move

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the business world in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: business and financial management. This

Speaker: NA
Text: provided me with opportunities to travel

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas, including to the USA and Canada,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the chance to observe other national fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial systems in action. This experience

Speaker: NA
Text: was invaluable, and I met many who were

Speaker: NA
Text: envious of the probity and efficiency of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian financial system.

Speaker: NA
Text: In November 1998, whilst working in

Speaker: NA
Text: to Launceston in northern Tasmania, something

Speaker: NA
Text: happened which dramatically changed the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of my life. While crossing a one-way

Speaker: NA
Text: street, I looked the wrong way in a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: of distraction. The result was a traumatic

Speaker: NA
Text: injury and many months in acute care in

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital, followed by well over three years of

Speaker: NA
Text: intensive physical rehabilitation. This placed

Speaker: NA
Text: great stresses on my personal life, and I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay tribute to my family-especially to

Speaker: NA
Text: my mother, Margaret Joy, and to my three

Speaker: NA
Text: sisters, Helen, Diane and Peta, who were

Speaker: NA
Text: enormously supportive during this period. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to acknowledge two of my sisters,

Speaker: NA
Text: Helen and Diane, who are here in the gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: today. My mother always gave our family

Speaker: NA
Text: unreserved support. She was our guiding

Speaker: NA
Text: light-a beautiful person who had a special

Speaker: NA
Text: and unique relationship with each family

Speaker: NA
Text: member. We were devastated when, after a

Speaker: NA
Text: short illness, she died in the middle of this

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign. I know she would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been proud to see one of her children stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say that every cloud has a silver lin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. On many occasions I could not see any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing positive about what happened to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet, that saying is true. I met some wonder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful medical and nursing staff at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Launceston General Hospital, and I made

Speaker: NA
Text: some truly inspirational friends amongst my

Speaker: NA
Text: fellow patients. Once I was back on my feet,

Speaker: NA
Text: I resolved to give something back to society.

Speaker: NA
Text: I became involved in the Road Trauma Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port Team in northern Tasmania and the Clif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ford Craig Medical Research Trust, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: became a member of the Tasmanian Road

Speaker: NA
Text: Safety Consultative Committee. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: widely known that for every road death in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, 30 people are seriously injured in

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicle accidents; and it is even worse

Speaker: NA
Text: in some mainland states. These injuries in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude paraplegia, loss of limbs and serious

Speaker: NA
Text: brain damage. A former Tasmanian Premier,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hon. Tony Rundle, rightly called this ‘the

Speaker: NA
Text: hidden disease'. I am strongly of the view

Speaker: NA
Text: that there should be compulsory driver edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation in every Australian school, from grade

Speaker: NA
Text: 9 to grade 12. If a school today decided not

Speaker: NA
Text: to offer computer science, maths or English,

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and the community would be rightly

Speaker: NA
Text: astonished. Yet a number of schools either

Speaker: NA
Text: ignore driver education or have ceased to

Speaker: NA
Text: offer it. Irreparable damage can be done by a

Speaker: NA
Text: young, inexperienced driver in charge of a

Speaker: NA
Text: motor car, and governments at all levels have

Speaker: NA
Text: an obligation to prepare young Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: for the nation's roads.

Speaker: NA
Text: One legacy which the experience of being

Speaker: NA
Text: in that road accident has instilled in me is

Speaker: NA
Text: highest regard for our public hospital system

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the quality of the people who make it

Speaker: NA
Text: work. That is something I shall never forget.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the tasks I took on was to become

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman of the Save Launceston General

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital Committee. In this role I acted as an

Speaker: NA
Text: intermediary for the hospital's medical and

Speaker: NA
Text: other staff and the state bureaucracy. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: astounded to find-having come from a pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate industry background-that no fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: than 32 approvals were needed for an expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture of $20,000 or more by the hospital. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not sure that the system has improved,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is very important that state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments around Australia tackle the burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: red tape and bureaucracy that is eating up so

Speaker: NA
Text: much of the health dollar.

Speaker: NA
Text: The electorate that I am privileged to rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resent is in a beautiful part of the state. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: marvelling last week, yet again, at how rich

Speaker: NA
Text: the agricultural land is in that part of Tasma-

Speaker: NA
Text: nia. And it will not be surprising for mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers to learn that 10 per cent of the popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Braddon are directly employed in

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture. There is a wide variety of farm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, including cropping and sheep farming,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is the state's centre for dairy produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We are also privileged to have other

Speaker: NA
Text: niche markets. We have kelp harvesting and

Speaker: NA
Text: poppy production, we are a world leader in

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrethrum production, and we have a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant tulip estate at Table Cape-which has

Speaker: NA
Text: grown to be so successful that it has become

Speaker: NA
Text: a popular tourist attraction and actually ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports products to the Netherlands during the

Speaker: NA
Text: northern winter. We also have a fledgling

Speaker: NA
Text: wine-growing industry in Braddon, which

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be too surprising given that our

Speaker: NA
Text: latitude is the same in the south as Tuscany

Speaker: NA
Text: in the north.

Speaker: NA
Text: Out of the city of Devonport, the ‘gateway

Speaker: NA
Text: to Tasmania', operate the three Spirit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania ferries-two to Melbourne and one

Speaker: NA
Text: to Sydney. It is important to remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that a large measure of the commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial success of these vessels, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: heralded a significant tourism boom in Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: mania and have contributed to lower airfares,

Speaker: NA
Text: came directly from the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's decision in 1996 to establish the Bass

Speaker: NA
Text: Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apart from the 10 per cent who are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in agriculture, 15 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: adults in the Braddon electorate are em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed in some form of manufacturing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry, and a further 25 per cent are em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed in construction or trade orientated

Speaker: NA
Text: industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have deliberately set out these statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: to give the House an indication of the profile

Speaker: NA
Text: of the seat of Braddon, which swung to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party by a margin of almost 7½ per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent on 9 October this year. That was the

Speaker: NA
Text: strongest swing to the Liberal Party nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide to gain a seat-an outstanding result for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party. That outcome is directly

Speaker: NA
Text: attributable to two things: the hard work of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party grassroots members in all

Speaker: NA
Text: of the branches on the north-west coast and

Speaker: NA
Text: the consistent leadership of this country by

Speaker: NA
Text: our Prime Minister. I wish to acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: and thank the Tasmanian Liberal Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: team: Senators Calvert, Abetz, Colbeck,

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson and Barnett. Richard Colbeck led the

Speaker: NA
