Text: north-west coast ably. I thank you. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the ministers who journeyed down to

Speaker: NA
Text: our great electorate, and I make a special

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: director, and his family, who gave me tre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendous support through the election.

Speaker: NA
Text: As someone working in financial man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement, I was in no doubt that the hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work undertaken by the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer over the last eight years-to

Speaker: NA
Text: first stabilise and then grow our national

Speaker: NA
Text: economy to be a world leader-is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: important achievement. Without a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, no government can do good things

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia and Australians. More than 70

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of people in my electorate own or

Speaker: NA
Text: are currently buying their homes, so they

Speaker: NA
Text: have a clear understanding of the vital im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance of managing our $800 billion econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy, of maintaining a budget surplus and of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proper management of interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was particularly pleased to see in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's speech that His Excel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lency mentioned the Future Fund, to take

Speaker: NA
Text: account of the ageing of the Australian popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. Braddon has one of the older demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphics in the country, with 14 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate being aged over 65 years, so I

Speaker: NA
Text: will take a particular interest in the manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the health and welfare sector. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most important elements of aged care is

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing people to remain independent as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as they are able, preferably in their own

Speaker: NA
Text: homes. People having to move because of

Speaker: NA
Text: frailty not only dislocates them but can also

Speaker: NA
Text: separate them from family, friends and the

Speaker: NA
Text: network with which they are familiar. I am a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong believer in improved domiciliary care

Speaker: NA
Text: and the development of graded aged care

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities, where a resident can move from an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent-living unit, to hostel type ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodation, to a nursing home-

Speaker: NA
Text: depending upon their personal circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: and own needs. There are a number of excel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent facilities in Braddon, but the ageing pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: file of our nation means that the private sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor will have to work more with the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: and state governments to fulfil this need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been very supportive of the How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard government's support for apprenticeships

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the technical education system na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally. Since 1996 the number of appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices in Braddon has increased threefold and

Speaker: NA
Text: the government has successfully moved to

Speaker: NA
Text: dispel the myth that vocational education is

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow ‘second best' to tertiary study. As

Speaker: NA
Text: someone with a rural upbringing who began

Speaker: NA
Text: his working career with a four-year appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeship, then decided to go on to university

Speaker: NA
Text: study and is in the process of completing his

Speaker: NA
Text: third university degree, I believe that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: equipped to remind the House that each ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: reer path is as valuable as the other. I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend the Prime Minister for his announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment during the election campaign that 24

Speaker: NA
Text: new federal technical colleges would be es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablished across Australia if the government

Speaker: NA
Text: were returned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The mining industry is also a strong con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributor to the economy in my electorate. A

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of mining operations flourish in

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon, such as the Savage River mine.

Speaker: NA
Text: Magnetite ore is mined at Savage River and

Speaker: NA
Text: then pumped along an 85-kilometre pipeline

Speaker: NA
Text: to Port Latta, where it is pelletised. Produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in 2002-03 totalled some 5.3 million

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes and provided employment for 420

Speaker: NA
Text: people. At Railton, south of Devonport, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cement Australia plant operates using local

Speaker: NA
Text: limestone. In 2002-03 more than 1.26 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion tonnes were produced, the vast majority

Speaker: NA
Text: shipped here to mainland Australia. The ce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment operation at Railton provides employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for over 170 people. There is a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: other mining operations including mineral

Speaker: NA
Text: sands operations at Naracoopa on King Is-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and magnesite mining at Arthur River

Speaker: NA
Text: and Main Creek. One of the as yet largely

Speaker: NA
Text: untapped resources is the dolomite resource

Speaker: NA
Text: at Circular Head. I am advised that the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve of dolomite in that area of Tasmania is

Speaker: NA
Text: the largest concentration in the Southern

Speaker: NA
Text: Hemisphere, and there are a number of excit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing possibilities there for future exploration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon also boasts Australian Paper's

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley Vale and Burnie mills, where com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bined annual production is more than a quar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of a million tonnes. Together they employ

Speaker: NA
Text: over 500 people and have ongoing relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships with some 140 local contractors. Brad-

Speaker: NA
Text: don also boasts major ports at Burnie and

Speaker: NA
Text: Devonport and a significant port at Stanley.

Speaker: NA
Text: These services not only export manufactured

Speaker: NA
Text: and raw materials but also support a flourish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing local fishing industry. Braddon is also

Speaker: NA
Text: where some of the finest cheeses in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world are produced and-this may surprise

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members-is the location of a

Speaker: NA
Text: growing market in quality chocolates, a

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of our rich dairy assets. My electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: is also one of the biggest exporters of onions

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas and provides all of the potato needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to two well-known national takeaway restau-

Speaker: NA
Text: rant chains.

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon also is a world leader in forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: and associated timber industries. It possesses

Speaker: NA
Text: timbers such as the magnificent Huon pine,

Speaker: NA
Text: blackwood, myrtle, celery-top pine and Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: manian eucalypt. After the implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Howard government's election policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: over one million hectares of forests in Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: mania will be protected forever. This

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts to some 42 per cent of Tasmania's

Speaker: NA
Text: landmass. This is a unique outcome un-

Speaker: NA
Text: equalled in the world today. It is my respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility to dispel the myth that there are few

Speaker: NA
Text: trees left in Tasmania. In fact, the opposite is

Speaker: NA
Text: true.

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon, therefore, is a diverse electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has two significant cities, a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: other substantial towns and no particular

Speaker: NA
Text: central point. This makes it a particular chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge for any federal representative, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: pledge now to represent every part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate from King Island to the far north-

Speaker: NA
Text: west coast, to Savage River and Waratah,

Speaker: NA
Text: Smithton, Burnie, Ulverstone and Devon-

Speaker: NA
Text: port. Tasmania is a small state and, perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: uniquely in Australia, most people know at

Speaker: NA
Text: least one state and/or federal parliamentar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian. I fully understand that with that friendly

Speaker: NA
Text: familiarity comes a burden of trust and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility that I will strive to fulfil.

Speaker: NA
Text: In common with many Australians and

Speaker: NA
Text: other honourable members, my family has

Speaker: NA
Text: served our nation in time of war. My grand-

Speaker: NA
Text: father Arthur Horden Baker fought in France

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Australian Army in World War I and

Speaker: NA
Text: paid the supreme sacrifice. My late father,

Speaker: NA
Text: Petre Baker, served as a Squadron Leader in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Australian Air Force during World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II, attached to Bomber Command, and

Speaker: NA
Text: participated in a remarkable 60 flights over

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied Europe. He returned to farm on the

Speaker: NA
Text: north-west coast and rarely talked about this

Speaker: NA
Text: brave service. He was a man of immense

Speaker: NA
Text: character whom I was privileged to have as a

Speaker: NA
Text: father. My brother-in-law Rodney Layton

Speaker: NA
Text: served in Vietnam and my nephew Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: than Layton has continued the family tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, serving in the Royal Australian Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Force in Iraq in this year. Honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers can perhaps imagine how proud I am of

Speaker: NA
Text: that. With this family background, I feel it

Speaker: NA
Text: so important that our nation has been led

Speaker: NA
Text: during these difficult times by a strong and

Speaker: NA
Text: resolute leader. We certainly have such a

Speaker: NA
Text: man in our Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: I look forward to contributing to the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of the fourth Howard government. I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to being a representative of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Braddon-to listening to their con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns and representing them in the counsels

Speaker: NA
Text: of government. When my great-grandfather

Speaker: NA
Text: died in 1966 at the age of 94, the Advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper said that ‘his main asset was his

Speaker: NA
Text: sincerity and he was guided by what he

Speaker: NA
Text: thought would be best for the state'. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know if a higher tribute is possible for any

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentarian. With the support of my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues I intend to dedicate myself to work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing hard and consistently for the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon and the Parliament of Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the House.

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: Melbourne Ports) (7.13

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I will begin rather slowly to allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Braddon, who has just made his

Speaker: NA
Text: first speech, to be congratulated. I take this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity of congratulating you, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, on your election to the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. I welcome your commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness in your treatment of those on all

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the House. I also congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members for Page and Scullin on

Speaker: NA
Text: their re-elections as Deputy Speaker and

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Deputy Speaker respectively. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that the House will be well served by

Speaker: NA
Text: all three senior occupants of the chair. I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate all the new members who have

Speaker: NA
Text: just made their first speeches.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great honour for me to have been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turned for a third term as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports, maintaining a Labor tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which dates back to 1906. The seat has

Speaker: NA
Text: changed beyond recognition since the days

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ted Holloway and Frank Crean, when it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a safe Labor seat. We retained the seat

Speaker: NA
Text: with a negative swing below the national

Speaker: NA
Text: is average and well below the Victorian aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age and for that I thank my constituents in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports very much for their support.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to thank all those who

Speaker: NA
Text: worked on my campaign team, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: my campaign director, Steve Donnelly. I fear

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's victory in Adelaide means that Steve

Speaker: NA
Text: will be transferring his loyalties elsewhere,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do appreciate the hard work he put into

Speaker: NA
Text: the campaign. I would also like to thank my

Speaker: NA
Text: staff, Alex Kats, Tony Williams and Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Adam Carr, and my campaign committee

Speaker: NA
Text: including Dr Henry Pinskier, Bunna Walsh,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonya Stephens, Alex Hicks, Sylvia Free-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, Donna Walsh, Dror Poleg, Byron

Speaker: NA
Text: Danby, George Droutsas, Natalie Lupton,

Speaker: NA
Text: and all the loyal Labor members and volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: teers across the electorate who did so much

Speaker: NA
Text: work to ensure our rather unusual result in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports. I would also like to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: my state parliamentary colleagues Tony Lup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton and John Thwaites and my friends at the

Speaker: NA
Text: AWU, MUA, SDA and HSU who gave me

Speaker: NA
Text: their assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Liberal Party thought they had a seri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous chance of winning Melbourne Ports at

Speaker: NA
Text: this election, and they chose a candidate

Speaker: NA
Text: whom they thought might appeal to some of

Speaker: NA
Text: my core supporters. The Victorian Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, the candidate and his family spent an

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated quarter of a million dollars trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to unseat me. They also resorted to some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most unpleasant campaign tactics we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen in Melbourne Ports in any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: also elections I have participated in, including

Speaker: NA
Text: unauthorised and anonymous leaflets attack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing my record, particularly on issues relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the gay community, and letterboxed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: homes of Orthodox Jewish families. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: tactic was the use of green how-to-vote

Speaker: NA
Text: cards, handed out by young women in green

Speaker: NA
Text: t-shirts and hats. This was a cheap trick de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to fool first-time voters into voting

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal in the belief that they were voting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Greens. Despite all these tactics, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's candidate was not successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, we on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: have to acknowledge that we lost the election

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the Howard Government has a man-

Speaker: NA
Text: date to govern for the next three years. From

Speaker: NA
Text: next July they will also have control of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate and thus will have the ability to legischampion

Speaker: NA
Text: late as they see fit. As we are already seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the abortion issue, I fear this means that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government will feel increasing pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: to move further to the right on a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: issues that up till now they have moved cau-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiously on. The government has a mandate,

Speaker: NA
Text: but history has shown that if they abuse it by

Speaker: NA
Text: putting through extremist measures they will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay a heavy price.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why did Labor lose this election? The ba-

Speaker: NA
Text: sic answer is that Australia has experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a decade of economic growth, low

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation, low interest rates and falling un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment, and Australian voters are usu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally reluctant to vote out a government when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are broadly happy with the state of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. The foundations of this economic

Speaker: NA
Text: success were laid by the Hawke and Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, and I think we on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House have not done enough to remind

Speaker: NA
Text: people of that fact. The Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer have had the good fortune of

Speaker: NA
Text: reaping the benefits of many of the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms that Labor enacted. The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: likes to boast of his record, but so far he

Speaker: NA
Text: not been tested by external factors. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: see what kind of navigator he really is when

Speaker: NA
Text: the ship of state really hits stormy economic

Speaker: NA
Text: waters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second factor was the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign on interest rates, which undoubt-

Speaker: NA
Text: edly influenced many voters in mortgage belt

Speaker: NA
Text: suburban seats. This campaign was bogus, as

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually every senior economist in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out. If interest rates are going to rise,

Speaker: NA
Text: for and I fear they may, they are going to rise

Speaker: NA
Text: govregardless of who is in government. In case

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite have forgotten, this is how

Speaker: NA
Text: free market economies are supposed to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: In their advertising the government cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paigned as though we were living in East

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany, with prices and interest rates fixed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the state. You cannot on one hand be a

Speaker: NA
Text: of deregulation and market forces

Speaker: NA
Text: and on the other claim that you are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: dictate whether interest rates will go up or

Speaker: NA
Text: down. I thought that was the preserve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank. The fact remains, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: that Labor was unable to counter the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's scare campaign, which we should

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen coming and will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: sharper in countering in the future. It is vital

Speaker: NA
Text: that Labor emphasises its strong economic

Speaker: NA
Text: credentials, and I am confident that the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer will put forward an effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive analysis and criticism of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's economic policies and develop poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies for the next election which will win the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third factor of our defeat, in my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: was the late release of our key policies on

Speaker: NA
Text: health, education and the environment, all

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in which the Australian people tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally look to Labor rather than the coali-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for answers. I believe our policies in all

Speaker: NA
Text: three areas were imaginative and well inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned, and some were received well by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people. But their late release

Speaker: NA
Text: has meant that we could not mount an effective

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign around them and we could not

Speaker: NA
Text: make a defence against the criticisms that

Speaker: NA
Text: were made in the media by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: and by affected lobby groups. In the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: forest policy, as a prospective beneficiary of

Speaker: NA
Text: this policy as an inner city member-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Greens polled 14 per cent of the vote in Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Ports and gave me 90 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their preferences-I believe our policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: ending logging in Tasmania's old-growth

Speaker: NA
Text: forests was a price we paid for those prefer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences with too high a coin. We would have

Speaker: NA
Text: got their preferences anyhow, and the defeat

Speaker: NA
Text: of two fine Labor members in Tasmania-

Speaker: NA
Text: including the previous member for Braddon;

Speaker: NA
Text: we have just heard the new member make

Speaker: NA
Text: his first speech-the loss of a Senate place in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania and probably our failures in Eden-

Speaker: NA
Text: Monaro, MCMillan and Gippsland was a

Speaker: NA
Text: price that was, in my view, too high. The

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of chasing Greens preferences at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of working-class voters is an issue

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Labor Party have to face very

Speaker: NA
Text: squarely and, in my view, was an error of

Speaker: NA
Text: judgement. Once again, the possibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: recouping the damage was lost because the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy was released late.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn to some of the issues that I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve will confront us during this parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary term. Recently, on the front page of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, we saw a story on the report by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Competition and Consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission into Australia's waterfront,

Speaker: NA
Text: which shows rising costs for exporters, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creasing congestion and delays at ports. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report shows that the rate of return for the

Speaker: NA
Text: two existing stevedoring companies-Patrick

Speaker: NA
Text: and P&O Ports-has risen from 10.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in 1998-99 to over 27 per cent in 2003-

Speaker: NA
Text: 04. The ACCC chairman, Graeme Samuel,

Speaker: NA
Text: was quoted as saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher average revenues-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, increased profits for the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: favoured friends at Patrick and P&O-

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that users are facing higher charges for ste-

Speaker: NA
Text: vedoring services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government likes to boast that its water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front reforms have greatly increased produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity in the stevedoring industry, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCC report shows that Australia's ports

Speaker: NA
Text: urgently need new investment to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity and reduce costs for exporters. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, the cosy duopoly that Patrick

Speaker: NA
Text: and P&O enjoy in the stevedoring industry

Speaker: NA
Text: has allowed them to increase their rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: profit rather than investing some of their in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come in increased capacity, which would

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit Australian exporters as well as pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide greater employment to waterfront com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities such as those in Melbourne Ports.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the article:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... margins in the stevedoring industry had risen in

Speaker: NA
Text: each of the six years since the ACCC commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: monitoring.

Speaker: NA
Text: The article quotes Mr Samuel:

Speaker: NA
Text: If the industry is beginning to experience ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity constraints then it is important from a

Speaker: NA
Text: competition perspective to see new investment ...

Speaker: NA
Text: This would expand capacity, alleviate congestion

Speaker: NA
Text: and ensure maintenance of service levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the selfish profit-taking of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's corporate mates is starving

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry of investment and pushing up

Speaker: NA
Text: costs for Australian exporters. Since these

Speaker: NA
Text: include our great agricultural exporting in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries, I thought we might have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: something from The Nationals about this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead over the last few years we have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Deputy Prime Minister and Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Transport and Regional Services, who

Speaker: NA
Text: has come in here and rabbited on about the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's reform of Australia's ports.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the trickle-down effect of his so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called microeconomic reform has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: happening at all, as I and many other mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers on this side have pointed out to him, as

Speaker: NA
Text: has the Australian shipping and export indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. We will continue to pursue this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: with the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last parliament, I had the honour of

Speaker: NA
Text: serving as Deputy Chairman of the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

Speaker: NA
Text: under the chairmanship of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kooyong. If I am again a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of this committee, which I hope to be, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a busy year for us. We have already

Speaker: NA
Text: seen Senator Abetz, the Special Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: State, indicate that he intends reintroducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's electoral legislation which

Speaker: NA
Text: was rejected by the Senate in the last parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. His bill would, amongst other things,

Speaker: NA
Text: close the electoral roll on the day the election

Speaker: NA
Text: is announced rather than allowing voters a

Speaker: NA
Text: week's grace to update their addresses or to

Speaker: NA
Text: enrol for the first time. We know-this is not

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of speculation-that this would

Speaker: NA
Text: have the effect of disenfranchising about

Speaker: NA
Text: 300,000 Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: I spoke about this matter at length in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last session and no doubt I will do so again. I

Speaker: NA
Text: only want to say now that this is a blatant

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of electoral manipulation by this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. It is designed to keep many young

Speaker: NA
Text: people-there are 70,000 young people

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst those 300,000-and transient and

Speaker: NA
Text: low-income people off the rolls. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's belief-a poll-driven belief, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you ask me-that, integrated with its happi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness at the increasing number of people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are voting informally, and its failure to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the AEC to pursue those who do not partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pate at all, which number has also gone up

Speaker: NA
Text: slightly over the last few years, it will get

Speaker: NA
Text: some electoral benefit out of this. In particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar, the prospect of disenfranchising people at

Speaker: NA
Text: the next election is designed on the belief

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would vote Labor rather than Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral. In doing this, the government is ignor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the unanimous report of the Joint Stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Committee on Electoral Matters that

Speaker: NA
Text: such a move is not necessary. The supposed

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about the integrity of the electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: system which Senator Abetz cites as the rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son for this change is no more than a smoke-

Speaker: NA
Text: screen for the self-interest of the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is ironic that, while this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: busy looking for ways to restrict democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: participation in Australia, democratic free-

Speaker: NA
Text: doms are expanding in other countries. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year more people around the world voted in

Speaker: NA
Text: free elections than at any other time in hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: man history. Amongst them were the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering people of Afghanistan, who in Oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tober-to their great credit-at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time as the Australian elections, elected their

Speaker: NA
Text: first-ever freely elected leader, President

Speaker: NA
Text: Hamid Karzai, who polled 55.4 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the vote. Despite Taliban and al-Qaeda

Speaker: NA
Text: threats, more than 10 million Afghans

Speaker: NA
Text: voted-three million more than were ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected. The United Nations believed that

Speaker: NA
Text: Afgans would be too afraid to enrol. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: courage of the Afghan people in enrolling

Speaker: NA
Text: and participating in this election in such a

Speaker: NA
Text: large measure was a great tribute to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was a remarkable achievement in one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world's poorest countries, until recently

Speaker: NA
Text: ruled by one of the most oppressive regimes

Speaker: NA
Text: in modern history. It was striking that the

Speaker: NA
Text: turnout amongst women was nearly as high

Speaker: NA
Text: as amongst men.

Speaker: NA
Text: This progress in Afghanistan, in which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forces played a modest but credit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able role, is in sharp contrast to the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in most of the Islamic world. Although we in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are very pleased to see Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: has made great strides towards democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: with its first direct presidential election this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, most of the countries in the Middle

Speaker: NA
Text: East still remain dictatorships or absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: monarchies. Last year's parliamentary elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in Iran, for example, were in my view a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete farce. The striking out of many

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic candidates-in fact, sitting mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of parliament-by some faceless group

Speaker: NA
Text: of mullahs was a disgrace to Tehran's claim

Speaker: NA
Text: to democracy. Pakistan is ruled by the mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary behind the facade of a parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: government and, unfortunately, the same has

Speaker: NA
Text: happened in what was formerly Soviet Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral Asia.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of this makes the elections in Iraq

Speaker: NA
Text: scheduled for January 2005 extremely im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant. Most of the bloodshed in Iraq at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment is part of a campaign to prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: these elections taking place. This campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: is usually depicted as resistance against the

Speaker: NA
Text: US and allied forces in Iraq. In fact, in my

Speaker: NA
Text: view, it is mainly intended to intimidate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraqi people by a minority who have tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally been able to control that country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those regimes behind this insurgency minor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, particularly the regimes of Iran and

Speaker: NA
Text: Syria, know that a successful election and

Speaker: NA
Text: inauguration of democratic Iraq would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: grave threat to their own hold on power.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are views that I know are shared by

Speaker: NA
Text: the new Iraqi Ambassador to Australia, Am-

Speaker: NA
Text: bassador Al Shildu, whom I had the honour

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet at a lunch hosted by the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General following his credentialling. Support

Speaker: NA
Text: for the elections is a view shared by many

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraqi professionals who live in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: who work under the Iraqi Forum trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage Australian support for democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: in Iraq.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is so important that these elections go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead on schedule, and that democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: countries give Iraq as much help as possible

Speaker: NA
Text: in conducting these elections and establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a freely elected government. An inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent authentic elected Iraq government

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the best way of getting foreign troops

Speaker: NA
Text: out of Iraq. The project of building a democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ratic Iraq is important for not only the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering people of Iraq but also for the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample it will set to the whole region. If

Speaker: NA
Text: be done in Afghanistan in the face of enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous difficulties, it can be done in Iraq. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe Ayatollah Sistani, the Shia leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 60 per cent of Iraqis who follow the Shia

Speaker: NA
Text: form of religion, wants the elections to go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead as scheduled. I believe they should go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead as soon as possible to enable people to

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect the democratic will of that country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing will do more to diminish the suicide

Speaker: NA
Text: bombings and the terrorism that are taking

Speaker: NA
Text: place there, than a successful election.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government argued during the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign that Australia should stay in

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraq until the job is done and now it has a

Speaker: NA
Text: mandate for that policy. So it is fair to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: what the government is now doing in prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice to help the Iraqi people for their first free

Speaker: NA
Text: elections next year. We have great experience

Speaker: NA
Text: in electoral systems and we have assisted our

Speaker: NA
Text: friends and neighbours in East Timor and

Speaker: NA
Text: Cambodia to establish efficient and transpar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent election systems; we should be doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: same to help Iraq in the run-up to the 2005

Speaker: NA
Text: elections.

Speaker: NA
Text: Elections are also scheduled for the presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dency of the Palestinian Authority in Janu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary. I make no secret of my belief that over

Speaker: NA
Text: the past four years the greatest obstacle to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving a peace settlement in the Middle

Speaker: NA
Text: East was the obstructionism of the late

Speaker: NA
Text: Yasser Arafat, whose rejection of the Barak-

Speaker: NA
Text: Clinton peace offer in 2000 triggered the

Speaker: NA
Text: current tragic train of events in that small but

Speaker: NA
Text: vital part of the world. His death creates new

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities to get the peace process mov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing again. Again it is elections that lead to

Speaker: NA
Text: this possibility-elections in the Palestinian

Speaker: NA
Text: Authority. Many people argue that it is ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: rorism, impoverishment and Western policy

Speaker: NA
Text: that lead to the extreme politics in that part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world. I think that when people have

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity for a free expression of

Speaker: NA
Text: views they overcome those kinds of extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: political attitudes that we have seen in that

Speaker: NA
Text: it can region for so long. We should welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Sharon's plan to withdraw

Speaker: NA
Text: from Gaza, and we should encourage the

Speaker: NA
Text: Palestinians to respond in the same spirit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia should do whatever we can to as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sist both parties to resume negotiations.

Speaker: NA
Text: During this parliament I will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: work for the people of Melbourne Ports. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to raise issues such as electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: reform, national security, human rights in

Speaker: NA
Text: many parts of the world and the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's callous treatment of asylum seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The voters have decided that Labor should

Speaker: NA
Text: spend another term in opposition, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to accept that verdict. That does not

Speaker: NA
Text: mean, however, that we should not continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to expose injustices as we see them and

Speaker: NA
Text: speak out in this House on behalf of our con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents. Over the next three years we have

Speaker: NA
Text: to work harder to develop policies that will

Speaker: NA
Text: win the confidence of voters at the next elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. In the meantime, we will hold this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to account.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by taking up some of the words

Speaker: NA
Text: of the new member for Prospect, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: very much like Prime Minister Blair's views

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United Kingdom: we have to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the democratic prospect throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: world as not just economic development but

Speaker: NA
Text: as a way of-particularly in that troubled

Speaker: NA
Text: area of the Middle East-solving problems

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as creating them. I really look for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward to the elections in Iraq as a way of

Speaker: NA
Text: ing those people in that part of the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing greater human rights to it and un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dermining the very basis on which a minority

Speaker: NA
Text: of people in that part of the world would de-

Speaker: NA
Text: prive their own people as much as us of their

Speaker: NA
Text: freedoms via terrorism. We have a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: work to do in this parliament, and I hope the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's democratic rhetoric is as valid

Speaker: NA
Text: as it says it is both in its assistance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Iraq and in this country, where

Speaker: NA
Text: there are some moves that it seems to have

Speaker: NA
Text: initiated to limit democratic freedoms.

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Text: Barker) (7.33 p.m.)-It is

Speaker: NA
Text: always a pleasure to follow the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports. He actually makes quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit of sense, certainly on foreign affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: ters, and I think this parliament would be

Speaker: NA
Text: much better if he had more influence on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party's policy when it came to foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. I certainly think what he said about

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraq, Palestine and Israel made a lot of sense,

Speaker: NA
Text: and anyone who listened to it would have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen that it was a very reasoned argument.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is always a pleasure to follow him, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though I may not agree with him on what he

Speaker: NA
Text: said on electoral matters, because I remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber many years ago when the Labor Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the guise of many different reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: brought the age for voting down from 21 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 18, and I am sure that was simply a reverse

Speaker: NA
Text: of what the member for Melbourne Ports was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying about young people voting. All I say

Speaker: NA
Text: about that is that perhaps we need to look in

Speaker: NA
Text: mirrors to see what is fair to all concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I proceed, I congratulate you, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker Quick, on your rise to this

Speaker: NA
Text: position. It is a pleasure to see someone like

Speaker: NA
Text: you in the chair. I know we will always get a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair deal from you. One thing I can say about

Speaker: NA
Text: this election and certainly the three years

Speaker: NA
Text: before the election is that, time after time, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would go and see people and the big thing

Speaker: NA
Text: they remembered about the Labor Party was

Speaker: NA
Text: the high interest rates. People do have long

Speaker: NA
Text: freememories in this country, and signing a big

Speaker: NA
Text: cardboard cheque to say ‘we will keep inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est rates down' just did not wash. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: many of my friends, and certainly acquaint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ances, lost farms and businesses, and if they

Speaker: NA
Text: did manage to struggle through it often took

Speaker: NA
Text: them two, three or four years to get over that

Speaker: NA
Text: high interest rate cycle, and they do remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. That was always one of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's weaknesses, and I do not think we

Speaker: NA
Text: should apologise as a party for actually say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that people should remember that interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates have always been higher under the La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: I noticed in recent weeks a former Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, Paul Keating, saying that the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: matParty should embrace the goals that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: as Treasurer and Prime Minister to modern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ise the country. I have often said that they

Speaker: NA
Text: did do some good things, but the big differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence between us and them is that in 1996

Speaker: NA
Text: they would not have made the changes that

Speaker: NA
Text: we made when we came into government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They would not have made the cuts that we

Speaker: NA
Text: made to spending so that we could get the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget deficit under control. It is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in Australian history that in the 90

Speaker: NA
Text: years since Federation in 1901 we accumu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated a total federal debt of $16 billion. In

Speaker: NA
Text: those 90 years we had two world wars, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Depression, the Korean War, the Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: War, the building of a national capital and

Speaker: NA
Text: lots of infrastructure to build as a country-

Speaker: NA
Text: yet we only accumulated $16 billion in debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: But that $16 billion was increased, on aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age, by the same amount each year for the

Speaker: NA
Text: next five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1991 to 1996 federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: debt went from $16 billion net to $96 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, we have repaid more than $60

Speaker: NA
Text: billion of that Labor debt. I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: one in their faintest dreams would have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that, if a Labor government were

Speaker: NA
Text: elected in 1996, they would have taken that

Speaker: NA
Text: action. They did not have the form. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were prepared to continue to allow our na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional debt to increase. One of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits of reducing that debt by over $60

Speaker: NA
Text: billion-in fact, we have reduced it by nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: $70 billion-is that as a nation we now have

Speaker: NA
Text: $5½ billion extra to spend every year forever

Speaker: NA
Text: and ever. We can spend that on health, edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and infrastructure. That money will be

Speaker: NA
Text: there forever and ever, unless this country

Speaker: NA
Text: gets another Labor government which starts

Speaker: NA
Text: to run up debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Howard government, with Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Costello as Treasurer, has continued to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce debt, has continued to deliver surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: budgets, has got interest rates down, has got

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment down and has got the dragon

Speaker: NA
Text: of inflation under control. Obviously when a

Speaker: NA
Text: government such as ours does all that, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: hard for any opposition party to make any

Speaker: NA
Text: inroads. But I will leave it to the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: to recriminate about ordinary campaigning

Speaker: NA
Text: and policies which certainly did not work

Speaker: NA
Text: and did not connect with the Australian peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to take this opportunity tonight to

Speaker: NA
Text: share with the House some of the things that

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe led to the re-election of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and my re-election as the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Barker. I was very pleased with the swing

Speaker: NA
Text: I received in South Australia in the seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker. I know probably a fair bit of that is

Speaker: NA
Text: due to our government's record, but I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to say that, for the second election in

Speaker: NA
Text: a row, I received the biggest swing in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. That is pleasing personally. We

Speaker: NA
Text: had a mixed result in South Australia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: lost two and we won two, but I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased with the result because I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: were under the gun. There is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: anythe Rann Labor government in South Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia is reasonably popular, but there was still a

Speaker: NA
Text: half a per cent swing to the coalition in this

Speaker: NA
Text: election. I think the vote we received in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia was the second highest vote

Speaker: NA
Text: for the coalition anywhere in Australia. That

Speaker: NA
Text: we can return eight seats out of 11 in a state

Speaker: NA
Text: like South Australia is a pretty good result.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were very close to returning nine out of

Speaker: NA
Text: 11, and it would not take much more to actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally return 10 out of 11. That is not through

Speaker: NA
Text: any electoral gerrymandering; it is due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that, in South Australia, we are getting

Speaker: NA
Text: over 55 per cent of the two-party preferred

Speaker: NA
Text: vote. And we do have some very effective

Speaker: NA
Text: and good ministers that come from South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We have the likes of the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mayo, the Minister for Foreign Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Senator Robert Hill, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence. Senator Amanda Vanstone is an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other minister.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Text: And there is the minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: finance.

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Text: Of course, Nick Minchin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Party How could I forget Senator Nick Minchin?

Speaker: NA
Text: We have four members of cabinet-equal

Speaker: NA
Text: membership to New South Wales and Victo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ria. So we in South Australia are batting

Speaker: NA
Text: above our weight in the Liberal Party. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleasing that we have some very good

Speaker: NA
Text: representation in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the past three years, the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government has had many wins and has pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided much for the Australian people. Within

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Barker, the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to regional Australia has en-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled me as a member of the coalition to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver beneficial outcomes on a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: issues which have assisted the constituents in

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker. Tonight I will inform the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: these achievements and happenings and also

Speaker: NA
Text: give the House some insight into my plans

Speaker: NA
Text: for Barker over the next term of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, before I do that, I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend my thanks to the hardworking Barker

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign team. Their dedication and assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance helped me to return to serve the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Barker for a third term as a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House. This fantastic team has seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Barker returned to the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party-and returned in fine form, as I men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned earlier. We experienced a swing of 3.2

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent in the electorate of Barker. We won

Speaker: NA
Text: 103 of the 108 booths, and I think three of

Speaker: NA
Text: the others were won by The Nationals. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: overall, I think the coalition won all but two

Speaker: NA
Text: booths, and in one of those booths there were

Speaker: NA
Text: about 48 votes in it. For the first time, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: almost pleased to say that I actually came

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty close in the booth of Nangwarry. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think we had got much over about 34 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent since Federation, and Barker is a Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration seat. In this election we had a two-

Speaker: NA
Text: party preferred vote of over 48 per cent. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was an amazing result, but one has to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: why we got that result. Nangwarry is a for-

Speaker: NA
Text: estry town, and there is no doubt that they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not like the Labor Party's forestry policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The results that we received in the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Barker were the culmination of

Speaker: NA
Text: months of hard work by my wonderful team

Speaker: NA
Text: both prior to and during the election. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment was just fantastic and their loy-

Speaker: NA
Text: alty was unwavering. I consider myself most

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate to have such a fantastic team. My

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign manager, the Hon. David Ridgway

Speaker: NA
Text: MLC, worked tirelessly on this campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Balancing his commitments as a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the South Australia Legislative Council with

Speaker: NA
Text: his family commitments and his commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the Barker campaign was no easy

Speaker: NA
Text: task. He has been a mate of mine for many

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I have helped him and he helped me

Speaker: NA
Text: this time around. I am very grateful for the

Speaker: NA
Text: effort that he put in. He made himself avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able at all times and he certainly did take a

Speaker: NA
Text: load off my shoulders.

Speaker: NA
Text: In our campaign committee we had mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers from all over the electorate. It is an elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of 64,000 square kilometres. Mr Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: uty Speaker Quick, it is nearly the size of

Speaker: NA
Text: your state of Tasmania, so you can imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to represent that area-the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: people involved, and trying to coordinate

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I had some fantastic people. There was

Speaker: NA
Text: my FEC chair, Anne Bell, and her husband,

Speaker: NA
Text: Graham. We had people like Roger Saunders

Speaker: NA
Text: from Mount Gambier, Stephanie Martin from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Barossa, Draz Barick and Kent Andrew

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Riverland, and Damien MCQueen

Speaker: NA
Text: from Murray Bridge. They were fantastic.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are distances of 500 kilometres be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween some of those people, so you can

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine the logistics of getting them to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would especially like to thank my lovely

Speaker: NA
Text: wife, Sharon, who is the best thing that has

Speaker: NA
Text: ever happened to me. Her positive and vi-

Speaker: NA
Text: brant attitude around the place, and her total

Speaker: NA
Text: support and commitment, not only during the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign but also over the last few years,

Speaker: NA
Text: has been one of those wonderful things.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of this parliament, when they have

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of support, know how lucky they

Speaker: NA
Text: are. I have no doubt that Sharon won a few

Speaker: NA
Text: votes for me because she is a very vibrant

Speaker: NA
Text: and attractive person who naturally gets on

Speaker: NA
Text: well with people. She certainly has a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: strength, and her support was second to

Speaker: NA
Text: none.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to thank my staff mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers Philippa, Vanessa, Leeanne, Karen and

Speaker: NA
Text: Alecia-a couple of them part time-who

Speaker: NA
Text: worked tirelessly throughout the campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were often there at almost daybreak

Speaker: NA
Text: and leaving at midnight. That is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: support and loyalty I had from my staff, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think anyone could wish for better.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be

Speaker: NA
Text: aware, election campaigns come at a great

Speaker: NA
Text: cost. I would like to take this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly thank those who lent their financial

Speaker: NA
Text: support to my campaign. Their generosity is

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly appreciated. Just as they have dem-

Speaker: NA
Text: onstrated their faith in me as their parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary representative, I would like to express

Speaker: NA
Text: my faith in the businesses and individuals in

Speaker: NA
Text: the seat of Barker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lastly, and with incessant appreciation, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to thank the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: branches of Barker. Their assistance, both

Speaker: NA
Text: financially and on the ground, was the life-

Speaker: NA
Text: blood of this campaign. As I said, Barker is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very large electorate-it has 108 polling

Speaker: NA
Text: booths-so we rely heavily on the loyalty

Speaker: NA
Text: and commitment of our volunteers and party

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I think something like 400 of our

Speaker: NA
Text: members worked on the polls during the day,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they certainly assisted the Liberal cause

Speaker: NA
Text: in Barker. They organised fundraisers, put up

Speaker: NA
Text: corflutes, set up polling packs and even

Speaker: NA
Text: campaigned beside me. Last, but by no

Speaker: NA
Text: means least, they gave up their time on Sat-

Speaker: NA
Text: urday, 9 October to man those polling

Speaker: NA
Text: booths. I know that all members of parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment rely on that support, but I am amazed at

Speaker: NA
Text: what support they give the Liberal Party. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure I speak for all members in saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Howard government has been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turned to this House for a fourth term as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of that dedicated support from our

Speaker: NA
Text: supporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think we are a positive, forward-thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: party and that the Howard government was

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously a stable choice for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people. It was a hard-fought election. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: well won by the coalition. I think our elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion policies reflected the needs of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people. Strong policies and good rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentation win elections, and we had both of

Speaker: NA
Text: these things. I think the election policies of

Speaker: NA
Text: this government really hit a chord with the

Speaker: NA
Text: voters in my electorate. I was very pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: get $219 million committed for road freight

Speaker: NA
Text: under Auslink. Roads infrastructure is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important for an electorate like mine. On top

Speaker: NA
Text: of that, the Roads to Recovery program has

Speaker: NA
Text: been very popular-and I am sure the Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: uty Speaker would say the same thing. In

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia it has probably been more

Speaker: NA
Text: popular than anywhere else in Australia be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we got the biggest increase in roads

Speaker: NA
Text: grants funding-118 per cent for every

Speaker: NA
Text: council in South Australia. That meant a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge amount for local roads as well as na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional highways. I think we need to contrast

Speaker: NA
Text: that with the state government in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The Commonwealth gives something

Speaker: NA
Text: like $100 million to local government in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. Even in Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and Queensland the state governments give

Speaker: NA
Text: $63 million and $62 million respectively to

Speaker: NA
Text: local governments for local roads. What does

Speaker: NA
Text: the South Australian state government give?

Speaker: NA
Text: A pathetic $800,000. They are by far the

Speaker: NA
Text: worst funders of roads infrastructure of any

Speaker: NA
Text: state in Australia. You can see many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: roads crumbling before your eyes, because

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not spending money on roads where

Speaker: NA
Text: it needs to be spent.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most important responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: of any government is looking after the health

Speaker: NA
Text: and welfare of the Australian people. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition has delivered results for Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, more specifically, for my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker-through the Medicare safety net

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in March this year. That is pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: important for an electorate like mine, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has a low bulk-billing rate because it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have competition between doctors. One

Speaker: NA
Text: of our problems has been getting doctors out

Speaker: NA
Text: into rural areas. That is one thing I know we

Speaker: NA
Text: have improved quite substantially since we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been in government. But, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not have the competition, we do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors giving the bulk-billing rates that

Speaker: NA
Text: some of us would like. As a result of that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net has been fantastic. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it has been the most fantastic im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement in the 20-year history of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare system. It is now a stronger, more

Speaker: NA
Text: robust system which protects the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people from high medical expenses beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: the door of their local GP.

Speaker: NA
Text: It certainly has been well received. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last eight months over 3,000 of my con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents have benefited from the new sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem. At last count there were 23,100 families

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate who have reached the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net threshold. I know they had greater peace

Speaker: NA
Text: of mind now that they know most of their

Speaker: NA
Text: medical costs, whatever they are for, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: covered. It gives a lot of peace of mind and

Speaker: NA
Text: security. I think it is very fair for an electorspeak

Speaker: NA
Text: ate like mine. One of the things that most

Speaker: NA
Text: grabbed the imagination in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: was the technical high schools-everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: wants one. I know there are only two in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia, but we want a lot more as

Speaker: NA
Text: well. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: Gellibrand) (7.53 p.m.)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very difficult not to respond to the last

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of the previous speaker, the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Barker, because it is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the great disappointments of the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: election of the Howard government that

Speaker: NA
Text: there may be some policies that people are

Speaker: NA
Text: keen on, but if the government cannot de-

Speaker: NA
Text: liver them in the areas where they are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed-my electorate, the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker and others-these big-scale promises

Speaker: NA
Text: are not going to turn into anything much.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is instead of putting that money into a

Speaker: NA
Text: system that exists, and services our commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities, but is underfunded. I do not want to be

Speaker: NA
Text: too distracted, because with this opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the address-in-reply we obviously get to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover a range of issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to focus on two things: firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: some issues for my electorate of Gellibrand

Speaker: NA
Text: and, secondly, some important issues that are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to feature in the ongoing debate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: next three years about the way our govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is structured and, in particular, my role

Speaker: NA
Text: as shadow Attorney-General. These are the

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of things that will become increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: important in holding the government to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count in a range of areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to take this as my first opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to thank the people of Gellibrand for re-

Speaker: NA
Text: electing me for a third time. It is obviously a

Speaker: NA
Text: great honour for all of us to be elected. It

Speaker: NA
Text: shows great trust in us as representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: when communities re-elect us several times.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been wonderful to listen to a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of first speeches today from new members

Speaker: NA
Text: on both sides of the House. They obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: feel the honour acutely when they rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place for the first time. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that never leaves us, and it never

Speaker: NA
Text: should, because we have the responsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: representing over 100,000 people each-it is

Speaker: NA
Text: about 120,000 in my electorate-who see us

Speaker: NA
Text: as their conduit to this national capital. The

Speaker: NA
Text: issues they are interested in and they care

Speaker: NA
Text: about which affect their lives can and must

Speaker: NA
Text: be raised here by us. It is an obligation and

Speaker: NA
Text: an honour that I take very seriously.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is with some regret in making this

Speaker: NA
Text: speech that I note how strongly the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity in Gellibrand endorsed Labor's policies

Speaker: NA
Text: at this election-in particular, I think, our

Speaker: NA
Text: direction on health and education was some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that many people in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: could see offered them a great alternative to

Speaker: NA
Text: the system they are currently under and the

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures they are currently feeling. That we

Speaker: NA
Text: were not elected as a whole across the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try is a great disappointment not just for us

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side of the House but also for those

Speaker: NA
Text: many people who voted for us and our policy

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda, who will not see it implemented and

Speaker: NA
Text: will not get the benefits of those policies, as

Speaker: NA
Text: would have happened in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular, I am disappointed that we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot deliver on some of the vital services

Speaker: NA
Text: that are much needed in Gellibrand, where

Speaker: NA
Text: we committed to better funding of our

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. I have lots of government schools

Speaker: NA
Text: and low-fee Catholic schools in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate, and one independent school with moder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate fees. No school in my electorate would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been worse off under our policy, and

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the schools-probably with the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ception of one-would have been far better

Speaker: NA
Text: off. Schools from Altona Meadows Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: School to the Maribyrnong Secondary Col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege, to the Footscray City College and Wil-

Speaker: NA
Text: liamstown High School are very good

Speaker: NA
Text: schools that really need some extra resources

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to give the education of our kids in

Speaker: NA
Text: that area an extra edge.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased that the Minister for Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, Science and Training is here at the ta-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble-quite by chance-while I am delivering

Speaker: NA
Text: my speech, because he would be acutely

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that regions like mine in Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: need extra assistance. They need to be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to accommodate students who come from all

Speaker: NA
Text: different ethnic backgrounds, such as those

Speaker: NA
Text: from the very large refugee population who

Speaker: NA
Text: face challenges in English language when

Speaker: NA
Text: they start their schooling and many other

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges that make their lives a little more

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult than others. For example, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively low levels of home Internet usage.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the sorts of things that affect a

Speaker: NA
Text: dent's day-to-day studying capacity but are

Speaker: NA
Text: not being dealt with by the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: funding policy for schools. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: is not putting extra resources into those

Speaker: NA
Text: schools that need it most. Those schools will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to do a good job by our kids, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they will do it with one hand tied behind

Speaker: NA
Text: their backs through lack of funding that

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been offered if Labor had been

Speaker: NA
Text: elected at the federal election.

Speaker: NA
Text: So that is a great disappointment. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointment that, because of the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: election of the Howard government, the extra

Speaker: NA
Text: $7 million of funding that would have gone

Speaker: NA
Text: to Victoria University will not. We will not

Speaker: NA
Text: have the better health and bulk-billing ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices that were promised. In particular, La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor was committed to ensuring that the west-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern region of Melbourne had a rebateable

Speaker: NA
Text: MRI machine for our public health services.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is extraordinary that a section of Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne that probably has a third of the popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation does not within its whole reach have

Speaker: NA
Text: an MRI machine that someone can go to and

Speaker: NA
Text: claim a Medicare rebate for. It means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: people with the most money can pay up front

Speaker: NA
Text: to get those services, and those that cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: have to go on long waiting lists for other

Speaker: NA
Text: public facilities that are often difficult to get

Speaker: NA
Text: to. It is often frail and elderly patients who

Speaker: NA
Text: need these services, who have to travel

Speaker: NA
Text: across town to get them and who often risk

Speaker: NA
Text: some other damage to their health.

Speaker: NA
Text: When an electorate like Gellibrand has

Speaker: NA
Text: voted for Labor at a ratio of about two to

Speaker: NA
Text: one, it is obviously my strong obligation and

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment, which I reaffirm here publicly

Speaker: NA
Text: today, to continue to fight for those issues-

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not it is from opposition. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important role for us to play in highlight-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the inadequacies of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies, particularly for regions like mine,

Speaker: NA
Text: where we have an extra need for some inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention at the federal level and proper re-

Speaker: NA
Text: stusources in areas where there is serious disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that many in the House are famil-

Speaker: NA
Text: iar with the type of electorate I live in, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to put some statistics together. Thirty-

Speaker: NA
Text: six per cent of our population speaks a lan-

Speaker: NA
Text: guage other than English at home. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 20 per cent-19.7 per cent-rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment and a 6.4 per cent gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral unemployment rate in western Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne. Everyone talks about how well the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy is going, but I think it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: to acknowledge that not everyone is yet

Speaker: NA
Text: benefiting from the economy going well and

Speaker: NA
Text: that we do have an obligation to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that everyone gets a fair share of the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: that are flowing through to the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had a decline of about 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in bulk-billing rates in our electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although compared to some other areas it is

Speaker: NA
Text: still relatively high, that is a great difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: A large number of families have local doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors who are now no longer bulk-billing

Speaker: NA
Text: them. We are seeing a growing number of

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints on that issue. The re-election of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government does not mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues and needs can be ignored and

Speaker: NA
Text: my job, obviously, is to make sure that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are not. We must ensure that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: will govern for everyone, and that includes

Speaker: NA
Text: the people in my electorate, many of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: are having a hard time.

Speaker: NA
Text: My job also reaches to holding the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to its election promises, and one of

Speaker: NA
Text: those promises was made in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was a promise made during the election

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Howard government if re-elected

Speaker: NA
Text: would put $8 million into the Western Bull-

Speaker: NA
Text: dogs Football Club to help redevelop the

Speaker: NA
Text: famous Whitten Oval and to make sure that a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of community services could be deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered through that redeveloped facility. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people of the region, who are very passionate

Speaker: NA
Text: about their football and their football club-

Speaker: NA
Text: as am I-were delighted that Mr Howard, in

Speaker: NA
Text: making his first trip out into the west of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, decided to make this commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the club. But I must say that we are a

Speaker: NA
Text: little bit concerned that since the election

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been deafening silence on this

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment. The club has written to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, requesting confirmation and

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking advice as to any other processes that

Speaker: NA
Text: now need to be gone through and asking

Speaker: NA
Text: which department is administering the

Speaker: NA
Text: money. I have written to the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to find out this information. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: had no response.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very concerned that after all the fan-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare-and even people who were not in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria would have seen the coverage, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was saturation coverage on the night, of

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments being make to our football

Speaker: NA
Text: club-there has actually been no follow

Speaker: NA
Text: through yet. It has made a lot of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: our electorate nervous. I am hopeful that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government will quickly clarify its commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, acknowledge the advantage it clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: got in the election in many areas and make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that it holds to its word.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having sat through question time today, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was obviously also concerned that when Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Anderson, the Acting Prime Minister, was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked a range of questions about other re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional projects he seemed to be suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that the election announcements that were

Speaker: NA
Text: made were only step 1 in the process and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the communities now should actually follow

Speaker: NA
Text: some other process as yet unknown to peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple. He seemed to be suggesting that the

Speaker: NA
Text: money that was promised under regional

Speaker: NA
Text: programs may not actually be there after all

Speaker: NA
Text: for these communities. I have no idea

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not this commitment to the West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Bulldogs Football Club, in my electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of those projects. It is extraordinary,

Speaker: NA
Text: really, that a commitment could be made

Speaker: NA
Text: without knowing that. But I am fearful that

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments to projects like mine in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Gellibrand are going to be bro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ken because the government has got the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: toral advantage it was after and has no inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of following through on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am here to tell the government that if

Speaker: NA
Text: they try to do that there will be a riot in

Speaker: NA
Text: western suburbs of Melbourne. It will be on

Speaker: NA
Text: the front page of every local paper. Every

Speaker: NA
Text: local paper, all of the metropolitan papers

Speaker: NA
Text: and all of the TV stations that followed it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be chasing Mr Howard and Mr Ander-

Speaker: NA
Text: son-the Prime Minister and the Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister-around, asking exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: what it was that they had committed to and if

Speaker: NA
Text: they were going to follow through now on

Speaker: NA
Text: the money or not. I am sure that the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment intend to honour their commitment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that they do. Like the Bulldogs, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: all be looking very closely at every line in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget when we get to it next year, to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the money is there for the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects that they committed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I have been talking about pockets

Speaker: NA
Text: of social disadvantage in Gellibrand, I also

Speaker: NA
Text: want to acknowledge that there are areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: new homeowners and people with very large

Speaker: NA
Text: mortgages. In 2001, there were nearly 12,000

Speaker: NA
Text: mortgage holders in Gellibrand and there are

Speaker: NA
Text: growing numbers of young families. Obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously, with this change and with lots of hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing developments under way we are seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: that people with large debts have very real

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns. We must make sure that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is held accountable on its promise to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep interest rates low. But we also need to

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate more generally the issues sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounding affordability of home ownership.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are also other pressures that grow

Speaker: NA
Text: when you have changing demographics, like

Speaker: NA
Text: the need for child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a number of other local issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that are going to come up in the next year

Speaker: NA
Text: that I will be following closely, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation of Tenix and the dockyards at

Speaker: NA
Text: Williamstown. They are still waiting for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to decide what it is going to do

Speaker: NA
Text: about the future of shipbuilding in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We still cannot get any guarantees that any

Speaker: NA
Text: tender process for shipbuilding will be fair

Speaker: NA
Text: and open. In my view, that would give Wil-

Speaker: NA
Text: the liamstown the best chance of proving that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the place to build Defence ships in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, being the only place where the Anzac

Speaker: NA
Text: frigates had been built over the past 10 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sale of the Maribyrnong Defence site is

Speaker: NA
Text: something about which there have been ne-

Speaker: NA
Text: gotiations between the Victorian government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth. We are still waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Commonwealth to sign off on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have growing pressures with our

Speaker: NA
Text: environment-for example, on the rivers,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the Maribyrnong River and

Speaker: NA
Text: Kororoit Creek and others, and also on our

Speaker: NA
Text: bay fronts in Williamstown and Altona. That

Speaker: NA
Text: will be something that I will be pursuing in

Speaker: NA
Text: this next term of opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the time that is remaining I want to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the issues in my portfolio, the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General's portfolio. We have a spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial role in this area to ensure the integrity of

Speaker: NA
Text: our legal and civic institutions. It is always

Speaker: NA
Text: important to do that, but the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: won control of the Senate and therefore both

Speaker: NA
Text: houses of parliament at this election and so

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the scrutiny that previously occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: in the parliament will actually have to occur

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the parliament. This will show that

Speaker: NA
Text: the strength of our other institutions is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important. Their robustness will be tested.

Speaker: NA
