Text: We have had a lot of important inquiries

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate in the past six to eight years,

Speaker: NA
Text: from inquiries into poverty and children in

Speaker: NA
Text: care to others like cash for visas and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘children overboard' issue. They were impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant opportunities for allegations to be tested,

Speaker: NA
Text: for important social issues to be aired, for

Speaker: NA
Text: people to give their expertise to the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and for us to make recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: on those issues. I think it is very important

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Senate does not lose that role but in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the accountability that the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: has been able to require from the executive

Speaker: NA
Text: government we may be looking to other arms

Speaker: NA
Text: of government to do that in a different way.

Speaker: NA
Text: I raise this because one of the things that

Speaker: NA
Text: we took to the last election was significant

Speaker: NA
Text: reform of the Freedom of Information Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those commitments are very important and

Speaker: NA
Text: we remain interested in implementing them,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I think we need to go much further than

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We need to look at how else the system

Speaker: NA
Text: should be reformed so that government deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions are transparent, so that the public are

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of all of the information at further

Speaker: NA
Text: elections, or when involved in public debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they know the information that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly available-because governments are

Speaker: NA
Text: actually elected to do work on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: public, not to operate as secret think tanks

Speaker: NA
Text: and not provide people with information and

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas that they may have gathered as a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a little bit fearful of a bill that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been introduced in the other place-because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the timing of the new parliament, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been introduced in the Senate first rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than in the House-which contains reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I

Speaker: NA
Text: raise this not to debate the detail of the bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be done at another time, but to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that there are moves, as part of that

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment, to downgrade the role of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administrative Appeals Tribunal and particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the role of the president. I think this

Speaker: NA
Text: of concern when you think about the types of

Speaker: NA
Text: matters that come before the Administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeals Tribunal.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is where people who have a dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: with the government most often take their

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints. If you have a dispute with the

Speaker: NA
Text: government over a social security issue, ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: peals from the Social Security Appeals Tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bunal go to the Administrative Appeals Tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bunal. It is the same for a dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: erans' Affairs matter, a workers compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion issue in Comcare, a child support dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: pute or a freedom of information request that

Speaker: NA
Text: is contested, and even for a number of issues

Speaker: NA
Text: in the immigration and citizenship area. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: if members of the general public who are

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in decisions made by governments

Speaker: NA
Text: have a problem, the place where they will

Speaker: NA
Text: most likely have to challenge the decision is

Speaker: NA
Text: the AAT.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is worrying that, at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: as we see the government gaining control of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate, we also see them seeking to have

Speaker: NA
Text: more control of institutions like the AAT by

Speaker: NA
Text: downgrading the role of the president-

Speaker: NA
Text: removing tenure from the president so that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are potentially politically vulnerable if

Speaker: NA
Text: the decisions they make are not favourable to

Speaker: NA
Text: the government. This is something that we

Speaker: NA
Text: will need to monitor very closely. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with the government might lead

Speaker: NA
Text: to some sensible developments in that area,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is why I do not want to go to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of the bill in detail, but I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to flag that it is something that we regard

Speaker: NA
Text: very seriously as an accountability matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also think that we should have a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion about a better process for judicial

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments and complaints against the

Speaker: NA
Text: judiciary. People will remember the extraor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dinary attacks on some of our judiciary by

Speaker: NA
Text: this government in its last term. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted the fact that we have no process

Speaker: NA
Text: for quickly dispensing with malicious or

Speaker: NA
Text: is vexatious complaints. At the same time, it

Speaker: NA
Text: must be acknowledged that we also have no

Speaker: NA
Text: process for dealing with serious complaints,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think that is something that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: explored. Again, these are things that I see as

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening the role of the judiciary, by

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure that each arm of government-

Speaker: NA
Text: government with a small ‘g'; the legislature,

Speaker: NA
Text: the executive and the judiciary-can operate

Speaker: NA
Text: to its full strength, free from the influence of

Speaker: NA
Text: over a Vet- the other arms of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have some questions on issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been much debated in the last cou-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple of weeks about the appropriateness of

Speaker: NA
Text: government spending and decision making

Speaker: NA
Text: that relates to government funding. As alle-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations by the member for New England

Speaker: NA
Text: have been explored, we have found that a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole range of other funding commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: are starting to unravel before us. The issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: propriety in procedural justice and the proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: esses that are used for allocating federal

Speaker: NA
Text: money are going to come under much closer

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutiny and indeed need to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to talk about a range of issues

Speaker: NA
Text: to do with access to justice. I have put this

Speaker: NA
Text: the record before, so I will just give a very

Speaker: NA
Text: short version because I would like to concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trate on a couple of issues. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: have a very poor record on legal aid. They

Speaker: NA
Text: slashed enormous amounts of money from

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget in 1996, and we are only getting

Speaker: NA
Text: back to 1996 levels now, eight years later,

Speaker: NA
Text: but of course with some reductions because

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation was not taken into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time we have seen a boom in

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on legal services for the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We need to much more closely con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider how we track the money that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment spends on legal services and

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we can divert some of that money

Speaker: NA
Text: from government expenditure, and use tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payer money to fund those ordinary mums

Speaker: NA
Text: and dads who need assistance in the courts-

Speaker: NA
Text: not to make sure that the department always

Speaker: NA
Text: has four opinions on the same issue and pays

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney rates for them. There is no excuse for

Speaker: NA
Text: that. It is extraordinary to us that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment does not know where a lot of its

Speaker: NA
Text: legal expenditure has gone. With modern

Speaker: NA
Text: technology, tracking systems and accounting

Speaker: NA
Text: processes, there is no excuse for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wanted to flag some family law issues,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I think time will defeat me so I am just

Speaker: NA
Text: going to raise an issue about Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander legal services. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government has started the first stage of ten-

Speaker: NA
Text: dering out these services in WA and Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although there have been some improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the extremely damaging tender

Speaker: NA
Text: document that was released earlier in the

Speaker: NA
Text: year, there is still nothing in the tender

Speaker: NA
Text: document that allows the services to be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: for work in Aboriginal communities for the

Speaker: NA
Text: prevention of crime and for community edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation about legal issues; it is focused only

Speaker: NA
Text: on legal work, case by case. This means that

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal people will lose a range of ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices that they currently have under the

Speaker: NA
Text: on ATSILS program. I think it sets us back a

Speaker: NA
Text: long way if we deal with the problems only

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are already in court rather than in

Speaker: NA
Text: a preventative way, which would be prefer-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff) (8.13 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: When I rose in this chamber for my first

Speaker: NA
Text: speech in the early evening of 13 February

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly three years ago, I asked one question:

Speaker: NA
Text: what is our purpose? I indicated that I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought this question would underscore my

Speaker: NA
Text: actions and provide a compass for my jour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney in this place. Having survived my first

Speaker: NA
Text: term as the second member for Moncrieff, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to take the time to review the

Speaker: NA
Text: progress that has been made both in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate and also nationally under the steward-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship of the Howard government.

Speaker: NA
Text: There can be no doubt that standing for

Speaker: NA
Text: office for a second term is far less daunting

Speaker: NA
Text: than standing for the first time. The cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign in Moncrieff in 2004 was an honest,

Speaker: NA
Text: clean campaign, and I thank my opponents

Speaker: NA
Text: for their contribution in this regard. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: I fiercely disagree with most of them on the

Speaker: NA
Text: path that they desire Australia to travel, I do

Speaker: NA
Text: applaud their commitment to being partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pants in our robust democracy. I pay particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar tribute and give thanks to the electors of

Speaker: NA
Text: Moncrieff. I have a great appreciation for the

Speaker: NA
Text: electors of Moncrieff, for they have certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: placed their faith and their confidence in me

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to being not only a strong advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate but also a passionate advocate for our

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the world. It is indeed a privilege and

Speaker: NA
Text: an honour to serve the people of Moncrieff,

Speaker: NA
Text: who live in Australia's fastest-growing city

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a consequence of boundary changes

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to the last federal election, I saw some

Speaker: NA
Text: significant changes in my electorate. I lost

Speaker: NA
Text: the suburbs of Parkwood, Arundel and Lab-

Speaker: NA
Text: rador, most of Southport and parts of Nerang

Speaker: NA
Text: to the member now to my immediate north,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hon. David Jull, the member for Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did, however, pick up nearly 20,000 addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional constituents in the suburbs of Mermaid

Speaker: NA
Text: Beach, Mermaid Waters, Miami, Nobbys and

Speaker: NA
Text: north Burleigh. I have been particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful to them, for they have embraced me

Speaker: NA
Text: and my advocacy on their behalf with regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to those parts of the central Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, the Gold Coast is a city that faces

Speaker: NA
Text: unique challenges. I have certainly been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to glean a good indication of what a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of these challenges are as a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: my regular listening posts and the various

Speaker: NA
Text: works I have done in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout my first term.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to take this chance to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: my campaign team who assisted me

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the most recent campaign. I must

Speaker: NA
Text: especially thank my incredibly loyal, dedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated and hardworking staff-Marianne

Speaker: NA
Text: MCCabe, Tricia Walsh and Mark Powell-

Speaker: NA
Text: who I am sure for quite some time thought

Speaker: NA
Text: an eight-hour day only took you as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: lunchtime. I also have to thank Alastair

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitchell, Jonathon Ellis, Sarah Allard, Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Cantazariti and the Moncrieff campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: committee for their undying work on tasks

Speaker: NA
Text: which they completed in full because they

Speaker: NA
Text: knew the importance of ensuring all tasks for

Speaker: NA
Text: the campaign were done to put us on the best

Speaker: NA
Text: possible footing to ensure victory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also must thank all of the volunteers.

Speaker: NA
Text: They contributed so much towards the cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign. Countless hours of work went into

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure the Liberal Party in Moncrieff

Speaker: NA
Text: was able to perform to the greatest possible

Speaker: NA
Text: extent. I thank my booth captains and all my

Speaker: NA
Text: prepoll volunteers who worked for the weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to polling day, especially my mother

Speaker: NA
Text: and father, who put in an exorbitant amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of effort in this regard. I also have to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the nearly 400 volunteers who turned out on

Speaker: NA
Text: polling day to assist not only my campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Liberal Party's campaign. They did

Speaker: NA
Text: so because they have a resolute belief in the

Speaker: NA
Text: good governance of the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the path we as a government are taking

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to thank my financial support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers. The reality is that modern day campaign-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is notoriously expensive. While some

Speaker: NA
Text: people would obviously desire that politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cians not have to incur any campaign dona-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions at all, the reality is that campaigning is

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive and does require financial assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance and support. I cannot thank enough

Speaker: NA
Text: those people who were willing to contribute.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether it was $5 or more, each one of them

Speaker: NA
Text: made a significant contribution towards en-

Speaker: NA
Text: suring the Liberal Party performed not only

Speaker: NA
Text: in Moncrieff but also in a number of key

Speaker: NA
Text: marginal seats within Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of all, I cannot ever truly show my

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciation and thanks to my wife, Astra,

Speaker: NA
Text: who truly does give meaning to my life and

Speaker: NA
Text: educates me every single day. Her support,

Speaker: NA
Text: her strength, her humour and her tenacity are

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly inspiring to me, and I am forever

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful for her support and her inspiration.

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw a 3.8 per cent swing towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition in the seat of Moncrieff, which

Speaker: NA
Text: raises the question: why was that the case?

Speaker: NA
Text: As I foreshadowed earlier, I believe it is fun-

Speaker: NA
Text: damentally because I and the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: have listened, responded and, most impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tantly, delivered for the Gold Coast. As I out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined, through my community listening posts

Speaker: NA
Text: and my regular work in the community I

Speaker: NA
Text: have on a number of occasions heard people

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward the key issues that are out-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing in the community. Among them-

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps first and foremost, as it was one

Speaker: NA
Text: I raised in my maiden speech-was the abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lute need Griffith University on the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast had for additional university places. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is fortuitous that the Minister for Education,

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Training, Dr Brendan Nelson, is

Speaker: NA
Text: in the chamber this evening. I thank him for

Speaker: NA
Text: his tireless efforts and, importantly, his

Speaker: NA
Text: lar visits to the Gold Coast to hear the very

Speaker: NA
Text: sound arguments that were put forward by

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith University for additional university

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Nelson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: I am pleased to hear that

Speaker: NA
Text: the education minister recognised how com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pelling they truly were, and I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that, in fact, the highest allocation of

Speaker: NA
Text: new university places across the nation was

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Griffith University Gold Coast cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: pus. There can be no doubt that in Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: fastest-growing city there is an absolute need

Speaker: NA
Text: for more university places, and whilst we

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly did make a very large dent in the

Speaker: NA
Text: shortfall that exists on a per capita basis

Speaker: NA
Text: there is still much work to be done. I reaffirm

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber tonight that I will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue the allocation of additional university

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I was initially elected, there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortfall of approximately 3,000 university

Speaker: NA
Text: places that Griffith University required just

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring the Gold Coast up to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: average. When compared to other cities such

Speaker: NA
Text: as Wollongong, that deficit rose to approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 5,000 university places. I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to be part of a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: has listened and responded to that cry and

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for new university places. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,500 additional places will certainly go a

Speaker: NA
Text: long way but, as I indicated, there is still

Speaker: NA
Text: some significant work to do in that area, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I intend to continue working on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also highlight that my electors raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with me that they sought a new medical

Speaker: NA
Text: school for the Gold Coast. The Gold Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: for far too long was seen as the inferior

Speaker: NA
Text: cousin to Brisbane. Brisbane had a medical

Speaker: NA
Text: school and the Gold Coast had been attempt-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to gain a medical school since the 1970s.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must particularly thank the former Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Health and Ageing, Senator the Hon. Kay

Speaker: NA
Text: reguPatterson, who together with Dr Brendan

Speaker: NA
Text: Nelson approved a new medical school for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gold Coast. Coincidentally, today the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Medical Council announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: both the Griffith University medical school

Speaker: NA
Text: and Bond University's medical school have

Speaker: NA
Text: received AMC approval. That is a great shot

Speaker: NA
Text: in the arm for our region, and I am particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly excited to see two quite different mod-

Speaker: NA
Text: els of a medical school going forward and

Speaker: NA
Text: coming onto the marketplace in the near fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very excited to watch Griffith Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity's medical school being constructed. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a mere 500 metres up the road from my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate office, and I was pleased to see

Speaker: NA
Text: within the last several weeks the Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: University medical school logo going up on

Speaker: NA
Text: the exterior of the building. It is a tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous shot in the arm for our city, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: means we have a long-term solution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing demand that exists within our city

Speaker: NA
Text: for access to doctors. Importantly, it also

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfies the very strong demand among

Speaker: NA
Text: young people on the Gold Coast to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: medical studies at a local campus.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the residents of Nerang and Highland

Speaker: NA
Text: Park, access to Medicare services was an

Speaker: NA
Text: important priority as well. I sought a new

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare office for them and, although I was

Speaker: NA
Text: unsuccessful, I was very pleased to announce

Speaker: NA
Text: in my last term the allocation of three new

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare Easyclaim booths. The sites for

Speaker: NA
Text: these have now been selected, and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the tens of thousands of resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents west of the M1 motorway will now

Speaker: NA
Text: have a great deal of access to Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: through these booths.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another key component which I spoke on

Speaker: NA
Text: at length in my maiden speech was the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the tourism industry is vitally important

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Gold Coast. The Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly has the runs on the board when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to the tourism industry. I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the former Minister for Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business and Tourism, the Hon. Joe Hockey,

Speaker: NA
Text: was able to steer the tourism white paper

Speaker: NA
Text: through both this chamber and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: place. That white paper will see over $600

Speaker: NA
Text: million going into the tourism industry over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next four years. The proof that the tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism industry is already reaping significant

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits from this white paper can clearly be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen in the number of inbound tourists to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I was pleased to see numbers re-

Speaker: NA
Text: leased by Tourism Australia which indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that there had been more inbound interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional tourists coming to Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months than for the year 2000 with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Olympics. This indicates a very

Speaker: NA
Text: strong resurgence and interest in visiting

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia among international tourists, which

Speaker: NA
Text: generates significant export income.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was also pleased in my last term to see

Speaker: NA
Text: the Cooperative Research Centre for Sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable Tourism-which is headquartered at

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith University on the Gold Coast-

Speaker: NA
Text: receive nearly $30 million of funding from

Speaker: NA
Text: this government. It received this money be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it has been producing a number of very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant and commercially attractive ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plications that the tourism industry has been

Speaker: NA
Text: embracing. We have seen significant runs on

Speaker: NA
Text: the board from this CRC which place it

Speaker: NA
Text: among the best CRCs currently operating in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. In the last 12 months I was also

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the new international centre of

Speaker: NA
Text: excellence for tourism was placed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast. These institutions not only en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure growing recognition of the important

Speaker: NA
Text: role that the Gold Coast plays as the engine

Speaker: NA
Text: room for tourism in Australia but also create

Speaker: NA
Text: a link for those in the tourism industry to

Speaker: NA
Text: additional applications, support and research,

Speaker: NA
Text: all of which help them to run their businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: better. At a time when our country is looking

Speaker: NA
Text: for additional opportunities to increase pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity, it is important to recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity can also occur through effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency gains realised in service industries

Speaker: NA
Text: like the tourism industry. I am very pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: that both the ICE and the CRC for Sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: able Tourism play very important roles in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the campaign it was encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the Prime Minister visit. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and I, whilst walking along the

Speaker: NA
Text: beach towards Surfers Paradise one day, had

Speaker: NA
Text: the chance to talk about a number of key

Speaker: NA
Text: issues and challenges facing the city of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast. Among them was the growing

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of those who have been vocation-

Speaker: NA
Text: past ally educated, and the announcement during

Speaker: NA
Text: the campaign of the new technical training

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges was a great shot in the arm. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased that the 24 sites selected in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded the Gold Coast. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast benefits from having a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: team of four Liberal members, and I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that the allocation of one of these new

Speaker: NA
Text: sites is a direct consequence of the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast having these four strong advocates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week I had the opportunity to partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pate in the first roundtable in our region to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss options for the new technical training

Speaker: NA
Text: college that will be placed on the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast, and I was very excited by the discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of and the enthusiasm for this new facil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity. It means that across the board young

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the Gold Coast will have the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to participate not only in tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: education but in vocational education, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is equally as important. They will have ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to education in the correct skills for, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the construction industry, the tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism industry and the marine industry-

Speaker: NA
Text: another nascent industry which presents

Speaker: NA
Text: great potential for the future. I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: see young people embrace the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake studies in the marine industry-

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it be in marine upholstery or fibre-

Speaker: NA
Text: glass-at the new technical training colleges

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be placed on the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was also pleased that an extension of the

Speaker: NA
Text: film tax offset to the television industry was

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward as part of the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's policy. The film and TV industry on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gold Coast is rapidly growing. Several

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred people are now directly employed

Speaker: NA
Text: not only in what are called ‘runaway produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions' from the United States but also in film

Speaker: NA
Text: and television productions indigenous to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, with scripts that are written, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced, directed and post-produced in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. The new film tax offset and its extension

Speaker: NA
Text: to the television industry will augment the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of incentives that already exist in

Speaker: NA
Text: this industry. I am very confident that this

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has its best days ahead of it and

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be opportunities for new graduates

Speaker: NA
Text: of vocational and tertiary education to under-

Speaker: NA
Text: take roles within this growing industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: My electorate has the highest number of

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses per capita in this nation. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen a rededication by the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and certainly by me to ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions within this country benefit small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses, which truly are the engine room

Speaker: NA
Text: of our nation. If we did not have entrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: neurs willing to take risks in seeking reward

Speaker: NA
Text: then we as a nation would not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet many of the challenges that face us. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard a number of those challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: enunciated today, not least of which is our

Speaker: NA
Text: ageing population. I believe fundamentally

Speaker: NA
Text: that the reforms that we are making in the

Speaker: NA
Text: small business sector-I note in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: the unfair dismissal laws which, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: new composition of the Senate, will finally

Speaker: NA
Text: have a chance to be passed-will remove

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the shackles that the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: left on the small business sector, enabling it

Speaker: NA
Text: to to be more productive and profitable and to

Speaker: NA
Text: employ more people into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have listed each of these points because I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that they not only relate to the needs

Speaker: NA
Text: and aspirations of middle Australia but also

Speaker: NA
Text: highlight and demonstrate the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government has delivered very

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly for the people of the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: With a population of nearly 500,000, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast does continue to face a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of significant challenges. The various points

Speaker: NA
Text: I have raised are some of the challenges but

Speaker: NA
Text: are also, importantly, some of the solutions

Speaker: NA
Text: that this government has highlighted. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, these are not final solutions. There still

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be more work done, and I will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to undertake that work. Principal

Speaker: NA
Text: among that work is to address the growing

Speaker: NA
Text: need for additional funding into traffic and

Speaker: NA
Text: transport infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot go further on this point without

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising the $12 billion investment that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government is making under the

Speaker: NA
Text: AusLink proposal and also expressing my

Speaker: NA
Text: extreme concern and disappointment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state Labor government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state Labor government this year

Speaker: NA
Text: ran a budget surplus of $2.3 billion. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget surplus and despite nearly $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in road funding that was put toward

Speaker: NA
Text: the M1 project, or the Pacific Motorway, that

Speaker: NA
Text: runs over the Tweed border, I was disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed to see the state Premier, Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Beattie, announce recently that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: not proceed with additional widening of the

Speaker: NA
Text: M1 between Nerang and the Tweed border

Speaker: NA
Text: unless the federal government was willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: put even more money into the project. I

Speaker: NA
Text: really question the bona fides of the Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland state government when they run a $2.3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion budget surplus and, most importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: have a $500 million windfall gain as a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequence of the introduction of the goods

Speaker: NA
Text: and services tax by this government and yet

Speaker: NA
Text: still cry poor when it comes to important

Speaker: NA
Text: transport infrastructure such as the M1 pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject. I implore the state Labor members on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gold Coast to please speak with the Pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mier and ensure that this very necessary and

Speaker: NA
Text: important road project is completed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I again thank my campaign team for their

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts in the last election. I also thank those

Speaker: NA
Text: opponents who stood because of their belief

Speaker: NA
Text: in having a robust democracy. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful to the constituents of Moncrieff;

Speaker: NA
Text: with their good grace I would like to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue serving them throughout the entirety of

Speaker: NA
Text: this next term.

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Text: Capricornia) (8.33

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I would like to take this opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to thank the people of Capricornia for seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: fit to re-elect me as their federal member. I

Speaker: NA
Text: sincerely appreciate the confidence that my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents have shown in me by allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: me to continue to serve them. I would also

Speaker: NA
Text: like to take this opportunity to guarantee that

Speaker: NA
Text: the confidence the voters of Capricornia

Speaker: NA
Text: have placed in me will not be taken for

Speaker: NA
Text: granted. I will continue to work hard for

Speaker: NA
Text: them and to bring their issues into this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight's speech feels a little bit like a de

Speaker: NA
Text: facto first speech because, as of 9 October,

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Capricornia changed dra-

Speaker: NA
Text: matically from that to which I was first

Speaker: NA
Text: elected in 1998. When I was first elected,

Speaker: NA
Text: Capricornia extended from the beautiful

Speaker: NA
Text: Capricorn coast to the outback town of Win-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton, the home of Waltzing Matilda, and be-

Speaker: NA
Text: yond. The redistribution has almost halved

Speaker: NA
Text: the geographic size of my electorate and has

Speaker: NA
Text: removed much of the outback which I was so

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to serve. Today's Capricornia now

Speaker: NA
Text: extends west only to the town of Clermont

Speaker: NA
Text: and takes in areas to the south-west, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Mount Morgan, Duaringa, Woorabinda

Speaker: NA
Text: and Banana shires. The redistribution of my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate leaves me with mixed feelings:

Speaker: NA
Text: sadness at the loss of so many beautiful

Speaker: NA
Text: places and wonderful people in towns like

Speaker: NA
Text: Winton, Longreach, Aramac, Barcaldine,

Speaker: NA
Text: Jericho and Alpha, and renewed motivation

Speaker: NA
Text: as I get to discover and make connections

Speaker: NA
Text: with the newly acquired areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the past six years it has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure to make my regular trips to Lon-

Speaker: NA
Text: greach and the other communities of the cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral west that are no longer part of my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate and talk to the residents, face to face,

Speaker: NA
Text: about their issues and their lives. Throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: this time, these people have been struggling

Speaker: NA
Text: through the worst drought they have ever

Speaker: NA
Text: seen, yet they remain determined and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted to life in the bush. I am going to miss

Speaker: NA
Text: these areas on a personal level as well, as

Speaker: NA
Text: they hold a special place in my heart. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: in Barcaldine where I was married to my

Speaker: NA
Text: partner, Craig, and it often feels like a second

Speaker: NA
Text: home to us. These areas also hold great his-

Speaker: NA
Text: torical and cultural value for Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they be the birthplace of Qantas or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party or the site of the

Speaker: NA
Text: penning of Waltzing Matilda. It can easily be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen how much I love these places and why I

Speaker: NA
Text: am saddened to be losing them. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am saddened by the loss of my Longreach

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate office and my staff member in that

Speaker: NA
Text: office, Kelly Wood. In order to better repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent the people of the far central west, I

Speaker: NA
Text: opened the first federal member's office in

Speaker: NA
Text: Longreach. I know this was greatly appreci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by everyone in the central west, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: trust that The Nationals' new member for the

Speaker: NA
Text: area will maintain the office I opened and

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to provide that level of service to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people around Longreach and the central

Speaker: NA
Text: west.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, there is another, more positive,

Speaker: NA
Text: side to the redistribution. I am happy to have

Speaker: NA
Text: picked up some new areas that are all inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: esting, dynamic places filled with people

Speaker: NA
Text: with initiative and a commitment to building

Speaker: NA
Text: on the strengths of our region. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: take this opportunity to welcome the new

Speaker: NA
Text: areas to Capricornia: the shires of Duaringa,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Morgan, Woorabinda and Banana.

Speaker: NA
Text: These diverse and wonderful areas will add

Speaker: NA
Text: to the distinct charm of Capricornia and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: hance the already strong presence of mining

Speaker: NA
Text: and primary industries in the electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: of the new areas to come into Capricornia is

Speaker: NA
Text: a region of economic and environmental sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificance, and I am pleased to have them as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the electorate that I represent. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are a good fit with the other areas of central

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland that I have represented for the

Speaker: NA
Text: past six years. Together they form a region

Speaker: NA
Text: growing significance to our nation across a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of activities-industrial, educational

Speaker: NA
Text: and cultural.

Speaker: NA
Text: Duaringa Shire, taken from the electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Maranoa, includes the towns of Duaringa,

Speaker: NA
Text: Blackwater, Dingo, Bluff and Bauhinia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Blackwater is known as the coal capital of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and makes a substantial contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to Australia's mineral export earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Duaringa shire is a strong mining, beef and

Speaker: NA
Text: cropping area which has an abundance of

Speaker: NA
Text: natural beauty and incredible places includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Blackdown Tableland National Park,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is home to hundreds of species of na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive plants and wildlife as well as examples

Speaker: NA
Text: of Indigenous art.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Morgan is a grand old town, with a

Speaker: NA
Text: history going back over 140 years. In its

Speaker: NA
Text: heyday it was the richest goldmine in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. Today, the town is a tourist destination

Speaker: NA
Text: for people from all over Australia who want

Speaker: NA
Text: to catch a glimpse of the past and enjoy the

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly small-town hospitality for which

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Morgan is renowned. Banana Shire

Speaker: NA
Text: also moves to Capricornia from the elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate of Wide Bay, incorporating the towns of

Speaker: NA
Text: Biloela, Theodore, Baralaba, Moura and

Speaker: NA
Text: more. Banana Shire contains some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: largest commodity production areas in Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral Queensland, contributing some $123

Speaker: NA
Text: million annually to Queensland's economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Woorabinda is an Indigenous community

Speaker: NA
Text: of around 1,600 people located about 170

Speaker: NA
Text: kilometres south-west of Rockhampton. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Woorabinda have strong family

Speaker: NA
Text: and community ties to Rockhampton. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: helped many of its residents on an individual

Speaker: NA
Text: Each basis in the past; I now look forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: working with the community as a whole to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve its collective goals. Capricornia has

Speaker: NA
Text: an interesting past and a bright future, which

Speaker: NA
Text: makes it a great place to live, work and

Speaker: NA
Text: watch your family grow. When I talk to local

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders, businesspeople and those involved

Speaker: NA
Text: of in the organisations that are the lifeblood of

Speaker: NA
Text: our Central Queensland communities, I hear

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is no shortage of challenges that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to overcome but also that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of opportunities to work towards.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we really need in Central Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland, and what I have been calling for ever

Speaker: NA
Text: since I got to this place, is a genuine partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship between our region and the federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. We need a federal government that

Speaker: NA
Text: is truly committed to understanding and

Speaker: NA
Text: working with our region to achieve our full

Speaker: NA
Text: potential. Among other things, that means

Speaker: NA
Text: providing important infrastructure, like the

Speaker: NA
Text: roads to Shoalwater Bay. It means assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Queensland University to build on its

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to provide top-class educational

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities to our local students. It also

Speaker: NA
Text: means improving access to essential ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, such as health services. Instead, this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has continually implemented

Speaker: NA
Text: policies that work against Central Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sland and, indeed, against rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia more generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: One example of this is the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy on the pricing for rescue and fire-

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting services at airports. Under the new

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing structure released by Airservices

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia earlier this year, airlines wanting to

Speaker: NA
Text: run services to Rockhampton Airport, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is already the second most expensive airport

Speaker: NA
Text: to land at in Australia, will cop a doubling of

Speaker: NA
Text: landing fees over the next five years. The fee

Speaker: NA
Text: to land an aircraft at Rockhampton Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: will increase to almost $20 per landed tonne,

Speaker: NA
Text: while the same aircraft landing in Sydney or

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne will cost less than $2 per landed

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne. Apparently, the Minister for Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: and Regional Services and Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals thinks it is good policy for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Central Queensland, every time

Speaker: NA
Text: they catch a flight from Rockhampton Air-

Speaker: NA
Text: port, to subsidise travellers from Sydney and

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government might think that the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion result is a resounding endorsement of

Speaker: NA
Text: their policies, but I can assure them that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are many areas in which the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment continues to fail to respond to the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs and aspirations of the people of rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional areas like Central Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, the people of Capricornia cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly did not vote for the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment agenda on Telstra. Interestingly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition candidates in Capricornia did not

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to like the Howard government's

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda on Telstra either. They certainly did

Speaker: NA
Text: not spend any time talking about it in the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. Instead, they spent the campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: pretending that it was not in fact government

Speaker: NA
Text: policy to sell the remaining publicly-owned

Speaker: NA
Text: share of Telstra. And for good reason-quite

Speaker: NA
Text: simply, the people of Central Queensland do

Speaker: NA
Text: not want Telstra privatised and they have

Speaker: NA
Text: voted that way in the last three elections.

Speaker: NA
Text: They understand, even if this government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not, that a privatised Telstra will mean a

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in services and jobs in our part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was advised that on Friday, 12 Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber the small community of Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Chalmers, some 40 kilometres from Rock-

Speaker: NA
Text: hampton, lost its telephone service. When

Speaker: NA
Text: advised of this problem, Telstra's response

Speaker: NA
Text: was that they were aware of the problem, as

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 100 telephone services in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: were out of commission. However, as no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area had a ‘diagnosed life threatening

Speaker: NA
Text: illness' everything was okay because ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices were expected to be resumed by 6.00

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m. on Wednesday the 17th. So Telstra be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieves the residents of this small community

Speaker: NA
Text: can do without telephone services for five

Speaker: NA
Text: days. You have to ask yourself what the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse would be if people living on the

Speaker: NA
Text: North Shore of Sydney were told the same

Speaker: NA
Text: thing by Telstra. You might well say that if

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a real emergency the residents can

Speaker: NA
Text: use their mobile phones. But there is no mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: bile phone service at Mount Chalmers. Ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: parently, this is what the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment considers ‘up to scratch' when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to regional phone services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have thought that The Nationals

Speaker: NA
Text: members in the Howard government would

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that this is taipan country, that

Speaker: NA
Text: farm accidents do occur, that children do fall

Speaker: NA
Text: out of trees and into dams, that illness can

Speaker: NA
Text: strike at any moment and that the most im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant item in a rural home at the time of an

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency is a working telephone. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: taught at school how Flynn and the pedal

Speaker: NA
Text: radio made it much safer for people to live in

Speaker: NA
Text: rural Australia because his pedal radio pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided instant communication in the event of

Speaker: NA
Text: an emergency. Well, here we are in 2004

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Howard government hell-bent on

Speaker: NA
Text: the full privatisation of Telstra without ensur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that services in regional and rural Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia are at an acceptable level. You would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to say that the people of Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Chalmers would have been safer 75 years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago with a pedal radio than with the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: existent Telstra service of last week. I appeal

Speaker: NA
Text: to our Nationals colleagues in this place to

Speaker: NA
Text: do what your constituents in rural Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: are asking of you. Stop the sale of Telstra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stop withdrawing services from rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas and start standing up for the

Speaker: NA
Text: regions you purport to represent in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: To even suggest that Telstra services in

Speaker: NA
Text: regional and rural Australia are up to city

Speaker: NA
Text: standards is an arrogant disregard for the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth. The Nationals must listen, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: done, to the people in my electorate and they

Speaker: NA
Text: must stop the further sale of Telstra. As I was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the Flying Doctor, it is appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate that I mention the chronic shortage of

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors in rural and regional Australia. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that those members of The Nationals

Speaker: NA
Text: who are listening to their electorate will

Speaker: NA
Text: know that what I am saying is not just rheto-

Speaker: NA
Text: ric. They know that every small town and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional centre is crying out for more medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal staff. I have a constant stream of people

Speaker: NA
Text: coming into my office who feel that their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives are at risk because they are on waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: lists due to the shortage of medical profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionals in our regional and rural centres.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just last Sunday night, a constituent of

Speaker: NA
Text: mine fell and badly hurt her leg. As is the

Speaker: NA
Text: way with so many country people, she did

Speaker: NA
Text: not ring for an ambulance because she did

Speaker: NA
Text: not want to occupy them when they might be

Speaker: NA
Text: needed for something more serious. So she

Speaker: NA
Text: made her own way to the local base hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: She arrived at 11.00 p.m. and left at 3.00

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m. the following day. Her four-hour ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience at the accident and emergency ward

Speaker: NA
Text: has had a profound effect on her. With only

Speaker: NA
Text: one doctor on duty, this woman tells me that

Speaker: NA
Text: two people died, a baby was born in the car

Speaker: NA
Text: park-which I can attest to because it was on

Speaker: NA
Text: the front page of the local paper-and a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of other patients were treated for a

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of other injuries. This is clearly not

Speaker: NA
Text: an unusual night in a regional or rural hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal.

Speaker: NA
Text: For too long the Howard government has

Speaker: NA
Text: simply ignored the medical needs of our ru-

Speaker: NA
Text: ral people. I guess they hope that foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors will plug the gaps and the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: regional and rural Australia will just accept

Speaker: NA
Text: second-class health system or one that sees

Speaker: NA
Text: them flying off to Brisbane for everything

Speaker: NA
Text: they need. Those gaps are now gaping holes

Speaker: NA
Text: and, whereas there was a time once when

Speaker: NA
Text: only young people left the country to find

Speaker: NA
Text: work in our cities, we are now seeing older

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians leaving regional and rural centres

Speaker: NA
Text: to live in our capital cities because they un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand that the health services provided in

Speaker: NA
Text: our cities are far superior to what is available

Speaker: NA
Text: to them in the bush. In many cases these

Speaker: NA
Text: people leave behind homes and families and

Speaker: NA
Text: communities where they have spent most of

Speaker: NA
Text: their lives and move to capital cities where

Speaker: NA
Text: they have no social contact and become an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing burden on the already over-

Speaker: NA
Text: stretched public system. I fear this trend will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue and even increase as the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government continues to ignore the health

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of our ageing citizens living in

Speaker: NA
Text: our regional areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: It surprises me that we do not hear more

Speaker: NA
Text: from The Nationals opposite about this. They

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to represent that 36 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: population which lives in rural Australia, so

Speaker: NA
Text: they must know the statistics-that the 36

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of Australians who live in rural Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia die younger and at a higher rate in

Speaker: NA
Text: every age bracket than Australians in our

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. This situation is not helped by the

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of medical services in rural Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. The truth is that this government has al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed rural medical services to run down to

Speaker: NA
Text: such an extent that they have now reached a

Speaker: NA
Text: critical level. I understand that the issues are

Speaker: NA
Text: complex, but surely the government is capa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble of taking one step at a time.

Speaker: NA
Text: My challenge to the government is to take

Speaker: NA
Text: just that first step by way of ensuring that the

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors who work and live in rural Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: are appropriately recognised. At the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: rural and remote practice is not recognised,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am saying that it should be badged as a

Speaker: NA
Text: specialist area. I believe this one simple step

Speaker: NA
Text: a would get more doctors into rural practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the moment it is difficult, and, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: some think risky, for young doctors to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills they need to feel confident about work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the bush. Existing programs are frag-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented and obviously not working. Rural

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors need to feel valued, not only by their

Speaker: NA
Text: community but also by their colleagues in

Speaker: NA
Text: the medical profession and by the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: community. I think it is time that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment seriously considers having those

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors working in the bush recognised as

Speaker: NA
Text: rural and remote practice specialists.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the topic of health services, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to mention a commitment that was made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Labor Party to the people of Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland during the election campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: and urge the government to follow suit now

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are the ones responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: health of my constituents. I am referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's pledge to fund a Medicare eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: MRI machine at the Rockhampton Base

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital. This announcement was widely

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomed and the service is still much

Speaker: NA
Text: needed by the Central Queensland commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. The government is in receipt of two

Speaker: NA
Text: applications from my region-one from

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Health seeking to install a Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care eligible machine at the Rockhampton

Speaker: NA
Text: Base Hospital and one from a private opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor, Central Queensland Medical Imaging.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's policy is that MRI services should

Speaker: NA
Text: be available through our public hospitals,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that, of course, remains my preference.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the bottom line is that we need this

Speaker: NA
Text: service in Central Queensland, so the private

Speaker: NA
Text: applicant has my support for the submission

Speaker: NA
Text: it made to the government if that is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: way we are going to see an improvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: people's access to this important health ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice in my region. The submissions have

Speaker: NA
Text: been with the government for some months

Speaker: NA
Text: now, so the government should get on and

Speaker: NA
Text: make its decision about the placement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 additional MRI services that the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: announced back in June. Rockhampton has

Speaker: NA
Text: been identified by both the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Queensland governments as a high

Speaker: NA
Text: priority regional centre, so the need for the

Speaker: NA
Text: service has already been clearly established.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am calling on the government to just get on

Speaker: NA
Text: with it and make its decision, and I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that they should announce Rockhampton as

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the recipients of those Medicare eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble MRI machines.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, we have heard quite a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: comment in the last couple of weeks stem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ming from the allegations that were made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for New England about just who

Speaker: NA
Text: this government seem to think they are work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for in this country. I would like to let the

Speaker: NA
Text: government know that I am here working for

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Capricornia and I expect as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor member that the government will take

Speaker: NA
Text: the needs of my constituents just as seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: as those of members sitting on the other side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the chamber.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (8.49

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-May I congratulate you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker Jenkins, on your re-election to your

Speaker: NA
Text: position and also, through you, the Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: on his election. I have served with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker on the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Economics since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996 and he does have a reputation for being

Speaker: NA
Text: fair and decent and for trying to achieve con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sensus where possible. I would also like to

Speaker: NA
Text: take the opportunity to pay tribute to several

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the 40th parliament who were

Speaker: NA
Text: not re-elected at the 2004 election: Ross

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron, Larry Anthony and Trish Worth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ross was the member for Parramatta. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Parliamentary Secretary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer at the time of the last election. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think I met Ross in 1996 when we first came

Speaker: NA
Text: in. He was a terrific orator. He made a big

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution in parliament, not least through

Speaker: NA
Text: his convening of the National Student Lead-

Speaker: NA
Text: ership Forum on Faith and Values, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was a bipartisan affair at which both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition used to speak, as well as a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of parliament, the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Larry Anthony was also a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: class of 1996. He did a great job in his ministhe

Speaker: NA
Text: terial portfolio. I thank him for finding some

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for a literary festival which we held

Speaker: NA
Text: in Boothby in November. He was a very tal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ented minister and did a great job of repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the electorate of Richmond in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. One of my neighbours, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Adelaide, Trish Worth, held what is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very difficult seat for the Liberal Party in

Speaker: NA
Text: four elections. At three out of four of those

Speaker: NA
Text: elections she had to wait 10 days until find-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing out whether she had been elected, but

Speaker: NA
Text: Trish also did a great job as Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Health and Age-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and Parliamentary Secretary to the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Education, Training and Youth Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Both Ross and Larry have politics in the

Speaker: NA
Text: blood, as you do, Mr Deputy Speaker Jen-

Speaker: NA
Text: kins, and I sincerely hope that their talents

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be lost to politics. Similarly, with

Speaker: NA
Text: Trish, I hope that she will be able to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something in the areas which she is so pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionate about: breast cancer, mental health

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am particularly proud to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: re-elected, for the fourth time now, to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent the electorate of Boothby. Members who

Speaker: NA
Text: have previously held the seat of Boothby

Speaker: NA
Text: include Sir John MCLeay, who was the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: est serving Speaker of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives; John MCLeay, who was a minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Fraser government; and former Pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mier Steele Hall. Interestingly, I found a

Speaker: NA
Text: book in a bookstore about another one of my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors, Archibald Grenfell Price, who

Speaker: NA
Text: held the seat from 1941 to 1943. The last

Speaker: NA
Text: time we lost the seat of Boothby to the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party was in 1943; it was a disastrous elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for us. Archibald Grenfell Price had a

Speaker: NA
Text: big involvement with St Mark's College at

Speaker: NA
Text: the University of Adelaide and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Boothby was redistributed dramatically in

Speaker: NA
Text: early 1990s so that the seat is quite dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent from what it was historically. Much of

Speaker: NA
Text: the western part of Boothby was the seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawker, which was held for a long time by

Speaker: NA
Text: Ralph Jacobi. Along the coast much of it was

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston, which was held variously by

Speaker: NA
Text: Gordon Bilney, Grant Chapman before him,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Richie Gun for the Labor Party during

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1970s. Having campaigned with Grant

Speaker: NA
Text: Chapman, it is encouraging to see that some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people still recognised him and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: membered him from his time as the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Kingston. It has been a real honour to be

Speaker: NA
Text: re-elected. Boothby is the seat where I went

Speaker: NA
Text: to school and where I worked prior to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming a member of parliament. It is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: area, the southern suburbs of Adelaide, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a real pleasure to represent it.

Speaker: NA
Text: In reflecting on the election result, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the key things was the collapse in the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: mocrat vote. The Democrats made a serious

Speaker: NA
Text: charge in Boothby in 2001. Their vote in

Speaker: NA
Text: Boothby was always about 13 per cent, but

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2001 they actually received almost 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. In 2004 that fell to two per cent and

Speaker: NA
Text: most of that went to the Labor Party. In re-

Speaker: NA
Text: flecting on the result, a group of people who

Speaker: NA
Text: previously voted for the Democrats have

Speaker: NA
Text: now, by and large, gone across to the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. As the member for Boothby, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that. They are voters who were con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with things other than the manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the economy, and I am aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues they are interested in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looking at the result nationally, I am par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly proud to be part of the team, led by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister John Howard, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to win such strong support not

Speaker: NA
Text: only in the outer suburban areas of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: but also in rural and regional areas. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect on this, this pattern was actually evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent at the time of the 1999 republican refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: endum; you could almost see a correlation

Speaker: NA
Text: between the yes vote and the distance from

Speaker: NA
Text: the GPO. Now we have seen this reflected in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2004 election whereby a seat like Ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: laide, an inner city seat, fell to Labor. But, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, Labor has lost seats like Kingston

Speaker: NA
Text: and Wakefield in my own state, Bonner in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, Hasluck and Stirling in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also particularly proud that the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party is now the choice of skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: tradespeople, apprentices and blue-collar

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. Looking at the 2004 election, we

Speaker: NA
Text: can reflect on the difference between the

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of people that the Liberal Party elects to

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and those that the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: elects to parliament. The Liberal Party crop

Speaker: NA
Text: of 2004 includes an ophthalmologist, a test

Speaker: NA
Text: pilot for the Air Force, a policeman who

Speaker: NA
Text: worked in counter-terrorism and a policeman

Speaker: NA
Text: who worked in the Star Force in my own

Speaker: NA
Text: state. These people represent the range of

Speaker: NA
Text: occupations right across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looking at the Labor Party's personnel,

Speaker: NA
Text: we can see that they are by and large people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have worked as either political staffers

Speaker: NA
Text: or trade union officials. Some people think

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a new phenomenon; I do not believe it

Speaker: NA
Text: is. If you look back to the 1949 election, you

Speaker: NA
Text: will see that pretty much the same sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: people were being elected to represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. In the 1949 election, the great

Speaker: NA
Text: crop for the Liberal Party were by and large

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen, many of whom were officers,

Speaker: NA
Text: who really did a much better job of repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the community. Where the change

Speaker: NA
Text: has occurred has been observed by Barry

Speaker: NA
Text: Cohen. In 1949, going back to when the Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Party was first formed, the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: still elected blue-collar workers to the na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional parliament. Right now very few people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Labor parliamentary caucus have ever

Speaker: NA
Text: been blue-collar workers; they are mostly

Speaker: NA
Text: apparatchiks, careerists and so on. Until the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party addresses this problem with

Speaker: NA
Text: their parliamentary personnel, it will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to struggle to find relevance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: wider community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The central question of the 2004 election

Speaker: NA
Text: was: who do you trust to manage Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: $800 billion economy? I think now at quiz

Speaker: NA
Text: nights or wherever people always know what

Speaker: NA
Text: the exact size of our GDP is. But the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant thing is that almost everyone agrees that

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy is running well: inflation is low,

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment is low and GDP growth is

Speaker: NA
Text: strong. But this has not occurred by accident;

Speaker: NA
Text: it only comes with discipline and by focusing

Speaker: NA
Text: relentlessly on every single question. The

Speaker: NA
Text: question of forestry versus timber workers

Speaker: NA
Text: really highlighted to me the fact that the La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor Party is not equipped to manage the

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and diverse national economy we

Speaker: NA
Text: have in Australia. Unemployment is at 5.3

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; it is the lowest it has been since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1977. There is, of course, more to do. We

Speaker: NA
Text: had two recessions-one in the early eighties

Speaker: NA
Text: and another in the early nineties-and a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of blue-collar workers lost their jobs. We

Speaker: NA
Text: now have the Minister for Workforce Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipation, who will be trying to get more

Speaker: NA
Text: people from these backgrounds back into

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 9.00

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m., I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aviation: Second Sydney Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight I again raise the issue of aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: noise and Sydney airport. Mr Speaker, you

Speaker: NA
Text: will doubtlessly recall that in the last two

Speaker: NA
Text: parliaments I raised this issue on countless

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions in speeches and questions on be-

Speaker: NA
Text: half of the constituents I represent in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Lowe. As I found out during the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent election campaign, the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate still believe it is acceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: to break promises, betray the people of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inner west and pretend this issue has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: away. Not a chance. I will continue to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: for my constituents who are unfairly affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by aircraft noise from Sydney airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have noted on many occasions, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial direction that brought the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: airport long-term operating plan into being

Speaker: NA
Text: back in 1997 stipulates an aircraft movement

Speaker: NA
Text: target to the north of Sydney airport of 17

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. It is an appalling indictment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government that since the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the LTOP not once in seven years has

Speaker: NA
Text: Airservices Australia achieved the target of

Speaker: NA
Text: 17 per cent of all aircraft movements prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised to the people living to the north of the

Speaker: NA
Text: airport. On the contrary, residents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ner west living to the north of Sydney airport

Speaker: NA
Text: have suffered percentages of aircraft traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: movement far in excess of the 17 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: target. Indeed, the minister's briefing notes

Speaker: NA
Text: on Sydney airport, which provide official

Speaker: NA
Text: data on air traffic movements for Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: airport, show that aircraft movements to the

Speaker: NA
Text: north of Sydney airport have averaged

Speaker: NA
Text: around 27 per cent of all air traffic move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in a single review period. This means

Speaker: NA
Text: there are nearly 60 per cent more movements

Speaker: NA
Text: to the north of Sydney airport than the resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents legitimately expect from the published

Speaker: NA
Text: LTOP targets. In fact, in certain review peri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ods air traffic movements to the north have

Speaker: NA
Text: risen as high as 33 per cent-or nearly 100

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent higher than the target. This situation

Speaker: NA
Text: is intolerable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cynically, the Minister for Transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Services has repeatedly responded

Speaker: NA
Text: to my questions by saying that the LTOP has

Speaker: NA
Text: been ‘substantially implemented'. That is an

Speaker: NA
Text: insult to my constituents. Aircraft noise for

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate in Sydney's inner west remains

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the major environmental issues con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fronting Sydney. It is a chronic environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental problem aggravated by the greedy

Speaker: NA
Text: sale of Sydney airport by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: before the aircraft noise problems had been

Speaker: NA
Text: solved. Following the sale of Sydney airport

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Southern Cross consortium for an ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: surd $5.6 billion on 28 June 2002, my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate can expect an ever increasing, massive

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of aircraft noise and, with it, air traf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fic. More disturbingly, the higher volumes of

Speaker: NA
Text: traffic mean more pressure to revert to paral-

Speaker: NA
Text: lel runway operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: All this is noted in an environment where

Speaker: NA
Text: the government systematically misled the

Speaker: NA
Text: public with the false expectation that the

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory provisions of the Airports Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996-in particular, sections 18 through 22

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusive, as they then were-would ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that Sydney West airport would be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: in- structed and made operational as part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic solution to Sydney airport's aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: noise problem. Instead, the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: abandoned Badgerys Creek and gave the

Speaker: NA
Text: winning bid to Southern Cross consortium

Speaker: NA
Text: and Macquarie Bank-not to mention the

Speaker: NA
Text: PM's former chief of staff, Mr Max Moore-

Speaker: NA
Text: Wilton, who I note is now both the chief ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ecutive officer and the general manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd. In this foul

Speaker: NA
Text: sequence of events, the worst case nightmare

Speaker: NA
Text: has unfolded for the people I represent. Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney airport was sold alone, devoid of any

Speaker: NA
Text: legal requirement on the winning privatised

Speaker: NA
Text: entity to build Sydney West airport. As a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult, the government has condemned the

Speaker: NA
Text: residents of Sydney to a single airport servic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a population nearing five million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I note that, following the making

Speaker: NA
Text: of the master plan for Sydney airport which

Speaker: NA
Text: projects huge increases in air traffic move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, the SACL exhibited the draft major

Speaker: NA
Text: development plan for Sydney airport's car

Speaker: NA
Text: parking and commercial facilities of the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternal terminal precinct in July 2004 and,

Speaker: NA
Text: within a short space of time, the Sydney air-

Speaker: NA
Text: port environment strategy. With that draft

Speaker: NA
Text: development plan came a non-renewal of

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing surveillance for parking facilities at

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney airport. At each and every opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity the coalition government has adopted an

Speaker: NA
Text: anarchic, laissez-faire approach: a system of

Speaker: NA
Text: no government is good government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition has given the owners of Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: airport carte blanche to make as much money

Speaker: NA
Text: as they like with all but no government inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference. It is truly repugnant-truly a total

Speaker: NA
Text: abnegation of environmental and governance

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. Tonight I again put the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment on notice that I will continue to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lentlessly pursue it in this House and through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney Airport Community Forum. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the least my constituents in Lowe deserve.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Roads: Roe Highway

Speaker: Dr JENSEN
Text: Tangney) (9.05 p.m.)-I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fer to comments made by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Fremantle as published in the Melville City

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald on Saturday, 27 November. I particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly refer to the comments made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member that Melville City Council's deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to spend $300,000 on an advertising

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign to criticise the state Labor gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment for not fulfilling its end of the bar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gain in regard to building stage 8 of the Roe

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway and therefore linking the highway

Speaker: NA
Text: to the port of Fremantle, Western Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: main commercial port, is a waste of taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers' money. I also refer to the member's

Speaker: NA
Text: comments that she has received only one

Speaker: NA
Text: email on the topic of the Roe Highway ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tension and the Fremantle Eastern Bypass

Speaker: NA
Text: and, unsurprisingly, it was in support of state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's position. If the member wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: criticise anyone for wasting taxpayers'

Speaker: NA
Text: money, she should point her finger at her

Speaker: NA
Text: state colleagues: Premier Gallop and the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for transport, Alannah MACTiernan.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind the member for Fremantle of an
