Speaker: NA
Text: election promise from her state Labor col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues to build the Roe Highway to stage 8.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would extend the Kwinana Freeway in

Speaker: NA
Text: Leeming to the end of the proposed Freman-

Speaker: NA
Text: tle Eastern Bypass in Beaconsfield. It would

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a safe and efficient regional road

Speaker: NA
Text: link between the western suburbs of Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: and destinations to the east. Primarily, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would ensure there was a designated heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: haulage route for the container loaded road

Speaker: NA
Text: trains travelling to Fremantle Port. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial traffic would enjoy greater pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity as there would be no lights along

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed highway, unlike the 27 sets of

Speaker: NA
Text: lights road trains are forced to negotiate

Speaker: NA
Text: while passing along their current route of

Speaker: NA
Text: Leach Highway. Leach Highway passes

Speaker: NA
Text: through the middle of many residences,

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, the largest netball centre in the

Speaker: NA
Text: southern suburbs, a public golf course and

Speaker: NA
Text: many other community amenities whose pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: trons all have to suffer the constant flow of

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy haulage commercial traffic.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have received insurmountable support

Speaker: NA
Text: from constituents and community groups

Speaker: NA
Text: who are concerned for their children, for

Speaker: NA
Text: their elderly and for their community if the

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of traffic is allowed to continue and

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor fails to deliver on its original promise

Speaker: NA
Text: to the electorate. However, the promises of

Speaker: NA
Text: the state Labor government will not be ful-

Speaker: NA
Text: filled. They will not be fulfilled, because

Speaker: NA
Text: state Labor cabinet is rezoning the land on

Speaker: NA
Text: which stage 8 was to be built-land that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been set aside for more than 30 years to be

Speaker: NA
Text: used for this very purpose. The state gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment squandered the good faith of this

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the good faith of taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate. I remind the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Fremantle that $15 million and a projected

Speaker: NA
Text: $26.32 million were allocated on the promise

Speaker: NA
Text: that state Labor would drop plans to rezone

Speaker: NA
Text: land designated for stage 8. The federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment was very clear that the missing

Speaker: NA
Text: link-the linking of the highway to Freman-

Speaker: NA
Text: tle Port-must be completed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Fremantle commented

Speaker: NA
Text: that Perth has the second highest kilometres

Speaker: NA
Text: of road per person in the world, with the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: evitable consequences, according to her, for

Speaker: NA
Text: air pollution and noise. I inform the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Fremantle that Perth is not a thriving

Speaker: NA
Text: tropolis with a high population density. Fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, I inform the member that it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of roads but the type of roads and

Speaker: NA
Text: their ability to carry traffic that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: analysed. Perhaps the member for Fremantle

Speaker: NA
Text: could explain to the House why she believes

Speaker: NA
Text: the Melville City Council-the local council

Speaker: NA
Text: that administers many of the suburbs where

Speaker: NA
Text: parents find that their children cannot cross

Speaker: NA
Text: road due to the continuous passing of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainer loaded road trains-is wasting taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers' money. At the same time, perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Fremantle could explain what

Speaker: NA
Text: her state Labor colleagues have wasted some

Speaker: NA
Text: of that $76 million of taxpayers' money on.

Speaker: NA
Text: It certainly was not used to build stage 8 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Roe Highway or the Fremantle eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: bypass.

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Text: Oxley) (9.09 p.m.)-This

Speaker: NA
Text: evening I would like to talk briefly about the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's infrastructure needs. It seems that

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever you turn these days people are talk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about infrastructure. Whether at school

Speaker: NA
Text: gatherings, at barbecues, over the back fence

Speaker: NA
Text: or even in the many columns in newspapers,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are all talking about it. In my part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world it has certainly become the real barbe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cue stopper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Roads, rail, ports, energy, hospitals,

Speaker: NA
Text: communications and schools all make up the

Speaker: NA
Text: vast network of infrastructure that we all take

Speaker: NA
Text: for granted. But we are becoming increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly aware of their existence. This can eas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily be explained by people's understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: that the things they use on a daily basis are

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer meeting their needs and increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly are becoming unreliable-individual

Speaker: NA
Text: expectations that when you drive to work

Speaker: NA
Text: you will arrive on time, that when you turn

Speaker: NA
Text: on the tap you will actually get some fresh

Speaker: NA
Text: drinking water or that when you turn on a

Speaker: NA
Text: switch you will get some light. This acute

Speaker: NA
Text: me- awareness of the things we have taken for

Speaker: NA
Text: granted is the result of a decline in invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in and maintenance of the most essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial parts of our society. It is a visible and

Speaker: NA
Text: actual cost to our lives and the liveability of

Speaker: NA
Text: our cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are dozens of reports, many of them

Speaker: NA
Text: recent ones, that inform us of the growing

Speaker: NA
Text: population, particularly in south-east Queen-

Speaker: NA
Text: a sland-or, I should say, the exploding popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation in that part of the world. It is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be over one million people

Speaker: NA
Text: moving to Queensland's south-east corner

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next 20 years and there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: need for some 500,000 new homes to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: commodate them. The thought of how to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for this number of families on our

Speaker: NA
Text: already congested road and rail networks is

Speaker: NA
Text: frightening-let alone thinking about how

Speaker: NA
Text: we will provide enough water and energy to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the lifestyles that drive these people

Speaker: NA
Text: to that part of the world in the first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet, with all the expert reports, the edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated opinion, the street talk and the obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: need for investment in infrastructure, it

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me that there is a less than urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: response from the federal government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems that the Commonwealth government

Speaker: NA
Text: is more content to play politics than to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide any real public policy solutions. A great

Speaker: NA
Text: teleexample of the government's drive in this

Speaker: NA
Text: direction is the national land transport plan,

Speaker: NA
Text: or AusLink, as it is commonly referred to as.

Speaker: NA
Text: This policy has been much talked about. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have even heard the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: compare it to the great Snowy Mountains

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme-the great nation-building enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prise of the 1950s.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to and during the recent federal elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign, the government used every

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to sell the benefits of AusLink to

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. It boasted incessantly about

Speaker: NA
Text: how the government was making huge in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestments in the nation's land transport net-

Speaker: NA
Text: works. It would go from electorate to elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate and it would promise money to much

Speaker: NA
Text: needed local community projects. And, in

Speaker: NA
Text: some instances, the same bucket of money

Speaker: NA
Text: was promised to more than one project-but

Speaker: NA
Text: that topic is for another time.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the fundamental principles of

Speaker: NA
Text: AusLink was the establishment of bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements between the states and the fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral government. While agreements between

Speaker: NA
Text: state and federal governments are essential-

Speaker: NA
Text: including on funding agreements-this

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be interpreted as a green light for

Speaker: NA
Text: the federal government to dump its responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities onto the states. AusLink was essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tially understood to mean that funding would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a shared responsibility between both lev-

Speaker: NA
Text: els of government, with the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment playing an active role. That was pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: election 2004. But, after the election, many

Speaker: NA
Text: of us are now learning that bilateral agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments mean something completely different

Speaker: NA
Text: in the context of AusLink.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the case of AusLink, it means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government wants to bully the states

Speaker: NA
Text: into reform in other policy areas. So we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's level of commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: AusLink and national infrastructure-its

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest plan since the 1950s Snowy Moun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains Scheme-being conditional on other

Speaker: NA
Text: policy areas. AusLink funding in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: is now becoming conditional upon industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations reform. This is an unacceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: principle in the delivery of the nation's key

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure needs. Many people who

Speaker: NA
Text: thought they were going to get the money for

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects in their local commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities are suddenly finding that these prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ises were conditional, that there were strings

Speaker: NA
Text: attached to the funding of AusLink-

Speaker: NA
Text: something they did not know pre election. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems we all forgot to read the fine print,

Speaker: NA
Text: ever existed in the first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: A cooperative approach is what is needed

Speaker: NA
Text: to build and maintain the infrastructure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have become reliant upon and which we

Speaker: NA
Text: all demand as a key economic driver of jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: of innovation and of growth. What we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want is the divisive policy, based on ideo-

Speaker: NA
Text: logical nonsense, that we are currently get-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting from the federal government. Infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture development should not descend into an

Speaker: NA
Text: us and them debate or a debate about paro-

Speaker: NA
Text: chialism between states and the federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. If it is to be taken seriously, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government needs to rethink its ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to the nation's most important infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure needs, in particular the AusLink

Speaker: NA
Text: funding conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mathwin, Mr John, OAM

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (9.14

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I rise to celebrate the life of Mr John

Speaker: NA
Text: Mathwin, OAM. John was born in 1919 and

Speaker: NA
Text: grew up in Liverpool. He died in June 2004,

Speaker: NA
Text: just two days short of his 85th birthday. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was a master painter by trade, and he served

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Royal Engineers 15th (Scottish)

Speaker: NA
Text: Division. He served in the Battle of Britain,

Speaker: NA
Text: was part of the landings at Normandy and

Speaker: NA
Text: was one of the first to cross the Rhine and

Speaker: NA
Text: enter Germany. In 1951 he came to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: with his first wife, Gladys, who, sadly, died

Speaker: NA
Text: at the age of 42 when John was the Mayor of

Speaker: NA
Text: Brighton. He joined the Liberal Party in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1953, and he was the Liberal candidate for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bonython in 1955. Although he did not live

Speaker: NA
Text: to see it, I know how pleased he would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been that much of the old seat of Bonython is

Speaker: NA
Text: now represented by the Liberal Party for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time ever. He served as a councillor with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Brighton City Council from 1960 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1971. Later, after 35 years, he returned to the

Speaker: NA
Text: same council as a councillor from 1994 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1997, and from 1997 to 2003 he was a coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: if it cillor and deputy mayor of the merged coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil, which was named Holdfast Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was no voluntary group in Brighton

Speaker: NA
Text: that John Mathwin was not involved in. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was involved in the South Australian Good

Speaker: NA
Text: Neighbour Council, Brighton Lacrosse Club,

Speaker: NA
Text: Somerton Surf Life Saving Club, Glenelg

Speaker: NA
Text: Rotary Club, Seacliff Youth Centre and

Speaker: NA
Text: Brighton Probus Club. He was involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: Brighton Meals on Wheels from 1962 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000. For much of that time he was a driver

Speaker: NA
Text: and the president of that organisation. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was involved with the City of Holdfast Bay

Speaker: NA
Text: Concert Band. He was involved with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Brighton Senior Citizens Club, and he helped

Speaker: NA
Text: to build their hall, which is now leased from

Speaker: NA
Text: the local council for a peppercorn rent.

Speaker: NA
Text: John was elected as the state member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Glenelg from 1970 to 1985. That seat was

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished in 1985. He ran for, and was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: feated in, the seat of Bright in 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to share several memories I

Speaker: NA
Text: have of John. I grew up in the seat he repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented in the state parliament, so one of my

Speaker: NA
Text: earliest memories of politics was of John

Speaker: NA
Text: Mathwin's posters on large gum trees along

Speaker: NA
Text: Brighton Road. Now we put them on Stobie

Speaker: NA
Text: poles, not on gum trees, because people do

Speaker: NA
Text: not like them being on trees. Even back then

Speaker: NA
Text: it was a problem and, if any ‘greenies' com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained, John would say that he was giving

Speaker: NA
Text: them their ‘three-year iron injections'. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995 I was fortunate to have John Mathwin

Speaker: NA
Text: show me around as a candidate. He took me

Speaker: NA
Text: around to local functions to meet with all the

Speaker: NA
Text: community groups. I am sure that all mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers know how useful it is to have someone

Speaker: NA
Text: like that. He also got me roped in to become

Speaker: NA
Text: a driver with Meals on Wheels and a patron

Speaker: NA
Text: of the City of Holdfast Bay Concert Band.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Liberal Party branch members, who

Speaker: NA
Text: had been his members for so long, he trained

Speaker: NA
Text: well. If ever I had a function, one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members, Mabs Pearce, would paint a paint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and donate it. When she received my

Speaker: NA
Text: material she would go and doorknock her

Speaker: NA
Text: street. It was the practice of an older genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Liberal voters that I never had to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: for anything; they did all these things off

Speaker: NA
Text: their own bat.

Speaker: NA
Text: To give an example of how long he was

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the community, I remember be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing struck by a plaque at the Seacliff Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre which showed that it had been opened

Speaker: NA
Text: by John Mathwin, as mayor of Brighton, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965. It would have been 35 years later that I

Speaker: NA
Text: was there, when he was deputy mayor of the

Speaker: NA
Text: successor organisation, the City of Holdfast

Speaker: NA
Text: Bay. I was very proud to be present at the

Speaker: NA
Text: opening of John Mathwin Park in November

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001, the day after the election, and to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent him with a Centenary of Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: Medal in July 2003. He always had a good

Speaker: NA
Text: word of advice, and he called everyone ‘lad'.

Speaker: NA
Text: When he retired from council in 2003, he

Speaker: NA
Text: was interviewed by the local paper, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that he hoped to return to Normandy in

Speaker: NA
Text: June 2004 for the 60th anniversary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: landings. Sadly, he was too ill to travel. I

Speaker: NA
Text: convey my condolences to his five children,

Speaker: NA
Text: John, Stephen, Jeanette, Peter and Kaye, and

Speaker: NA
Text: their families, and to John's friend Cecily,

Speaker: NA
Text: who provided him with so much support. He

Speaker: NA
Text: helped me enormously, and I will miss him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs: Native Title

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Text: Fraser) (9.19 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to challenge the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in particular, the Minister for Immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: to seize an important opportunity to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's bona fides in Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs and in native title in particular. Alter-

Speaker: NA
Text: natively, the government will reinforce the

Speaker: NA
Text: view that it is trying to unwind previous

Speaker: NA
Text: hard-won gains and return to the paternalistic

Speaker: NA
Text: attitudes of the 1960s.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Howard government justifies its cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: to Indigenous programs on the grounds that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is eager to support Indigenous Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: to help themselves. I do not disagree with all

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures it appears the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to propose, if we can believe what is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the leaked incoming government brief-for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the ‘no school, no pool' policy has

Speaker: NA
Text: brought some positive achievements in some

Speaker: NA
Text: communities-however, the evidence to date

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates more enthusiasm for the stick than

Speaker: NA
Text: the carrot.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to outline tonight an opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Howard government to put its money

Speaker: NA
Text: where its mouth is. I refer to the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate funding for prescribed bodies cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porate, PBCs, under the Native Title Act. A

Speaker: NA
Text: PBC holds and manages native title under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Native Title Act. The Native Title Act of

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament sets out the functions for

Speaker: NA
Text: PBCs, which include managing the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of native title holders but also negotiating

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements with third parties, such as min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, pastoralists and other developers, who

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to undertake economic activity on the

Speaker: NA
Text: land in question. Both of those parties re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire well-funded, competent PBCs, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are both being let down by the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: PBCs also have costs imposed on them by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth, by the proper require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to meet compliance obligations under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Aboriginal Councils and Associations

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, but that is expensive, and they get no

Speaker: NA
Text: funding to assist them to do it. Funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: PBCs is not a new problem-it has been an

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing issue-but it seems to be becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: more acute because of the important statu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory roles played by PBCs, the growing

Speaker: NA
Text: number of native title determinations and the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of funding for PBCs, especially post-

Speaker: NA
Text: registration of native title.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lack of funding raises important issues ir-

Speaker: NA
Text: respective of whether the PBC covers native

Speaker: NA
Text: title holders in remote areas or Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: people who hold native title in townships

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue of resourcing of PBCs was referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to recently in the case of Nangkiriny v.

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Australia. In that case, Justice North

Speaker: NA
Text: identified an issue that caused him ‘some

Speaker: NA
Text: concern', as he called it. It related to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Karajarri Traditional Lands Association Abo-

Speaker: NA
Text: riginal Corporation, the PBC for the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses of section 56 of the Native Title Act on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Karajarri people in that matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be an absurd outcome if, after the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure of such large sums to reach a determi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation of native title, the proper utilisation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: land was hampered because of lack of a relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: small expenditure for the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: PBC.

Speaker: NA
Text: The judge considered not making the orders

Speaker: NA
Text: in that matter because of the lack of funding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the PBC, although he subsequently did.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, this issue is not confined to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote areas. There is the case of the Lhere

Speaker: NA
Text: Artepe Aboriginal Corporation which was

Speaker: NA
Text: established as the result of a determination of

Speaker: NA
Text: native title for the Arrernte People in Alice

Speaker: NA
Text: Springs. A Northern Territory government

Speaker: NA
Text: submission to the Joint Committee on Native

Speaker: NA
Text: Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander Land Fund outlined the extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: demands being placed on the LAAC to nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiate with a large variety of stakeholders like

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory government, the Alice

Speaker: NA
Text: Springs Town Council and individual devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opers. This means that they require resources

Speaker: NA
Text: so that they can conduct that negotiation. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment we are missing out on the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity. Native titleholders are losing out on

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to achieve broader social,

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and cultural development for their

Speaker: NA
Text: community, despite having a determination

Speaker: NA
Text: that their native title continues to exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: People who want to use the land, the third

Speaker: NA
Text: party interests who want to conduct what is

Speaker: NA
Text: called future acts under the Native Title

Speaker: NA
Text: Act-developers, miners, sometimes pastor-

Speaker: NA
Text: alists and property developers in Alice

Speaker: NA
Text: West- Springs-cannot get the agreements con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted to get that economic activity under

Speaker: NA
Text: way on the land because the body responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble does not have the resources. As one of

Speaker: NA
Text: them said, ‘I might be a chairman but we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot afford to buy a chair'. It is literally

Speaker: NA
Text: true in that case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth has tried to pass the

Speaker: NA
Text: buck to the states but these are bodies cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by the Commonwealth to perform func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions specified by the Commonwealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: are required to comply with regulation speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied by the Commonwealth. The bodies are

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility of the Commonwealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: not the states and they are being denied the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity of funding. There is a report

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter which was commissioned by

Speaker: NA
Text: ATSIC, paid for by the taxpayers and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to the government in October 2002,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Parliamentary Library cannot obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: a copy for me-even from the consultants

Speaker: NA
Text: who wrote the report. That report needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: released now. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders Electorate: Hastings and

Speaker: NA
Text: Somerville Area Development

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Parliamentary Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary to the Minister for the Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Heritage) (9.24 p.m.)-I present to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House this evening a plan for development

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Hastings and Somerville areas within

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Flinders. Hastings has

Speaker: NA
Text: evolved as an old fishing town. It has be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come a steel town-a town which is still be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginning to change and transform, with

Speaker: NA
Text: younger families coming in. The nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: the town is changing. Somerville is a young

Speaker: NA
Text: family town. Young people have come in

Speaker: NA
Text: from throughout the Melbourne district. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has changed from being an agricultural town.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are four parts to the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: Hastings and Somerville and the surrounding

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of Tyabb and Baxter which need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered. The first part is the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: pride. Hastings produced John Coleman, the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest full forward in Australian history. A

Speaker: NA
Text: group of people from the Western Port

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamber of Commerce, led by Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: MCCulloch, have put together a plan for the

Speaker: NA
Text: creation of a John Coleman statue. It is about

Speaker: NA
Text: building pride, understanding and a sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: history in the town of Hastings. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are involved and urge all those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are able to contribute to the funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: the project, costing over $100,000, to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second part of the development is for

Speaker: NA
Text: marine education for Hastings and Somer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ville through the rubric of cooperation be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Dolphin Research Institute in

Speaker: NA
Text: Hastings and the Australian Maritime Col-

Speaker: NA
Text: into lege. The Australian Maritime College will

Speaker: NA
Text: be setting up a national centre for marine and

Speaker: NA
Text: coastal conservation as part of the proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: at Point Nepean. The opportunity exists and

Speaker: NA
Text: the pledge has been made for cooperation

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Dolphin Research Institute in

Speaker: NA
Text: Hastings and the Australian Maritime Col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege. I believe that practical marine educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for maritime skills can exist and be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped in Hastings in cooperation at the

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary and tertiary levels. It is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for the young people of Hast-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings-Hastings has no significant tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities either at the TAFE or the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: gree level-and a step forward in their fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, which is tied to the particular elements

Speaker: NA
Text: of Hastings interface and history of dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the sea.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third element which is critical to the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the region is the creation and

Speaker: NA
Text: fulfilment of the long-held commitment,

Speaker: NA
Text: made in 2002 by the state government, for a

Speaker: NA
Text: Somerville secondary college. The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth has already allocated $2 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: That money is there; it is clear; it is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: table; it is banked. It is ready to be used, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been no significant progress. The

Speaker: NA
Text: school has been delayed; the children have

Speaker: NA
Text: been denied. Families which have expected

Speaker: NA
Text: their children to begin in 2005 have been

Speaker: NA
Text: told that their children will not be able to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so and that they should make alternative ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements. Only in 2006 will families be

Speaker: NA
Text: afforded the privilege of allowing their chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren to attend a Somerville secondary col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege in their own town.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even now that process is being delayed by

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary backflip: the original de-

Speaker: NA
Text: sign-an internationally leading, first-class

Speaker: NA
Text: design-is not good enough. Instead of hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a modern 21st century design for a

Speaker: NA
Text: school, the state government are looking at a

Speaker: NA
Text: 1960s cinder block combination built up

Speaker: NA
Text: against residences; multi-stories rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: the interesting and innovative pod arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is a backflip; a disappointment. It

Speaker: NA
Text: not only delays the opportunity for education

Speaker: NA
Text: for children within Somerville but also de-

Speaker: NA
Text: nies succeeding generations a national stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard school. There is a very simple message:

Speaker: NA
Text: stick with the plan, stick with the original

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal. Do not be dissuaded. I urge the

Speaker: NA
Text: state to do that. The Minister for Education,

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Training, Dr Brendan Nelson,

Speaker: NA
Text: has said there is funding available at the fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral level. If it is a funding question, I urge

Speaker: NA
Text: the state government to come back for addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final proposal is for a Somerville po-

Speaker: NA
Text: lice station. My commitment remains clear

Speaker: NA
Text: and absolute: to continue to fight for a

Speaker: NA
Text: Somerville police station and in the interim

Speaker: NA
Text: to encourage local residents and the local

Speaker: NA
Text: community to support the idea of a mobile

Speaker: NA
Text: police van for Somerville. It is a great town

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is in need of additional security. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: both a long-term plan for the security of

Speaker: NA
Text: Somerville and a short-term interim measure

Speaker: NA
Text: to help the police, who do a great job, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they have the resources. Hastings

Speaker: NA
Text: and Somerville are fantastic areas. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear plan, pride, education and security. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend this plan to the House. (Time ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pired)

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 9.30

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m., the debate is interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 9.30 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: NOTICES

Speaker: NA
Text: The following notices were given:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Laurie Ferguson to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) calls on the United Nations Security Council to

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately consider and take appropriate ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to respond to the growing threats posed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Southeast Asia region by conditions in

Speaker: NA
Text: Burma;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) supports actions implementing the result of 1990

Speaker: NA
Text: elections in Burma and to support the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Representing the People's Parliament for the res-

Speaker: NA
Text: toration of Democracy in Burma; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) records its strong concern about the continued

Speaker: NA
Text: detention of Aung San Suu Kyi and 2000 politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal prisoners and calls for their immediate and

Speaker: NA
Text: unconditional release.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brendan O'Connor to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) acknowledges 1 December 2004 as World AIDS

Speaker: NA
Text: Day;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges that the primary objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: World AIDS Day 2004 is to further enable

Speaker: NA
Text: women and girls to take a primary role in chang-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the underlying cultural, social and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: barriers which make women more vulnerable to

Speaker: NA
Text: infection;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) acknowledges that women have a central role in

Speaker: NA
Text: educating their families and their wider commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities about HIV/AIDS prevention, and in sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting those with the disease; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) recognises that women and girls are biologically,

Speaker: NA
Text: economically and socially vulnerable to HIV in-

Speaker: NA
Text: fection and AIDS, and that violence or economic

Speaker: NA
Text: dependence disproportionately increases their

Speaker: NA
Text: chances of contracting the virus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Randall to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) acknowledges the profound impact autism has on

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families and the challenges they face

Speaker: NA
Text: in finding sufficient educational, develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental and respite services to help children

Speaker: NA
Text: and their carers with this life long disability;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes that the funding of programs by the States

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide vital support to children with autism

Speaker: NA
Text: is vastly inadequate and causing unnecessary

Speaker: NA
Text: hardship and concern for their families; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) accepts that while the States have primary

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for the provision of disability

Speaker: NA
Text: support services, the Federal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should play an active leadership role in what

Speaker: NA
Text: is a nationwide issue that affects 1 in 1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: children born in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Johnson to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) acknowledges the importance and value of

Speaker: NA
Text: free trade agreements in strengthening bilat-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral relations between countries and produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing international trade benefits;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) recognises the enormous opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in furthering trade arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: with the world's fastest growing economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: China; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) supports the Government's Australia-China

Speaker: NA
Text: Free Trade Agreement Joint Feasibility Study

Speaker: NA
Text: currently underway into the viability of a free

Speaker: NA
Text: trade agreement between Australia and China.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lindsay to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) recognises that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) passive welfare payments to Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, asking nothing in return

Speaker: NA
Text: from the recipient, have denied them the

Speaker: NA
Text: pride they deserve and the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: shape their own destiny;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) education is the key to change, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: childhood intervention to improve edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation will boost employment opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and head off longer-term problems;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) the leadership capacity of individuals in

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities must be fostered, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that we should support those Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders who want to stand up and ‘tell it

Speaker: NA
Text: like it is', rather than dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: elected or appointed intermediaries who

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be accountable;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) condemns the violence and unlawful destruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of property in Aboriginal communities this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, which puts the lives of police and others at

Speaker: NA
Text: risk; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls on Aboriginal communities to show the

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership they need to move forward into a

Speaker: NA
Text: more successful future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sercombe to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) international observers, including the In-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational Election Monitoring Mission

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Organisation of Security and Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation in Europe (OSCE), have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported that the recent election in Ukraine

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen short of international stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) free elections are an essential component

Speaker: NA
Text: of the democratic process which reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: the will of the Ukrainian people;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) there is a widespread perception in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world community that the conduct of the

Speaker: NA
Text: elections in Ukraine has not achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic norms;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) the most blatant and widespread abuses

Speaker: NA
Text: of the election process in Ukraine are re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported to have involved the manipulation

Speaker: NA
Text: of absentee votes and the uneven and bi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ased access to the government-owned

Speaker: NA
Text: media; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) a resolution to the disputed election re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sults can only be achieved through a new

Speaker: NA
Text: election which is conducted in a trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: parent manner that meets international

Speaker: NA
Text: standards;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls on the Government of Ukraine to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) ensure the safety and welfare of all its

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens taking part in peaceful demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strations that exercise their democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: rights; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) hold a new presidential election based on

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic principles, which:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) allows both presidential candidates

Speaker: NA
Text: equal and unbiased access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: mass media of Ukraine in the pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod leading up to the new election

Speaker: NA
Text: date; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) ensures that international observers

Speaker: NA
Text: participate at all levels of the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion process to achieve a result that

Speaker: NA
Text: is acceptable to all parties;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) requests the Speaker of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives to transmit this resolution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: outgoing President of Ukraine, Leonid Ku-

Speaker: NA
Text: chma, the Parliament of Ukraine and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukrainian Ambassador to Australia; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) urges the Australian Government to make

Speaker: NA
Text: further representations to the above effect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Neville to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) recognises the role of parents raising pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: foundly disabled children;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges the challenges faced by these

Speaker: NA
Text: parents in respect of caring, respite and fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of special equipment and services;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls for a comprehensive re-assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the eligibility of parents (generally, though

Speaker: NA
Text: not exclusively, the mother) to a Carer's Al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance or Payment according to the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of disability and dependence; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) requests an examination of respite services

Speaker: NA
Text: and medical requisites available to parents

Speaker: NA
Text: and their disabled charges.
